headline: 15 SENATORS PRESS REAGAN ON A-ARMS
abstract: Fifteen senators from both parties urged the Reagan Administration today to press within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for a significant reduction of American tactical nuclear weapons now stationed in Western Europe.   In a letter to President Reagan, the lawmakers said such a move would help correct the widespread impression among NATO members that Washington is not sincerely committed to arms reduction. And unless that impression is changed, they added, the alliance might have trouble deploying a new generation of medium-range missiles this year.   ''We confront a clear and pressing need,'' the letter said, ''to fortify public confidence throughout the alliance in the rational basis of NATO's deterrent posture.''

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MILITIAMEN CLASH IN LEBANON
abstract: Christian and Druse militiamen battled with artillery, rockets and grenades in Lebanon's central mountains today, killing 17 people and wounding 34, the Lebanese police reported.   The police said Israeli forces occupying the Aleih and Shuf areas southeast of Beirut were trying to impose a cease-fire.

headline: Flooding in Leningrad
abstract: Large areas of Leningrad were flooded overnight as a storm in the Gulf of Finland swept water up the Neva River, raising it six feet above its normal level.

headline: Carter in Egypt; Sees Habib and Mubarak
abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter arrived in Egypt Tuesday night for an eight-day visit, and today he paid a ''courtesy visit'' on Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy to the Middle East. Later in the day, he met for an hour with President Hosni Mubarak and other Egyptian officials.   It was Mr. Carter's first trip to Egypt since he attended the funeral of President Anwar el-Sadat in October 1981.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; 2 U.S. Diplomats Told To Get Out of Suriname   PARAMARIBO, Suriname, Jan. 6 (UPI) - Suriname announced today that it had ordered two United States diplomats to leave the country because of their ''destabilizing activities.''   A communique said the country's military leader, Lieut. Col. Daysi Bouterse, told the United States Ambassador, Robert U. Duemling, on Monday that the deputy chief of mission, Richard @La@Roche, and the public affairs officer, Edward Donovan, would have to leave by Jan.  15.

headline: NOVEMBER INVENTORIES SLID 1.1%
abstract: Improving sales, coupled with a continuing decline in production, allowed American businesses to reduce the value of their inventories of unsold goods by 1.1 percent in November, the biggest drop the Government has ever recorded, the Commerce Department announced today.   While the value of inventories of manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers fell $5.6 billion, to a seasonally adjusted $508.6 billion, their total sales rose 1.2 percent, to $336.37 billion, from $332.54 billion in October, the department said.   That resulted in a sharp plunge in the closely watched inventoryto-sales ratio, which was 1.51 in November, compared with 1.55 in October. The ratio, which measures the number of months it would take to liquidate inventories at the November sales pace, was at its lowest level since July.

headline: Up to 50 Peruvian Rebels Are Reported Slain
abstract: The police and peasants killed 30 to 50 left-wing rebels in the last three days, news reports said today.

headline: Market Place; Valuating Bell's Shares
abstract: THE reorganization of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the nation's largest corporation, is due to be completed by next Jan. 1. As a result, brokerage firms and other investors are trying to figure out the breakup value of the company's stock. Interested parties to the deliberations include Ma Bell's 3.2 million stockholders.   According to many analysts, the sum of Bell's parts appear to be worth more than the whole, or the current market price. A.T.& T.  stock yesterday rose 7/8, to 65 3/8, after equaling its five-year high of 65 1/2 earlier in the session. It finished last year at 59 3/8.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Allegheny Beverage Corp., Baltimore, has elected to its board William D. Houser, vice president of Comsat General Corporation.   * Amfac Inc., San Francisco, has named Gary L. Rhodes president of its Fisher Cheese Company.

headline: SHULTZ WARNS OF FIGHT WITH EUROPE ON FOOD
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz warned today that the Atlantic allies risk fighting a food trade war of ''devastating impact'' unless the Europeans ''take seriously'' Washington's efforts to negotiate an end to export subsidies.   His comments before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee were the strongest yet made by any Administration official about the danger of a trade conflict erupting from farm surpluses and growing pressure to dump the surpluses at cheap prices on world export markets.   Mr. Shultz spoke against a background of mounting resentment in Europe against a sale of one million tons of wheat to Egypt by the United States. The wheat was sold at $155 a ton, which is $25 a ton below the current world market level. This was possible because the sale was subsidized by the American Government.

headline: Suharto Is Chosen For a Fourth Term
abstract: The Indonesian Assembly unanimously elected President Suharto to his fourth five-year term today and granted him expanded powers.   It approved decrees giving President Suharto virtually complete power to do whatever he deems necessary for the safety and security of the country of 150 million people.

headline: Civil Servant Slain in Sicily
abstract: Gunmen shot a civil servant to death in the center of Palermo today in the first Mafia killing of 1983, the police said. Last year, 151 people were known to have died in bloodshed between rival clans in Sicily, and about the same number were reported missing.

headline: Market Place; Stores' Hopes For Quarter
abstract: THE generally weak Christmas shopping season - which stores had counted on to produce as much as 25 percent of the year's sales and as much as 50 percent of profits - would appear to have dimmed prospects for the retailers' all-important fourth quarter, which ends on Jan. 30.   But the three more weeks of sales remaining, along with two other factors, may still produce respectable profits for the period, retailing consultants and analysts say.   The two additional factors are declining interest rates and corporate programs begun early last year to shore up profit margins through major changes in the mixture of merchandise.   ''A year ago, the prime rate was substantially higher than today's 11 percent, and that means that retailers, as well as many other businessmen, have been paying less for loans on accounts receivable than they were,'' said Robert M. Warner, a management consultant.

headline: Southeast Banking
abstract: The Southeast Banking Corporation, a Miami concern, said it had acquired 24 branch offices of Florida National Bank of Florida Inc.  and certain other assets in exchange for Florida National stock held by Southeast. Southeast said it had received seven of Florida National's banks with 15 offices and nine branch offices in Palm Beach County, as well as $5.7 million in cash and certain nonbanking assets, a parcel of real estate in downtown Miami and mortgage servicing rights to $500 million in mortgages recently acquired from Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. In return, Southeast transferred 1.73 million Florida National shares to Florida National.

headline: CHEAP RAIL RATES ON CANADA'S WHEAT ENDING
abstract: For wheat growers on Canada's prairies, an 86-year-old free lunch appears to be over.  The federal Government announced today that, over the next eight years, the rate that farmers pay railroads to transport their grain to eastern markets will likely quintuple, after remaining unchanged since 1897.   At that time, the Crowsnest Pass Agreement between Ottawa and the Canadian Pacific Railway cemented in place a rate per ton-mile of half a cent (which equals about four-tenths of a United States cent) for grain shipments to the east from the central and western prairie provinces.   It is now cheaper for farmers to ship 100 pounds of grain to Thunder Bay, Ontario, on Lake Superior, than it is to mail a 30-cent letter there from the west. Nearly all of Canada's grain is shipped by rail at the Crowsnest rate.

headline: Coast Bank Closed
abstract: The Newport Harbour National Bank, Newport Beach, Calif., has been declared insolvent and closed by the Comptroller of the Currency. The authorities arranged for the Trans American National Bank of Monterey Park, Calif., to acquire it and for it to reopen immediately. The bank, declared insolvent Friday, had assets of $40 million and deposits of $40 million.

headline: BLUE CHIPS ARE HIT
abstract: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in much slower trading as profit taking again weakened the list. The biggest losers were bluechip and energy-related issues.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was off most of the session, closed down 9.66 points, to 1,073.95. On Wednesday, the key barometer surged to the 1,100 level, its highest ever, before dropping back.

headline: GRAND DEBUT OF AMERICAN BELL
abstract: High-technology companies often start with a few people working in a garage. American Bell Inc. will open for business today with 28,000 employees working in 700 buildings.   Such a grand beginning is appropriate for a company that is opening a new era of competition in the telephone business.  American Bell, a subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, was established to market telephone equipment and computerized services at unregulated prices. It is expected to bring a vast array of products to market, from office computers to computerized department store systems, able to handle such tasks as bridal registry.   Starting today, consumers wanting telephones and other phone equipment will buy them from either American Bell or one of its competitors. The local telephone companies, such as New York Telephone and New Jersey Bell, will no longer provide equipment for lease under state regulation, once their current inventories run out.

headline: THAILAND'S KUOMINTANG WARLORDS GO RESPECTABLE
abstract: Tigers and opium poppies abounded in the neighborhood when this mountaintop community in remote northern Thailand was settled in 1961. But the most dangerous creatures were the settlers - soldiers of the Chinese Nationalist Fifth Army who fled China, and later Burma, after Mao's victory in 1949.   Once in Thailand the soldiers grew wealthy from opium. The Thai Government did not want them, but they were well-trained anti-Communists on a delicate frontier, and they also made some corrupt Thai officials very rich.

headline: U.S. JEWISH GROUPS PRAISE ISRAELIS FOR 'MORAL DECENCY'
abstract: The Israeli commission's report on the Beirut killings drew approving comments from American Jewish spokesmen yesterday along with expressions of relief that the findings were detailed and made public immediately.   Most agreed with the most sensitive recommendation of the report: that Defense Minister Ariel Sharon should resign or be dismissed. But many refused to comment on that issue and those who did spoke reluctantly, taking pains not to judge Mr. Sharon but to say they thought his resignation would be in Israel's best interests.   In interviews, 25 spokesmen all praised Israel for conducting an inquiry that, they said, demonstrated the country's devotion to democracy.

headline: U.N. Chief Arrives in Uganda
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations arrived in Uganda today on the final leg of an eight-nation African tour. The Secretary General has discussed talks on the independence of South-West Africa with officials in Angola, Zambia, Mozambique, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Tanzania and Kenya.

headline: 4 DAYS OF TREASURY SALES THIS WEEK
abstract: In the Treasury market this week, an auction is scheduled every day except Friday. Treasury financings will be frequent and large in coming weeks, as Government experts estimated last week that they would need to raise $59.5 billion this quarter and $33 billion to $38 billion next quarter.   In advance of today's sale of new three- and six-month Treasury bills, dealers offered outstanding issues late Friday at rates of 7.98 percent for three-months bills and 8.03 percent for six-month bills.

The company has also agreed in principle to acquire approximately 25 percent of New England Sportschannel, a partnership that is being formed to conduct similar activities in New England. Financial details of the purchase were not disclosed.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: The Mighty Dollar   Despite falling interest rates, the dollar has remained strong against the deutsche mark because of uncertainty over West German elections scheduled for March 6. The mark, traditionally Europe's strongest currency, has fluctuated between 2.330 and 2.596 since September, when the Christian Democrats unseated the Social Democrats.   The growing strength of the Social Democrats has worried the business community, while the depressed state of other European currencies gives investors no choice but to remain with the dollar.  Should the Social Democrats gain power, ''there's a general perception that West Germany will be an ungovernable country,'' said Fran,coise Soares, head corporate trader at Credit Lyonnais.

headline: FRENCH LEFT IS TESTED IN A 'SAD, GRAY LITTLE PLACE'
abstract: Clichy looks like this: rotting buildings, tiny grocery stores, dead concrete slabs slapped into housing projects. On one side, alleys, cobblestones, updated Zola; on the other, Mean Streets, low-rent apartment buildings 10-stories high, a Reader-Adviser who has set up shop in the back of a truck parked on the sidewalk.   It is an unlikely place to land with a parachute. But Finance Minister Jacques Delors, who under normal circumstances might never have anything to do with Clichy, was sent here by the Socialist Party early this year - parachuted, in French political jargon - to run for Mayor. That is the genteel description; more directly, the plan was for Mr. Delors to create himself a nice political base in this rough little town, pop. 47,000, just over the Paris city line.

headline: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1983; The Economy
abstract: Banks are keeping interest rates high in part to protect themselves from losses on problem loans, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan told a Senate panel. The banking industry denied Mr. Regan's assertion.  The Secretary also cited uncertainty in the financial community about Federal Reserve policies and about projected Treasury borrowings to meet large budget deficits. (Page A1.)   New car sales by the Big Three auto makers fell 5.1 percent in the first 10 days of February, the first year-to-year decline since early last autumn. Chrysler's sales rose during the period, by 2.8 percent, but G.M.'s dropped 5.2 percent and Ford's, 8.6 percent.  Analysts were not overly disappointed by the results, saying that the industry is in the early stages of an upturn. (D1.)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Borden Inc. filed a shelf registration statement with the S.E.C.  for up to $200 million of debt securities, to be offered from time to time.   * Chemical New York is selling $450 million of zero coupon notes, due in one to 20 years, through Credit Suisse First Boston.   * Colorado National Bancshares filed with the S.E.C. an offering of $65 million of notes due in 1993, through Blyth Eastman Paine Webber.

headline: COURTING THE ELITE AT CONDE NAST
abstract: THE last issue of Vanity Fair came out in February 1936, the midst of the Depression and, publisher Conde Nast regretfully conceded, no time for Gershwin or Gertrude Lawrence or Gloria Swanson or the frivolous magazine that exalted them all.   Now, 47 years later, with the economy in the worst downturn since the 1930's, the March issue is - finally - ready to roll. After more than a year of preparation, an outlay of more than $10 million and months of high-brow fanfare, the magazine will start coming off the presses this week.   Its publisher is still Conde Nast, but the august Madison Avenue company is now owned by the Newhouse family, which bought the troubled publishing concern in the late 1950's and brought it to good times in the 1970's. The new Conde Nast has seven successful magazines on its roster, advertising revenues that far outpace the industry's, and enough extra backing from its parent company to be undaunted by the prospect that the new Vanity Fair may, at the start, be a losing proposition.

headline: Hanoi Pressing Attack On Cambodian Rebels
abstract: Vietnamese troops pressed their attack today for a fourth day against anti-Communist Cambodian forces on the Cambodian side of the border with Thailand.

headline: FINANCIAL FUTURES AS BAROMETER
abstract: NO traders are as fickle as those in the commodity futures market: they thrive on the volatility of prices, unlike stock investors who think in terms of company earnings, dividends and other longer-term factors. Financial futures provide good illustrations of the changing preferences of traders in these markets in recent months.   For example, the volume of trading in domestic bank certificates of deposits, currently about 4,500 contracts a day, has fallen 50 percent since Labor Day. But the turnover in Eurodollar futures, which began trading only a year ago, is running at 4,000 a day.

headline: JAPAN'S PRODUCTIVE CAR UNIONS
abstract: Tetuo Ohsone, the top labor union official at the Toyo Kogyo Company, gives a visitor a small gift, a tie clip.  Prominently displayed on it is the word ''Mazda,'' the trade name for Toyo Kogyo cars, and a symbol depicting the company's unique rotary engine. The union's initials are barely discernible.   Mr. Ohsone's gesture indicates the close links that unions in Japan have with automobile companies. In Detroit, confrontation has marked labor-management relationships ever since members of the United Automobile Workers union sang ''solidarity forever, the union makes us strong'' as they fought to organize and struck for better wages.  In Japan, assembly line workers have long been encouraged to feel they are as much a part of the company as the president.   As a result, during the past two decades of rapid growth, the Japanese auto industry has been untroubled by the long strikes that were regular events in Detroit into the 1970's. And Japanese auto workers have become known the world over for their attention to quality, low absentee rates and willingness to shift from one job to another as needed. The auto companies have responded with steadily rising wages and fringe benefits, including subsidized housing, and a no-layoff policy.

headline: RATE PANEL SLOWS DEREGULATION PACE
abstract: Federal banking regulators decided today that deregulation of bank interest rate ceilings has gone far enough for the time being.   The regulators, sitting as the Depository Institutions Deregulation Committee, voted unanimously to give commercial banks and savings institutions more time to adjust to recent regulatory changes that have sharply scaled back interest rate limits on deposits. In doing so, they adopted a position advocated by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, a member of the committee.

headline: Sallie Mae to Market Adjustable-Rate Issue
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association announced plans yesterday to sell $200 million of adjustable-rate preferred stock in the week of Feb. 14 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.   Adjustable-rate preferred issues have been very popular with bank holding companies, which have sold more than $3 billion of such issues in the past year, and have other sales pending.

headline: Anderson Is Reining In Continental's Lending
abstract: Over the past decade, Roger E. Anderson, the soft-spoken chairman of the Continental Illinois Corporation, has transformed the bank holding company into the largest and perhaps most competitive corporate lender in the United States. Until recently, the strategy seemed a great success.   Last year, however, Continental's aggressive lending blew up in its face, stunning the industry and giving Continental a most embarrassing year.

headline: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1983
abstract: The nation's governors want higher taxes and less spending in the military sector to cut the Federal budget over the next five years, rather than any further reduction in social expenditures. (Page A1.)   Treasury Secretary Regan doesn't think the $4.6 billion jobs bill is too large for the Administration to accept. While $300 million more than the President had proposed, it does not stretch the Administration's credibility, Mr. Regan said. (A1.)

headline: Thomson Cleared To Buy AEG Unit
abstract: West Germany's antitrust authorities approved plans by France's state-owned Thomson-Brandt group to take control of AEG-Telefunken's consumer electronics subsidiary.

headline: INTERMOUNTAIN POWER PLANS LARGE BOND ISSUE
abstract: The already heavy volume of new tax-exempt bonds will increase this week with the marketing of a $750 million bond issue of the Intermountain Power Agency. Some investment bankers said the size of the issue might be increased to as much as $1 billion, which would make it the largest public issue of tax-exempt bonds ever.   The power agency is building two coal-fired generating plants that will provide electricity primarily for towns in Utah and California.  The project, in an early stage of construction, was recently scaled down to two plants from four plants.

headline: Petro-Canada Bid
abstract: Federally owned Petro-Canada Exploration Inc. said it had made its previously announced offer for all the outstanding class A and B shares of BP Canada Inc.'s BP Refining and Marketing Canada Ltd. It is offering $1.236 per class A share and $12.414 per class B share for acceptance until March 31.

headline: Market Place; The Pluses At Warner
abstract: AFTER Warner Communications made its unexpected announcement last month that it expected a severe slump in its fourth-quarter earnings because of sluggish sales of video games made by its Atari subsidiary, analysts who championed Warner during its high-flying days hurriedly scratched it off their recommended lists. Warner shares were sent reeling.   In recent trading sessions the stock has rebounded slightly, even though analysts remain cool about its prospects this year. Some feeling is beginning to build, however, that Warner is worth a look as a long-term investment.

headline: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS CUTBACKS
abstract: Still shaken by large loan losses, the Continental Illinois Corporation is planning to reduce the level of its business loans by about 5 percent this year and cut its staff by 800, Roger Anderson, the banking company's chairman, said at a closed-door meeting of senior officers Tuesday afternoon.   After a loan-by-loan analysis, Mr. Anderson said he believes that Continental would be able to reduce its problem loans by about $500 million this year, from the $1.9 billion level at the end of 1981.   The company's goal, he said, was to increase its net operating income to $150 million this year from the $84.4 million earned in 1982. That would still be far below the record $260.3 million that Continental earned in 1981.

headline: Cable Penetration Up
abstract: The latest report from A.C. Nielsen is that cable televison is now used in 37.2 percent of all American homes, which means more than 31.1 million households for February 1983. That is a growth of 7.4 million households, or 28 percent, from February 1982.

headline: ANY DECLINE SOON IN OIL PRICES MAY BE SMALL, ANALYSTS SAY
abstract: The breakdown of the OPEC meeting in Geneva yesterday has set the stage for a slight decline in oil prices and a further cutback in production by Saudi Arabia and its allies on the Arabian Peninsula, energy economists said yesterday.  But a sharp drop in the price of oil from the current world average of about $33 for a 42-gallon barrel appeared unlikely - at least for the present, the economists said. The current price among members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is based on $34 for Saudi Light crude.  Total oil production by Saudi Arabia and its neighbors has declined to about 8.5 million barrels a day, from an average of 13.7 million in 1980, as they have tried to maintain their price structure despite the abundance of oil in world markets. That has prompted other OPEC producers to discount prices in order to sell their oil.

headline: ...WHILE NKOMO SAYS HE IS A VIRTUAL PRISONER
abstract: Joshua Nkomo, the Zimbabwean opposition leader accused by Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of plotting a coup, charged today that the police had placed him under ''virtual house arrest'' inside his fenced bungalow.   Mr. Nkomo, 65 years old, head of the Zimbabwe African People's Union, said in a telephone interview that the police had ordered him to inform them before he wished to leave his home in the township of Pelendaba.   ''This is just further harassment,'' he said. ''This is virtual house arrest, as they can say no. They can stop me from leaving.'' Official police spokesmen in Bulawayo were not available for comment and dispatchers and officers at police headquarters would not comment on Mr. Nkomo's statement.

headline: Advertising; Billboards: Campaign Insurance
abstract: THE erosion of network TV audiences notwithstanding, the successful promoters of other media generally play it smart and promote their own favorites as a supplement to television rather than a substitute for it.   The picture tube is powerful. It works for advertisers. The only chink in its armor, before the erosion (and the erosion has not helped its competition all that much), was the cost, and it is still a major source of continuing complaints by advertisers.

headline: Salvador Sends Bones For U.S. Identity Check
abstract: Bones believed to be the remains of an American freelance writer who disappeared more than two years ago in El Salvador were sent to the United States this weekend.   The writer, John Sullivan, a 26-year-old native of Bogota, N.J., disappeared the night of his arrival in San Salvador on Dec. 28, 1980.

headline: Kuwait Lease Denial
abstract: The Kuwaiti oil minister, Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, said today that a recent United States Government decision banning Kuwait from leasing Federal Government land to drill for oil or gas was illegal. ''The decision from our point of view is illegal,'' he told the Kuwaiti Parliament, ''but we will work to rectify the situation.''

headline: BRIEFS

headline: News Analysis
abstract: In asking for an ''intensive'' national effort to create an effective defense against nuclear attack, President Reagan is apparently seeking to begin a sweeping, longrange change in national strategic doctrine.   In his televised speech tonight, Mr. Reagan called his proposal ''a vision of the future that offers hope'' and one that could free the United States from the threat of nuclear war. However, some strategic thinkers will question not only whether his plan is technically feasible but also whether it is militarily desirable.   Two assumptions have served as the foundation of the policies of deterrence that have guided the United States and the Soviet Union since the Russians acquired nuclear weapons in 1949. These assumptions are that there is not now any effective defense against nuclear attack, and that the present level of technology does not promise to provide such defense.

headline: Danish Fishermen Sail Into Disputed Waters
abstract: Danish fisherman sailed six trawlers into disputed waters off Scotland today, but storm-tossed seas delayed a showdown with Britain over fishing rights.   The British assembled 22 Royal Navy warships, inspection ships and Nimrod long-range surveillance planes to repel any ships challenging a new ban on fishing within 12 miles of British shores.

headline: Jobless Rate In Europe
abstract: The number of unemployed in the Common Market dropped slightly in February, to 12,345,500, while the unemployment rate remained at 11.1 percent of the work force, the organization's statistical agency said today.   It said the drop of 17,400 in the number of jobless, however, was less than the usual decline of 1 percent to 4 percent at this time of year.   A Common Market spokesman said the latest figures bear out predictions that the number of unemployed in the community will rise in the next few years.

headline: Columbia Gifts Of $3 Million
abstract: The Columbia University business school has received gifts of more than $3 million for enlargement of its administration and classroom building, the university has announced.   The expansion fund, initiated by a $500,000 gift from the Mobil Foundation and augmented by $2.5 million from the Uris Brothers Foundation, will enable the school to begin renovation this summer of Uris Hall, which was originally funded by and dedicated to Percy and Harold Uris, founders of the New York construction company that bears their name.

headline: Zimbabwe Seizes Ex-Army Commander
abstract: The former Rhodesian Army commander, John Hickman, who led the war against black nationalists in the late 1970's, is being detained by authorities along with his business partner, Mr. Hickman's lawyers said today.   No charges were filed against Mr. Hickman or his partner, Peter Macdonald, according to the attorneys.

headline: TENNECO UP 10.8%
abstract: The Natomas Company reported yesterday that an extraordinary charge caused a loss of $8.4 million in the fourth quarter, in contrast to earnings of $48.8 million, or 90 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenues in the latest quarter remained virtually even, at $441.3 million.   Dorman L. Commons, president, said the fourth-quarter loss included a $32.9 million charge against income resulting from a provision made in anticipation of an adverse ruling in an Indonesian tax dispute. The dispute, previously reported as a contingency, involves claimed tax obligations related to a production sharing arrangement between Indonesia and Natomas in Southeast Sumatra before 1978.

headline: NEW MONEY FOR THE NEW ROCKEFELLERS
abstract: AS legend has it, John D. Rockefeller, who turned an oil monopoly i nto one of the first great American family fortunes, used to give a way shiny new dimes in the depths of the Depression to those he p assed on the street. Some of his heirs may now be wishing that the p atriarch were still around to toss a little spare change their way.   No, the Rockefellers aren't running out of money. But their wealth is beginning to look just a little bit less awesome as more and more relatives line up to dip into the family kitty. In 1937, John D.  Rockefeller left his vast riches to a single son, John D. Rockefeller Jr., who in turn divided the fortune among his six children. Now the great pie is being sliced again -this time among 23 heirs, who themselves will have to provide for some 40 fifth-generation descendants.   With such demands on their inheritance, the Rockefellers are moving quietly, but purposefully, to generate more earnings from one of their principal sources of income - Rockefeller Center Inc.  R.C.I., which is owned by trusts benefiting the family members, is under pressure from the younger Rockefellers to invest in businesses that provide immediate dividend income and to sell off some of its more traditional real estate holdings, which offer only long-term gains.

headline: Massey to Issue Shares to Canada
abstract: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. said it will issue 5 million common shares to the federal Government of Canada and 3 million common shares to the Government of the Province of Ontario instead of cash dividends. The shares represent $60 million (Canadian) in unpaid and future cash dividends owed on $200 million (Canadian) worth of preferred shares that the two governments acquired in a 1981 refinancing.   Massey is negotiating a further refinancing plan that bankers say will be similar to the deal accepted by the federal and Ontario governments, in which lenders of $900 million (United States) of Massey's debt will accept common shares in lieu of unpaid dividends.

abstract: A bomb exploded at the Bank of Vizcaya here today, killing two employees and wounding seven others among the more than 600 people in the building.

headline: Ad Age Lists Top 10 According to Size
abstract: The biggest excitement in the annual billings issue of Advertising Age due out tomorrow will be the ranking of agencies according to revenues. In it, thanks to its acquisition of the William Esty Company, Ted Bates Worldwide has bounced the J. Walter Thompson Company out of second place, into which it was nudged two years ago, when Young & Rubicam moved in and took its long-held first-place slot.

headline: BUSINESSES GROW ON FAMILY TREES
abstract: Port Washington, L.I. WHEN Irwin Math set up a fiber-optics manufacturing company six y ears ago, he hired his first employee without reading her resume or c hecking her credentials. As he recalls: ''I said to my wife, 'I'm t his great technical guy who can design anything in the world but w hen it comes to running a business and paying the bills, I need y ou.' ''   Ellen Math decided he was right - ''I am the organized one,'' she says - and the couple joined the growing roster of ''mom-and-pop'' partnerships in high-technology businesses. Such companies have prospered as high technology has spread beyond its original breeding grounds near major universities, where pioneers divided their time between professorial duties and entrepreneurial dreams.   On Long Island alone, economists say, dozens of family-owned businesses have set up shop as assemblers, subcontractors and systems manufacturers. ''The problem in keeping up with them is that the falloff is extremely high,'' said Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. ''For all the ones that are created, there are many that don't make it.''

headline: Advertising; Us Delays Plans to Go Weekly
abstract: LAST July Michael J. Boylan, executive vice president of Us magazine, promised a group of advertising types at a luncheon in the St. Regis that the magazine would double its publishing frequency to weekly in September and greatly increase its advertising income.   So here he is six months later, still working for a fortnightly, but bragging about a 34 percent gain in ad pages and a 51 percent gain in ad revenues. A .500 batting average isn't all that bad.   And, since Garey T. Symington, senior vice president and advertising director, is batting 1.000, he gets to be publisher. It's official. And that's a title he once thought he was going to get on Sports Illustrated when he was actually being let go, as they say, as domestic ad director of Time magazine.

headline: SOLIDARITY AIDE IS PUT ON TRIAL
abstract: Anna Walentynowicz, a crane operator whose dismissal helped set off the Gdansk strike that led to the creation of Solidarity, went on trial today, charged with continuing union activity after the imposition of martial law.   In another development, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate, met with Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, to discuss arrangements for a visit by Pope John Paul II in June.

headline: PERES BIDS BEGIN MEET TO DISCUSS ISRAELI VIOLENCE
abstract: Shimon Peres, head of Israel's opposition Labor Party, said today that he wanted to meet with Prime Minister Menachem Begin to discuss how to keep the peace between opposing political and social factions in Israel.   His proposal, made in an interview on the Israeli radio, came in the aftermath of a hand-grenade attack on a group of anti-Government demonstrators outside Mr. Begin's office Thursday night. One man was killed and nine people were wounded, including two policemen.   Mr. Peres called the man who was killed, 33-year-old Emil Grunzweig, ''the first victim on the altar of democracy in Israel.''

headline: Sudan Reports Discovery Of Arms Cache for Coup
abstract: The authorities have seized 70 tons of arms, ammunition and explosives that Libyan agents smuggled into the Sudan last month in an effort to topple President Gaafar al-Nimeiry, the Sudanese press agency reported.   The report, which was issued Sunday and quoted Sudanese intelligence sources, said the Sudanese Navy had intercepted a ship carrying weapons and explosives and arrested five crew members, including a Libyan agent.

abstract: President Reagan, in a written and tape recorded statement for what is New Year's Day in much of Southwest Asia, urged the Soviet Union today to ''end the bloodshed'' in Afghanistan, which its troops entered in 1979.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM A STATEMENT BY ROSTOW ON HIS DEPARTURE
abstract: I have invited you here this morning to say ''thank you'' and ''goodbye.'' We first met nearly two years ago. It was a dispiriting time for A.C.D.A. The agency had been neglected for several years.  Much of its statutory jurisdiction had been taken over by others. As some of you may remember, I recalled on that occasion that I had dedicated a book to the Foreign Service and Civil Service of the United States.   What has happened in this period has confirmed my faith in our professional services, civil and military. What you have done here has been in the highest tradition of the public service. Our programs have been restored. A.C.D.A. has been the architect and moving force behind many important enterprises. You have earned the respect of the entire Government and of the foreign governments with whom we deal. And you have won my affection and gratitude in full measure. And all this has been done despite political and bureaucratic difficulties which never quite went away and have now been manifest anew. I am sure that you will give our new director, my fine and able friend, Kenneth Adelman, the same unstinting support you have given me.

headline: BONN'S FREE DEMOCRATS SEE A SHAFT OF SUNLIGHT
abstract: The small Free Democratic Party, the junior partner in the governing coalition, ended a two-day convention today buoyed by public-opinion polls that for the first time show it winning almost enough votes to remain in Parliament after the March 6 elections.   The two days of speech-making and deliberations in the southern city of Freiburg appeared to have drowned out the quarrels between the party's right and left wing that marred a similar gathering in West Berlin in November.   After the party abandoned Chancellor Helmut Schmidt in September, many left-wing Free Democrats' quit.

headline: No Headline
abstract: U.S. SUPPORTS MIXED-RACE PARTY ON JOINING PRETORIA POLITICAL PLAN   WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) - The State Department today endorsed the decision of South Africa's Labor Party, the largest political group among the mixed-race people called colored, to accept a Government offer of token political representation in a revised parliamentary system.   A department spokesman, John Hughes, said the decision demonstrated that a ''process of change is under way'' in South Africa, ''and we support it.''   At the same time, Mr. Hughes said the United States ''fully recognizes that the current proposals for reform do not address the fundamental question of national political rights for the 72 percent of South Africans who are black.''

headline: Market Place; Pros and Cons Of O-T-C Data
abstract: ADHERING to the mandate of Congress and the blessing of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the National Association of Securities Dealers has broadly expanded its Nasdaq national market system. The move adds 100 stocks to the 84 already trading in the advanced system.   The N.A.S.D. regulates the over-the-counter market in unlisted securities and, through its Nasdaq subsidiary, operates an electronic communications network for 3,700 stocks.   But the national market system, called NMS, is the more revolutionary sector. Far more than a communications network, it provides trade reports within 90 seconds of a transaction as well as current volume. Until the system went into operation last April, this type of data was available only for securities traded on stock exchanges.

headline: 9 Die on Bus in Turkey
abstract: A bus plummeted over a 395-foot cliff in eastern Turkey on Friday, killing 9 people and injuring at least 36, most of them critically, the Anatolia News Agency reported today. The accident occurred as the bus traveled through the mountainous eastern Black Sea region, which was hit by severe snowstorms recently, the agency said.

headline: Price Rises Ease in Italy
abstract: Consumer prices in Italy rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in December from the previous month, the smallest monthly increase of the year, the Italian statistical agency Istat said today. December prices were up 16.3 percent from December 1981, slightly above the 16 percent ceiling set by the Government in its antiinflation campaign for 1982.

headline: HOW DIRECT IS A DIRECT FLIGHT?
abstract: According to the Official Airline Guide, Northwest Orient's Flight 542 from Las Vegas to Newark starts in a DC-10 in Las Vegas then flies to Phoenix and then to Minneapolis. There is a plane change to a Boeing 727-200, which proceeds to Milwaukee, then Detroit and finally arrives at Newark.   Northwest Orient promotes the flight as ''direct.'' But Don Pevsner, a Miami attorney who often handles consumers aviation cases, calls the label ''misleading.'' In fact, Mr. Pevsner has filed a petition with the Civil Aeronautics Board, which is now open for public comment, asking the board to outlaw the use of the term ''direct'' and replace it with ''through flight'' to indicate a flight that has at least one stop or a change of planes or both. The Northwest Orient flight is one of the examples Mr. Pevsner cited in his petition to the C.A.B.

headline: BIG 3'S AUTO SALES UP 10.5%
abstract: The nation's Big Three automobile makers, starting 1983 on an encouraging note, reported today that retail sales increased by 10.5 percent in the first 10 days of January, continuing an upward trend that began in October.   Combined sales at General Motors, Ford and Chrysler totaled 108,348 units in the Jan.1-10 period. The three companies sold 98,039 units during the comparable period in 1982, which, like this year's period, had seven selling days. The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for domestic cars was set at 6.8 million units.

headline: Opel Reports A Profit for '82
abstract: Adam Opel A.G., the West German unit of the General Motors Corporation, released preliminary figures today indicating it made a profit equivalent to $37.1 million in 1982, following two consecutive years of heavy losses.   Ferdinand Beickler, Opel's chief executive, called the result an ''encouraging first step.''

headline: Cadillac Fairview
abstract: The Cadillac Fairview Corporation said it had received a $1.2 million mortgage payment on the 11,000 apartment units it sold to the Greymac Credit Corporation in November for $270 million. Cadillac took a second mortgage worth $113 million in the deal, and third mortgages were provided by three trust companies, Greymac Trust, Seaway Trust and Crown Trust, which were seized by the Ontario government on Jan. 7. These mortgages, totaling $152 million, fell into default after payments of $3.3 million were not received for December and January.

headline: EUROPEANS ASSESS SLIDE IN OIL PRICES
abstract: A decline in oil prices of a few dollars a barrel would produce more winners than losers in Western European economies, economists on the Continent say.   ''If you weigh the pluses and minuses, the positive tends to dominate,'' said Gerhard Riedel, chief economist at the Berliner Handels- und Frankfurter Bank in Frankfurt. ''We're in a phase of recovery where a price decline would be very welcome.''   In recent conversations, he and other bank economists agreed that a moderate oil price reduction would raise Europeans' purchasing power, help dampen inflation and encourage Europe's central banks to trim interest rates further. Lower rates, it is hoped, would encourage consumers and businesses to borrow, hastening a recovery.

headline: Business Week Account
abstract: Business Week is moving its trade advertising account to Bozell & Jacobs to take advantage of its worldwide facilities. That means it will be leaving Fearon, O'Leary & Kaprielian, its agency of about six years. Billings will be in the $2 million area.

headline: Prices of Cattle Futures Begin to Decline Again
abstract: After support from bad weather and a truckers' strike, live cattle futures prices resumed their decline yesterday, much to the relief of many spreaders who had been selling the nearby contracts and buying the summer deliveries since Jan. 28.   On that date the Government reported that the nation's cattle herd totaled 115.2 million head at the start of 1983, or 0.35 percent below the figure a year earlier. The herd was much larger than many traders had expected, and they began selling the nearby futures and simultaneously buying contracts in June and August, when they expect prices to be higher.

headline: No Headline
abstract: SHIPYARD PREVENTS WALESA FROM RETURNING TO HIS JOB   WARSAW, Jan. 14 (UPI) - Lech Walesa, former leader of the outlawed Solidarity union, was refused a work certificate today for his old job as an electrician at the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk because, officials said, his documents were incomplete.   ''I have not been reinstated,'' a colleage of Mr. Walesa quoted him as having said after Mr. Walesa was stopped and turned away at the shipyard gate. Shipyard officials said Mr. Walesa was not allowed to enter because he failed to meet ''certain formalities.''

The bond is expected to be placed shortly by Salomon Brothers.

headline: MOSQUE IN CAIRO MARKS ITS 1,000TH YEAR
abstract: Only a year younger than Cairo itself, Al Azhar Mosque and University held a celebration Friday to mark a thousand years of teaching and devotion to the precepts of the Moslem faith.   The ancient mosque's five spidery minarets glistened in the bright sun as hundreds of Moslem holy men and teachers began the traditional Friday noon prayers led by Al Azhar's Grand Iman, Sheik Gad Alhaq Ali Gad Alhaq.   Among the worshipers was the Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak, who arrived amid intense security. Plainclothesmen were everywhere in the teeming streets of the Khan El Khalili Bazaar and on rooftops of the ancient, crumbling buildings that surround the Moslem holy place whose construction began in the year 970.

headline: MOSCOW PLANS TALKS WITH TOKYO
abstract: Several days after Secretary of State George P.  Shultz ended his visit to Japan last week, the Soviet Union protested strongly against Japanese defense policies and offered talks in the spring on Japanese-Soviet issues, officials here report.   The protest and offer, which were generally regarded here as a Soviet diplomatic countermove to Mr. Shultz's visit to East Asia, were made on Friday by Ambassador Valdimir Y. Pavlov in what Japanese officials described as a sometimes stormy 90-minute call at the Foreign Ministry.   Meeting with Yoshiaki Kato, director general of the ministry's bureau of European affairs, the Ambassador said, according to the officials, that the Soviet Union was disturbed by what it viewed as a trend to ''militarism'' in Japan in alliance with the United States.  He was also said to have threatened ''appropriate measures'' against Japan if it did not desist.

headline: No Headline
abstract: MARINES EXPANDING PATROL ROUTES TO HELP LEBANESE ARMY IN BEIRUT   BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 18 (AP) - The United States Marine Corps contingent here said today that it would begin expanding its patrol routes in and near East Beirut on Saturday in support of Lebanese troops who moved into the predominantly Christian sector of the capital this week.   Capt. Dale Dye, the Marine spokesman, said the frequency of the patrols would not be increased from the current two a day, involving four jeeps and about a dozen men.   These patrols have been conducted from the Marine base near the international airport since the beginning of November, when the Lebanese Army was scheduled to move into East Beirut. When its entry was postponed, the American patrols went in irregularly. The patrols reportedly became more regular only recently.

headline: HOW PANEL MARSHALED MOUNTAIN OF FACTS
abstract: The three-member Israeli commission of inquiry that reported today on events surrounding the massacre of Palestinian civilians in West Beirut last September was appointed by the Cabinet on Oct. 1.   The retiring president of the Supreme Court, Justice Yitzhak Kahan, was appointed chairman, with Justice Aharon Barak and Maj. Gen. Yona Efrat of the Army Reserve as members.

headline: ATLANTA ISSUE SOLD
abstract: Major new tax-exempt bond issues this week included a $150 million issue of the Metro Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority, which was tentatively priced by Salomon Brothers to yield from 5.75 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 10.20 percent in 2005, with 7 percent bonds due in 2011 priced at a discount price of 73.675 to yield 9.75 percent while 10 1/4 percent bonds due in 2020 were offered at 100 to yield 10.25 percent. The authority, known as ''Marta'' to bond traders and underwriters, is rated A/A+.

headline: THE NEW CHIEF OF SHEARSON/AMERICAN EXPRESS IS AN OLD PRO AT 36
abstract: WHEN Peter A. Cohen got the word that he would be elected president a nd chief executive of Shearson/American Express at a board meeting e arlier this month, the 36-year-old executive arrived for the o fficial proceedings with a big paper bag.   First, he pulled out an emperor's crown and mace and, as a sign of respect, ceremoniously gave them to Sanford I. Weill, Shearson's chairman and one of its founders.   Then he removed two oversize shoes for the board to see. ''Peter,'' one board member said, ''wanted to show the size of the shoes he's got to fill.'' Now they rest on the mantelpiece in Mr. Cohen's enormous office near the top of the World Trade Center at the tip of Manhattan.

headline: MEXICO IN $5 BILLION LOAN PACT
abstract: Mexico today announced completion of negotiations with about 530 Western banks on the largest commercial loan in history - a $5 billion ''jumbo'' credit that should be ready for signing in New York late next week.   In a statement, Mexico's Finance Ministry also disclosed that a 13-bank Advisory Committee, which represents Mexico's creditors, will disburse a ''bridge'' loan Friday of about $433 million to be repaid when the first $1.7 billion portion of the main credit is made available in mid-March.   The ''jumbo'' loan is part of a major rescue package for Mexico worked out last December with the International Monetary Fund following the country's worst financial crisis in 40 years. But the timing of the credit also should soften the blow of a reduction in Mexico's oil export price, expected to be announced this weekend.

headline: Farmers' Profits Rose in 1982
abstract: Farmers' net income actually rose last year instead of declining as earlier estimates had indicated, according to revised figures, but it may show little change this year, the Agriculture Department said today.   However, a new prediction held some promise that improvements could occur as the Government's new payment-in-kind or ''crop swap'' program takes hold and the record grain surplus is reduced.

headline: FOR 22 MILLION, AN EZ ALTERNATIVE
abstract: In its continuing efforts to provide taxpayers with a simplified tax form, the Internal Revenue Service developed the new 1040EZ for filing 1982 returns.   The I.R.S. estimates that as many as 22 million people, a quarter of the nation's 95.5 million taxpayers, are eligible to use the new form, and that about half of those eligible will do so.   But in creating the 1040EZ, the agency discovered that developing something simple that could also be used by many taxpapers was in fact quite difficult.   To use 1040EZ, a taxpayer must be single and claim only one exemption; taxpayers older than 65 may not use the form because they automatically claim two exemptions. To qualify, taxable income, including wages, salaries, tips and up to $400 in interest, cannot exceed $50,000.

headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS
abstract: Tax-change proposals are expected to be part of President Reagan's State of the Union message Tuesday. The President said last week that he was considering modified flat-rate plans to simplify the income tax. Martin S. Feldstein, his economic adviser, discussed another option - a tax on consumption but not on savings.   A deficit of $185 billion is likely in the fiscal 1984 budget that President Reagan is scheduled to announce Jan. 31, according to Congressional and Administration sources. The budget message may include a plan for standby tax increases to hold down deficits later in the decade.

headline: I.B.M. to Offer Robot System
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said it was introducing a computer-controlled robotic system that can perform a variety of industrial operations.   The I.B.M. 7565 manufacturing system can also respond to changes in its environment.

headline: Poland Says It Will End Rationing of Soap Feb. 1
abstract: A Government official said today that the rationing of soap and washing powder would be stopped on Feb. 1, but he had little good news about other items.   Zygmunt Lakomiec, Minister for Internal Trade, said in a radio interview that there was sufficient powder and laundry soap for two months.

headline: Israeli Settlements Criticized By Common Market Leaders
abstract: European leaders strongly criticized Israeli settlements on the West Bank today and said the time had come for Israel to show that it was ready to negotiate seriously for Middle East peace.   A statement issued by the heads of Government of the 10 European Common Market countries at the end of a two-day regular meeting here said the Israeli settlements were a major and growing obstacle to peace efforts and were contrary to international law.

The participation certificates, which the corporation now sells daily, are backed by its guarantee as well as the monthly payments of principal and interest from a pool of fixed rate 30-year conventional home mortgages.

headline: Singapore Airlines
abstract: Singapore Airlines has canceled the purchase of two A300 Airbus aircraft and dropped an option to buy two more A310-type planes from Airbus Industrie of France to enable it to buy newer generation aircraft, the airline spokesman said. ''We are interested in new technology, innovation and fuel efficiency,'' the spokesman said. ''There is usually a time lag of a few years between ordering and delivery of a plane,'' he said.

headline: Jozef Glemp
abstract: Archbishop Jozef Glemp, 54 years old, was Pope John Paul's choice to lead the Roman Catholic Church in Poland at a time of civil unrest. Since being named to the post in July of 1981, Archbishop Glemp has sought to be a link between Catholics in Poland and the Polish-born Pope. His has been a moderate voice in the nation, steering a path between the military regime and the more radical segments of the labor union movement.   He succeeded a greatly revered primate, the late Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, who was a symbol not only of the church but of Polish nationalism. About 95 percent of the 36 million people in Poland are Catholics.

headline: FOR ZAMBIA, OLD FRIEND BECOMES EMBARRASSMENT
abstract: Just opposite the golf club here, in a leafy part of town, lie the ruins of a house that was once a nerve center of war. Chickens and crab grass compete for the space among the debris these days but, not long ago, the villa was home to Joshua Nkomo, Zimbabwe's opposition leader, who fled his own country this week.   Lusaka, the tranquil Zambian capital, was his headquarters during the seven years of guerrilla war that preceded Zimbabwe's independence in 1980. But from the perspective of Zambia and others among southern Africa's ''frontline'' countries, Mr. Nkomo's political fortunes, like his onetime residence, are beyond repair and, officials said, he would not be welcome if he eventually tried to return here.

headline: Turkey Says Greece Has 'Baseless' Fears
abstract: Greek fears that Turkey poses a threat are ''totally baseless,'' the Turkish Foreign Minister, Ilter Turkmen, said today.   ''It is well known that Turkey has no hostile intentions against Greece and pursues a cautious policy seeking consensus,'' he said.

headline: LATVIAN CARDINAL SURPRISE TO SOVIET
abstract: A spokesman for the Soviet organization that oversees church affairs says there was no prior contact with the Vatican about the elevation to cardinal of Archbishop Julijans Vaivods of Latvia.   ''It was a surprise to the U.S.S.R.,'' the spokesman for the Council for Religious Affairs said in a telephone discussion Thursday. ''We have not been officially informed.''   The council acts as a coordinating body for the activities of the officially registered churches, the Roman Catholic Church among them, and exercises a wide degree of control over their activities.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: In the nearly three years that Zimbabwe has been independent, Prime Minister Robert Mugabe and Joshua Nkomo have seemingly fulfilled the worst expectations that each has had of the other, reinforcing a history of mutal distrust that goes back two decades.   Mr. Nkomo's flight across the Botswana border on foot Tuesday night not only made a pathetic contrast to his triumphal return to what was then Rhodesia in January 1980, when a throng of 150,000 turned out to acclaim him at the start of his campaign for the election that was to dash his political dreams. It also appeared to mean that the longstanding division in the national movement is now beyond healing, in this generation at least.   In fact, the country had two national movements and two independence struggles from the time 20 years ago when Mr. Mugabe and others rejected Mr. Nkomo's leadership on the ground he was devious and prone to compromise. The split was papered over when the white minority regime was in its death throes and again after independence when Mr. Mugabe formed a coalition with Mr. Nkomo's party, even though his own Zimbabwe African National Union had won a clear majority in Parliament and a firm grip on power.

headline: Hijacked Libyan Plane Held at Malta Airport
abstract: A Libyan airliner carrying about 160 passengers was hijacked in midflight today and landed at a Malta airport ringed by policemen and soldiers, the Maltese police reported.   The airliner, a Boeing 727 of Libyan Arab Airways, was parked in a remote part of Luqa Airport outside Valletta, Malta's capital.

headline: YARDNEY ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ASSOCIATED RISES 24.3%
abstract: Four of the country's leading retail chains yesterday reported earnings gains for the fourth fiscal quarter ended Jan. 29. Federated Department Stores had a 9.7 percent rise; the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, 24.3 percent; the F.W. Woolworth Company, 72.4 percent, and May Department Stores, 16.6 percent.   On Tuesday substantial earnings gains were reported by the Allied Stores Corporation, Carter Hawley Hale Stores and Toys ''R'' Us, the nation's largest toy retailer. The gains reflected a broad-based turnaround for retailers in the fourth quarter, after nine months of weak results.

headline: 18 NEW CARDINALS NAMED BY PONTIFF
abstract: Pope John Paul II named 18 new cardinals today, among them Jozef Glemp, the Pontiff's successor as Primate of Poland, and Joseph I. Bernardin, the Archbishop of Chicago.   The Pope also elevated Msgr. Julijans Vaivods, an 87-year-old Latvian, who becomes the Soviet Union's first publicly proclaimed Cardinal.   The elevation of Archbishop Glemp had been expected since the head of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in Poland is traditionally a cardinal.

headline: SOVIET SEES A TREATY VIOLATION IN ARMS PROPOSED BY REAGAN
abstract: The Soviet press said today that President Reagan's plan for new antimissile technologies amounted to a new stage in the arms race and that their deployment would violate the 1972 treaty limiting such defensive systems.   Official commentaries also depicted Mr. Reagan's speech as an effort by the Administration to push its arms buildup through the Congress.   The Soviet responses consisted of summaries of the President's televised address, referring to his ''beloved theme'' of a Soviet military threat and accusing him of using ''figures about the Soviet military potential fabricated by the Central Intelligence Agency to try and justify the unprecedented military expenditures.''   One commentary, by Tass, the official press agency, focused on Mr.  Reagan's proposed program ''to counter the awesome Soviet missile strength with measures that are defensive.''

headline: Bank in Jersey Closed by U.S.
abstract: The office of the Comptroller of the Currency announced today that it had closed the Pan American National Bank in Union City, N.J., because of ''serious loan losses and other earnings problems.''

headline: Tokyo Politician's Death Is Now Called a Suicide
abstract: Ichiro Nakagawa, a former Cabinet minister whose death had been attributed to a heart attack, committed suicide by hanging, police officials said Tuesday.

headline: PRODUCER PRICES ROSE 0.1% IN FEBRUARY
abstract: Rising food costs pushed up the Producer Price Index in February by a mild one-tenth of 1 percent, the Labor Department reported today.   Food costs actually jumped six-tenths of 1 percent, the largest increase since last April. But this rise was balanced against declining energy costs.   Analysts said that food prices would continue to rise, putting pressure on the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, which measures the cost of goods ready for sale at the retail level.Nevertheless, they said the index would rise this year less than last year's 3.5 percent increase, chiefly because of declining oil prices. Last year's rise was the smallest since 1971.

headline: Excerpts from Bush speech, page 5.
abstract: Vice President Bush, pressing the Soviet Union to revise its positions in the arms reduction talks here, met with the chief Soviet negotiators today and told them the United States was ''deadly serious'' about achieving weapons cuts.   The meetings with the Soviet officials followed a speech by the Vice President to the United Nations Disarmament Committee. In his remarks, Mr. Bush linked progress in the discussions about intermediate-range missiles with the Soviet Union's abandoning what he said was its monopoly on the weapons and recognizing the ''legitimate security concerns'' of the United States.   The Vice President talked separately for an hour at the United States Mission with Yuli A. Kvitsinsky, head of the Soviet delegation in the intermediate-range missile talks, and for another hour with Viktor P. Karpov, chief of the Soviet delegation discussing strategic arms.

headline: INTEREST RATES RISE MODESTLY
abstract: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday, with all of the increase coming in the last two hours of what was an otherwise uneventful trading session, reflecting weak investor demand.   The actively traded 10 3/8 percent Treasury bonds due in 2012, for example, traded at prices slightly above 94 until late afternoon, when the issue fell to an offered price of 93 1/2, down 1/4 point on the day, to yield 11.13 percent. Among other Treasury issues auctioned last week, the 9 7/8 percent notes due in 1986 were offered at 99 10/32 to yield 10.10 percent, and the 10 7/8 percent notes due in 1993 were offered at 99 10/32 to yield 10.99 percent.   Rates on Treasury bills rose as much as a tenth of a percentage point from the levels quoted early in the day, with the three-month bill closing at 8.29 percent and the one-year bill at 8.5 percent.  The Treasury's announcement late in the day that next week's bill auctions will total $12.4 billion, up from $12 billion recently, was widely expected and had little impact on prices.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Associated Press Broadcast Services division to Needham, Harper & Steers, Washington.

headline: Goodrich Deficit
abstract: The B.F. Goodrich Company's chairman, John D. Ong, said that the company would report next month a loss of about $14 million from operations for the fourth quarter and an after-tax provision of about $20 million from the restructuring of several businesses. A year earlier it earned $32.4 million.

headline: Advertising; J. Walter's 'Bad' Year Was Good
abstract: TO people who are up on their advertising news, the retrospective January trade ad from the J. Walter Thompson Company with the headline ''It was a very good year'' came as a bit of a surprise.  But, if you could invade the hearts and minds of the troops at the huge agency, you'd probably find it was a correct statement.   Sure, there was that terrible mess in the now defunct syndication operation involving computer manipulation and the ensuing investigation, dismissal, pretax write-offs, stockholder suit and the earnings loss. But what effect did all that have on the agency's workforce?

headline: McLennan 15.8% Higher
abstract: Marsh & McLennan Companies, a diversified insurance services company, reported that net income advanced 15.8 percent, to $25.6 million, or 74 cents a share, from $22.1 million, or 60 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenues rose 6.4 percent, to a record $219 million, from $205.8 million in the comparable quarter a year earlier.

headline: ENVOY OPPOSES CUT IN SALVADOR AID
abstract: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador said today that a Congressional refusal to approve additional military aid would give ''new heart to the guerrilla movement.''   Ambassador Deane R. Hinton made his remarks after Jeane J.  Kirkpatrick, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, declined to comment on the subject at a news conference.   Mrs. Kirkpatrick's two-day visit to El Salvador has heightened speculation about whether the Reagan Administration will use an emergency discretionary fund to increase military aid above the $26.3 million Congress has already allocated for El Salvador in the fiscal year that began last Oct. 1.

headline: A Strong Merger
abstract: To the Business Editor: Unfortunately, Leslie Wayne's article on the Occidental Petroleum-Cities Service merger (''A Costly Merger for Occidental,'' Jan.23) suggests a broadly held negative opinion of the merger. In addition, the author made a material error in fact concerning the recent sale of an important Cities Service asset.   Those of us who have been close to the merger and to the leaders of both companies who made it happen clearly recognize the business risks involved. We are also, however, impressed with the imagination and extraordinary potential benefits which those risks, properly managed, can bring to this new ''major'' oil company which is now the twelfth-largest company in the United States.

headline: Broker in Playboy Quits
abstract: Marina E. Verola, a broker who posed seminude for Playboy magazine, has resigned under pressure from E.F. Hutton & Company, her lawyer said today. Thomas Rae, Hutton's chief general counsel in New York, said Mrs. Verola had resigned voluntarily. But her lawyer, Donald A. Wich Jr., said she had been given an ultimatum. Mrs. Verola, who is 29 years old and the mother of two, had worked as an account executive in Hutton's Fort Lauderdale office since August.

headline: DOW FACES MORE SUITS ON ADDITIVE
abstract: It was only a few months after the Central National Bank bought its 23-story Cleveland headquarters in November 1977 that dangerous cracks appeared all over the eight-year-old building's brick facade.   Last week the bank won a $26 million jury award against the Dow Chemical Company, the maker of Sarabond, the mortar additive that caused the damage.   The 18-week Central National trial in Cleveland's Common Pleas Court was the first Sarabond case to get to a jury, but lawyers familiar with the problem say that Dow is facing dozens - and possibly hundreds - of similar claims. The Brick Institute of America estimates that Sarabond has been used in about 2,000 buildings.

headline: Portugal's Devaluation
abstract: The Bank of Portugal today increased the escudo's monthly crawling peg devaluation to 1 percent from three-fourths of 1 percent. This amounts to a total devaluation of 2 percent, the bank said, following this week's realignment of currencies in the European Monetary System.

headline: Vice Chairman Quits Posts at Dean Witter
abstract: Keith S. Wellin, vice chairman of the Dean Witter Financial Services Group and of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., has resigned his executive roles, the companies said yesterday.   Mr. Wellin, 56, was formerly president of E.F. Hutton.

headline: Glemp Holds Mass in Rome
abstract: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, Primate of the Roman Catholic Church in Poland, celebrated mass for Rome's Polish community today at the St. Stanislaw Church.

headline: Suspected Mass Killer Is Remanded in London
abstract: A 37-year-old British civil servant who told the police that he had strangled and dismembered 16 young drifters was remanded in jail today on a single murder charge.   While the police searched for more remains in the garden of a house where he had once lived, Dennis Andrew Nilsen made his first court appearance in the North London district of Highgate in connection with the case.

headline: West Indian Athletes Touring South Africa
abstract: A breakaway team of West Indian cricketers began a tour of South Africa today to a standing ovation from a packed, multiracial crowd despite criticism over the tour from South African blacks and from abroad.

Last year the short interest totaled 85 million shares.   In the latest period, the short interest on the American Stock Exchange fell 93,358 shares, to 12.6 million.  A short position can result from the sale of borrowed stock in the hope of buying the same issue at a later date and at a lower price to cover the sale. headline: 2 U.S. AIDES SAY SALVADOR FACES AN ARMS 'CRISIS'
abstract: Administration officials told Congress today that El Salvador faced a ''crisis'' and could run out of military supplies in 30 days unless the United States provided an additional $60 million in military aid.   At the same time the two officials -Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs and Nestor D. Sanchez, Deputy Assistant Defense Secretary for Inter-American Affairs - insisted that ''major national interests'' of the United States were at stake in El Salvador. Should the Salvadoran Government be defeated by the guerrillas, the officials said, the result would threaten other nations in Central America as well as Mexico and the Panama Canal.   ''We understand the concern of those who remember the specter of Vietnam that the war in El Salvador is being 'Americanized,' '' said Mr. Sanchez, who appeared before the House Foreign Affairs Committee's panel of Western Hemisphere Affairs. ''But Vietnam was 10,000 miles away. El Salvador is a contiguous region right at our doorstep. San Salvador is closer to Washington, D.C. than is San Francisco.''

headline: WESTINGHOUSE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues   * Affiliated Bankshares of Colorado filed an offering of $50 million of notes, due March 15, 1993, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley.   * Federal-Mogul Corp. plans to exchange up to 500,000 common shares for $15 million of 7 1/2 percent debentures due Jan. 15, 1998, owned by Goldman Sachs.   * Deere & Co.'s $200 million of 9 percent 25-year convertible subordinated debentures are offered at a price of 100 by Merrill Lynch.

headline: STERLING TO TRY AGAIN WITH A NONASPIRIN DRUG
abstract: For Sterling Drug Inc., the makers of Bayer aspirin, the recall of Johnson & Johnson's Tylenol last September presented an unexpected opportunity. Sterling had for years been trying unsuccessfully to break Tylenol's grip on the pain reliever market, and this sudden moment of vulnerability must have seemed just the right time for Sterling to try again.   It was also an opportunity for the company to gain a foothold in the aspirin-free pain reliever market, something it has been refusing to attempt in recent years despite a decline in demand for aspirin products.   Accordingly, analysts say, Sterling decided to introduce its Panadol drug, a nonaspirin pain reliever sold only overseas for the past 25 years, into the United States next month. ''This marks a significant change in company strategy,'' said David Crossen, an analyst at Smith Barney.

headline: Knapp Communications
abstract: Harry Myers, who became publisher of Knapp Communications' Geo magazine after 20 years with the Meredith Corporation, has now been named group publisher of all Knapp magazines - Architectural Digest, Bon Appetit and Home, in addition to Geo. He will be working in New York and will succeed John L. Decker, 47, who will remain at Los Angeles headquarters ''in a yet to be determined capacity.'' Mr.  Myers, 51, joined Geo in the spring of 1982. At Meredith he had been, among other things, the publisher of Apartment Life who repositioned it as Metropolitan Home.

headline: Madison Fund Bars Merger Bids
abstract: The Madison Fund Inc., a New York-based management investment company, announced that it would decline certain unspecified acquisition offers from other companies, and remain an independent, nondiversified company, in accordance with the business plan approved by its shareholders in April 1982.   Madison said it had also approved a $100 million budget for its Madison Resources Inc. subsidiary, to be used for energy investments, and a repurchase plan to buy up to six million shares of Madison Fund common stock at a priced approximating net adjusted asset value.

headline: U.S. Military Team Meets Nicaraguan Army Chiefs
abstract: A four-man United States military delegation met today with the leaders of the Nicaraguan Army, military sources here said.   The United States delegation conferred with the Nicaraguan Defense Minister, Humberto Ortega, in the converted bunker that served as the command post of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle before he was ousted by the Sandinists, the sources said.

headline: DAYTON MALLEABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27

headline: Real Estate; Some Brokers Criticized
abstract: LEASES for commercial space in New York City are getting so complex that even the professionals who negotiate them may not understand them, according to Harry Huberth, president of Huberth & Huberth Inc., a major real estate firm.   ''The odds are over 50 percent that a tenant will wind up with a broker who doesn't know what he's talking about,'' said Mr. Huberth, who is also chairman of the ethics and professional practices committee of the Real Estate Board of New York.   His colleague, S. Donald Friedman, executive vice president of Huberth & Huberth, shares that harsh view and added that some brokers handling commercial leases were not only unprofessional but also might be unethical. Mr. Friedman is chairman of the community information and education committee of the real estate board. The board is the leading trade organization in the city and represents most of the major brokers, owners and managers.

headline: No Headline
abstract: MEXICO TO KEEP CURRENT OIL OUTPUT   MEXICO CITY, March 18 (AP) - The Mexican Government, observing the 45th anniversary of its takeover of the Mexican oil industry, said today that it would maintain current levels of oil production as it sought to avoid a price war with other petroleum exporters.   Mario Ramon Beteta, director of the state-controlled Petroleos Mexicanos, said Mexico would hold production at 2,750,000 barrels daily, with exports of 1.5 million barrels. Half of those exports go to the United States.

headline: MACMILLAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

headline: Commodities; A System For Stock Futures
abstract: FUTURES traders often joke that the biggest killings in any new market are usually made in its first year of trading, before the professional hedgers, speculators and arbitragers get a handle on the market. But it is nearly a year since the first of the three broadbased stock index futures markets opened, and the handle still seems to elude and frustrate the professionals.   Much of the frustration stems from the fact that while the stock market has been on a strong upward trend since August, index futures longs, or buyers, have usually been whipsawed out of their paper profits by the many violent price swings that have attended the rise.    While the trading volume has soared, along with the stock market, since last August, the Value Line, Standard & Poor's 500 and New York Stock Exchange composite indexes remain ''coin-toss markets'' to most traders. About the only trend that is predictable is that these indexes rise and fall to varying degrees with the underlying averages.

headline: 'Magazine Buff' Starts Dobbs Ferry Quarterly
abstract: A one-time reporter and columnist for Advertising Age who also edited two other trade publications and describes himself as ''a magazine buff'' has gone out and started one of his own.   Robert Z. Chew 3d, an Ohio native, is now editor and publisher of Hudson Valley Living, a regional, quarterly magazine based in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., that is scheduled to go to a six-a-year frequency next year.
