headline: Lilco Rating Is Lowered
abstract: Standard & Poor's said yesterday that three ratings on Long Island Lighting Company issues had been lowered because of the lack of an evacuation plan for the company's $3.2 billion nuclear power station at Shoreham.   The investment service said its rating on Lilco's outstanding publicly rated first-mortgage bonds had been lowered to BBB, from BBB.

headline: PACIFIC SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Surprising Life In Tool Stocks
abstract: AN intriguing thing about the stock market is its perversity.  Consider, for example, the way it's treating machine tool stocks: Nobody on Wall Street is rushing out these days with ''buy'' recommendations.   It's not difficult to understand why, however. The industry's new orders plunged 49 percent in 1982 and profits suffered. As a result, plant closings, salary cuts, employee layoffs and shortened workweeks have become the order of the day. In addition to having to cope with weak domestic demand, the industry is also losing market share to foreign producers.

headline: GUATEMALA LIFTS ITS STATE OF SIEGE
abstract: President Efrain Rios Montt today lifted the state of siege he imposed last July and announced he would turn power over to an elected civilian government.   He gave no indication, however, when elections might be held, and civilian political leaders complained that the decrees issued today could allow him to remain in the presidency for several more years.   General Rios Montt took power after a military coup whose first anniversary was celebrated today. Stores, schools, businesses and government offices were closed in observance of the ''Day of National Dignity.''

headline: PHONE-MATE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: JAPAN'S NEW NONCONFORMISTS
abstract: Japanese companies seeking new employees typically have one goal in mind: hiring the graduates of leading national universities. Masaya Nakamura, president of Namco Ltd., however, takes an entirely different approach.   In colorful magazine advertisements, Namco, a producer of video games, solicits reformed juvenile delinquents and C students.  ''For game designers,'' Mr. Nakamura explained, ''the knowledge acquired in school is not so helpful. I want people who think in unusual ways, whose curiosity runs away with them, fun-loving renegades.''

headline: U.S. SEEKS TO KEEP SCHOOL IN PANAMA
abstract: The United States wants to continue training Latin American soldiers at its School of the Americas here, despite a clause in the 1978 Panama Canal treaty that says the school must close next year.   The treaty requires the Army-run school to close by Oct. 1, 1984, ''unless the two Governments otherwise agree.'' Informal talks aimed at reaching such an agreement are under way, according to diplomats and Panamanian politicians.   Western diplomats familiar with the American position said the United States was willing to give Panama a larger voice in running the school if that was necessary to keep it open. Some nationalists in Panama, together with leftists from other Latin countries, demand that the school be removed because it symbolizes American support for militarism in the hemisphere.

headline: TIGHTER CREDIT IN FARM BELT
abstract: Bankers across the troubled farm belt are tightening up on their agriculture loans, under the watchful eye of state banking officials.   The danger lies in a growing number of cases like one at the Kingsley State Bank, which is operated by two brothers, Robert and George Phelps, in this town of 1,200 people.   Leaning forward over his desk, Robert Phelps, the bank's president, described the file he held in his hand. It was that of a young farmer who bought 90 acres two years ago when times were better and land prices had risen. He paid $2,500 an acre.

headline: Libyans Accusing U.S.  Of Provocative Actions
abstract: The United States and Libya traded charges today at a Security Council meeting called by Libya to protest what it called ''provocative military actions'' off its coast.   Ali Treiki, the Libyan delegate, said the movement of American warships in Mediterranean waters off Libya and Egypt and the sending of four Awacs electronic surveillance planes to Egypt were the latest in a long series of American ''provocations.''

headline: Advertising; Revlon May Raise Ad Budget
abstract: REVLON, a leader in the cosmetics and fragrance industry, which is known for having fairly tight strings on its ad budget, is describing its planned 1983 advertising budget for its fragrances as ''huge.''   Of course, neither Sanford Buchsbaum, executive vice president-advertising, worldwide, nor Joseph R. Liebman, senior vice president, public relations, would say how much is being spent. They cited competitive reasons.   What we have is Leading National Advertisers, an independent media measuring organization, tracking between $3.5 million and $4.5 million in 1981 for each of the three major brands, and a promise enunciated by the company in mid-1982 that it would be exceeding its traditionally low advertising-to-sales ratio.

headline: THE ATTACK ON THE POPE: NEW LINK TO BULGARIANS
abstract: The authorities in Western Europe have information that supports testimony given to them by a Turkish assassin, Mehmet Ali Agca, that when he tried to kill Pope John Paul II on May 13, 1981, he was acting at the behest of Bulgarian intelligence agents.  The evidence, though not conclusive, includes information from a Bulgarian official who defected in France in July 1981.  The official, Iordan Mantarov, 48 years old, told French intelligence agents that the plot to kill the Pope was devised by the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence agency, and by the Bulgarian secret service, which many Western intelligence specialists consider subservient to Moscow.  The plan was drawn up, Mr. Mantarov said, because the two agencies believed that the Pope was the keystone of a United States effort to subvert the Polish Government and move it away from the Communist bloc.  The Bulgarian Government has called the implication that Bulgarians were involved in the assassination attempt on the Pope entirely without foundation and a fabrication put together by Western intelligence agencies. The Soviet Union has repeatedly denied any role in the attack.

headline: People
abstract: * John J. Fisher appointed president of Frank J. Corbett Inc., Chicago, a wholly owned subsidiary of BBDO Health and Medical Communications Inc.   * Felix Kaufman named executive vice president in charge of administration at Ruder Finn & Rotman Inc.

headline: Wainoco Notes Credit Default
abstract: The Wainoco Oil Corporation said that is in technical default on a $50 million credit, but that its banks are waiving the default until at least Thursday.   Wainoco, based in Houston, said that at the end of last year, it had current assets of $30 million and current liabilities of $32 million, violating a condition of a revolving credit agreement that current assets at least equal current liabilities.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * B. Altman & Co. has promoted Alfred B. Gates to vice president and general merchandise manager.   * Bank of New York has elected Donald K. Bump president of the Southwestern Region.

headline: Italian Trade Deficit
abstract: Italy's overall balance of payments deficit narrowed slightly in February to a provisional $210 million from $212.5 million in January, the Bank of Italy said today. The February deficit was sharply less than the deficit of about $900 million recorded in the same month last year.

headline: SEIZING OF POLISH ACTIVISTS GOES ON DESPITE SUSPENSION OF MARTIAL LAW
abstract: Although the internment of political dissidents was formally ended Dec. 30 with the suspension of the basic provisions of martial law, the authorities are still arresting underground Solidarity activists.   The largest recent roundup came just before New Year's when the police seized what they said was an underground printing plant near the city of Poznan that was directed by an art historian and a history lecturer, both of whom had been released from internment earlier.   Fifteen underground activists were arrested in connection with the plant's operation, the authorities said. This week the state television presented a special program on the underground operation, shown after the nightly news, that prominently featured the possession of scarce imported food by the group.

headline: Zenith and Taft Co.  In Teletext Venture
abstract: The Zenith Radio Corporation, a manufacturer of color televisions, desk top computers and cable television equipment, annouced today that it had signed a five-year agreement with the Taft Broadcasting Company to produce teletext receiving equipment.   The agreement, which is to take effect when the Federal Communications Commission authorizes commercial teletext service, is the first between a manufacturer and a broadcaster, Taft said.

headline: POLITICS AND COSTS HINDER LAND PROGRAM
abstract: The land redistribution program is mired in debt and is caught between two political forces, one of which would like to see it succeed and another that has tried to undermine its success, according to Government and labor officials here.   The Reagan Administration, for which the program has epitomized social progress in El Salvador, must certify progress in land redistribution to continue sending military aid to the country. In addition, the success of the program is seen by moderates here as a crucial element in the country's effort to succeed as a democracy and win the civil war against the leftist opposition.   While more than 80,000 peasants theoretically control land that was not theirs three years ago when the program began, they are struggling to hold onto their property through waves of evictions and vandalism. Moreover, the administrators of one of the two major agencies that manage a farm program are ''inefficient and incompetent,'' according to a high Government official.

headline: Seiko Time Corporation Sets a Spring Campaign
abstract: The Seiko Time Corporation, the United States marketing arm of the Japanese manufacturer, will break a new spring campaign next month with the theme ''Setting the standard for the future for the world,'' in both television and print.   The advertising flight, lasting from April through June to catch the gift-giving troika of Mother's Day, Father's Day and graduation, will feature two 30-second television commercials from AC& R Advertising, a Ted Bates Worldwide subsidiary.

headline: Washington Watch; Feldstein Tune Called Off-Key
abstract: WASHINGTON WITHIN days of the delivery of the Reagan Administration's economic forecast, Martin S. Feldstein, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, was singing a new, more upbeat tune.  But in the Office of Management and Budget, the Treasury and some parts of the White House, it all sounded off-key.   Mr. Feldstein, with a new prediction that the economy could grow at a 5 percent rate from the fourth quarter of 1982 to the fourth quarter of 1983, has become more optimistic than many forecasters.  And the switch, to the chagrin of some observers, has occurred in a matter of days.

headline: Atari Home Computers To Wells, Rich, Greene
abstract: Well, it finally happened. Atari, the Warner Communications subsidiary that makes video games and computers, has finally officially switched its home computer business to Wells, Rich, Greene from Young & Rubicam, as marketplace rumbling had said it was about to do last month.

headline: Eastman Kodak
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company said about 96,800 of its United States employees would receive wage dividends totaling about $252.1 million on Friday. The company said the dividend would include cash payments of $174.2 million and payments to the Eastman Kodak employees' savings and investment plan. Kodak paid a wage dividend of about $246.4 million last year to about 92,600 employees.

headline: NORTHERN STATES POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DELHI PARLEY ENDS WITH U.S. ASSAILED
abstract: A five-day conference of 101 third world nations and organizations ended here today with the issuing of declarations that ranged from Cuban- and Palestinian-backed denunciations of the United States to appeals for disarmament and economic cooperation.   In a 55-page draft of the declarations, the United States was chastised 11 times. All but two of those references were in sections dealing with Latin America and the Middle East, areas where the Cubans and the Palestine Liberation Organization concentrated extensive lobbying efforts. The documents listed the Soviet Union by name only once, in an appeal to it and the United States to hold talks on demilitarization of the Indian Ocean.

headline: Ciba-Geigy Deal
abstract: Ciba-Geigy A.G. said it had reached agreement in principle to acquire the Titmus Eurocon Group, a manufacturer and distributor of contact lenses and lens care products based in Aschaffenburg, West Germany. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: U.N. CHIEF REJECTS U.S. NAMIBIA POLICY
abstract: United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today rejected American efforts to link the withdrawal of Cuban soldiers from Angola to independence for South-West Africa.   The United Nations Secretary General, who is on an eight-country tour of Africa, said after talks with President Julius K. Nyerere that the United Nations plan for independence in South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, ''is the real and only solution.''   ''Namibia is a bilateral problem between the United Nations and South Africa,'' Mr. Perez de Cuellar said. ''We cannot accept outside interference but we do welcome assistance in solving the Namibian problem.

headline: THAT FINE PRINT IN BANK ADS
abstract: A blizzard of bank ads promoting the new money-market-rate accounts has hit in the last month. They feature big numbers, in big bold type. But some Government agencies and consumer advocates taking a close look at the promotions are concerned about what lies in the fine print.   These critics point to what they see as obscure and possibly misleading descriptions of the period of time for which advertised interest rates are available, the blending of two different rates into one on the checking accounts and maintenance fees that effectively reduce the actual interest paid.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt   * Citicorp said an average rate of 8.806 percent had been set at its weekly auction of 91-day commercial paper, down from 8.856 percent last week. Bids ranged from 8.785 percent to 8.819 percent.   * Compagnie Financiere Michelin of Switzerland announced plans to float a 100 million Swiss franc bond at 5 1/2 percent interest on the Swiss capital market, starting Friday. The bond will have a maximum life of 10 years.

headline: Heublein Closing
abstract: Heublein Spirits announced tentative plans to close its four-year-old, $26 million production and bottling plant here, a move that would leave 230 people without jobs. Robert R. Weiss, company president, said the decision was based on an examination of the company's production capacities, the economy and the forecast of spirits sales through 1987. Heublein is a unit of R.J. Reynolds Industries.

headline: TIGER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POPE RENEWS BID FOR EFFORTS AT DISARMAMENT
abstract: Pope John Paul II called today on the world's opposing forces to carry out a joint program of disarmament.  ''Peace cannot be built by some without the others,'' the Pope declared in a New Year's homily in St. Peter's Basilica, ''but all must undertake the task together.''   He continued: ''There lies the true sense of the dialogue for peace: It demands that all the parties work in common, to progress in common on the path of peace. It is therefore difficult to imagine how the problem of peace in the world can be resolved in a unilateral manner, without the participation and the concrete commitment of all.''

headline: Rainier National
abstract: The Rainier National Bank has shelved plans to move its credit card division to South Dakota and decided to raise its card user fees instead.   The bank's annual card user fee has been raised to $18 from $12, C.W. Strong Jr., Rainier Bancorp president, said.

headline: Britons and U.S. Ad Agency Discuss a Campaign on Arms
abstract: Britain's Defense Ministry is discussing with an American advertising agency a campaign to be paid for by British taxpayers aimed at counteracting growing support for nuclear disarmament.

headline: Grey Network Expands
abstract: Grey Advertising, the world's 13th largest, announced yesterday that it had become majority owner in Gramm & Grey, a West German advertising agency with almost $100 million in billings and the country's fifth-largest shop. Bernd Michael, who has 16 years with the business, has become managing director and chief executive. The shop is the largest in Grey's international network, which is now made up of 56 offices in 27 countries.

headline: SIMON, NORTON, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NICKLOS OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A WOMAN'S WORK IS NEVER DONE
abstract: Wenda Brewster-O'Reilly, a researcher at Stanford University's School of Education, wanted to observe dual-career marriages under what she considered the best of circumstances. Her purpose: to determine just how equal these husbands and wives were. Her finding: not very.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Torrington Company, Torrington, Conn., to BBDM Inc., Chicago.

headline: U.S. STEEL DISCUSSING IMPORT PLAN WITH THE BRITISH, ANGERING UNION
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it was holding talks with the British Steel Corporation about importing unfinished steel from the state-owned British enterprise to U.S.  Steel's Fairless Works and possibly some of its other plants. The announcement set off a furor in the steelworkers' union.   Lloyd McBride, president of the United Steelworkers of America, said in a statement from its Pittsburgh headquarters: ''It is our intention as a union to resist this arrangement in every way that is at our disposal. These discussions have grave implications which go beyond any one facility to the very future of the industry itself.  The jobs of thousands of steelworkers are at stake.''

headline: Georgia Utility
abstract: A $125 million issue of 13 1/4 percent, Baa-rated bonds of the Georgia Power Company was offered yesterday at 99.63 to yield 13.3 percent to maturity in 2013. The underwriters, led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., said sales ''were off to a good start.''

headline: POSTAL INSTANT PRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. PLANS TRUST INQUIRY ON AIR ROUTES TO BRITAIN
abstract: The Justice Department announced today that it was investigating possible criminal violations of the antitrust laws by airlines flying between the United States and Britain.   Subpoenas will be issued shortly and information will be presented to a Federal grand jury here dealing with violations of the Sherman Antitrust Act, said Mark Sheehan, a department spokesman, but he refused to name the airlines involved in the investigation or specify the acts that prompted the inquiry.   Spokesmen for both Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines, two large international carriers operating between the United States and Britain, said they had been notified by the Justice Department about the investigation.

headline: TREASURY CONCESSIONS ON WITHHOLDING ISSUE
abstract: The Treasury Department, under pressure from the banking and securities industries, agreed today to some concessions in the way taxes are to be withheld from interest and dividend payments to cosnumers.   But John E. Chapoton, Assistant Treasury Secretary for Tax Policy, said that the 10 percent tax on interest and stock dividend payments will go into effect as scheduled on July 1. ''It will definitely go into effect July 1, and that is it,'' Mr. Chapoton said.

headline: ARTHUR KOESTLER AND WIFE SUICIDES IN LONDON
abstract: Arthur Koestler, an archetype of the activist Central European intellectual who drew on his Communist background for the antitotalitarian novel ''Darkness at Noon,'' was found dead with his wife at their London home yesterday. Police officials said their deaths were apparently by suicide.   Scotland Yard said the police, alerted by a maid, found the bodies of Mr. Koestler, who was 77 years old, and his wife, Cynthia, believed to be in her 50's, seated in chairs in the living room of their home in the Knightsbridge section. The maid, Amelia Marino, had found a note instructing her to call the police.   Police officials said they believed Mr. Koestler suffered from leukemia and Parkinson's disease but that his wife was not known to have had any grave ailment. The police said the deaths appeared to be from an overdose of barbiturate tablets. Autopsies were to be conducted today.

headline: SOCAL OFF 25.6%
abstract: Weakened by sagging demand and lower oil prices, the Exxon Corporation's net income rose 6.9 percent in the fourth quarter, while that of the Standard Oil Company of California skidded 25.6 percent, the companies reported yesterday.   Both had lower earnings for the full year, and cited in part the costs resulting from their obligation to purchase oil from Saudi Arabia at that country's benchmark price of $34 a barrel for Saudi Light crude at a time when others were selling similar crude oil at lower prices.   Exxon and Socal are partners in the Arabian American Oil Company, or Aramco, which produces Saudi Arabia's oil and markets most of it.  The four American companies in the partnership - Exxon, Standard Oil, Texaco and Mobil - are committed to purchase Saudi oil at $34, although the price of Saudi Light oil on the spot, or noncontract market has fallen to as low as $28 a barrel. The companies process the Saudi crude and market the resulting petroleum products. Profits have been squeezed by falling retail prices for these products.

headline: Real Estate; New Status For Puck Building
abstract: PETER GEE and Paul Serra are longtime friends who have successfully combined careers in the arts with conversions of loft buildings into residential cooperatives in the Tribeca and SoHo areas of Manhattan.   Now they are engaged in a more unusual venture: renovation of the 98-year-old Puck Building into a commercial condominium offering 150,000 square feet of space for businesses and individuals active in graphic arts. Sales are to begin in April.   Mr. Gee said their project - apparently the first arts-related commercial condominium in New York City -marks the slow emergence of the commercial condominium as an accepted real estate activity in the city.

headline: FRENCH LEFT EXPECTS LOSSES IN RUNOFF
abstract: The Socialist and Communist coalition Government expects to lose more cities Sunday in the final round of the nationwide municipal elections.   Changes in the Cabinet of President Francois Mitterrand are likely as a result of the voting, but the nature of the personnel movements, described as imminent by Socialist Party sources, will be determined by how much ground is lost.   In last Sunday's first round, the Government parties were defeated by the conservative or moderate candidates in 16 cities with populations over 30,000 that the left had controlled. With 67 races still undecided in large cities, the final total could grow to 45 or more after this Sunday's runoff.

headline: Tribune Co. Net Up 69%
abstract: The Tribune Company said fourth-quarter net rose 69 percent, to $50.5 million, from $29.9 million a year earlier, on revenue of $390.9 million.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: REAGAN IS SILENT ON POPE PLOT
abstract: President Reagan, asked Wednesday night about charges by Italian officials that Bulgaria instigated the shooting of Pope John Paul II in May 1981, said at his news conference tonight that it would ''not be proper'' to comment while the investigation was still under way.   ''I know that the Italians are investigating and in view of their procedures and their handling of the Gen. Dozier case, I have great confidence in their abilities,'' the President said in reference to Gen. James L. Dozier, the American general who was kidnapped by Italian terrorists in late 1981.

headline: ANCHOR HOCKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS
abstract: Production in U.S. factories fell only one-tenth of one percent in December, the Federal Reserve said, giving a promising signal that the economic decline may be touching bottom. Auto production surged 13 percent, but business equipment output fell 19.5 percent. For the year, production fell 8.2 percent, the biggest annual decline since 1974.   American businesses reduced the value of their inventories by 1.1 percent in November, the largest monthly drop recorded. Inventories fell $5.6 billion to a seasonally adjusted $508.6 billion. Spending for expansion and modernization will be reduced by 5.2 percent in 1983, American business executives said.

headline: NONALIGNED BLOC BACKS NICARAGUA
abstract: Nicaragua tonight won the backing of an important bloc of third world nations in its continuing dispute with the Reagan Administration over what it says is United States support for anti-Sandinist rebels based in neighboring Honduras.   Delegates at a weeklong meeting of the 97-nation movement of countries that profess nonalignment, which was expected to end late tonight or early Saturday, specifically denounced ''systematic attacks'' against Nicaragua that ''form a part of a deliberate plan to harass and destabilize Nicaragua, as admitted publicly by a foreign power.''   After lengthy closed-door negotiations, however, several key paragraphs in the meeting's final declaration were couched in less strongly anti-American language than in the draft originally proposed by Nicaragua and Cuba, which is the current head of the movement.

headline: Business and the Law; Interest Clash Splits Up Firm
abstract: WHAT'S a law firm to do when its Chicago office takes on work that creates a conflict of interest for its Washington branch?  Well, if the law firm is Kirkland & Ellis, the answer is that many of the Washington lawyers split off to create their own firm. The split, effective next week, arose from the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, when Elmer W. Johnson, the managing partner of Kirkland & Ellis, was asked to be special counsel to the Middle Western holding company that is taking over the operation of five of A.T.& T.'s Middle Western subsidiaries.   Mr. Johnson's decision to take the job did not sit well with Richard E. Wiley, the former Federal Communications Commission chairman who was hired by Mr. Johnson in 1977 to head Kirkland & Ellis's Washington office. Mr. Wiley, who has a large communications practice, knew that Mr. Johnson's new client would make it impossible for him to keep his clients, and said as much to the partnership, but the Chicago office chose to take on the holding company anyway.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Saudi Pipeline Tactic
abstract: Saudi Arabia is reported cutting pipeline charges in half in an effort to increase use of the $1.6 billion trans-Arabian oil pipeline.

headline: Bid for Miami Coke Bottler
abstract: The Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Miami Inc. said it had reached an agreement in principle to be acquired by a private investor group for $154 million.

headline: People
abstract: * Charles D. Einach has been named an executive vice president at Nadler & Larimer Inc.   * Alice Goldberg, a senior vice president at Benton & Bowles, has been promoted to director of research services.

headline: Arafat in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, discussed the Middle East today in Riyadh with the Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal. The official Saudi press agency gave no details of the talks.

headline: Two New Chief Rabbis To Be Elected in Israel
abstract: Parliament today defeated a Government bill that would have again extended the tenure of Israel's two Chief Rabbis.   Proponents of rigorous Orthodoxy on the one hand and the liberal wing of the Likud bloc on the other balked at supporting the extension and helped defeat the Government move, 47 to 40.

headline: Bonn Seizes Arsonist
abstract: A man was arrested early today after he broke into a British Army camp supply center and set fire to two military trucks, a police spokesman said. He was not identified.

headline: THE BIG DEFICITS WILL GET SCANT SUPPORT
abstract: THE 1984 Federal Budget is evidence that President Reagan intends tos tick to his guns despite diminished popular and Congressional s upport. The new budget extends the President's economic policies andp riorities without significant compromise or concern for political r ealities. Thus, like last year, Congress is confronted with tough c hallenges - but the mood and composition of this year's Congress is c hanged.  The toughest challenge derives from the persistent huge budget deficits that threaten to impair the future health of the economy for years to come. According to the official estimates, the budget deficit would rise from $231 billion in fiscal year 1984 to $300 billion in fiscal year 1988, if the Administration's request for rapidly escalating defense spending were fully implemented without further tax increases or offsetting cuts in domestic programs.

headline: Harris to Sell Unit
abstract: The Harris Corporation announced that it had signed a definitive contract to sell its $400 million printing equipment business to a new company organized by Clayton & Dubilier Inc., a New York investment firm. The Melbourne, Fla., company said it expected to receive about $250 million from the sale, which is scheduled to be closed within 30 days.

headline: U.S. AIDES REPORT POLICY UNCHANGED ON MISSILE CURBS
abstract: American negotiators in talks on limiting intermediate-range missiles and intercontinental-range nuclear weapons will be sent back to Geneva later this month with essentially unchanged positions, according to Administration officials.   That plan is said to run counter to advice from Paul H. Nitze, the negotiator on intermediate-range systems. In recent interagency deliberations, he is reported to have recommended the abandonment of President Reagan's demand for reducing both Soviet and American missiles in Europe to zero.   In Bonn today, Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, firmly rejected the United States' insistence on the so-called zero option. (Page A11.)

headline: GAS DECONTROL BILL SENT TO CONGRESS
abstract: President Reagan, declaring that consumers are ''poorly and unfairly served'' by an inflexible regulatory system, sent to Congress today a bill to remove controls on the price of natural gas at the wellhead by 1986.   Although the bill contains features aimed at protecting consumers from sharp price increases, the predominant response among key legislators was skepticism or stout resistance.   ''I know it will help the major oil and gas producers,'' said Representative Philip R. Sharp, the Indiana Democrat whose energy subcommittee will begin hearings on the bill during the third week of March. ''But I am not convinced it will help consumers.'' A House aide put the bill's chances of passage in its current form at ''practically zero.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Goodyear Plant Set for South
abstract: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced it would locate a $50 million steel wire cord manufacturing plant for radial tires in Asheboro, N.C., employing 350 people.

headline: OPEC TALKS EXPECTED TO FOCUS ON PRODUCTION
abstract: The 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, at their meeting this weekend in Geneva, will focus much more intensively on how much oil each produces, rather than on past conflicts over pricing.   And if the 13 fail again to agree on production quotas, Saudi Arabia may be forced to reduce its output further to avert a price war, industry sources said today.   The prospects for an agreement are far from clear: One source close to the oil producing countries of the Persian Gulf said of two countries that have been the focus of the dispute: ''The Iranians and Libyans are sufficiently rattled to be willing to compromise.'' But, he noted, there is ''still quite a long way to go,'' with no certainty a compromise can be reached.

headline: Short-Term Rates in Decline; Action by Fed Is Anticipated
abstract: Interest rates fell yesterday on speculation that the Federal Reserve Board might have embarked on a policy that would foster a decline in short-term interest rates.   Although some analysts expressed doubts that the Fed would act soon, speculation that such a move might be afoot was enough to reduce short-term interest rates on Treasury bills and bank certificates of deposit by five to 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.   In the note and bond market, prices of Treasury issues rose between one-eighth and five-eighths of a point. Among active issues, the new 9 7/8 percent notes due 1988 were offered at 99 18/32, to yield 9.89 percent, and the 10 3/8 percent bonds due in 2012 were offered at 98 1/8, to yield 10.58 percent.

headline: Argentina Gets Loan
abstract: A $500 million short-term loan offered to Argentina by the Bank for International Settlements last month has been made available, Economy Ministry sources said. Banking sources said earlier that the loan had been stalled by problems in arranging collateral.

headline: BONN CANDIDATE WRITES REAGAN ON ARMS
abstract: The West German opposition candidate for Chancellor, Hans-Jochen Vogel, has written a letter to President Reagan calling on the United States and the Soviet Union to ''abandon their respective starting positions'' in the Geneva talks on the reduction of medium-range missiles.   He said refusal to do so was blocking a settlement that ''could eliminate unilateral threats and make additional missiles unnecessary.''   The letter, which reiterated Mr. Vogel's call for compromise, was described by Social Democrats as a reaction to Mr. Reagan's statement Wednesday that the United States would receive a ''terrible setback'' if West Germans elected a government opposed to the deployment of 572 Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Western Europe under a decision of the Atlantic alliance. These missiles are intended to offset 600 medium-range missiles already deployed by the Soviet Union.

headline: CHICAGO & NORTH WESTERN TRANSPORTATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Investigators in Israel Get Police Protection
abstract: Police protection has been provided to the three members of the state commission that found ''indirect responsibility'' on the part of Israel for the Lebanese Phalangists' massacre of Palestinians in Beirut, a police spokesman announced today.   The commissioners - Yitzhak Kahan, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court; Supreme Court Justice Aharon Barak and Yona Efrat, a retired Major General - were given protection after a threatening telephone call was made to the home of Justice Barak.

headline: THATCHER PRIDE IS SHOWING IN FALKLANDS
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher toured military positions on the Falkland Islands today as opposition politicians at home accused her of trying to make political capital out of the British victory in the remote archipelago seven months ago.   ''This is more than a visit,'' the Prime Minister told a special meeting of the islanders' leaders. ''It is a profoundly moving experience because we have all been through things we hope will never be repeated. But I think, having come through them as we have, we can all take a little bit of pride in being of British stock.''

headline: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Why Braniff Head Recorded That Call
abstract: Howard D. Putnam, chairman of Braniff International, says that when he received a call in February 1982 from Robert A. Crandall, the president of American Airlines, he went first to see his lawyer. Mr.  Putnam then returned the call - with a tape recorder running.   Last week a portion of that phone call was made public by the Justice Department, which charged American and Mr. Crandall in a civil suit with trying to fix ticket prices. Mr. Crandall is quoted as suggesting to Mr. Putnam that both airlines raise fares 20 percent on routes they served out of the Dallas-Fort Worth airport hub.  American has said it would vigorously defend itself in the suit.

headline: SATURDAY, JANUARY 1, 1983; Markets
abstract: Stocks edged higher in slow trading, finishing a year that saw the strongest sustained rally since the bottom of the Depression in 1932. The Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.83, to 1,046.54, but advances outnumbered declines by 924 to 602 and most other indicators posted small gains. (Page 25.)   The dollar was mixed in light trading. Gold bullion dropped $5.50 an ounce in London, to $448. (31.) Meat and livestock futures prices ended mostly higher in very light trading. (31.)

headline: Airlines Attacked in Iraq
abstract: The manager of the Air France office in Baghdad, Iraq, died today of injuries received Saturday when a boobytrapped package exploded, airline officials here said. The state-run Iraqi press agency, meanwhile, said the police dismantled a second bomb today at the office of Kuwait Airways in the Iraqi capital.

headline: FOOTE CONE & BELDING COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: M-1 JUMPS
abstract: Interest rates rose modestly in late trading yesterday after the Federal Reserve reported a bigger-than-expected $4.8 billion increase in the basic money supply.   The Fed said that M-1, which measures currency and checking deposits readily available for spending, reached $497.8 billion in the week ended March 9. Market analysts were expecting an increase of only $1 billion to $3 billion, and the higher figure raised fears that the Fed might begin to tighten credit availability.   The Fed had said in October that it would no longer focus on M-1 in determining monetary policy, but new interest has been given to this measure of money supply in the wake of a recent statement by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Fed, that he was concerned about a too-rapid growth of M-1 in recent months.

headline: Comsat Planning Stock Split
abstract: Directors of the Communications Satellite Corporation have voted to recommend a two-for-one stock split to shareholders at the company's upcoming annual meeting. The Comsat board has also decided to recommend an increase in the number of authorized common shares from 25 million to 40 million.

headline: WACKENHUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. TO PUT RADAR SYSTEM IN HONDURAS
abstract: The United States has decided to set up and operate a sophisticated radar system in southern Honduras with the intention of monitoring what the Reagan Administration says are Nicaraguan arms shipments to Salvadoran guerrillas, according to well-placed Hondurans.   The radar system, used during last month's joint United States-Honduran military maneuvers, will be installed, according to the sources here, on a hill outside the border city of Choluteca and will include the nearby Gulf of Fonseca in its range.   Reagan Administration officials have frequently accused Nicaragua's Sandinist Government of smuggling arms to Salvadoran guerrillas in light aircraft and small boats that cross the Gulf of Fonseca at night, but they have never made public any evidence to support their accusations.

headline: BEIRUT REJECTING NEW CONCESSIONS
abstract: The special United States envoy to the Middle East, Philip C. Habib, held new talks today on the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon, as the Lebanese insisted they could make no more concessions to Israel on security arrangements.   Mr. Habib flew to Beirut from Israel and immediately held a short meeting with the Lebanese Foreign Minister, Elie Salem.

headline: Times Mirror Wins a Ruling
abstract: A Superior Court judge ruled that the Times Mirror Company may retain both The Hartford Courant and its cable television franchises in the Hartford and Meriden areas.   Judge David M. Borden of Superior Court overturned a decision by the State Department of Public Utility Control, which had ordered Times Mirror to divest itself of either The Courant - Connecticut's largest newspaper - or the franchises.

headline: CHINA SEEKS INVESTORS FOR ITS HAINAN ISLAND
abstract: Hainan is an island in the sun that seems to offer something for virtually everyone. It has a balmy climate, miles of unspoiled sand beaches, ample farmland, an array of untapped minerals, and potentially rich oil reserves offshore in the turquoise waters of the South China Sea.   China is now dangling the island's varied potential as one of its latest attractions for foreign investment under its open-door economic policy. Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang recently underscored the interest in developing Hainan when he stopped over for several days on the way home from his tour of Africa.   Officials remain vague about specific plans for the island.  ''Several policies are being considered to let Hainan enjoy more flexible measures than Guangdong Province,'' said Zeng Dingshi, the deputy governor of Guangdong, which administers Hainan. ''Later on, these series of policies can be made public.''

headline: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BLACK JOBLESSNESS UP IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: South Africa returned to work this week after the midsummer holiday season that annually calls a halt to most construction and manufacturing, and there were strong indications that thousands of black migrant workers found they had no jobs to return to.   Economists at major financial institutions have been predicting that the number of unemployed blacks could soar by 250,000 or more in the coming months as a result of a simultaneous slump in the country's foreign and domestic markets.   The level of black joblessness in the country has been a matter of prolonged dispute between the keepers of the Government's statistics and academic experts. The official estimate of black unemployment now stands at about 500,000, but Government statistics no longer take account of blacks in four tiny black states, or so-called homelands, that are deemed by South Africa - but by no other government - to have gained their independence.

headline: VYQUEST INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ENDING THE 'SUNSET YEARS' WITH ZIP
abstract: The ''golden years'' and the ''senior citizen'' were words that once worked for advertisers aiming their wares at the older crowd.  But one generation's euphemism is another's problem, and Madison Avenue has discovered that today's older folk like to think of the ''vital years'' ahead - not of a ''golden sunset.'' Thus, advertisers increasingly are lumping the Social Security set together with those considerably younger and are showing them all living the good and active life.

headline: Market Place; Temporary Help Thriving
abstract: STOCKS of companies that provide temporary help for office work and other assignments have been climbing briskly despite the longest recession since World War II and the nation's highest unemployment rate since 1941.   Moreover, this small group of equities has prospered - in the stock market, at least - in the face of depressed earnings during 1982.  ''These stocks charged ahead because of investor expectations,'' said Judith M. Vale of Ingalls & Snyder, a brokerage firm.''Typically, in past business cycles, profits of temporary-help companies showed improvement before the rest of the economy.''

headline: PABST BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FRIDAY, MARCH 18, 1983; Companies
abstract: Great Western Financial is to acquire Financial Federation for $184.4 million in stock, the two companies announced. The merged institution, with $15.8 billion in assets, would have California's largest network of savings and loan branch offices. (Page D1.)   Trading in shares of Baldwin-United remained halted for the third consecutive session as the company sought another extension on $440 million in loans due late this month. Baldwin units were fined for insurance law violations in Arkansas, and a brokerage house told its sales personnel to stop selling Baldwin insurance products. (D1.)

headline: Pan Am Outlook
abstract: Pan American World Airways expects to be ''back in the black'' on its profit and loss account for the month of March, C. Edward Acker, chairman, said at a news conference. He said the company, which lost $485 million in 1982, had a substantial earnings improvement in both January and February, but gave no earnings forecast for the first quarter as a whole. Mr. Acker also said that Pan Am, which operates flights to China, is planning to resume flights to Taiwan.

headline: Queen Elizabeth in Caymans
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II today began her first visit to the Cayman Islands, one of Britain's few remaining Caribbean colonies. The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh flew here from Jamaica, where they spent three days. The welcoming crowd was estimated at 5,000.

headline: Gulf Oil, Kuwait Discussing Deal
abstract: The Kuwait Petroleum Corporation is holding negotiations with the Gulf Oil Corporation in London to buy its marketing and refining assets in Denmark and Sweden, a Gulf spokesman said.

headline: Moody's Lowers Lilco Bond Rating
abstract: Moody's Investors Service yesterday lowered its rating on bonds of the Long Island Lighting Company, citing the problems associated with the Shoreham nuclear power plant.   The downgrading, to Baa3 from Baa2, puts the Lilco bonds at the lowest possible level for investment grade securities.

headline: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS SUES OVER SECRETS
abstract: Texas Instruments Inc. has filed suit in Federal District Court in Houston charging that the Compaq Computer Corporation stole trade secrets and infringed on its patents to develop a portable computer compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's Personal Computer, it was learned yesterday.   Officials of Compaq, a small Houston computer company founded by former Texas Instruments employees, replied that the suit, filed last month, was ''totally groundless.''

headline: News Analysis
abstract: There are important differences between the cease-fire South Africa is now discussing with Angola and the one to which it committed itself nearly five years ago when it accepted a Western plan for a   South-West African settlement that has been kept on the shelf ever since.  The original cease-fire proposal involved only the forces directly involved in the South-West Africa conflict. That is, South Africa itself and the insurgent South-West Africa People's Organization, which wants the South African-administered territory to become the independent nation of Namibia.   The new proposal fits the Reagan Administration's efforts to use the Namibian plan as a lever for a broader regional settlement, in that it provides for the mutual withdrawal from southern Angola of foreign forces - both South Africans and Cubans - as well as those of the Luanda-based Angolan regime.

headline: Dow Off 5.16 as Volume Drops
abstract: The stock market ended moderately lower yesterday in slower trading as investors cashed in some of their recent gains.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which had advanced about 36 points since the beginning of the year, closed down 5.16 points, to 1,079.65. In the overall market, issues that declined on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that rose by 867 to 761.

headline: THE LATEST BATTLE OF POITIERS
abstract: The first Battle of Poitiers, in which a Frank warlord known as Charles (The Hammer) Martel saved Christendom by crushing an advancing Moorish army in A.D. 732, is widely recognized as a turning point in world history.   Now, the French Government of President Francois Mitterrand is fighting another Battle of Poitiers, but this time the objective is to save the French video recorder market from being overrun by Japanese imports.   Since last November, all foreign-made video recorders entering France must be cleared through a nine-man customs depot in this pleasant town in western France -which, not coincidentally, is hundreds of miles from the northern ports where the units are landed. Once the recorders make their way to the depot here, they are subjected to intensive, time-consuming checks. And by coincidence, 732 is the code number the French Customs use to identify goods coming from Janpan.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: For Europeans worried about the future of West Germany, the Christian Democratic election victory is regarded as an opportunity to help strenghen the country's involvement in Western Europe and its defense.   There is growing interest in France, and to a lesser degree in Britain, for greater speed in developing European defense options that would complement NATO's systems, strengthen allied commitments to defend West Germany and offer it greater possibilities to increase its sense of control over its own affairs.   For several West European analysts, an important lesson emerging from the West German election campaign and its talk of neutralism, pacifism and drift is that Chancellor Helmut Kohl is not finished struggling with those trends. As much as Mr. Kohl's election removed intense concern about destablization in West Germany, some officials, notably at the French Foreign Ministry, regarded the entry of the Greens into the Parliament and the apparent leftward movement of the Social Democratic Party as relative gains in insitutional strength and respectability for anti-Atlantic Alliance attitudes.

headline: Atari Assignment
abstract: Another announcement has been made by Warner Communications' Atari and this time we learn that Needham, Harper & Steers has also got a bit of the action - two new unidentified video game cartridges scheduled for introduction later this year. The West Coast company also formally identified for the first time the business that Wells, Rich, Greene had before its new home-computer assignment. It was the Sesame Street Library, the Child's Video Game Catridges and the computer keyboard for the Atari video game machine, all of which are due out later this year.

headline: HOUSING CALCULATION CHANGED
abstract: What defensive Government officials would say three and four years ago when the inflation rate was running in double-digits was, ''Yes, but ...''   Yes, the Consumer Price Index figures were high, they said, but the price index overstates the inflation rate because sharp upward swings in mortgage interest rates and house prices distort it.   Now, with inflation quiescent for the first time in years and with most of the damage from the distortions already done, the Government has finally fixed the index.   Today, with the release of the January price index, the Bureau of Labor Statistics has switched to a new method of calculating housing costs. The change, which has been in the works for years, finally removed mortgage interest rates and house prices from the index.

headline: A Corning Closing
abstract: Corning Glass Works said it would close its color television bulb manufacturing plant in Bluffton, Ind., by mid-May, idling about 460 workers. Corning cited overcapacity in the domestic color TV market and competition from foreign manufacturers. Workers at the plant had offered Corning a package of concessions to keep their jobs, but a company spokesman, Robert Edwards, said the concessions would not have mitigated the basic problem of low demand.

headline: U.S. EXPECTED TO END LONG FREEZE ON MILITARY AID FOR GUATEMALANS
abstract: Congressional and senior State Department officials said today that the United States was likely to end a long freeze on military aid to Guatemala soon. They said the policy change was expected because of signs that the Government of President Efrain Rios Montt had made progress in improving human rights conditions.   The officials said that, as a gesture to the Guatemalan Government, the United States planned to approve the sale of $4 million worth of spare parts for American-made helicopters being used by the Guatemalan Army against leftist rebels.

headline: REAGAN OFFERS CUT IN U.S. MISSILE PLAN FOR WEST EUROPE
abstract: President Reagan offered today to cut back on the planned deployment of new American medium-range missiles in Western Europe in exchange for Soviet reductions in Europe and Asia.  The cutbacks by the two sides would leave each with the same number of warheads on such missiles.   The new aspect in the proposal is the stress on equality in warheads rather Transcript of speech, page A10. than in missiles. The United States plans to deploy single-warhead missiles, but the modern Soviet SS-20 missile can be armed with three warheads.

headline: BONN SAYS SOCIAL DEMOCRATS MIGHT HINDER ARMS DEBATE
abstract: The West German Government accused the opposition Social Democratic Party today of undermining efforts to persuade the Soviet Union to dismantle its medium-range missiles targeted on Western Europe.   The accusation, apparently also intended to muffle differences on the issue among the coalition partners, came as the new Social Democratic leader, Hans-Jochen Vogel, was ending a visit to Moscow.  The accusation suggested that a missile debate would figure prominently in the campaign for the West German elections of March 6.

headline: Corsican Rebels Attack Home of 2 Teachers
abstract: Terrorists sprayed gunfire at the home of two teachers and bombed their car today in the 10th incident of separatist violence in two weeks on this French island.   Officials said there were no injuries in the attack against the home of the two teachers, who recently requested transfers back to the French mainland.

headline: DOW ADVANCES 3.96, TO 1,084.81
abstract: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday, spurred by expectations of a cut in interest rates and by strong performances by American Telephone and International Business Machines, the market's current bellwethers.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, finished ahead 3.96 points, to 1,084.81, after being ahead 11 points at 2 P.M. The late sell off was attributed mostly to investors' cashing in recent profits.   Volume on the New York Stock Exchange climbed to 89.2 million shares from 86.5 million shares on Friday.  ''Speculation that the Federal Reserve will soon reduce the discount rate from its present 8 1/2 percent level was mainly responsible for triggering the market's advance today,'' said Serge J. Enni, vice president of Edward A. Viner & Company.

headline: CANADA, NEWFOUNDLAND END OIL-REVENUE TALKS
abstract: Talks between Canada and the province of Newfoundland on how to develop and share revenues from the giant Hibernia oil and gas field off the province's East Coast have broken down, Canada's energy minister conceded today.   Development of the field, estimated to contain at least two billion barrels of oil, could now be delayed for a year or longer, analysts said.   ''It's over, it's over, and it saddens me,'' the federal Minister, Jean Chretien, said today during a previously scheduled speech in St. John's, the capital of Newfoundland.   Exactly why the talks broke down is not yet known, but both sides are accusing the other of bargaining in bad faith.  Mr. Chretien, in a message earlier this week to his Newfoundland counterpart, William Marshall, said, ''I can only conclude that you are clearly not interested in resuming negotiations. I have to believe that you have been instructed by your Premier and your colleagues effectively to break negotiations by engaging in fruitless delaying tactics.''

headline: Renault Denies Import Report
abstract: Regie Nationale des Usines Renault said it categorically denied a report in the United States journal Automotive News that the American Motors Corporation, in which Renault holds 46.4 percent, will stop importing the R-18i sedan when new models are introduced next year.   The journal said A.M.C. will drop four passenger cars, including Renault's R-18i and its Le Car R-5 model. Renault has sold 105,600 Le Car models and 20,000 R-18i models on the United States market.

headline: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1983; The Economy
abstract: Corporate profits deteriorated further in the fourth quarter of 1982. Particularly affected were the cyclically depressed steel, oil, auto and forest products industries. Analysts forecast that, over all, after-tax profits for the quarter should be down 20 percent from a year earlier, to $116 billion. (Page D1.)

headline: Peking Criticizes Reagan For Remarks on Taiwan
abstract: China said today that comments President Reagan made about Taiwan marked a step backward in the American position on relations between their countries.   An official New China News Agency commentary accused Mr. Reagan of interfering in Chinese affairs by remarks on the Taiwan question quoted in the conservative weekly Human Events that it said discarded all nine points of a Chinese-American communique last August that promised to reduce arms sales to Taiwan.

headline: Egypt and Soviet Set Ties
abstract: Egypt and the Soviet Union are preparing to exchange ambassadors again, restoring full diplomatic relations for the first time in 18 months, state-controlled newspapers reported here Friday. The reports said Deputy Prime Minister Nikolai K.  Baibakov of the Soviet Union delivered ''definite ideas'' on repairing the rift in a meeting with Assistant Foreign Minister Shafei Abdel-Hamid.

headline: SOVIET MARSHAL WARNS U.S. ON ITS MISSILES
abstract: Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, chief of the Soviet General Staff, suggested today that if the American medium-range missiles planned for deployment in Europe were used against the Soviet Union, the Russians would retaliate directly against the United States. For the most part, the marshal, in a rare interview with a Western correspondent, struck a moderate posture, in particular by modifying his previous position and saying that once nuclear war began it could not be limited and controlled. He said: ''The idea of nuclear war has never been tested. But by logic, to keep such a war limited will not be possible.''   ''Inevitably,'' he added, ''such a war will extend to all-out war.'' Statements by Civilian Leaders   This new statement brings Marshal Ogarkov, who is also a First Deputy Minister of Defense, into line with virtually identical statements by top Soviet civilian leaders. It was apparently intended to curtail speculation about civilian-military rifts over nuclear doctrine and to undercut Western assertions that Soviet policy called for fighting prolonged nuclear wars, as United States policy does.

headline: POPE PLOT TRIAL IS LIKELY IN '83
abstract: The magistrate investigating the shooting of Pope John Paul II said today that the trial of Bulgarians and Turks accused of complicity should begin by the end of the year.   ''I hope the investigation will be finished before summer, and, if all goes well, the trial will begin by the end of the year,'' Magistrate Ilario Martella said in an interview.

headline: Chip Developed
abstract: The General Instrument Corporation and the Milton Bradley Company said they had developed the first computer chip that can both recognize speech and synthesize words.

headline: EUROPEANS MEET TODAY ON CURRENCY PROBLEMS
abstract: After another turbulent day during which the French franc came under heavy speculative attack and the West German mark soared in value, the French Finance Ministry announced tonight that finance ministers of the European Economic Community would meet in Brussels on Saturday to discuss possible changes in European currency values.   Bankers and dealers generally expect the officials to agree on a realignment of the fixed exchange rates that eight of the 10 Common Market countries maintain among their currencies under the rules of the European Monetary System.   The realignment is expected to involve an upward revaluation of the mark by about 4 percent or 5 percent and a devaluation of the French franc by roughly the same amount, with some adjustments in the other currencies possible as well.   It would be the third devaluation of the franc since the Socialists came to power nearly two years ago and tried to break out of the world recession by a sharp increase in Government spending. The result was higher inflation and a widening of France's external trade deficit.

headline: DYING BONN PARTY SHOWS SIGNS OF LIFE
abstract: At the start of the campaign, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the Deputy Chancellor and the longest-serving Foreign Minister in the West, was reduced to luring pensioners with beer and free pea soup into half-filled taverns or addressing listless crowds from a special train.   His Free Democratic Party looked as if it was heading for political extinction.  But in the biggest turnaround of this campaign, the crowds are now thronging to the Free Democrats' rallies. One week before the election Mr. Genscher, perspiring as he rasps through one speech after another, senses that he is going to save both his endangered party and his job as Foreign Minister.

headline: Extendable Notes
abstract: The I.B.M. Credit Corporation sold $100 million of three-year extendable notes, offered by a Salomon Brothers group with an initial coupon of 9 5/8 percent at a price of 100.

headline: Article 221464 -- No Title
abstract: Business leaders in Presque Isle, Me., won state approval for a $5.5 million loan guarantee for a proposed $94 million plant in Auburn to supply New England with alcohol to be added to gasoline to increase octane ratings.   As a result, New England Ethanol Products Inc., which the leaders have organized, said it hoped to begin construction in May.

headline: COKE'S NAME HELPS DIET SODA
abstract: If there was ever a sure thing in marketing, diet Coke seems to be it. After six months in the New York area, the soft drink went national in January and is clearly living up to its promise.   ''It is the hottest-selling soft drink in the shortest amount of time ever,'' said Jesse Meyers, editor of Jesse Meyers' Beverage Digest, a publication of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. ''If diet Coke is well marketed, in a very short time it will be No. 3. Even if it is marketed badly, it will be No.5.'' The No. 1 soft drink is Coke, followed by Pepsi and 7-Up.

headline: Teledyne Net Off 89.1%
abstract: Teledyne Inc. reported yesterday that a $49.1 million write-down on its investment in the International Harvester Company had sharply depressed earnings.

headline: Washington Watch; Oil Tax, Deficit And Recovery
abstract: THE idea, on its face, is very appealing: now is the time to levy a tax on imported oil because it will provide needed income to offset some of the Federal deficit, and the bite on consumers will be more like a nibble while oil prices are falling.   Not entirely unexpectedly, Senator Pete V. Domenici, a long-time supporter of the idea, is expected to introduce a bill this week to levy a $10-a-barrel tax on imported petroleum and refined products.  The only exemption, according to the New Mexico Republican's staff, would be for crude oil that is imported and then refined for immediate export.   The tax program would permit the President, subject only to a twohouse veto, to adjust the tax rate up or down in $2.50 increments.  There is only one problem. So far President Reagan has been inhospitable to the idea of taxing imported oil, preferring instead to see cheaper oil help the fledgling economic recovery, which with luck and a further decline in oil prices, could be in full swing in the 1984 election year.

headline: BASQUE PEACE EFFORT IS ENDED BY KILLING
abstract: A sudden upsurge in terrorism has upset what many Spaniards viewed as the most promising effort in years to bring peace to the Basque region of northern Spain.   The effort was undertaken at considerable political risk by the head of the regional Basque government, Carlos Garaikoetxea. It centered on prospective three-way talks involving his own Basque Nationalist Party, local representatives of the Socialist Party, and the political wing of E.T.A, the Basque separatist organization.   The talks, which were still in a formative stage, collapsed after guerrillas belonging to E.T.A.'s hard-line ''military'' faction killed a civil guardsman and wounded two seriously in an attack on their vehicle in the town of Ordizia on Feb. 2. Three days later a bomb went off in the head office of the Banco de Vizcaya in Bilbao, killing two employees and wounding seven. One of the wounded later died.

headline: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1983; Markets
abstract: Stock prices surged to a new high, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing above the 1,100 level for the first time. Analysts cited continuing signs that the recession is ending and expectations that interest rates will continue to decline. The Dow gained 24.87 points, closing at 1,121.81. The two other major indicators, the Big Board's composite index and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, also set new highs. Advances outnumbered declines by almost 3 to 1.  Turnover soared to 113.2 million shares, from 84.1 million Wednesday. (Page A1.)   Interest rates declined amid speculation that the Federal Reserve may be encouraging lower short-term rates. (D7.) Assets of money market funds dropped $1.3 billion in the week ended Wednesday. (D8.) Strong demand enabled underwriters to increase the New York City bond issue to $201.7 million, from $150 million. (D7.)

headline: Carter Sees King Fahd
abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter conferred with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia today on prospects for Arab-Israeli peace negotiations, the official Saudi press agency said.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Colgate-Palmolive Co. has appointed Peter D. McLeod vice president of corporate manufacturing.   * David Crystal Co. has named Robert Tutnauer to the new position of president and chief executive officer of its Izod International division.

headline: Guatemala Extends Siege
abstract: The Guatemalan Government extended for a further 25 days its eight-month-old state of siege measure suspending constitutional rights because of continuing leftist guerrilla activity, the presidential office said today. Political sources said the state of siege would expire on March 23, exactly a year after President Efrain Rios Montt seized power in a coup.

headline: Belo Set to Buy Gaylord TV Outlet
abstract: Officials of the A.H. Belo Corporation say they have signed a letter of intent to purchase New Orleans television station WVUE.

headline: LOW-GROWTH FORECAST IS ACCEPTED BY REAGAN
abstract: President Reagan has accepted a scaled-down economic forecast of 1.4 percent economic growth this year over 1982, after adjustment for inflation, Administration officials said today.   The projection leaves the unemployment rate near 10.5 percent at the end of this year and still around 9 percent at the end of the 1984 Presidential election year.   Administration officials had earlier stated that the growth rate for this year would be below 2 percent. That was a significant cut from a preliminary forecast in September of 3.1 percent growth after inflation.

headline: Getty Sues Kuwait Over Oil Lifting
abstract: The Getty Oil Company said it had sued Kuwait in a dispute involving oil lifting in a partitioned neutral zone between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia.

headline: KILLINGS DOWN IN EL SALVADOR
abstract: Since Pope John Paul II's visit here early this month, the number of political murders in this country has dropped dramatically, a top Salvadoran churchman said today.   Auxiliary Archbishop Gregorio Rosa Chavez, delivering the weekly homily in the capital's Metropolitan Cathedral, said there were 47 murders during the week of March 18 to March 24.

headline: ARAB BANK BOYCOTT OF DATA LINKS
abstract: Arab banks in the oil countries of the Persian Gulf are boycotting the leading international system for transferring money around the world because 10 Israeli banks have become members, according to banking and business sources here.   Western banks that are established in Bahrain, which is the banking center for the Persian Gulf region, are reluctantly going along with the boycott. They say it would be difficult for them politically to join a communications system that the Arab banks oppose. The Western banks also say that the Bahrain Government would probably use its telecommunications monopoly to stop them from being members.

headline: Japanese Surplus Down
abstract: Japan, which is under pressure to cut its exports to the West, announced today an $18.19 billion trade surplus with the world last year, down from $19.97 billion in 1981. The Finance Ministry said exports amounted to $137.65 billion and imports to $119.46 billion.

headline: U.S.-CANADIAN RELATIONS TAKE A TESTY NEW TURN
abstract: This week's falling out over three Canadian film documentaries was the latest in a series of incidents in recent months that have put the relationship between the United States and Canada to new tests.   Officials on both sides have taken pains to play down the significance of the Justice Department's ruling that three documentaries by the National Film Board of Canada were ''political propaganda'' and must be labeled as the work of foreign agents.   A Canadian Embassy official described the issue as ''pretty silly,'' and a State Department official characterized the incident as an ''abberration.'' A Complex Relationship   These officials, however, said today that the furor was symbolic of the complex and, at times, testy relationship between the two countries.

headline: FRIDAY, MARCH 4, 1983; Markets
abstract: Stock prices swept upward again, with the three major indicators closing at record levels for the third consecutive session. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 3 points, to 1,138.06, while the Big Board's composite index rose 0.70, to 88.48, and Standard & Poor's index rose 1.18, to 153.48. Turnover increased to 114.4 million shares in the third 100 million-plus session in a row. (Page D1.)   Interest rates rose and prices fell in all maturities of the Treasury market. Investor demand was said to be weak. (D6.) Citicorp is selling a $750 million issue of floating rate notes. (D6.) Assets of money market funds declined $1.5 billion during the week ended Wednesday, Donoghue's Money Fund Report said. (D8.)

headline: Pros and Cons In U.S. Views
abstract: A decline in oil prices would stimulate world economic growth but might put new strains on some heavily indebted developing countries, Treasury Under Secretary Beryl Sprinkel said today.   He told the Senate Banking Committee that preliminary estimates by the Treasury Department indicated that a drop of $5 a barrel in prices set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would speed world economic growth by about five-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29

headline: Market Place; Dillard Stores' Amex Record
abstract: THE nation's best-known department store chains are mostly giants, such as R.H. Macy, Allied Stores, Dayton-Hudson and Associated Dry Goods. But small can be beautiful in the retailing business - and in the stock market.   Consider, for example, the class A common stock of Dillard Department Stores Inc. This company, with headquarters in Little Rock, Ark., operates a chain of 65 stores, mainly in suburban shopping malls in Texas and neighboring states.   Two years ago Dillard's shares were trading at 12 on the American Stock Exchange. A year ago the shares changed hands at 22. Last week, after the company reported fiscal-year earnings of $7.46 a share, the stock jumped 17 points. Yesterday the shares rose 2 7/8, to 74 1/4, after trading at a record price of 74 3/4.

headline: Greece Approves Family Law Changes
abstract: Parliament today unanimously approved sweeping changes in the country's family law, making divorce easier, guaranteeing equality between spouses and ending official discrimination against illegitimate children.

headline: The Sciences Magazine To Take Advertising
abstract: Sooner or later, or so it seems, publishers of magazines that do not take advertising fall in line and go out looking for those extra bucks.   Add to that list the New York Academy of Sciences, founded in 1817 as the Lyceum of Natural History.

headline: UPPER EAST SIDE ATTRACTS TWO MIXED-USE PROJECTS
abstract: A five-block stretch of Third Avenue just above 59th Street in Manhattan illuminates this truism of the development community: Despite the straitened conditions of the market generally, the East Side's allure for the affluent continues undiminished.   In those five blocks are two substantial mixed-use projects, one under way and one in the planning stage, that are the work of major developers.   At Third Avenue and East 61st Street, Donald J. Trump is building a 39-story structure containing 180 cooperative apartments over groundfloor retail space. The $50 million building is being constructed as of right -what is permitted under the zoning code.

headline: U.S. Official Tells Legislators Aid for Israelis Is Generous
abstract: A senior State Department official today defended the Reagan Administration's $2.48 billion aid program for Israel against Congressional complaints that it was not enough.   Nicholas Veliotes, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs, testifying to a House of Representatives Foreign Affairs subcommittee, said the aid was generous and was sufficient to back the Administration's policy of supporting Israel.

headline: A Bombing in South Africa
abstract: A bomb damaged Government offices Friday night in a black residential area near Pietermaritzburg in Natal Province, the South African radio reported today. There were no injuries in the blast, which occurred on a lawn outside the building, shattering windows and damaging the roof. No one claimed responsibility.

headline: URUGUAYAN VOTERS HEED VOICE MUFFLED BY ARMY
abstract: ''Thank God, you're still well,'' a woman at the next table said to Jorge Batlle Ibanez in a restaurant here.   Outside, a kiosk owner stuck his head out from among the magazines and newspapers to call out, ''I'm with you, Mr. Batlle.'' A toll taker, giving Mr. Batlle a thumbs-up sign, refused to take his money.  So goes the daily round of testaments to the extraordinary political popularity of this member of Uruguay's most famous political family - extraordinary because in the eyes of Uruguay's 10-year-old military regime, Mr. Batlle does not exist politically.

headline: CONCERNS IN MOSCOW: MISSILES AND U.S. AND SOVIET LEADERS
abstract: The dominant impression from 10 days of conversations with officials in the Soviet Union is that they are waiting for developments in three areas: to see whether the United States will have the necessary political support to deploy new missiles in Western Europe; to gauge whether politics will push the Reagan Administration toward compromises, and, above all, to find out how the Soviet Union will ultimately fare under the new leadership of Yuri V. Andropov.   Compared with past conversations with many of the same officials and academic experts, even after the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan in late 1979, there seemed to be outright hostility toward the United States. The feelings of the officials seemed to match the hostility President Reagan expressed in his ''focus of evil'' speech of March 8.   There also seemed to be more than the usual reluctance to acknowledge any Soviet faults, less hope about and even less interest in improving relations with the United States, and greater felt but unspoken uncertainty about their own future.   These are the impressions gathered in conversations from March 7 to 17 with military, civilian, party and academic officials in Moscow and Kiev, in restaurants, in walks along gray boulevards and in the conference rooms of foreign policy institutes where outsiders are usually received.

headline: Costa Rica Drops Charge
abstract: Costa Rica has dropped criminal charges against an American journalist accused of illegally practicing his profession here for lack of membership in the Costa Rican College of Journalists.

headline: Dancer Fitzgerald
abstract: Dancer Fitzgerald Sample has become agency for the United States and Canadian consumer finance group of the Beneficial Management Corporation, which had been a client of Al Paul Lefton Inc., for 25 years. There are indications that the account, which was believed to be in the area of $5 million in billings, might end up in the more affluent neighborhood of $10 million. Gary Susnjara, president of the agency's New York office, sort of alluded to that possibility when he talked of the client's ''ambitious growth plans.''

headline: Saxon Refinancing
abstract: The Saxon Oil Company said the Dallas Interfirst Bank had demanded immediate payment of about $89 million of principal and interest and exercised its rights of offset against some of the company's accounts. Saxon said it had requested that the bank rescind its demand and the offset because of continuing negotiations covering a pending trade-creditors agreement and a refinancing agreement with the bank.

headline: Dun & Bradstreet
abstract: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, a compiler of business information, said employment in the United States may increase 2.7 percent this year.

headline: Commodities; Trading Crude Oil Futures
abstract: If, as expected, the Government tomorrow approves the trading of crude oil futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade, both exchanges plan to begin operations on Wednesday.   But the significance of the new crude oil futures market goes far beyond the competitive race between the two exchanges. If successful, the new markets could profoundly change the way crude oil is priced and traded on the world market.   ''Crude oil futures markets are logical now as never before for several important reasons,'' said John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Bureau Inc.

headline: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT LESS IN JANUARY
abstract: Rising farm exports and declining oil imports narrowed the American trade deficit to about $2.96 billion in January, the Commerce Department reported today.   The Government, after revising slightly downward the December red ink, reported that the deficit for 1982 was still a record, $42.7 billion.
