headline: AROUND THE WORLD; China's Catholic Church Fills High Shanghai Post
abstract: China's independent Catholic Church has appointed a vicar general of Shanghai to assist the city's bishop without consultations with the Vatican, the New China News Agency said today.  The agency said the cleric, Msgr.

headline: PAN AM'S MARKETING ERROR
abstract: Pan American World Airways is seeking to recover from a costly marketing mistake it made involving travel agents last year, just as it enters the lean winter months when it must dip into cash reserves until the seasonal spring pickup begins.   The miscalculation cost the carrier much business during the height of the summer tourist season, when it generally makes most of its money, and has left it in a more difficult position during the current slow period. Pan Am's experience also illustrates the power of the travel agent over the airline industry.   Last March, Pan Am suspended commission overrides - the added payments that some travel agencies receive if they surpass certain sales levels. It also withdrew such bonuses as free travel for those who arrange convention business.

headline: Postal Service Surplus
abstract: The Postal Service said today that it had a $710 million surplus in the last fiscal year, reversing the trend of losses the two previous years. The governing board of the service said there was a $1.082 billion surplus on operations.

headline: Suriname's Strongman Selects a Premier
abstract: Suriname's strongman, Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse, has named Errol Alibux, a sociologist and former Cabinet minister, as the country's new Prime Minister.

headline: BRITISH OFFER A BUDGET SHY ON 'GOODIES'
abstract: The Government today announced a budget for next year that suggested to many politicians that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had decided against calling a general election this summer.   The budget, disclosed by Sir Geoffrey Howe, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, in the traditonal, minutely detailed speech to the House of Commons, contained tax cuts for individuals and industry. But they amounted to only $2.2 billion - considerably less than some people had predicted - and the tenor of the $182 billion budget lacked the vote-getting appeal that British Governments usually try to incorporate into pre-election budgets.   Eric Heffer, a leading Labor Member of Parliament, spoke for many in the opposition and some Tory back-benchers when he predicted a more political budget a year from now before Mrs. Thatcher goes to the country. ''There were a few goodies given away here and there,'' he commented, but he described the budget as a whole as restrained.

headline: DILLON, READ TO RECOVER CONTROL FROM BECHTEL
abstract: Dillon, Read & Company, the Wall Street investment banking house, said yesterday that its managing directors had agreed to buy a sufficient number of Dillon, Read shares from the Bechtel family of San Francisco to give the banking house's management control of the firm.   Neither company would disclose the number of shares changing hands or the terms of the transaction.  In June 1981, the Bechtels, through their Sequoia Ventures Inc.  investment company, bought the bulk of the shares of the 152-year-old private banking house from C. Douglas Dillon, the former Treasury Secretary, and his family as an investment. The number of shares was not disclosed, but Dillon, Read said it was considerably more than 50 percent of the 30,000 outstanding.

headline: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1983; The Economy
abstract: The jobless rate fell sharply in January, its first decline in the 17 months since the start of the recession. With the military included in the data for the first time, the rate dropped to 10.2 percent from 10.7 percent, the Labor Department reported. Without the military, the decline was to 10.4 percent from 10.8 percent. By adding the military, officials increased the total number of employed. President Reagan hailed the report as evidence of a trend toward lower unemployment, but economists cautioned that January data are subject to wide seasonal swings. (Page 1.) In New York City, the jobless rate rose. (7.)   The President, condemning truck strike violence, said he would not consider repealing the taxes that the truckers are protesting. (1.)

headline: Financial Aid Set for Brazil
abstract: The first two parts of a four-part financing program for Brazil will be signed on Friday, a spokesman for the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company said yesterday.

headline: UNITED MERCHANTS & MANUFACTURERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN POLICY IN CENTRAL AMERICA: AFTER 2 YEARS, TOUGH TONE SOFTENS
abstract: The Reagan Administration, once given to tough statements about the need to confront insurgencies in Central America, has softened its tone.   The new approach consists of substantial economic aid mixed with military assistance, support for democratic social change and a deliberate retreat from the Administration's early statements portraying the poor and weak countries of Central America as dominoes of the East-West conflict. Administration officials say the approach amounts, in some ways, to a bipartisan continuation of Carter Administration policies.   But there are conflicting assessments both within and outside the Administration of how much the policy itself has really changed. Assertions of Progress   State Department officials say that events in the region have taken a positive turn and that left-wing movements there have lost their momentum. In contrast to two years ago, Administration officials assert, guerrillas in El Salvador and Guatemala no longer threaten to topple the Governments there. Nicaragua's leftist Government, which has sought to blunt the powers of the Roman Catholic Church and the press, has lost considerable support at home and abroad. Costa Rica, Panama and Honduras are openly supporting American policy.

headline: Original Mandate
abstract: To the Business Editor: When William W. Winpisinger accused the current Department of Labor of ''Abandoning Its Original Mandate'' (Dec.5), he opened the way for Labor Department Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and Thorne G.  Auchter, in charge of the department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration, to make sanctimonious claims that it is they who are serving all workers by their reliance on the cooperation of employers motivated equally by humanitarian and monetary considerations.   The president of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers ignores the fact that most other union officials have also forgotten their ''original mandate'' and are concentrating on the preservation enhancement of the ''goodies'' acquired in its halcyon days of Labor with a capital ''L'' while he, Mr. Winpisinger, pursues his lonely course.   In this time of national and world crisis, they are more concerned with illusory protective tariffs, special safeguards for members of privileged unions, and retention of the ''fringes'' which they obtained from hitherto affluent corporations and government bureaus with fat budgets, paid for by the 80 percent nonunion, wage-earning consumers with higher taxes and inflated prices.

headline: AIRLINE COMPUTERS GENERATE FARE RIFT
abstract: A quarrel has erupted over whether two major airlines could take unfair advantage of the way tickets are sold at most travel agencies. With perhaps tens of million of dollars at stake, the Civil Aeronautics Board has expedited hearings on the matter.   The issue concerns the possibility that under recently revised guidelines, American Airlines and United Airlines, which own the reservation and ticketing computers used by most travel agents, may routinely be designated as the ''ticketing'' carriers -even when they will not actually transport the passengers involved.   Since fares will promptly be paid to the computer owner, that carrier may be able to make profitable use of the funds long before the actual trip is made and money flows back to the airline, or airlines, that do the flying.

headline: PREMIER AND CABINET TAKE OFFICE IN AUSTRALIA
abstract: Robert Hawke, the leader of the Labor Party, took office as Australia's Prime Minister today and promised to ''change the face of decision-making in this country.''   He announced that invitations had been sent to business, labor and Government leaders to attend a ''national economic summit'' beginning April 11 to work out a common program for Australia's troubled economy. The conference is expected to last a week.

headline: Webb Purchase
abstract: The Del E. Webb Corporation said the North Central Development Company, a partnership between it and Harry and Newton Rosenzweig, had bought the Rosenzweig Center of Phoenix in a transaction valued at $50 million. The purchase took place at a trustee's sale as a result of a default by the previous owner. The center includes the Townehouse Hotel, the Del E. Webb headquarters tower, the Greyhound headquarters building, the Continental Bank building, the Greyhound Management Center, parking garages and 15.4 acres of land.

headline: HIJACKERS FREE 158 ON LIBYAN JETLINER AND SURRENDER IN MALTA
abstract: Two hijackers who were later identified as Libyan Army lieutenants today released 158 passengers and crew members of a Libyan national airline jet they had hijacked Sunday, and surrendered to the Maltese authorities.   The officers, First Lieut. At-Tawati Mansur al-Mahdi and First Lieut. Abdessalam Abu Kijla, offered to surrender after negotiations conducted over three days by Prime Minister Dom Mintoff from the airport control tower.

headline: BONN SAYS ARRESTED RUSSIAN IS PROBABLY HEAD OF SPY RING
abstract: A Soviet trade official who was arrested Thursday is thought to be the head of the K.G.B. spy network in West Germany, the authorities said today.   The trade official, Gennadi Batashev, 42 years old, was arrested as he met a West German double agent in the crowded square in front of the cathedral in Cologne, 15 miles northwest of Bonn.   West German agents seized Mr. Batashev after the double agent handed him ''technological information in the field of electronics'' - secret information on a decoding machine used by West German agents, a Justice Ministry spokesman said.

headline: MONSANTO GAINS
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation, battered by the weak economy, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1982 plunged by 78.4 percent, while sales dropped 6.2 percent.   Union Carbide, the nation's second-largest chemical company after E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, said that net income in the latest three months fell to $30.2 million, or 42 cents a share, from $139.8 million, or $2.04 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales fell to $2.28 billion, from $2.43 billion.   For all of 1982, Union Carbide reported a net income of $309.7 million, or $4.47 a share, down 52.3 percent from $649 million, or $9.56 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales dropped 10.9 percent, to $9.06 billion, from $10.17 billion.

abstract: Ashland Oil Sees Deficit for Quarter   ASHLAND, Ky., March 17 (Reuters) - Ashland Oil Inc. said it expected to report a loss for its second quarter, ending March 31.

headline: No Headline
abstract: THIRD-WORLD AID CALLED DRAIN ON SOVIET RESOURCES   BRUSSELS, Jan. 22 (Reuters) - The Soviet Union's aid to its client countries in the developing world has proved a significant drain on Moscow's limited economic resources, according to a North Atlantic Treaty Organization study made available today.   The study, compiled from data provided by NATO governments and completed last year, estimates that total economic aid and arms deliveries to the 11 client countries amounted to almost $6.3 billion in 1980, about half of it going to Cuba. In its report, the NATO Economic Department stressed that some of the estimates were only tentative.   The document makes a distinction between developing countries where Communist governments are firmly established - Cuba, Mongolia, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos and North Korea -and other developing nations where Marxist-oriented administrations are in power but are not considered to be in firm control. The second group consists of Angola, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Afghanistan and Southern Yemen.

headline: Excerpts from interview, page 14.
abstract: Yuri V. Andropov said today that President Reagan's new proposal for an American defense system against missiles was ''a bid to disarm the Soviet Union'' that would launch the two nations into ''a runaway race'' in strategic nuclear weapons and defense systems against them.   The Soviet leader said the United States and the Soviet Union had agreed a decade ago that no progress in limiting offensive nuclear weapons could be made unless there was ''mutual restraint'' in the field of missile defenses.   Mr. Andropov said that Mr. Reagan, by announcing Wednesday that he favored a research program to find a defense system that could destroy missiles aimed at the United States, had shown that the United States intended ''to sever this interrelationship.'' 'This Would Open the Floodgates'   The Soviet leader added: ''Should this conception be converted into reality, this would actually open the floodgates to a runaway race of all types of strategic arms, both offensive and defensive. Such is the real purport, the seamy side, so to say, of Washington's 'defensive conception.' ''

headline: Poland to Try Central Figure In the Formation of Solidarity
abstract: Anna Walentynowicz, a central figure in the formation of the independent Solidarity labor federation, will go on trial next week on charges of organizing strikes under martial law, relatives said today.   In trying Mrs. Walentynowicz, whose dismissal from the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk touched off the strike that led to the formation of Solidarity, the Government appears to be signaling its readiness to punish workers for the 1980-81 labor upheaval.   The court said the trial would open March 9 but refused to confirm the charges.

headline: The Talk of Lagos
abstract: A doctor here likes to tell a story about the women of the white, foreign community who frequent his private practice.   In the past, he says, he has treated them for all kinds of esoteric woes but, of late, they have been arriving in numbers seeking the banal: ointment for burns, stitches for cuts, balm for sundry indignities. The reason, the doctor says, is that previously the women all depended on their stewards from Ghana and Benin and elsewhere to do the household chores. The servants, largely, are gone now, victims of Nigeria's decision to expel illegal immigrants, and so the women must cope with forgotten challenges: overheating stoves and undisciplined carving knives. There has even been a run on washing machines in the local market now that human launderers have departed.

headline: MOVES ON CAPITOL HILL IRK CHINA
abstract: China today condemned as violations of its sovereignty two resolutions before the United States Congress referring to its relations with Taiwan.   The New China News Agency said in a report from Washington that the resolutions were submitted to the House Foreign Affairs Committee on March 1 and to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Feb. 28.

headline: ADVERTISING

headline: ISRAELI PRESIDENT OPENS 11-DAY U.S. TRIP
abstract: President Yitzhak Navon of Israel began an 11-day visit here today as the Reagan Administration showed a degree of skittishness about the timing of his tour and its potential political impact in Israel.   Mr. Navon, a 61-year old Labor Party veteran who holds what has traditionally been a ceremonial post, is said by some in Israel to be contemplating a challenge to Prime Minister Menachem Begin.   The White House is anxious to avoid any action or statements that would appear to involve the United States in Israeli politics, Administration officials said. Specifically, they said, the Administration wants to avoid any impression that it is supporting Mr. Navon against Mr. Begin, with whom the Reagan Administration has clashed on Middle East policy.

headline: ISRAELIS ACHEIVE AGENDA ACCORD WITH LEBANESE
abstract: After three weeks of negotiation, Israel and Lebanon reached agreement today on an agenda for their talks.  An Israeli spokesman said the agenda included ''the termination of the state of war,'' ''a framework for mutual relations,'' security arrangements and the withdrawal of Israeli troops ''within the context of the evacuation of all foreign forces.''   The announcement was made while Israeli, Lebanese and American negotiators were meeting in the northern Israeli border town of Qiryat Shemona. Formulation Was the Issue   The sticking point had been the issue of mutual relations. Israel originally wanted the term ''normalization'' to appear at the head of the list of items to be discussed, but Lebanon objected, fearing that such an explicit step toward diplomatic recognition of Israel would further complicate Moslem-Christian relations in Lebanon and strain ties with other Arab nations.

headline: Volcker Cites Upturn's Basis
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reseve Board, said today that last year's sharply lower inflation rate had laid the foundation for a large and lasting decline in interest rates for the record levels of the last few years.

headline: NUCLEAR-POWERED SOVIET SATELLITE IS EXPECTED TO CRASH THIS MONTH
abstract: The United States said today that a nuclearpowered Soviet reconnaissance satellite had apparently run into problems and would probably crash somewhere on the earth's surface before the end of the month.   A statement issued by the Defense Department said the satellite, known as Cosmos 1402, was similar to an earlier Cosmos satellite that crashed in an uninhabited area of northern Canada in January 1978, causing minor radiation contamination. Administration officials said the Cosmos 1402 was believed to contain about 100 pounds of enriched uranium for a reactor that provides electricity for its radar, which observes American naval operations. Danger From Radioactivity   Officials emphasized that the danger of the satellite was not from the possibility of an explosion but from the radioactivity of its nuclear-fission products. Strontium 90, for example, builds up in the reactor as its uranium fuel is consumed.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: Intelligence sources, citing some small shifts in Soviet military deployments in Eastern Europe, speculate that Moscow is readjusting its military strategy as a result of Middle Eastern developments and the expected arrival of new Atlantic alliance weapons.   The first impulse toward a review of strategy, some high-ranking Israeli and Arab intelligence sources said, came last summer after the Israeli Air Force destroyed Soviet-made radar and surface-to-air missile systems in eastern Lebanese areas held by Syrian troops.   This destruction was said to have brought Col. Gen. Yevgeny S.  Yurasov, a first deputy commander of the Soviet Air Defense Forces, to Damascus on June 13. The general and his aides reportedly inspected the ruined SAM sites in the Bekaa in eastern Lebanon and promised extensive new supplies of both weapons systems and radar.

headline: U.S. IS SAID TO BAR DEAL WITH ISRAEL
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has rejected a proposed agreement with Israel under which Israeli forces would have shared military information they gained during the Lebanon conflict, Administration officials said today.   The officials said Mr. Weinberger decided against the agreement because he felt it would have trapped the United States into longrange commitments to Israel that he wanted to avoid. They said Mr. Weinberger distrusted present Israeli leaders, who demanded too much.   The Administration officials said Mr. Weinberger had decided, as one put it, ''The information was not worth the price being asked.'' They tried to play down the value of the intelligence, tactical and technical information and said much had already been learned through normal military contacts.

headline: Foreign Money Futures Are Moderately Higher
abstract: Foreign exchange currency futures prices closed moderately higher yesterday, despite some late selling. Brokers said that most of the selling was caused by an unexpectedly small rally in the dollar's value among interbank foreign exchange dealers.   Most foreign currency traders in both the cash and futures markets have been selling the dollar short recently through the purchase of actual foreign currencies or futures, thebrokers noted. Because many of these traders now have large paper profits, the slightest rally in the dollar tends to provoke profit taking.

headline: SHULTZ SAYS U.S. TOLD SALVADORANS TO 'CLEAN-UP' THEIR RIGHTS RECORD
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, seeking to defuse opposition to increased military aid for El Salvador, told a Senate subcommittee today that Salvadoran leaders had been warned to ''clean up'' their human rights record or lose all American support.   Testifying on behalf of the Administration's request to transfer $60 million more for emergency military aid to El Salvador, Mr.  Shultz avoided confrontations with critics on the committee. He did so by agreeing with most of their complaints about human rights abuses in El Salvador, particularly the delay in bringing to trial five former National Guardsmen accused of killing four American churchwomen in December 1980. 'Support Is Going to Dry Up'   ''You cannot get me to sit here and defend what has happened under the judicial system of El Salvador,'' Mr. Shultz told Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennslvania. ''I won't do it. I don't do it.  I don't think it is defensible. If they don't clean up this act, the support is going to dry up, and they've been told that and they know that and that will happen.''

headline: Envoy to Burundi Nominated
abstract: President Reagan said today that he would nominate James R. Bullington to be the next Ambassador to Burundi.  Mr. Bullington, a career Foreign Service officer, was most recently senior adviser for African affairs with Washington's United Nations delegation.

headline: Advertising; Lorimar Buying K.& E.
abstract: KENYON & ECKHARDT, the ad agency for an important number of television network advertisers, is about to become a subsidiary of Lorimar, a major supplier of programming to those same networks. It is the first merger of its kind.   The 13-year-old production company announced the agreement in principle from its Culver City, Calif., headquarters yesterday, noting that the deal should close around June 30. The 54 stockholders of K.& E., a privately held company, will get $21 million in cash right off the bat and more money later if certain conditions are fulfilled.

headline: SOMETIMES, ISRAEL AND P.L.O. COOPERATE, DISCREETLY
abstract: Occupied Gaza Strip, March 10 - Behind the whitewashed, stone house of a Palestinian family here lies a reservoir for the sewage that runs through open gutters in the lanes and markets of Rafah.   The reservoir, which is half the size of a football field, was visited on an inspection trip recently by an Israeli engineer carrying blueprints for a United Nations project. The project envisages draining the noxious pool, replacing Rafah's sewage gutters with 24 miles of underground asbestos pipe and building a modern plant whose treated water would irrigate the surrounding groves of oranges, lemons and grapefruit.   The venture is one of 1,200 projects run by the United Nations Development Program in an effort to raise living standards in the third world. But in this Israeli-occupied area it also represents a little-noticed example of indirect collaboration, through the development program, between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

headline: Armco Plans to Sell Coal Assets to Arch
abstract: Armco Inc., the nation's seventhlargest steelmaker, said today that it was negotiating the sale of ''substantially all its West Virginia coal properties'' to a subsidiary of the Arch Mineral Corporation of St. Louis, which is 50 percent owned by the Ashland Oil Company, for about $320 million.   Armco, which lost $345 million on sales of $5.4 billion last year, had said it would try to sell its coal properties as part of a program to divest itself of ''nonstrategic assets'' and improve its cash position.

headline: Stokely-Van Camp Faces Esmark Bid
abstract: Esmark Inc., the Chicago holding company, disclosed yesterday that it had acquired 6.1 percent of the common stock of Stokely-Van Camp Inc., the large food packer, as the first step in a possible takeover.   An acquisition attempt, however, would face the obstacle of an agreement by Stokely-Van Camp last month to sell all its shares to a private investor group headed by its chairman, William B. Stokely 3d.    Esmark purchased 168,000 of Stokely's nearly 2.7 million outstanding prices ranging from $50 to $53.50 a share, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. At the lower price, the purchase would cost $8.4 million.

headline: Louisiana Utility Sells 20% of Unit

Central Louisiana said it would retain a 30 percent interest in the 530,000-kilowatt unit, and that it would reduce the rates it charges its customers by $13.2 million to reflect the reduced ownership of the facility.

headline: IN SALVADOR, THE TALE OF DENNIS, 21 MONTHS OLD
abstract: The story of Dennis Orlando Gallardo Quintanilla, a 21-month-old American citizen, is a peculiarly Salvadoran tale.   It begins with the murder of his parents and reported squabbles among soldiers over whether to kill the baby too. It includes a painstaking, four-month search for the child that finally came to an end last Monday when the head of the Salvadoran National Guard telephoned the United States Embassy and said simply, ''I have the child in my office.''   Today Dennis, in the care of his uncle, left El Salvador for the United States.  Dennis was born at the University of California Medical Center on May 6, 1981, to a Salvadoran mother who was a permanent resident of the United States and a Salvadoran father.

headline: JEWS ISSUE APPEAL ON SOVIET AT MADRID TALKS
abstract: A delegation of prominent Jews from Europe and the United States met this week with representatives at the Madrid conference on security and cooperation in Europe to express concern over what they said was increasing repression against Jews in the Soviet Union.   At a news conference, the group said that fewer Jews had been allowed to emigrate from the Soviet Union since Yuri V. Andropov became the Soviet leader.   ''We are not anti-Soviet,'' said Arieh L. Handler, chairman of the National Council for Soviet Jewry in England and Ireland. ''We are conscious of the fact that over 260,000 Jews have left the Soviet Union over the last 13 years. We are hoping and still hope that the new regime led by Mr. Andropov might change its attitude.

headline: WHERE TO PUT YOUR I.R.A. MONEY
abstract: THERE is still time to make a contribution to your 1982 Individual R etirement Account and take advantage of one of the most generous p rovisions of the tax code.   Under the 1981 tax act, last year was the first time that all workers - even those covered by employee pension plans - could get a tax break for setting up a retirement nest egg. Not only does an I.R.A. lower current taxes by permitting a deduction for the amount of your yearly contribution, but the income that your I.R.A. account earns gathers tax-free until you start to withdraw it at retirement.   The law gives everyone until the due date for filing their tax returns (April 15), plus any extensions, to make I.R.A. contributions for the previous tax year. The contribution limit for 1982 is 100 percent of earned income, up to a maximum contribution of $2,000.  Individuals with a nonworking spouse can contribute $2,250, while two-income married couples can stash away $4,000.

headline: Economic Scene; Budget Debate: Two Questions
abstract: THERE are two strategic questions at the core of the great debate on the Federal budget that is racking Washington: First, how big should the Government be? Second, what is the optimal allocation of real resources among the military, transfer programs such as Social Security and public sector investment in roads, transit, schools and hospitals?  Economics cannot answer these questions. They are political issues that - to the extent they are ever resolved - will be settled in the competitive political marketplace on Capitol Hill. As always, those with power will win. But economics can help by putting the argument in context, and by pointing out the implications of one course or another.

headline: U.S. Aide Sees Oil Price Drop
abstract: A top Energy Department official told a Congressional hearing today that oil prices, already tumbling because of a worldwide oversupply caused by the recession, are likely to drop further.   The official, George Bradley, a deputy assistant secretary, said, ''There is reason to believe that a cut in the Saudi benchmark crude of between $2 and $6 per barrel could occur.''

headline: POLISH CHURCH REPORTS POPE WILL VISIT JUNE 18
abstract: The Roman Catholic Church of Poland announced today that Pope John Paul II would begin the second visit of his papacy to his native country on June 18.   No Vatican announcement was made. But the statement from Warsaw was made public here at the same time that it was read from all Polish pulpits in the form of a pastoral letter from the country's bishops.The Vatican press office distributed the text of the letter in Italian translation.

headline: 2 Accounting Firms Sued
abstract: Five former customers of the closed Toledo brokerage firm of Bell & Beckwith have filed a $100 million lawsuit against the company's former managing partner and two accounting firms yesterday in Lucas County Common Pleas Court.   The firm was closed last week by the Securities and Exchange Commission after auditors learned that $36 million had been borrowed against six cash and securities accounts owned by Edward P. Wolfram Jr., managing partner, and his wife, Zula.

headline: NICARAGUA, COMBATING INCURSION, WARNS HONDURAS ON RISK OF WAR
abstract: The Nicaraguan Government said today that there was a ''serious danger of war'' with Honduras because of intense fighting north of Managua that it blamed on the United States-supported Honduran military.   Defense Minister Humberto Ortega said Nicaraguan soldiers and militiamen were battling at least 1,200 guerrillas around Matagalpa, 90 miles north of Managua. Fighting also was reported near Jinotega, 20 miles north of Matagalpa.

headline: WARSAW AIDE SAYS EXPULSION IS A WARNING TO ALL REPORTERS
abstract: The Polish Government said today that its decision to expel an American news agency correspondent was intended as a warning to all journalists here against maintaining contacts with what it denounced as the political opposition.   This warning was voiced at a news conference by the Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban. He hinted that the Government would lift the credentials of all those who continued to publicize the statements of underground leaders of the outlawed Solidarity trade union and other political dissidents.   ''I am saying this openly,'' Mr. Urban declared. ''We want to eliminate the practice of newsmen becoming the representatives of criminal circles.

headline: 46 KILLED IN ANKARA AS A TURKISH JETLINER GOES DOWN IN STORM
abstract: A Turkish Airlines jetliner carrying 67 passengers and crew members crashed while landing in a storm at Ankara's airport today and 46 people were killed, the authorities reported.   Fourteen passengers and all seven crew members - a pilot, co-pilot and four flight attendants - survived the crash, officials said.

headline: Texas Eastern Earnings Charge
abstract: The Texas Eastern Corporation, a Houston-based energy company, said it would take a charge of $25 million, or 97 cents a share, against fiscal year 1982 earnings to account for an exploratory well off the Red Sea coast of the Sudan that the company was forced to plug and abandon. Texas said the well indicated minor, but noncommercial, hydocarbon levels.

headline: Tanaka Case Admission
abstract: A one-time aide to former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka admitted today that he had received $2.1 million for Mr. Tanaka from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's Japanese agent.   But the aide, Toshio Enomoto, said he thought the cardboard boxes stuffed with 500 million yen were a political contribution from a Japanese concern, the Marubeni Corporation.

headline: JUDGE NAMES EXAMINER FOR DELOREAN MOTOR
abstract: A Federal bankruptcy judge today appointed an independent examiner to search the books of the defunct DeLorean Motor Company for financial irregularities.   Judge George Woods ordered Touche Ross & Company to account for all the company's cars, examine the personal bank account of its founder, John Z. DeLorean, and investigate whether there were special transactions, among them the sale of some cars at below fair market value to Mr. DeLorean's brother, Charles.   The appointment was made at the request of the DeLorean Motor creditors' committee. Judge Woods said creditors were entitled to such a request when they suspected fraud, misconduct, mismanagement or irregularities by a company or its officers.

headline: China-U.S. Textile Talk
abstract: Chinese and United States negotiators today began a fifth round of textile trade talks aimed at solving a bitter dispute in which each side has restricted imports from the other country.

headline: 2d Chinese Executed For Economic Crimes
abstract: An accountant has been executed in China for embezzling more than $300,000 from the bank where he worked in Guangdong Province, on the border with Hong Kong, the New China News Agency said today.   The agency said Li Jingfang, 55 years old, who was executed Tuesday, began stealing public funds in December 1978 by obtaining bank loans in the name of fictitious enterprises, forging money orders and using the cash for speculation and smuggling.

headline: SCHLESINGER'S WARY OIL VIEW
abstract: How advantageous is the oil price decline?  James R. Schlesinger, the nation's first Secretary of Energy, believes it is likely to inhibit the domestic industry's ability to keep replacing the oil that is now being consumed. Moreover, he says, it may further dampen efforts to develop alternative fuels.   Mr. Schlesinger, a former top budget, defense and intelligence official as well as Energy Secretary, is now a senior adviser to Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. and Georgetown University's Center for Strategic and International Studies. The following are excerpts from a conversation with him this week about the new pricing and production agreement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and other energy matters.

headline: Two Climbers Die in Wales
abstract: Two climbers fell to their deaths from a peak in the Snowdon range and six others were hospitalized. A 16-year-old boy ran nearly five miles to a farmhouse to report that his companions in a party of seven boys and two teachers from a London school had fallen Friday while climbing the 3,000-foot Craig-yr-Ysfa ridge.

headline: Home Resale Total Down
abstract: Resales of single-family houses dipped 4.3 percent in February after rising for five straight months, a real estate trade group said today. However, a spokesman said that the sales rate ''remained healthy'' and that the upward trend would resume soon.

headline: AMERICAN ECONOMY SEEN UNAFFECTED BY REALIGNMENT
abstract: The realignment of currency values in the European Monetary System -the third in the last 13 months -should quiet the foreign-exchange markets for the time being, bankers in New York said yesterday. They added that the realignment should have little direct impact on the American economy or the cost in this country, for example, of West German automobiles or French wines.  ''From the viewpoint of the dollar, this was a non-event,'' said Rimmer deVries, chief international economist for the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. ''The realignment was strictly an internal European affair. The important issue for the U.S. is the overvaluation of the dollar in relation to the yen.''

headline: News Analysis
abstract: In the politically charged maneuvering over arms control, both President Reagan and Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, have sometimes dangled the prospect of a summit meeting to sway public opinion, but so far neither side is visibly engaged in serious preparations for such a meeting.   In his open letter Monday calling for a meeting, President Reagan proposed that Mr. Andropov accept terms that Moscow had previously rejected - the original Reagan offer to ban all intermediate-range missiles, including the 572 that NATO is scheduled to deploy in Europe and the 600 missiles that Moscow already has lined up against Western Europe and Asia.   Thus it came as no surprise here that Mr. Andropov rejected the proposal as ''a political or a propaganda game'' offering nothing new and treating a meeting between the two leaders lightly. His speedy rebuff was seen as a shrewd effort to prevent Mr. Reagan from throwing Moscow on the defensive.

headline: SLUMP EVEN SLOWS NATION'S DRINKING
abstract: When things go wrong with the economy, the alcoholic beverage business usually holds its own. Drinking customs resist change, and almost anybody can afford a glass of beer. But in today's recession, many drinkers have reduced their intake or switched to less expensive drinks, and the $47 billion industry is suffering.   Indeed, for the first time since the Great Depression, the experts report, an economic downturn is having a noticeable effect on the consumption of liquor, beer and wine.

headline: Two Letter Bombs Received in London
abstract: A letter bomb mailed to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was intercepted and safely defused today just hours after another letter bomb exploded in the United States Navy's European headquarters in London, the police said.   No one was injured in the incident at 10 Downing Street, but a chief petty officer burned his hand when a letter bomb burst into flames at headquarters of the commander-in-chief of the United States Naval Forces Europe.

headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS; FOR FED WATCHERS, YET ANOTHER CLUE
abstract: Vintage Volcker. In last week's standing-room-only appearance before the Senate Banking Committee, Fed chairman Paul A. Volcker (right) took the oath again to encourage both recovery and lower inflation. Precisely how remains the question. But the chairman gave Fed watchers a new clue to future central bank behavior. They should keep one eye on the M's and the other eye on a new statistic: total borrowings by nonfinancial businesses, households and governments.  The market's response to Mr. Volcker's recital: rates up, down, flat.   Flexing its muscles. That's how President Reagan characterized the economy during a news conference. Just weeks ago, the President only saw economic seeds beginning to sprout. Whatever the case, analysts are coming around to the idea that G.N.P. growth, fourth quarter 1982 to fourth quarter 1983, will reach 4 percent. And news from the Government - that housing starts were up 35.9 percent and factory output gained nine-tenths of 1 percent in January -seems to support the upbeat view.

headline: SECURITIES OPERATIONS LIFT PHIBRO-SALOMON 21%
abstract: Phibro-Salomon Inc. reported yesterday that strong gains by its securities operations lifted earnings in the fourth quarter of 1982 by 21 percent while revenues advanced 27 percent.   The company said that net income in the latest three months rose to $98 million, or $1.44 a share, from $81 million, or $1.20 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1981. Revenues rose to $8.18 billion, from $6.44 billion.   For the full year, Phibro-Salomon said that net income rose 16.6 percent, to $337 million, or $4.97 a share, from $289 million, or $4.23 a share, in 1981. Revenues edged up 3.9 percent, to $26.7 billion, from $25.7 billion.

abstract: Belgrade Says It Will Repay   BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 26 (Reuters) - The Government remains opposed to rescheduling Yugoslavia's $20 billion of foreign debt, the minister overseeing foreign financial problems said today.   The official, Janko Smole, told a news conference that Yugolsavia would pay all its debts, $4.5 billion of which are due this year.

abstract: Genentech Inc., a prominent genetic engineering company in San Francisco, received a patent this week for a method of producing certain proteins from microorganisms.

Rosen, 50, who founded the newsletter nine years ago, plans to sell Rosen Research Inc. to Esther Dyson, 31, who has been working at the New York-based concern since last August. The price is still being negotiated, she said. Rosen Research owns the newsletter.

abstract: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon defended Israel's new arms and military aid agreement with Zaire today as a step toward increasing Israeli influence in Africa.   He said he thought that the accord, reached during his four-day visit this week to Zaire, would lead other African countries to turn to Israel for military aid.

headline: A CASE IS MADE FOR OPTIMISM
abstract: Could the recovery turn out to be appreciably stronger than almost everyone expects? It has happened before. Although predictions for an anemic recovery still predominate, some economists foresee a somewhat snappier comeback.   ''I think people are going to be surprised about the strength of the recovery as we move through the year,'' said Edward Guay, chief economist for the Cigna Corporation, the insurance company. He predicted that real gross national product in the fourth quarter of 1983 will be 5.8 percent higher than in the last quarter of 1982, and that industrial production will be 8 percent higher. He said that average annual real G.N.P. in 1983 will be 3.6 percent above 1982.   ''Forecasters, by and large, have usually underestimated the speed of recovery once it gets started,'' stated Edgar R. Fiedler, vice president for economic research at the Conference Board. ''It is often hard to see the sources of strength. But once they get started, they tend to cumulate even faster than expected.''

headline: SOVIET SAYS JAPAN RISKS DEVASTATION
abstract: Moscow warned Japan tonight that it could face a retaliatory strike more devastating than the 1945 atomic bomb explosions if it agreed to the deployment of more weapons aimed at the Soviet Union.   The warning was included in a commentary by the official Tass press agency on remarks made by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone in Washington that Japan should substantially improve its air and naval defenses.

headline: A 'Die-In' Held in Geneva
abstract: Antinuclear demonstrators splashed with their own blood staged a symbolic ''die-in'' in front of the Soviet Mission today to protest the nuclear arms race. Five of the 15 protesters laid down in front of the mission gate, the blood falling on their faces and clothes through tubes attached to plastic hospital blood bags. The blood was collected Wednesday night by a medical student in the group.

headline: CONSOLIDATED CIGAR ENTERS NEW PHASE
abstract: When Alex N. Brainard joined the Consolidated Cigar Company 11 years ago as president, he did not smoke cigars. But now he does, and yesterday, with one in hand, he explained why more men ought to be smoking cigars in another decade or so.   Mr. Brainard led a group of Consolidated Cigar executives who purchased the company last week from its corporate parent, Gulf and Western Industries, which had owned it since 1968. He will remain president and chief executive officer of Consolidated, which makes Dutch Masters and other cigars.

headline: ISSUE AND DEBATE; THIRD-WORLD DEBT PROBLEM
abstract: Foreign debts of the less developed countries - both oil-producing and not - now total more than $550 billion, and they clearly carry the potential to disrupt the world financial system.  Plainly, if some significant portion of this huge indebtedness goes into default - because of recession, disinflation, lower oil prices or any other reason - some of the largest American banks could easily be in trouble.  Should government, in the United States or elsewhere, foot part or all of the bill for cleaning up the mess in international credit markets?  Yes, say some influential investment bankers and economists. They maintain that government intervention is essential, including the creation of new agencies to assume some of the credit risk and impose new controls. One way or another the public will inevitably be involved, they say, noting the general interest in the functioning of major multinational banks.

headline: Bangladesh Relaxes Ban On Political Activity
abstract: President Hussain Mohammed Ershad eased a ban on political activity today and proposed discussions with opposition parties that would lead to elections in 1984.

headline: Burnup & Sims Reports a Loss
abstract: Burnup & Sims Inc., a Fort Lauderdale-based telecommunications company, reported a net loss of $1.8 million for the third quarter, ended Jan. 31, compared with earnings of $900,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter a year earlier.

headline: Mobil Accord Proposed
abstract: The Department of Energy has proposed settling for $27 million, or less than 3 cents on the dollar, more than $920 million in claims against the Mobil Corporation for reported violations of now-expired price controls on oil, Government sources said today. Under the settlement, which awaits final approval of Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel, civil enforcement actions related to Mobil's transactions with crude oil ''resellers'' would be suspended unless the resellers were convicted of criminal violations.

headline: Portuguese Agree On a New Coalition
abstract: Portugal's ruling right-wing alliance reached basic agreement today on a new coalition Government to be led by a former Education Minister, Vitor Crespo.   The breakthrough came when the Christian Democrats said at the end of a nightlong meeting that they would accept the 11 ministers proposed by their coalition partners.   Portugal's Government crisis, now in its fourth week, was caused by the resignation Dec. 19 of Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao over feuding in the coalition.

headline: Washington Watch; Battle Brewing On Trade Law
abstract: WASHINGTON ''LOOK for blood on the floor before this is over,'' said one key Administration figure as the hawks and doves of East-West trade circled over the Export Administration Act of 1979. The legislation, under which President Carter and President Reagan have imposed foreign policy trade sanctions against the Soviet Union, will expire Sept. 30 unless it is renewed.   At the sub-Cabinet level the hawks, led by Lawrence J. Brady, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Trade Administration, and Richard N. Perle, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Policy, have already moved to toughen the statute.   At higher levels and in the international business community there is dismay over the way things are headed. Clashes have already been reported at the Commerce Department.

headline: I.B.M. SUES COMPETITOR
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation, continuing its aggressive moves against both domestic and foreign competitors, filed suit today against an American rival and five of its own former employees, charging theft of trade secrets.   I.B.M. accused the Cybernex Corporation of San Jose, Calif., and the five former I.B.M. executives who founded it of misappropriation of trade secrets and unfair competition.   The complaint, which seeks an injunction and unspecified damages, involves the principal component of a computer disk storage device known as the ''head.'' The component is used to ''read'' and ''write'' data on the disk's surface for storage.

headline: SAUDIS CONSIDER BUYING NEW U.S. ARMS
abstract: The Reagan Administration, in response to a request from Saudi Arabia, has begun a program intended to sell M-1 Abrams tanks and M-2 Bradley armored personnel carriers to that nation, Administration officials said today.   The officials said that most details of the plan remain unsettled but that the initial phase would begin soon when Saudi crews arrive at the armor center at Fort Knox, Kentucky, to start training.  Training on the advanced armored personnel carrier would be conducted by the FMC Corporation, the maker.   Officials said the plan called for shipping several M-1 tanks to Saudi Arabia at Saudi expense during the summer for demonstrations in the deserts there. American crews will put the tanks through their paces with Saudi crews also taking part, they said.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; U.S. Helping Aliens Forced Out of Nigeria   WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (Reuters) - The United States has made available more than 800 tons of food and $70,000 to buy emergency supplies for several hundred thousand aliens expelled from Nigeria, the State Department said today.   The department spokesman, Alan Romberg, said the United States was participating in the relief effort led by the United Nations Disaster Relief Coordinator.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT ON ISRAELIS' RESPONSIBILITY IN MASSACRE
abstract: Following are excerpts from a report made public today by an Israeli commission of inquiry into the slayings of civilians last September in Beirut at two Palestinian refugee camps, Sabra and Shatila, as issued in translation by the Government press office: I   The Direct Responsibility   All the evidence indicates that the massacre was perpetrated by the Phalangists between the time they entered the camps on Thursday, 16.9.82, at 18.00 hours, and their departure from the camps on Saturday, 18.9.82, at approximately 8 A.M.   The victims were found in those areas where the Phalangists were in military control during the aforementioned time period. No other military force aside from the Phalangists was seen by any one of the witnesses in the area of the camps where the massacre was carried out or at the time of the entrance into or exit from this area. The camps were surrounded on all sides: on three sides by I.D.F. forces and on the fourth side was a city line (between East and West Beirut) that was under Phalangist control.   We heard testimony from two doctors and a nurse who worked in the Gaza hospital, which was run by and for Palestinians.

headline: 2,000 POLES ATTEND ILLEGAL PROTEST RALLY AT GDANSK SHIPYARD
abstract: More than 2,000 Poles defied the authorities today by holding an illegal rally at the workers' monument by the gates of the Lenin Shipyard in this Baltic seaport.   The brief protest, quickly broken up by the riot police, reflected the resentment deeply held by many in Poland over the imposition of martial law in December 1981 and the crushing of the independent union Solidarity.   It was the largest demonstration since since early last fall and came after a declaration by the former Solidarity leader, Lech Walesa, that ''harder tactics'' must be used and after a bitter letter of protest to Parliament by the shipyard workers.   The rally was called for 1 o'clock this afternoon in leaflets furtively handed out in the last few days in the streets and near Roman Catholic churches. The 13th of each month - the date on which martial law was declared - has become a traditional day of protest. A similar call for another rally has gone out for Monday, timed to coincide with the midafternoon shift change at the shipyard.

headline: DOW ADVANCES 9.19, TO ,1087.10
abstract: Optimism over the improving economy enabled the stock market to post a strong gain yesterday, with some of the blue-chip issues registering the biggest advances.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was ahead 13.43 points at 12:30 P.M., ended up 9.19 points, to 1,087.10. The late weakness was attributed mostly to profit taking.

headline: American Bell
abstract: American Bell, the new equipment subisidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said that the Chase Commercial Corporation would provide American Bell customers with the option of Chasebacked financing on the purchase and installation of advanced telephone systems. Under the one-year agreement, $200 million would be available in financing. American Bell said it would continue to provide its own financing for leased equipment.

headline: SOVIET PREMIER TO VISIT GREECE
abstract: The Soviet Prime Minister will visit here later this month, it was announced today. The visit will be the first to Greece by a senior Soviet official.   In formal terms, Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov of the Soviet Union will be returning a visit paid to Moscow in 1979 by the then Greek Prime Minister, Constantine Caramanlis, and the occasion will be used to sign commercial agreements initiated under previous governments.

headline: U.S. May Grant Aid to Mexico
abstract: The United States is expected to approve $400 million to $600 million in credit guarantees next month to help finance sales of farm products to Mexico, Administration officials said today.

headline: GREEK CYPRIOTS, IN VOTING TODAY, TO PICK PRESIDENT
abstract: After a bitterly contested political campaign, Greek Cypriots are voting on Sunday in presidential elections that are generally expected here to give the incumbent, Spyros Kyprianou, another term.   While the campaign formally opened at the beginning of January, it has dominated politics for the last 10 months and virtually paralyzed the United Nations-sponsored talks between the Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots.   Turkish Cypriots have vowed to boycott the elections. Instead, spokesmen say, they will celebrate the eighth anniversary of the Turkish Federated State of Cyprus that they proclaimed on the northern part of the island, an entity recognized only by Turkey.

headline: ARGENTINA'S 200% INFLATION
abstract: Pedro Fischer, a leading Argentine textile manufacturer, had a simple explanation of how he does long-term business planning in a country that has an inflation rate of more than 200 percent: He doesn't.   ''To an Argentine businessman,'' said Mr. Fischer, with black humor that belied his exasperation, ''short term is until tonight, medium term is until the end of the week, and long term is until the next change of economics ministers.''   Interviewed in his bustling women's garment factory in this suburb on the outskirts of Buenos Aires, Mr. Fischer, 62 years old, is in many ways a typical Argentine businessman. He has learned to be extraordinarly adept in his business, devising tactics that an American might find boggling.

headline: DILLARD DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Of Amdahl And Heizer
abstract: THE two biggest price gainers on the American Stock Exchange's active list last week were the Amdahl Corporation, rising 5 3/4 points, to 39 3/8, and the Heizer Corporation, advancing 1 7/8 points, to 15 7/8.   Yesterday Amdahl gained 1 1/2, to 40 7/8, while Heizer added 3/8, to 16 1/4.  There is more than coincidence at work here. ''Amdahl represents nearly one-half of Heizer's assets,'' said S.F. Accardo of Shearson/American Express yesterday.

headline: SALVADORAN PRESIDENT ORDERS COLONEL TO ACCEPT A TRANSFER
abstract: The provisional President of El Salvador tonight ordered the rebellious commander of a northern province to comply ''immediately and without conditions'' with an order transferring him to a diplomatic post.   At the same time, President Alvaro Magana, acting as the commanding general of the armed forces, ordered a study of ''the causes that motivated the anomalous institutional situation'' that led the commander, Lieut. Col. Sigifredo Ochoa Perez, to refuse the order and, with his 1,200 troops, to seal off the province of Cabanas.   Mr. Magana's statement, in which he declared the country to be in ''grave danger'' because of the rebellion, offered neither strong condemnation for Colonel Ochoa nor strong support for Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, the Defense Minister, whose resignation Colonel Ochoa has demanded.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Net Income   Percent

headline: SECURITIES DEALERS IN REFORMS
abstract: The government securities market, shaken by the collapse last year of three dealer firms, has changed some of the practices that brought on the failures and is considering other reforms to help prevent future ones.   ''It gave our business a black eye,'' the chairman of one firm acknowledged after the collapse last May of Drysdale Government Securities, a small concern that managed to accumulate losses of more than $300 million before they were discovered.   The Chase Manhattan Bank, which suffered a $135 million after-tax loss as a result of its dealings with Drysdale, has since charged the firm and its accountants, Arthur Andersen & Company, with misrepresenting its financial condition.   And throughout the government securities market, where securities worth billions are routinely bought and sold over the telephone, the Drysdale affair led dealers to look more closly at the creditworthiness of their customers, including other dealers.

headline: U.P.I. Bureau in Warsaw Closed by Government
abstract: The Polish authorities closed United Press International's bureau here today, saying the news agency's operation in Warsaw would remain suspended until a correspondent of the official Polish press agency, P.A.P., was allowed back into Washington.   The State Department revoked the accreditation of the P.A.P.  correspondent in Washington, Stanislaw Glabinski, in retaliation for the expulsion of U.P.I.'s Warsaw correspondent, Ruth E. Gruber, last month.

headline: REBEL SALVADOR COLONEL MAY GET PLUM POST IN U.S.
abstract: The former commander of the northern province of Cabanas, who prompted a national crisis by refusing to obey transfer orders from the Minister of Defense, is likely to be sent to the Inter-American Defense Council in Washington for a year of study, according to a person familiar with the plans of the Salvadoran high command.   Although the former commander, Lieut. Col. Sigifredo Ochoa Perez, has agreed to leave the country, his ability not only to avoid punishment but apparently to receive the prestigious Washington appointment would be considered a victory for him.   The outcome of the crisis leaves in question the position of the Defense Minister, Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, who was the target of the colonel's rebellion.

headline: MONTANA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHUN SPARES 2 DOOMED IN KOREAN ARSON CASE
abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea today commuted the death sentences of two men convicted of setting fire to a United States cultural center last March, killing a student and injuring three others.   A Presidential spokesman announced in Seoul, the South Korean capital, that the two defendants - Moon Bu Shik, a 23-year-old theology student, and Kim Hyon Jang, 32, a lay worker at a Roman Catholic education center - would now serve life sentences in prison.    The President's action followed quiet appeals for mercy from the United States Government and a public campaign led by South Korea's National Council of Churches, a Protestant group, and the Catholic Church. Both American and church officials were said to fear that if the two men were put to death, violent protests might erupt at the nation's universities in the spring.

headline: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POLAND SAYS DISSIDENTS PLAN PROTESTS FOR MAY
abstract: Poland's Interior Minister told Parliament today that the authorities had halted the ''process of disintegration of the state'' in the 15 months since martial law was imposed. But he said dissidents still planned protests early in May.   ''They are preparing society for a general strike, that is, for a confrontation, an explosion,'' the minister, Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, declared.

headline: Greeks Retire 15 Officers After Rumors of Coup
abstract: The Government tonight announced the ''retirement'' of 15 senior military officers.

headline: TANGLING WITH THE COMPUTER MONSTER
abstract: Despite all the interest in home computers, most people seem to be holding off in buying one, and not because of the price. The hesitancy, surveys show, is a fear of handling. People simply don't know how to use the technological monster once they get it home, and therein lies a challenge for computer makers,   A consumer survey taken in January by Casio Inc., a maker of computers, found that 83 percent of those surveyed were interested in computers -but 85 percent had no plans to buy one. ''They said no because they didn't know what to do with it,'' said Dennis Reer, computer marketing manager for Casio. Casio and others suggest that the situation could get worse before it gets better. They have found that consumers are falling farther and farther behind the technology embodied in today's fast-changing computers.

headline: HIGH P.L.O. OFFICIAL CONFERS IN JORDAN
abstract: A high-ranking Palestine Liberation Organization official met with Jordanian leaders today on a role for King Hussein in American-led Middle East peace talks and said the P.L.O. and Jordan were ''going in the right direction.''   The official, the P.L.O. political director and foreign affairs spokesman, Farouk Kaddoumi, met twice with Foreign Minister Marwan al-Kassem of Jordan.   Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, had been expected in Amman on Sunday but instead visited King Fahd in Saudi Arabia, then flew to Iraq.

headline: U.S. CALLED READY TO CONSIDER SHIFT ON MISSILE PLAN
abstract: President Reagan has agreed to consider recommendations from key allied leaders that he propose a compromise plan to the Soviet Union on reducing the number of medium-range missiles in Europe, White House officials said today.   Mr. Reagan has been insisting on complete elimination of such missiles.  The officials said that on Friday Vice President Bush, just back from a 12-day trip to Western Europe, told the President that several allied leaders had expressed a desire for what they called an ''interim solution'' to the missile issue.   One White House official said that Mr. Bush's dispatches from Europe had prepared the Administration for the necessity of looking at the possibility of an interim approach. He stressed, as Mr. Bush did in a television interview today, that it was uncertain what the President's decision would be or when any action might be taken.

headline: TEJON RANCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NAVON ENDS CAUTIOUS VISIT TO U.S.
abstract: President Yitzhak Navon of Israel ended an 11-day visit to the United States today, a trip billed as nonpolitical but one that prominent American Jews said enhanced his reputation in this country.   Mr. Navon, a 61-year-old Labor Party veteran whom some see as a potential political challenger to Prime Minister Menachem Begin, refrained from criticism of Mr. Begin's policies or expressing political views that diverged from those of his Government.   Instead, he dwelt mostly on themes about which there was a consensus in Israel, but not necessarily among American Jews.  ''America is a great country,'' Mr. Navon said in a speech to more than 1,000 Jews in Kehilath Jeshurun Synagogue in New York last Sunday night. ''But any Jew who lives in any part of the world lives by chance. The only place they live not by chance is in Israel.''

headline: Queen Elizabeth Settles Suit Against Newspaper
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II settled her damage suit against Britain's biggest tabloid today after the newspaper admitted it had no right to print the backstairs gossip of a former palace servant.   The Sun, controlled by the Australian publisher Rupert Murdoch, agreed in the out-of-court settlement to pay $6,000 to the Newspaper Press Fund, and to pay Buckingham Palace's legal costs, Mr.  Murdoch's News Group Ltd. announced.

headline: POPE SET TO ISSUE NEW CHURCH LAWS EASING STRICTURES
abstract: A totally revised code of Roman Catholic canon law breaks new ground by stressing rights of the laity, allowing bishops to make more decisions locally and reducing the number of religious obligations expected of Catholics, according to church specialists familiar with the draft submitted to Pope John Paul II.   The Pope is expected to issue the new code on Tuesday, the 24th anniversary of the announcement by Pope John XXIII ordering the revision.   The church specialists say the draft of the revised code, reflecting the sweeping changes set forth by the Second Vatican Council of 1962-65, emphasizes meeting people's needs more than issuing strictures. For example, it reduces the offenses punishable by excommunication from 37 to 6.   Canon law defines church procedure based on official teachings, as set forth by Popes and supreme councils such as Vatican II. The code is seen as a measure of how liberally or conservatively those teachings will be interpreted. And though it sets standards, most Catholic officials agree that church government in modern times is effected by consent rather than compulsion.

headline: AMERICAN AIR'S DALLAS COUP
abstract: Displaying an aggressive style, Robert L. Crandall, the toughminded American Airlines president, has by almost all accounts clearly succeeded in making American the dominant carrier at its Dallas/Fort Worth hub.   Since Mr. Crandall took over as president and chief operating officer of the carrier in July 1980, American has been able to consolidate its flights at Dallas and create a stronghold that is even greater than what Delta Air Lines has built up over many years at Atlanta.   But the question is whether Mr. Crandall overstepped the line. The issue arose last week, when the details of a February 1982 telephone conversation between him and Howard D. Putnam, chairman of American's rival, Braniff International, came to light. Mr. Crandall placed the call and in a salty, emphatic conversation, offered to raise fares 20 percent if Mr. Putnam would.

headline: Coradian in Deal
abstract: The Coradian Corporation, a major installer of private telephone systems in New York and New Jersey, has signed a contract with American Telecom Inc. allowing American Telecom to purchase $2.5 million in Coradian securities. American Telecom, based in Anaheim, Calif., is an affiliate of Fujitsu Ltd. and expects to name Coradian as a distributor for some of its products. The deal comes after Coradian failed to reach an agreement with Burnup & Sims Inc.

headline: DAMAGE TO TALKS IS FEARED
abstract: Lebanese reaction to the report by an Israeli commission on the killing of Palestinians at two camps in Beirut in September was muted but there was concern among officials here over possible repercussions on the negotiations on the withdrawal of Israeli and other foreign forces from Lebanon.   The Lebanese Prime Minister, Shafik al-Wazzan, said he would let the world judge Israel for the massacres at Sabra and Shatila.  Government officials said privately they were worried that the commission's conclusions would upset political life in Israel to such an extent that the United States-sponsored talks under way between Lebanon and Israel since December would be affected. Another round of talks was held today by Lebanese, Israeli and American representatives in Beirut's southern suburb of Khalde.

headline: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DELTA DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; Le Jardin's Romance Fragrance
abstract: ''ROMANCE is back in style,'' said Linda J. Wachner, who is betting a bundle on that judgment.  As president and chief operating officer of Norton Simon's Max Factor & Company, she is putting several millions of dollars behind a new fragrance called Le Jardin de Max Factor. Flowery in scent, packaging and advertising, it will get its first network TV support on Sunday, Feb. 27, the start of a five-week, $2.7 million splurge, mostly in prime time.

headline: 2 YEARS OF LOSSES AT HARLEY-DAVIDSON
abstract: When Vaughn Beals led a buy-out of the Harley-Davidson Motor Company from AMF Inc. in 1981, the numbers seemed promising.  Harley-Davidson, beneficiary of the leather jacket/big bike mystique and the only American company to manufacture motorcycles since 1948, had recorded pretax earnings the year before of $12.3 million on record sales of $289 million.   ''It was in good shape,'' said Mr. Beals, now the company's chairman. ''We knew what we had done to improve our competitive position, and we believed that with the continuation of our programs we could be competitive.'' Mr. Beals had been vice president at AMF from 1976 until he and a group that included two sons of the founder of Harley-Davidson bought the company for $65 million.

headline: Bank Board Nomination
abstract: President Reagan announced yesterday that he would nominate Edwin J. Gray, senior vice president of the Great American Federal Savings and Loan Association of San Diego, to be a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the chief regulatory agency for the savings and loan business. Willilam B. O'Connell, president of the United States League of Savings Institutions called Mr. Gray ''extremely well equipped for the job.''

headline: Market Place; The Nature Of Warrants
abstract: THE Chrysler Corporation's common stock was a huge winner on the New York Stock Exchange last year, starting out just above $3 a share and climbing above $18. But, percentagewise, Chrysler's warrants did even better, jumping from a low of 1 1/8 to a high of 10 1/2.   Thus, the old-fashioned warrant, after being upstaged in recent years by explosive trading in listed call options, showed it has some life left -for the right issue at the right price.   Basically, a warrant gives its holder the right to purchase a stock at a set price during a specified time period. In this respect, it is similar to a call option.

headline: ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN CAN FORESEE SUMMIT MEETING
abstract: President Reagan says that he can foresee a meeting sometime this year with Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, but that there are no plans for such a session.   Mr. Reagan made the statement in an interview Friday with The Sunday Times of London that was made public today. He told the newspaper he strongly believed that despite differences between the United States and the Soviet Union ''peace is achievable.''   As to a meeting with Mr. Andropov, he said he was not setting any conditions except that there be advance certainty of ''some significant results.''

headline: Nashua Chief Retiring; Successor Is Sought
abstract: ''I wanted to do it,'' James E. Conway said. ''It just seemed to me like I wanted to be retired. With that in mind, I talked to the directors and decided to proceed with it.''

headline: A Top Official Resigns His May Stores Position
abstract: John W. Boyle has resigned as chairman of the May Department Stores Company in what one trade source called a sort of ''family feud'' among executives.   Mr. Boyle, 54, had been chairman of the big St. Louis-based retailer since 1980.

headline: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES UP 15.7%
abstract: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that the diversity of its product line helped net income in the fourth quarter of last year to rise 15.7 percent, to $112.8 million, or $1.78 a share, from $97.5 million, or $1.51 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1981. Revenues edged up to $3.54 billion, from $3.51 billion.   For the full year, the big Hartford-based technology and aerospace concern increased earnings 16.6 percent, to $533.7 million, or $8.74 a share, from $457.7 million, or $7.71 a share, in 1981. Revenues eased to $13.58 billion, from $13.67 billion.

headline: VW Cuts in U.S.
abstract: Volkswagen of America Inc. has started reorganizing and laying off some staff members in at least one department at its Troy, Mich., headquarters. A spokesman, Ted Kade, confirmed today that William H. Maypole, director of VW's styling design, had left the company and that his position had been eliminated as part of VW's cutback of 1,500 workers nationwide.

headline: Firestone Settles
abstract: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company has agreed to settle a $3.2 million stockholder suit accusing the company of concealing defects in its radial tires.

headline: Harvester Recall
abstract: The International Harvester Company announced a recall of all hourly production employees who had been on layoff status from its Indianapolis engine operations. The last group of 35 employees returned to work Jan. 10, bringing total employment at the facility to 1,242, it said. About 390 foundry workers remain on layoff, and 89 salaried and skilled trades employees have not been recalled, it said.

headline: 5 COMPANIES IN VENTURE TO RUN 2 PAY-TV UNITS
abstract: Three film studios and two companies with major positions in satellite entertainment announced yesterday that they had agreed to form a joint venture to operate Showtime and The Movie Channel, the second- and third-largest pay-television networks.   The partnership - comprising American Express, MCA Inc., Paramount Pictures, Viacom International and Warner Brothers - represents the latest in a dizzying series of maneuvers involving the nation's largest entertainment conglomerates in the widening field of pay television.   In the most recent of several earlier agreements within the industry, Time Inc.'s Home Box Office, the largest pay television network, with 11 million cable subscribers, joined forces with CBS Inc. and Columbia Pictures last month to create a new motion picture company that could provide feature films for the network.   In November, Paramount, MCA and Warner Brothers formed a partnership to buy equal shares in The Movie Channel, which has 2.3 million cable subscribers. And last August, Viacom paid $75 million to Group W Cable for its half interest in Showtime, which has 4 million cable subscribers.

headline: NITZE SAYS HIS EFFECTIVENESS AS NEGOTIATOR IS INTACT
abstract: Paul H. Nitze, the chief American negotiator at the Geneva negotiations on medium-range missiles, said today that he was convinced that he retained ''the authority to pursue a meaningful agreement'' with the Soviet Union.   In his first public comments since the ouster of Eugene V. Rostow as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, Mr. Nitze sought to rebut the widespread view here and abroad that his known effort to alter the Administration's approach toward the negotiations had reduced his effectiveness, or might lead to his resignation.   ''I have had and will continue to have the necessary flexibility,'' he said in comments made to some reporters. As to his belief that the so-called ''zero-zero solution'' would not be acceptable to Moscow, Mr. Nitze said that ''I fully support the United States position, the zero-zero solution, as the best possible outcome for the United States, the Soviets and the world.''

headline: ESMARK TO LIMIT STOKELY STAKE
abstract: Esmark Inc., the big Chicago-based diversified company, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had agreed not to increase its 6.1 percent stock interest in Stokely-Van Camp Inc., the food products company, for a six-month period that began March 11.

headline: A-ARMS OPPOSITION IN WEST GERMANY
abstract: West Germany's Green Party concluded a two-day convention today by confirming that its opposition to the deployment of American medium-range missiles will be the main plank in its platform for parliamentary elections in March.   Petra Kelly, the American-educated Green leader, announced to loud applause that she would hold a ''war crimes tribunal'' next month in her parliamentary constituency of Nuremberg to condemn the United States, the Soviet Union and other nuclear powers for possessing ''first-strike weapons.''   Miss Kelly said she had invited survivors of the Nazi death camp at Auschwitz and Japanese who lived through the American bombing of Hiroshima. ''We want no military pacts!'' shouted Miss Kelly, who like other Greens would like to see West Germany leave the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
