headline: U.S. SENDING BUSH TO EUROPE TO MEET THE ALLIES ON ARMS
abstract: President Reagan, citing ''encouraging words'' from the new Soviet leadership, announced today that he would send Vice President Bush to meet with America's European allies and to address the Committee on Disarmament in Geneva.   ''Clearly, the Soviets want to appear more responsive and reasonable,'' the President said in his weekly radio speech, taking a noticeably temperate tone toward Moscow. ''But moderate words are convincing only when they're matched by moderate behavior.''   Referring to the Soviet-United States arms negotiations that resume in Geneva next month, Mr. Reagan said that ''a serious foundation for progress had been laid'' by the proposals offered from Washington and Moscow.

headline: EATON TO SELL OR END SEVERAL OPTIONS
abstract: The Eaton Corporation announced plans today to sell or discontinue several operations and said it would result in an after-tax charge for the year of about $205 million. The company also said the charge would cause it to have a loss for the year, but did not disclose the size, and said it was cutting its quarterly dividend to 20 cents a share, from 43 cents.

headline: Vietnamese Criticize Reagan On American Foreign Policy
abstract: President Reagan is ''incapable'' and has not learned from his mistakes, the Vietnamese Communist Party newspaper Nhan Dan said today.   ''Reagan's State of the Union message proved that he had not learned sufficiently from his setbacks and blunders,'' the paper said in a commentary.

headline: HEALTH CARE & RETIREMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Careers; Achieving Computer Literacy
abstract: WHAT is computer literacy? Stripped of the mystique that has surrounded the concept for some time, it turns out to be simply another skill.   Dr. Louis Robinson, director of university relations for the International Business Machines Corporation, explained it this way last week:   ''Computer literacy is more often defined as the ability to use computer technology in a particular discipline. It does not imply that the person is a world-class programmer. It is a skill like driving an automobile and being able to know how to get to Cape Cod, for example. That is very different from knowing how to take a car's transmission apart. Kids as well as adults can be taught computer literacy.''

headline: SOVIET SAYS KOHL RECEIVED NO MANDATE ON MISSILES
abstract: The Soviet Union issued a series of news commentaries today warning the West German Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl of retaliation if it took its victory in Sunday's elections as a mandate to proceed with the deployment of American nuclear missiles.   The commentaries followed a barrage of anti-Kohl articles during the campaign that led Bonn to charge Soviet interference. Moscow backed the opposition Social Democrats, saying that their support for a Soviet-American accord on medium-range missiles was the only way for West Germany to avoid the ''nuclear gallows.''

headline: NEW U.S. BONDS YIELD 11.01%
abstract: The Treasury sold $3.5 billion of 10 3/8 percent long-term bonds yesterday at an average yield of 11.01 percent to complete this week's three-part note and bond financing that totaled a record $14.5 billion.   A notable aspect of the week's activity was the increase in yields that investors and speculators required, compared with similar Treasury issues sold three months ago. The pattern of declining prices and rising yields continued in yesterday's trading as prices of outstanding notes and bonds fell as much as a point from the highs set at midday.   ''The auctions were the first public opinion poll of investors since the President's budget message,'' said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc. ''They told us that they didn't like what they heard.''

headline: Circumvention
abstract: To the Business Editor: Earlier this year, the Federal Reserve Board gave the BankAmerica Corporation permission to acquire the Charles Schwab Corporation. As a result, a commercial bank can now engage in retail brokerage services.   The Schwab ruling parallels the Fed's monetarist solution to inflation through a tight money policy. Prolonged high interest rates are arguably a direct cause of the current recession and the Schwab ruling seems counter to express statutory and Supreme Court language. More disturbing, both were made by appointed officials through procedures contrary to the legislative process.

headline: Article 057154 -- No Title
abstract: People Express Airlines won tentative approval yesterday from the Civil Aeronautics Board to fly between Newark and London, and the C.A.B. endorsed the carrier's plan to charge $149 one-way. That's less than half the lowest fare now available on trans-Atlantic flights.   Whether People Express will actually be able to introduce the fare depends on the British Government, which must give its approval.  People Express, which has grown rapidly by offering low fares on its routes in the Northeast and Florida, plans to charge the $149 for its unrestricted economy class and $439 one way for a more luxurious service on the 747-200 aircraft that the company plans to lease.

headline: Beneficial Considering A Switch in Agencies
abstract: For the first time in its 25-year relationship with Al Paul Lefton Inc., the Beneficial Corporation is talking to other agencies.

headline: OHIO ART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Tokyo Trade Warning
abstract: The Japanese Foreign Minister, Shintaro Abe, warned recession-gripped Europe today not to expect more reductions in Japanese tariffs.

headline: OUTBOARD MARINE CORP reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Mexico Clarifies Move On Foreign Reporters
abstract: The Mexican Government today denied issuing a request that foreign correspondents based here submit copies of their dispatches sent abroad.   A Government spokesman said that reports to this effect were the result of a misunderstanding by a junior Interior Ministry official who passed on erroneous information to some correspondents Tuesday, causing alarm within the foreign press corps here.   The spokesman added that it was the Government's intention merely to request that part-time correspondents submit a few samples of their work to become eligible for accreditation.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN TRAGEDY: JAIL PARTS LOVERS
abstract: She and Neil Aggett had been a couple for the better part of a decade. In that time, they both became doctors, then followed separate paths into welfare and trade union activities on behalf of black industrial workers.   Their medical and political preoccupations were similar but not always shared. Often they were so intensely involved in their work that they were apart even when they were together. When the knock on the door they had long expected finally came early one morning 13 months ago and the security police burst in, their working lives were suspended and time froze.   Elizabeth Floyd speaks with tenderness of the morning of her arrest, not simply because those moments proved to be her last with Neil Aggett, but more especially because they were brought so close together before they were parted. For two hours the police searched the house they had shared.

headline: U.S. Diplomat Leaves Soviet
abstract: The United States Embassy said today that Richard W. Osborne, a first secretary, had left the Soviet Union.  Last week the Government newspaper Izvestia said he had been caught working with a device for the transmission of intelligence via a communications satellite.

headline: WALDBAUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Joblessness Rates
abstract: To the Business Editor:   Paul B. Manchester's new unemployment index, reported in your ''Prospects'' column (Feb.6), captures both depth and duration aspects of unemployment severity. Since Mr. Manchester's index multiplies the number of unemployed by the average duration of unemployment, though, it is sensitive to the absolute size of the labor force, which grows over time.

headline: Egypt Cuts Oil Prices
abstract: Egypt, which is not a member of OPEC, lowered the price of its top-grade Suez Light crude oil to $27.25 a barrel, from $29.

headline: Mafia's Help Reported In the Rescue of Dozier
abstract: American and Italian intelligence officials turned to the Mafia for help in locating Brig, Gen. James L. Dozier after his kidnapping in Italy and rescued him the day after a Mafia leader revealed where the general was being held, Time magazine reports in its current issue.   The magazine said the operation was so secret that not even the American Ambassador to Italy, Maxwell Rabb, had been aware of it.

headline: Defense Dept. Contract Data
abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation received $5.9 billion worth of defense contracts in 1982, heading the list of 18 companies that each did more than $1 billion in business with the Defense Department, according to Pentagon data.   The McDonnell Douglas Corporation was second, with $5.6 billion, and the United Technologies Corporation of Hartford third, with $4.2 billion.

headline: HURCO MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Italy Rejects a Plan by Rome For an 'Archeological Park'
abstract: Italy's Culture Minister has vetoed a plan by Rome's Mayor to use state money to create an ''archeological park'' in the center of Rome.   The minister, Nicola Vernola, announced his decision at a news conference Tuesday night, saying $117 million approved by Parliament under a special law is earmarked primarily for the restoration of monuments and not new excavations.

headline: Coca-Cola Net Climbs 14.2%
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company yesterday reported a 14.2 percent rise in fourth-quarter net income, largely because of stronger soft-drink sales.   The company earned $121.3 million, or 89 cents a share, compared with $106.2 million, or 86 cents a share, in the comparable 1981 period.

headline: China Presses Asian Bank
abstract: China is pressing for the disqualification of Taiwan and its own admission into the Asian Development Bank, the last international agency where the island state is still recognized, Masao Fujioka, president of the institution, told reporters.   The question has gone to the bank's board of governors for resolution, he said at a news conference Friday.

headline: Technology; Issue of Deceit In Electronics
abstract: IN the fast-changing electronics industry, getting to market quickly with the latest product can be crucial to success. Two recent lawsuits, however, raise questions about whether the scramble to market is leading to unethical practices.   Last week, the Securities and Exchange Commission accused the Paradyne Corporation of using fraudulent tactics to win a $100 million computer contract from the Social Security Administration.  Because Paradyne's own computers were not ready at the time of its scheduled presentation, the S.E.C. charged, the company showed the Social Security Administration another company's computer with Paradyne's name on it. The company also demonstrated a data encoder that was merely an ''empty box with blinking lights,'' the S.E.C.  said.

headline: Washington Watch; Money Funds And Their Ads
abstract: WASHINGTON THE Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to add a new weapon this week to the arsenal of money market mutual funds in their fierce battle with banks for consumer deposits.   The commission will vote whether to offer for public comment a proposal that would allow the money funds to advertise the effective yields on their assets on a compounded basis. This figure would be comparable to the compounded interest rates now featured in many ads for banks' money market accounts and ''Super NOW'' accounts.   At present, banks are permitted to advertise the return on their accounts on a compounded basis, but money market funds are not. This means, for instance, that over a short period each might return investors an annualized yield of, say, 12 percent, but the banks can boast - often with big numbers in bold type - that their money market accounts yield a compounded annual rate of 12.68 percent.

headline: ANDROPOV CALLS FOR ECONOMIC OVERHAUL
abstract: An article by Yuri V. Andropov today offered the Soviet leader's toughest indictment yet of the country's economic failings and outlined a fresh approach that would combine political flexibility, material incentives and a crackdown on those who, in his words, ''sponge on society.''   The article appeared intended to place as much distance as possible between him and the policies he inherited from Leonid I.  Brezhnev, but it stopped short of specific programs. Mr. Andropov confined himself to generalities, suggesting that he wanted first to hammer home the seriousness of the problems before espousing remedies that could be politically contentious.   The article, running to 8,000 words, was prepared for publication in Kommunist, an authoritative party journal that appears 18 times a year and has a circulation of a million. An advance text was distributed by the press agency Tass on its foreign service.

headline: A BREAK FOR YOUTH COULD BE COSTLY
abstract: THE Administration's proposal to establish a special $2.50 an hour s ub-minimum wage for teenagers seeking after-school and summer jobs i s a high-risk proposal. The likely gain of a youth sub-minimum is t he creation of a substantial number of new jobs for youth. The d ownside risk, however, is that many adult workers from low-income f amilies may find themselves out of jobs. Unfortunately, no one r eally knows how likely it is that this will happen.  Without advocating the Administration's objective, I shall suggest that other options are open to the Administration that would avoid the problems inherent in the current proposal. In fact, a policy of no action might also allow the Administration to reach its objective.

headline: Stocks Off 3.29; Drop Is Broad
abstract: The stock market declined broadly yesterday and showed little reaction to the news that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had finally agreed on a plan to cut oil prices and set production levels.   In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outpaced stocks that rose in price by 1,016 to 545.  The Dow Jones industrial average closed down by 3.29 points, to 1,114.45, after recovering from a loss that was almost 8 points at 1:30 P.M. The two other major indexes also ended lower. The exchange's composite index of 1,500 common shares dropped 0.30, to 86.99, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 0.41, at 150.83.

headline: Bill Rates Increase; 6-Month at 8.225%
abstract: Rising interest rates in the market for Treasury securities will mean that higher rates may be offered on a variety of new savings deposits beginning today.   The weekly auction of new Treasury bills resulted in an average rate of 8.122 percent for the three-month issue, the highest since Nov. 29, and up from 8.055 percent last week. The average for the six-month bill was 8.225 percent, the highest since Dec. 6, and up from 8.144 percent last week.

headline: BUSH SAYS REAGAN ARMS OFFER STANDS
abstract: Vice President Bush, responding to the Soviet rejection of President Reagan's proposal of a worldwide ban on medium-range nuclear missiles, said today that the offer held, but that the United States would listen to any serious new plan from Moscow.   Mr. Bush went from The Hague to Brussels on his tour of capitals of North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries to convince Western European public opinion that the Reagan Administration is intent on seeking arms reductions. The Vice President emphasized that the allied willingness to eliminate an entire class of nuclear weapons was the strongest possible moral position the NATO countries could take.   At the same time, he said, it is up to the Russians to respond.  This approach - stressing morality and calling for Soviet movement - appeared to be the developing theme of the 12-day tour of six alliance countries.

headline: I.M.F. Loan To Argentina
abstract: The International Monetary Fund said today that it had approved a loan of 2.02 billion special drawing rights, a reserve asset based on a market basket of currencies, to assist Argentina.   The loan consists of 1.5 billion S.D.R.'s under a 15-month standby arrangment and the remainder under the agency's compensatory financing facility. The I.M.F. said that, as a condition of the loan, Argentina had agreed to reduce its budget deficit from more than 14 percent of gross domestic product in 1982 to 8 percent in 1983 and 5 percent in 1984.

headline: COMMONWEALTH NATIONAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AN OIL MINISTER'S POEM STOLE THE SHOW
abstract: PARIS AFTER all was said and done, it was Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, the diminutive 37-year-old oil minister from the United Arab Emirates, who captured the OPEC spotlight last week. It was his poem, distributed during the closing hours of the cartel's cantankerous London meeting, that seemed to cause more hard feelings among his colleagues than the discord over prices.   But while his rhymed lament about OPEC's langourous negotiating habits - to say nothing of the obstinacy of his Nigerian colleagues - has become his best-known work, it is arguably not his most important piece of writing.   That distinction belongs to one short passage in his published Ph.D. thesis, which marked him as one of the first Arabs to say publicly that it was the Nixon Administration that encouraged the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to quadruple world oil prices in 1973 by suggesting that the West had few, if any, alternatives to Arab oil.   The dissertation soon became a key document in the once fierce controversy that raged in Washington some years ago over whether the United States itself was responsible for the first oil price explosion and the decade of recession that followed it.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: No Headline
abstract: To the Business Editor:   Professor McKinnon's Jan.23 article is the strongest, clearest and most important statement I have seen on what has gone wrong with the world's economy in the last few years. It is worth a smile, however, to note that like most economists, he seems to wish it were possible to separate economic forces from political forces when he says of the dollar's rise against other hard currencies since 1980: ''The origins of this sharp appreciation now seem partly political and partly economic'' - and then cites two paragraphs of strong political factors.

headline: 8 Iraqi Soldiers Die as Copter Falls Near Italy Military Sites
abstract: Eight Iraqi soldiers were killed today when their Soviet-made helicopter crashed into a mountain near here in the vicinity of important military sites, Italian television reported.

headline: Carborundum Co.
abstract: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) announced it would close two of its Carborundum Company bonded abrasives manufacturing plants, in Niagara Falls and Logan, Ohio, with a loss of 900 jobs. The company, which said it was also closing or selling bonded and coated abrasives operations in Canada, Europe and Latin America, said it expected a $75 million write-down, including operating losses before shutdowns or sales.

headline: MUGABE'S MILITARY AIDE CALLS NKOMO A COWARD GOING INTO EXILE
abstract: A Cabinet Minister said today that Joshua Nkomo had fled into exile because he was a ''paranoiac'' and a ''coward.'' The official denied that the Government had ever planned to arrest Mr. Nkomo or ban his party.   The Minister, Dr. Sydney Sekeramayi, who oversees the armed forces, confidently discounted the possibility that Mr. Nkomo could manage to muster support for an armed insurrection against the Government of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe.   But Dr. Sekeramayi expressed concern that Mr. Nkomo, who crossed the border on foot into Botswana Tuesday night, might exploit recent accusations about indiscriminate killings by Government troops in rural Matabeleland in hopes of getting Western nations to use their aid programs as a political lever here.

headline: ATLANTIC METROPOLITAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MUBARAK STARTING A U.S. VISIT TODAY
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt arrives in Washington on Wednesday for a state visit at a time when the Reagan Administration shares his concern over the sluggish pace of negotiations on the withdrawal of foreign forces from Lebanon.   The Egyptian leader has said repeatedly that if the United States does not speedily obtain the removal of Israeli soldiers from Lebanon, American relations with the Arab world will be gravely affected.   Simultaneously, he has been urging Arab leaders, most of whom have no formal diplomatic ties with Egypt, to act quickly on President Reagan's plan for finding a solution to the Palestinian problem.   The relationship with the United States, Egypt's largest provider of economic and military aid, is still strong, Egyptian officials say. But it is not the close-knit, even cozy, alliance favored by Mr. Mubarak's predecessor, Anwar el-Sadat, who was assassinated on Oct. 6, 1981.

headline: HELIONETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DEADLOCKED EAST-WEST PARLEY REOPENS IN MADRID
abstract: After a seven-week break, the East-West conference to review the 1975 Helsinki accords on European security and cooperation resumed here today with no sign of any change in positions that have produced a longstanding deadlock.   The 35-nation conference opened in November 1980 and the thought then was that it would end in a matter of months. It has turned into an exchange of accusations and counteraccusations reflective of the unraveling of detente, which eight years ago produced the Helsinki accords.

headline: Bolivia Is Reported to Seize Barbie, a Nazi War Criminal
abstract: A convicted Nazi war criminal, Klaus Barbie, was arrested by the police today and taken to a prison here, sources close to Mr. Barbie said.

headline: TRADE GAP WIDENED IN FEBRUARY
abstract: The nation's merchandise trade deficit widened slightly to $3.58 billion in February despite a plunge in oil imports to the lowest level in more than a decade, the Commerce Department reported today.   Imports of some other items, notably cars, increased from January levels, the report said. And overall United States exports dropped even more than overall imports, causing the deficit to rise from January's $3.57 billion.

headline: GANDHI RELATIVE ANNOUNCES OPPOSITION PARTY
abstract: Maneka Gandhi, the rebel daughterin-law of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, said today that she had formed a political party aimed at mobilizing India's youth.   Predicting general elections within nine months, Maneka Gandhi said she had formed party organizations in most parts of India except Kashmir and the northeast.

headline: MOSCOW TO SCREEN U.S. TV NETWORKS' VIDEOTAPES
abstract: Correspondents for American television networks have been told by Soviet authorities that videotapes will be screened at the airport here before permission is given for shipment to or from the West.   Previously, videotape destined for the United States has been subject to clearance only when American crews transmitted it via satellite from television headquarters here. When that route has been taken, Soviet officials have required notification of the subject matter, but have not generally asked for screenings before transmission.

headline: COLONIAL LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Turkish Publisher On Trial for Incitement
abstract: Nadir Nadi, publisher of one of Turkey's oldest daily papers, Cumhuriyet, and a leading Turkish journalist, pleaded not guilty before a military court today to a charge of inciting people to violate the law.   The 75-year-old publisher, who faces a maximum two-year prison term if convicted, told the court, ''I have never incited anyone to crime nor will I ever do so.''

headline: Tinto Officer in Talks On British Steel Post
abstract: Sir Alistair Frame, deputy chairman and chief executive of the Rio Tinto-Zinc Corporation, the mining and manufacturing conglomerate, is reportedly poised to become head of the beleaguered British Steel Corporation. He would replace Ian MacGregor, a former New York investment banker, who is in line to take charge of the National Coal Board this summer.   Scottish-born Sir Alistair, an engineer by training, has been ''approached'' by the government about the chairmanship of British Steel, said an RTZ spokesman, but no decision has yet been made. It appears to hitch on negotiations about the salary and other benefits that Sir Alistair, aged 53, would receive.

headline: AN INTELLIGENCE UNIT IS REPORTEDLY READY TO END OPERATIONS
abstract: The International Reporting Information Systems, a private company formed in late 1981 to gather intelligence, plans to file for bankruptcy, according to several employees.   From the start the company had the reputation, later denied by company officials, as something of a private Central Intelligence Agency for businesses and governments.

headline: PRESIDENT STUDIES CURB ON GAS PRICES
abstract: President Reagan is considering a plan under which natural gas prices would in effect be frozen, Administration sources said today, because of the effects on consumers of sharply rising prices.   The freeze, for perhaps a year or more, was suggested to the President this afternoon at a meeting of his Cabinet Council on Natural Resources and Environment, the sources said. The council is headed by Interior Secretary James G. Watt and includes Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel.

headline: ELGIN NATIONAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BUSTLING AIRPORT IN VERMONT
abstract: For Tom Schmidt, director of operations at Burlington International Airport, the proof is in the parking lot - there is not enough space these days.   Since Nov. 15, 1982, when People Express brought its low fares and no-frills service here, the airport parking lot has been overflowing virtually every day, and expansion plans are in the works.   ''This is an example of deregulation at work,'' said Mr. Schmidt, who is leaving Burlington this month for an airport post in Las Vegas, Nev. Passenger boardings here set a record in December, he said, and ran about 50 percent above the December 1981 level.  Burlington, a city of fewer than 40,000 people, today is served by seven air carriers: USAir, Air Florida, People Express and four smaller commuter lines.

headline: GROMYKO OFFERS NO SHIFT ON ARMS
abstract: Senior West German officials said today that Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, had not outlined any substantial changes in Moscow's nuclear arms negotiating positions during his four-day visit here.   The pressing question of the Geneva medium-range missile negotiations with the United States, which has grown into a major issue in West Germany's election campaign, dominated Mr. Gromyko's discussions with Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, Chancellor Helmut Kohl and other politicians.   Friedrich Ruth, Bonn's top disarmament expert and a participant in the talks, will fly to Washington on Thursday to brief Reagan Administration officials on Mr. Gromyko's visit. Next month, Mr. Ruth will go to Moscow to discuss a broad range of arms reduction issues.

headline: Energy Expert Gets A Top Post at Tosco
abstract: When world oil prices surged during the so-called price shocks of 1973 and 1979, Maurice F. Strong, the peripatetic Canadian businessman and statesman, recognized that developing countries could least afford the increases and would suffer the most.   The recognition inspired Mr. Strong - an energy expert who is well known in most of the world's capitals - to put together an omnibus energy management group to help cash-poor but resource-rich countries to produce fuel inside their own borders.   The Geneva-based and largely Kuwaiti-financed organization, the International Energy Development Corporation, is active now in the Sudan, Australia, Tanzania and Pakistan, among other countries. Last week, Mr. Strong took another step to buttress its development capacity when he was named vice chairman of the Tosco Corporation.

headline: NEW BRUNSWICK SCIENTIFIC CO INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Pacific Telephone
abstract: The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company said in a statement filed in Federal court here that although it was still not satisfied with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's divestiture plant, it now believed that the divestiture would leave Pacific Telephone as a viable entity. Pacific Telephone, which earlier had said that it would be threatened by the plan to split up the Bell System, said it had modified its opinion as a result of Congress's resolution of Pacific Telephone's back-tax case, which eliminated most of its $1.2 billion back-tax liability.

headline: No Headline
abstract: SALVADOR REBELS ISOLATE KEY TOWN A SECOND TIME   SAN SALVADOR, Feb. 16 (AP) - Several hundred rebels attacked the strategic northeastern town of Suchitoto today, cutting it off from San Salvador for the second time in a week, and heavy fighting was reported on the outskirts.   The guerrillas attacked in force before dawn and also seized control of an eight-mile stretch of the 27-mile highway to the capital, military sources said.   In a three-pronged assault, the rebels entered the town's San Jose neighborhood to the east, La Cruz to the south and Santa Lucia to the west.   ''We have three curtains of fire. They haven't gotten inside and we will not let them pass,'' said a national guard officer, who asked not to be identified for security reasons, in a telephone report.

headline: BRAINPOWER: A NEW NATIONAL CONCERN
abstract: AGAINST a backdrop of Disney World's elaborate new celebration of American history and technological achievement, President Reagan earlier this month added his voice to the many who believe America's technological superiority is waning.   ''The number of scientists and engineers engaged in research and development in the United States increased by only 25 percent between 1964 and 1979,'' he said to an audience that included 500 of Florida's top math and science students. ''The increase in France was 90 percent; a 125 percent increase in Germany and 145 percent in Japan,'' he continued. Moreover, he added, Japan, with roughly half the population of the United States, is producing more engineers.   The Soviet Union, Mr. Reagan said, which introduces basic concepts in geometry and algebra in its elementary schools, turns out five times as many engineering specialists each year as the United States. ''Obviously,'' he concluded, ''we must do better or we will be overtaken. In math and science instruction, the United States is a slow learner among the major industrial nations.''

headline: Elizabeth Taylor in Accident
abstract: Elizabeth Taylor was slightly injured today when a limousine taking her to meet Defense Minister Ariel Sharon struck the back of a car in a heavy rainstorm. A spokesman for her during a 10-day visit to Israel said the actress was released from a hospital after aid for leg pains.

headline: THE AIR DELIVERY FREE-FOR-ALL
abstract: The ads for overnight package delivery have a frantic quality.  Couriers and planes race to overtake rivals while hapless customers grow beards and miss business opportunities.   For the industry, things are frantic, too. Just yesterday, Emery Worldwide started an overnight letter service that is now cheaper than the Federal Express Corporation's and handles up to four ounces, compared with two ounces for Federal. The day before, Purolator Courier, a subsidiary of Purolator Inc., had offered an overnight letter at a price that undercuts even that of the Postal Service.

headline: Stocks End Lower; Dow Falls by 7.91; Technology Issues Off
abstract: The stock market ended lower yesterday, after a late recovery erased some of the earlier losses.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which was down 13.15 points at 2 P.M., closed off 7.91 points, to 1,067.42. Analysts said the late recovery resulted mostly from bargain hunting following the loss of 11.77 points in the key average on Tuesday.   However, the broad market for the second consecutive session outperformed the Dow average. Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange just barely outscored stocks that rose by 819 to 768.

headline: NATO Rejects Soviet's Plan For Cutting Nuclear Missiles
abstract: The NATO allies rejected as inadequate today a Soviet proposal to reduce its medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe to 162, matching the total held by France and Britain.   After a one-day meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's special consultative group on arms control, senior officials said the Soviet attitude had been disappointing since the Geneva talks on limiting medium-range missiles resumed two weeks ago.

headline: PRETORIA PURSUING WIDE ANGOLA PACT
abstract: South Africa is seeking to negotiate a ceasefire with Angola as a preliminary step toward settling the tangled issues of independence for South-West Africa and a Cuban troop withdrawal from Angola, Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said today.   He said a cease-fire would provide an opportunity to ''test the ground'' for this wider settlement.  Mr. Botha's account of the negotiations came as a South African envoy, Adriaan Eksteen, was meeting in the Cape Verde Islands with Angolan officials to arrange a second round of ministerial talks.  Discussions were held there last month. The first round, the Foreign Minister said, skirted both South Africa's demand for the withdrawal of the estimated 25,000 Cuban troops as a condition for a settlement in South-West Africa and Angola's charges that South Africa supports the Angolan insurgency led by Jonas Savimbi.

headline: SATURDAY, JANUARY 15, 1983; The Economy
abstract: Factory production fell only 0.1 percent in December, the Federal Reserve reported. The figure was seen by some economists as a signal that the recession may finally be touching bottom, but others were more cautious in their assessments. For all of 1982, the factory production index fell 8.2 percent, its sharpest decline since 1974, in the midst of another recession. (Page 1.) Producer prices rose 0.1 percent in December. The increase brought the rate for all of 1982 to 3 1/2 percent, the lowest rise in 11 years and half the 1981 rate. (31.)

headline: Chrysler Expects $100 Million Profit
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it expects a pretax operating profit of at least $100 million in the first quarter of 1983, compared with a pretax loss of $89 million in the similar period last year. Chrysler made the prediction in an amendment to a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Dr Pepper Drink
abstract: Dr Pepper Inc. said it would begin marketing next month a sugared version of its no-caffeine soft drink Pepper Free, now available only in a sugar-free form. The no-caffeine segment of the soft-drink industry is expanding faster than the industry as a whole, Richard Armstrong, Dr Pepper's president, said in making the announcement. He said that when regular Pepper Free is introduced, the company will expand distribution of both its no-caffeine sodas so that they are available to 75 percent of its distributors.

headline: MARCHER IS KILLED IN ISRAELI PROTEST
abstract: A hand grenade exploded in a crowd of anti-Government demonstrators outside Prime Minister Menachem Begin's office Thursday night, killing one man and wounding nine other people, including the son of Interior Minister Yosef Burg.   The explosion, which was followed by screams and wailing sirens, occurred while the Cabinet was meeting inside to formulate its response to the recommendation of a state commission that Defense Minister Ariel Sharon and three generals leave their posts because of their ''indirect responsibility'' for the Beirut massacre. About an hour and a half after the explosion, the ministers voted to accept the recommendations, but it was hours before this morning's announcement that Mr. Sharon had, in fact, resigned.   Thursday's grenade was either thrown or placed under a van belonging to one of the demonstrators, most of whom had marched from the center of Jerusalem to the Prime Minister's office to demand the adoption of the recommendations and the resignation of the Government.

headline: 4 BANKS END LITIGATION OVER FLORIDA TAKEOVER
abstract: Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., in a move that could speed its eventual merger with the Chemical Bank of New York, said last night that a settlement had been reached to end all litigation involving Florida National, Chemical, the Southeast Banking Corporation and C.A. Cavendes Sociedad Financiera of Venezuela.   Cavendes owns 1,873,938 shares of Florida National, a bank holding company, and had agreed to sell the stake to Southeast, the state's biggest such company. But last fall Southeast ended a seven-month battle to take over Florida National and agreed instead to swap its 23 percent interest in the company for Florida National banking assets.

headline: STRAUSS JUMPS OFF ON CAMPAIGN TRAIL
abstract: Franz Josef Strauss opened the electoral campaign of his Bavarian conservatives here today, saying that victory next month by the opposition Social Democrats could lead to ''the de facto neutralization'' of Western Europe.   In a three-hour speech to some 8,000 festive and beer-drinking supporters in this Danube River town, Mr. Strauss said that a postelection alliance between the Social Democrats and the antinuclear and environmentalist Green Party would yield ''chaos'' and ''street democracy.''   Mr. Strauss asked ''all Social Democrats who really love their party'' to vote for the Christian Democrats and their Bavarian sister party, his Christian Social Union.   ''This is the only way to consolidate the Federal Republic, to bring order to Bavaria, to bring order to Germany, and the only way to save our endangered parliamentary system,'' he said.

headline: CHINA PARTY CHIEF CALLS FOR MARXIST FLEXIBILITY
abstract: The Chinese Communist Party leader, Hu Yaobang, said today that the world Communist movement had suffered ''severe setbacks'' in the last three decades, and he called for flexibility in interpreting Marxist theory.   In a speech marking the 100th anniversary of the death of Marx, Mr. Hu said Marxism was immortal and had inspired ''a worldwide, irresistible historical tide propelling social progress.''

headline: Rolls Airplane Unit Has Loss
abstract: Rolls-Royce Ltd., the state-owned airplane engine manufacturer, said it had a 1982 pretax loss of $132.4 million against a profit of $26.2 million the previous year.  Sales rose to $2.17 billion from $2.09 billion.   Operating profit fell to $126.5 million from $183.3 million, but the company said the operating profit was outweighed by research and development costs and the layoff of about 7,600 workers.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Armco Inc. elected James H. Giffen a corporate vice president.   * Century Telephone Enterprises, Monroe, La., named Clarke M.  Williams Jr. president and chief operating officer.

headline: Foley and Seaman Named to Hall of Fame
abstract: Paul Foley and Alfred J. Seaman, a pair of seasoned pros who rose from the ranks of agency copywriters to become heads of two of the largest companies in the business, have both been voted into the American Advertising Federation's Advertising Hall of Fame.

headline: SALVADOR'S MIDDLE CLASS: A WARY WISH FOR CHANGE
abstract: Tucked into the gentle slope of a hill that rises to some of the city's more exclusive homes is the neighborhood of Miramonte where some of the solidly middle class in this city of half a million live.   These are not the kind of people that visiting delegations from the United States tend to meet. Indeed, a better understanding of the social background of the country's three-year-old civil war can be gotten by spending a day in a refugee camp and the evening in one of the fortressed homes of the upper class.   But the men and women of Miramonte had plenty to say to a visitor about the war and their Government. Many believe that unless opportunities are given to El Salvador's poor, the leftist opposition will be strenthened and their own ambitions threatened.

headline: District Telegraph Hires Gilbert, Whitney
abstract: Gilbert, Whitney & Johns of Whippany, N.J., has become the ad agency for American District Telegraph, which is said to be the country's largest and oldest company in electronic security systems.  These days it's what you call a growth company.   Even though growth in the security sector has been sporadic during the recession, Patrick G. Monroe, A.D.T.'s director of marketing, says his company expects to report a 15 percent profit rise for 1982.

headline: Market Place; Gains Defy Forecasts
abstract: ON the New York Stock Exchange last Thursday, 337 issues sold at their highest prices in 52 weeks, while only one stock set a new low. It meant that the bull market, defying repeated forecasts of stumbling blocks, kept moving ahead nimbly.   What happened to investors' fears of budget deficits? ''I can't get paid worrying about that,'' replied one money manager. ''I have to run the race every day.''

headline: Floating-Note Sale By Hanover
abstract: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, a bank holding company, said yesterday that it was selling two floating-rate note issues totaling $250 million through Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., as sole underwriter.   One issue consisted of $150 million of notes with a maximum maturity of nine years and the interest rate set at 75 basis points, or hundredths of a point, above the bond equivalent rate determined by the auction results of 90-day Treasury bills. Another $100 million of notes, also with a final maturity in 1992, has its interest set at 50 basis points above the bill rate.

headline: Yugoslavia Says Albania Threatens to Use Force
abstract: The Yugoslav Government accused Albania today of ''openly threatening to use force'' against it and demanded an end to what it termed Albania's hostile policy.   A protest note handed to the Albanian Ambassador, Lika Seiti, also attacked Enver Hoxha, the head of Albania's ruling Communist Government since 1944, and accused him of making ''monstrous fabrications'' about Yugoslavia to divert attention from his own problems.

headline: EAST BLOC STRESSES COMPUTERS
abstract: The Leipzig Spring Fair, the premier trade fair for East-West business, emphasized last week the motto ''Programmed Efficiency Through Microelectronics,'' a reflection of what Western business executives and bankers said was a coordinated effort among East bloc economies.   The nations of Eastern Europe are striving, and indeed, must succeed at the use of scarce and expensive microprocessor technology to increase productivity and reduce spending for imported energy and raw materials, to overcome a serious economic slump that has spilled over from the West, these executives added.   Despite the many displays of hissing and twisting industrial robots and flickering display screens on microprocessor-controlled machinery in the fair's 16 sprawling pavilions, Western experts said the capacity of the equipment limped far behind that of the West. There were clear indications, they said, that East bloc companies were stepping up efforts to acquire partners in the West.

headline: AFGHAN ARMY UNITS REPORTEDLY MUTINY AND JOIN GUERRILLAS
abstract: Western diplomats said today that hundreds of Afghan soldiers mutinied and killed several Soviet advisers and Afghan officers in a southern town last week and then defected to the Moslem rebels.   One informant quoted a diplomatic report from Kabul, the capital, as saying the incident involved men of a 1,000-member garrison based in Khost, 100 miles to the southeast.

headline: THE COSTLY BLUNDERS OF CENTRAL BANKERS
abstract: IN the 1970's, the banks were part of the solution. If they had not l ent large sums to less developed countries, the oil shocks of 1 974-75 and 1979-80 would have done far more damage to the whole w orld economy.   Now, in the 1980's, the banks are part of the problem, because they have lent so much to less-developed countries. If economic recovery is slow or weak in the industrial countries, the less developed countries will be unable to service their debts - to pay interest and refinance principal. Worse yet, they will continue to face large balance-of-payments deficits and will be unable to cover them by new borrowings. Moreover, their debt problems may even weaken global recovery.   At the end of 1982, the external debts of these countries (excluding debts of East European countries and of members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries) exceeded $550 billion. Their debts to banks exceeded $350 billion, including about $130 billion owed to American banks. The total debt is sharply concentrated. Mexico, Brazil and Argentina top a short list of large debtors that also includes such OPEC countries as Venezuela, Indonesia and Nigeria. In the 1970's, you could have counted on the fingers of one hand the countries that had fallen behind in their debt-service payments. Now, you would run out of fingers and toes.

headline: WHEN TO SELL IN TELECOMMUNICATIONS
abstract: NOW that the prices of the volatile telecommunications stocks have d oubled since the market began to surge in August, analysts are w ondering if it is time to sell or simply to hold their positions. Ifa n investor believes that history repeats itself, it might be a time t o get out. Twice in the last 18 months, sharp rises in t elecommunications stocks have wilted as anticipated pickups in d emand failed to take shape.   Should an investor who bought California Microwave on Aug.16 at $9.63 bail out now at the $22 level? And what about someone who bought Avantek at $12.63 at about the same time and is now looking at $22 a share also. Or M/A-Com Inc., now at about $23, up from $13.25 in August.   ''People will get impatient'' if prospects for rising earnings aren't in evidence by the first quarter, said William R. Becklean, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company. ''And the risk does exist that the earnings won't be there.''

headline: 3 Assert Justice System In Salvador Is Negligent
abstract: More than two years after four American churchwomen were murdered in El Salvador, little has been done to bring the perpetrators to justice, according to three New York lawyers who recently returned from a nine-day inspection tour of the Latin American country.   The Government of El Salvador ''remains unwilling or unable to translate its promises into the trial and conviction of the guilty parties,'' the lawyers said in a 35-page report on their visit that they plan to make public this week.

headline: Olin Buys Stake
abstract: The Olin Corporation, based in Stamford, Conn., said it had purchased 3.6 million common shares, or 63.4 percent of the common outstanding, of the Philip A. Hunt Chemical Corporation, from Turner & Newall Industries for $25 a share, or about $90.1 million. Turner & Newall is a unit of Turner & Newall Ltd., the British asbestos company. Olin said that it had no immediate plans to acquire the entire equity interest in Hunt, a Palisades Park, N.J., chemicals maker, but that it may purchase additional shares from time to time.

headline: FRIDAY, MARCH 11, 1983; The Economy
abstract: Utilities may charge wholesale customers for the costs of building new electric generating plants before they go into service, Federal energy regulators decided. The move would raise the bills of consumers of about one-tenth of the nation's electricity. The utilities said it would improve their cash flow. (Page A1.)   Two top economic officials cautioned that the recovery may not be as strong as some are expecting. Martin S. Feldstein, the President's chief economic adviser, said January data overstated the upturn's strength. And Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned against ''wishful thinking.'' (D1.)

At the same time, one of the main competitors of the The Wall Street Journal-Europe, The Financial Times of London, said it would add ''comprehensive statistical coverage of Wall Street'' in a new section of its international edition.

headline: IN THE GULF, SPENDING AS USUAL
abstract: Snapshots of economic life in this Persian Gulf city-state on the day after Saudi Arabia said it was ready to let oil prices fall:   - Two veiled women buy $4,000 worth of trinkets at the Reyadh Jewelry Store in the gold souq, paying cash with bundles of banknotes extracted from beneath their chadors.   - Katherine Asquith, a London rare print dealer, arrives to deliver an early 19th-century illustrated book on falconry to a sheikh.  Price: $42,500.   - The Viking Adventurer, Britain's floating arms showroom, docks on a trip down the Gulf with a tempting cargo of tanks and bombs to show the local military. ''Security spending is as strong as ever with the Ayatollah on the rampage,'' a salesman says.

headline: Kenya and Albania Set Ties
abstract: Kenya and Albania established diplomatic relations on an ambassadorial level today, the first formal exchange of diplomatic missions between the two countries, the Kenyan Government said.

headline: PATENTS; Communications Plan Involving Computers
abstract: A communications network for computers was patented this week by staff members of the International Business Machines Corporation. The network, as described in patent 4,376,982, includes a number of electronic devices called requestors and responders, which may be controlled by operators or programmed.

headline: ROOS OF ST. LOUIS FED TO JOIN BEAR, STEARNS
abstract: Lawrence K. Roos may be leaving as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, but his monetarist voice will still be heard.  Mr. Roos, who retires Feb. 1 at the Federal Reserve System's mandatory retirement age of 65, plans to associate himself with Bear, Stearns & Company, the investment banking firm, as a special limited partner and adviser on monetary policy.   ''What that involves is traveling throughout the country meeting with groups of customers and prospects of the firm and, in effect, briefing them on Federal Reserve policy, on monetary policy,'' Mr.  Roos said.   He added that he would work in the St. Louis area for Bear, Stearns in arranging and developing relationships with corporations ''in the merger and acquisitions and underwriting types of activities.'' Separately, he will serve on the boards of several companies, he said, ''but my top-priority commitment is to Bear, Stearns.''

headline: Boeing Jet Approved
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration has approved the Boeing Company's largest jetliner, the 747-300, for commercial service after a four-month flight test program, Boeing said today. The new jetliner accommodates more passengers than Boeing's 747.

headline: Italy Cuts Sentences Of Dozier's Kidnappers
abstract: An Italian appeals court reduced the sentences of 10 Red Brigades members convicted of kidnapping Brig.  Gen. James L. Dozier and ordered a retrial for four still at large.

headline: WIDE CHANGES AT BRITISH BANK
abstract: With the international banking system in crisis and with domestic competition intensifying, the National Westminster Bank, the world's ninth largest in terms of assets, is undergoing a changing of the guard.   Since last August, the retirement of a handful of senior executives has touched off promotions and job switches that leave nine of the bank's 11 top executives in new positions.   And today, in the most important change, Philip Wilkinson, a solid, silver-haired man who describes himself as ''not all that colorful,'' moved up to the post of chief executive officer. He succeeds W.J.  Benson, who becomes deputy chairman in place of the retiring Alex Dibbs.

headline: MERRILL RESHAPING ASIA LINK
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday announced a restructuring of its Asian partnership with Fung King Hey. The Hong Kong businessman, as part of the deal, plans to sell half of his 4 percent holding in Merrill Lynch, currently valued at about $65 million.   The partnership was formed last May, when Merrill Lynch bought 25 percent of Mr. Fung's brokerage and investment firm, Sun Hung Kai Securities Ltd., and 15 percent of his bank, Sun Hung Kai Bank Ltd.  In return, Mr. Fung received $55 million worth of Merrill Lynch convertible debentures and $20 million in cash.

headline: Navigating Sea of Debt
abstract: In September, Jacques de Larosiere issued a blunt warning to bankers and finance ministers: Continue lending to developing nations, he said, or jeopardize ''the stability of the international financial system.''   Mr. de Larosiere, managing director of the 146-nation fund, worked feverishly to see that his advice was followed - and thus became the single most important figure in fending off the economic collapse of Brazil and Mexico, which together owe more than $160 billion abroad.

headline: CENTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

headline: FOREIGN STOCKS MAY SHINE TOO
abstract: NOW is the time for investors to slice off some of their profits f rom Wall Street and invest abroad, say portfolio managers of mutual f unds that specialize in overseas markets. Japanese, Dutch and West G erman stocks have moved up and may be at the start of a prolonged b ull market. Even Australia and Spain, after being shunned by foreigni nvestors, are favorites of some top money men.   The reason, according to mutual fund managers who specialize in overseas stock markets, is that if the American economy continues to recover, other economies will follow and their markets will move up sharply.   It's not that these funds have done particularly well lately. They were left in the dust last year by funds that invest at home and that reaped the huge gains of the 1982 bull market. And they still are lagging. From the first of the year through late last week, the 13 international mutual funds tracked by Lipper Analytical Services were ahead 6.19 percent, compared with an 8.99 percent gain for the 358 equity funds that invest in the United States.

headline: A NEW TRACK FOR CHICAGO'S JMB REALTY
abstract: For more than a decade, Judd D. Malkin and Neil G. Bluhm have taken their share of risks in directing the JMB Realty Corporation, a Chicago real estate investment firm with nationwide interests.   Now, JMB, one of the nation's largest sponsors of real estate limited partnerships, is taking another chance. In a joint venture announced last month with Federated Department Stores Inc., JMB will use its own money to develop five shopping malls.   Until now, the 14-year-old firm has readily invested its own capital in office-building properties. But when it came to shoppingcenter properties, JMB limited itself to less risky deals that involved putting capital raised through limited partnerships into existing, occupied centers.

headline: D'Arcy-MacManus
abstract: Chet Lane, who worked for Alvin Hampel, the chairman of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York, at both Benton & Bowles and earlier at Young & Rubicam, has joined him again as executive vice president/ creative director, a new position.

headline: FROM AREA'S FARMERS, SUPPORT FOR REBELLIOUS COLONEL
abstract: After Lieut. Col. Sigiferdo Ochoa Perez explained his refusal to accept orders to leave his battalion, he invited into his office a group of about 30 community leaders who had arrived to show support for him.   The gesture of the men and women who had left their fields demonstrated one of the major reasons that Colonel Ochoa has been able to disregard an order from his own commanders.   The province of Cabanas is protected by the colonel's 1,200-man battalion, and the farmers, who help by working in civilian patrols, have not been bothered with the guerrilla war in El Salvador since June.   ''He is a commander who works very hard for us,'' said Francisco Raul Maya, one of the farmers who waited outside Colonel Ochoa's office this morning. ''I am a worker in the field, and he protects my fields.''

headline: Coast Thrift Units in Link
abstract: A California savings and loan holding company was given Government permission today to acquire a savings and loan association in Berkeley, Calif.   The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said that the newly formed 1201 Beach Boulevard Corporation of LaHabra, Calif., had acquired the Twin Pines Federal Savings and Loan Association.

headline: Denial by Japanese
abstract: The Japan Chemical Fibers Association today denied assertions by American manufacturers that Japanese textile makers were selling certain products at unfairly low prices in the United States. It plans to ask the Government to challenge the dumping complaints.

headline: HEAD ACCUSES BONN
abstract: A West German holding company and its steel producing group, which operates mills in South Carolina and Texas, formally declared bankruptcy yesterday in West Germany after failing to raise money to pay at least 35 percent of their debts.   The parent company, Korf Industrie und Handel G.m.b.H., had asked a court receiver in early January to protect it from its creditors, after it had suffered heavy losses in Europe's steel crisis.   Under German law, however, the court may only go along with the protection procedures and direct a settlement with creditors if a company can honor 35 percent of its financial obligations. A spokesman for the Korf organization indicated that it had been impossible to raise more than 11 percent of the $306 million owed.

headline: WORLDWIDE DEBT DATA FOR BANKS
abstract: Worried about shaky loans abroad and the threat they pose to the world banking system, 35 international banks today formed a clearinghouse to collect financial information on countries that have problems paying their foreign debts.   The main goal of the Washington-based private organization, named the Institute of International Finance, will be to improve the quality and availability of data that lenders use to make decisions about extending new credit to countries or renegotiating the terms of existing loans.   The clearinghouse, according to a statement announcing its formation, will seek to reassure regional banks participating in foreign loans as junior partners of the giant international banks that their exposure is not unduly great. The major banks are known to be reluctant to let regional banks back out of syndicated foreign loans.

headline: WHEN PLANNING TO INVEST IN TREASURIES
abstract: THIS week the Treasury is selling notes and bonds totaling $14.5 b illion, a record package that is needed to finance a record Federal b udget deficit.   In advance of those auctions, which have been prominent in the minds of speculators and traders for several weeks, dealers in Government securities have already begun distributing and trading the securities. This pre-auction activity has the approval of the Treasury, since it gives dealers more time to find buyers - most of whom are speculators or large instititions - and thereby helps lower the interest rate, set at the auctions, that the Treasury has to pay.    Although individual investors rarely make commitments before the auction, they watch the early activity for indications of what interest rates the auctions will produce.

headline: MRS. GANDHI LOSES GRIP ON 2 STATES
abstract: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi suffered a major political defeat today when her Congress Party lost control of two southern states it had dominated since India became independent in 1947.   Opposition parties swept to stunning victories in legislative elections held on Wednesday in Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka, the only states in India where the Congress Party had not previously been defeated.   An election was also held in the northeastern state of Tripura, where Gandhi nominees failed in their effort to oust a coalition of leftist parties.   While the outcome in the three state elections was a jolt to Mrs.  Gandhi's prestige, her party still controls 15 of India's 22 states, and it has a two-thirds majority in the national Parliament. But the setbacks led to some speculation that she might decide to call a general election before it is due in January 1985.

headline: Litton's Itek Offer
abstract: Litton Industries said 4,018,587 common shares of the Itek Corporation, as well as $18,494,000 of debentures, were tendered as of Feb. 11 under a Litton unit's tender offer.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The pre-eminence of Japanese companies as the world's masters at making small cars was emphasized this week as never before by the decision of the General Motors Corporation to seek assistance from the Toyota Motor Corporation in producing a new subcompact.   Not only will the car, to be assembled at a G.M. plant in Fremont, Calif., be a Toyota design, but it will have a Toyota engine and transmission and the entire 50-50 operation will be under the supervision of a Toyota executive.   G.M.'s need for help from a company that its executives hardly deigned to notice not many years ago raises the question of why the world's largest manufacturing corporation, once studied as the model of scientific management, cannot produce a high-quality small car on its own.   ''The answer is, they can, but they would have to price it at $10,000,'' said Martin L. Anderson, director of the Future of the Automobile program at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The key advantage enjoyed by Japanese manufacturers is an efficiency of production that permits Toyota, for example, to sell its subcompact Tercel in the United States for about $5,000.

headline: U.S. STEEL'S 1982 LOSS A RECORD
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's larget steelmaker, reported yesterday that it lost $363 million in the fourth quarter and $361 million for all of 1982, the largest one-year loss in its history.   The losses were attributable primarily to the weak performance of the company's steel operations, which suffered, like others in the industry, from one of the lowest levels in demand for steel since World War II.   U.S. Steel's latest figures contrasted with earnings of $101.8 million, or $1.13 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1981 and $1.08 billion, or $12.07 a share, for all of 1981. Sales in the latest quarter were $4.3 billion, up from $3.3 billion a year before, while sales for the full year totaled $18.9 billion, up from 1981's $13.9 billion.

headline: British Trade Surplus
abstract: The British trade surplus rose to the equivalent of $910 million in December, from $725 million in November, the Trade Department said today.

headline: A 'DEPRESSING' CAUSE AT U.N.: INDEPENDENCE FOR EAST TIMOR
abstract: From January to June, Jose Ramos Horta prowls the corridors and lounges here, buttonholing African diplomats, holding long talks with two each day. The rest of the year, he works on lobbying the less promising delegates from Europe, Asia and Latin America.   His cause, independence from Indonesia for the half million people of East Timor, loses ground every year at the United Nations.  ''It is very, very depressing,'' the slight, soft-spoken Mr. Horta said in a recent conversation. ''The hypocrisy of certain countries contributes to this fallback in support. An act of typical colonial aggression is carried out by a third world country, but most of the members of the third world bloc prefer to shut their eyes. There is a live-and-let-live principle among third world nations.''

headline: Eurobonds Up; Trading Quiet
abstract: United States dollar-denominated fixedcoupon bonds rose around 1/4 point today in quiet trading.
