headline: France's Bossard Hires Head of U.S. Operations
abstract: Bossard Consultants, France's largest management consulting firm, plans an expansion in the United States and has hired Frank D. Rich for the new job of president of United States operations.   Mr. Rich, 55, most recently was a principal of Case & Company.

headline: Winnebago's President Will Add More Duties
abstract: John K. Hanson, 69, the entrepreneur who founded Winnebago Industries 25 years ago, has stepped down as chief executive. Mr.  Hanson, who owns 45 percent of Winnebago's stock, will continue as chairman.   Ronald E. Haugen, 41, president, was named to the additional post of chief executive. Mr. Haugen, who joined the company in 1960, has spent his business career at Winnebago.

headline: AUSTRALIA'S PERSISTENT SLUMP
abstract: No matter who wins the national elections on Saturday, the severe recession that has gripped this resource-rich nation of 15 million people is unlikely to end soon, analysts say.   Australians, who will choose between the Liberal Government of Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser and the opposition Labor Party led by Robert Hawke, felt the effects of the worldwide economic downturn comparatively late, largely because the Australian economy had been buoyed in 1981 by extensive investments in coal mining, oil exploration and the exploitation of other minerals.   Last year, however, the depressed international markets for minerals, high wage settlements and this country's worst drought pushed the economy into its most severe downturn since the mid-1970's. Upturn in Resources Awaited   ''This is a country that depends on energy resources and largescale farming,'' said Rodney J. Wood, economic adviser for the Westpac Banking Corporation. ''The functioning of these things is only possible in the context of world markets.''

headline: SFM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARMS TO SALVADOR REPORTED AT PEAK
abstract: A senior State Department official said today that the infiltration of weapons by air into El Salvador ''is considerably above anything we've seen before.''   The official also said Algeria had joined such countries as Cuba, Vietnam and Libya in sending weapons to the guerrillas.  The official, who spoke at a briefing, said that officials in El Salvador were worried about the increase in air shipments of arms and that Salvadoran military authorities ''don't have any radar, as they remind me every day.'' He said the Salvadorans would need modern fighter planes to intercept the aircraft from Nicaragua.

headline: TANAKA UNDER GROWING PRESSURE TO QUIT ASSEMBLY
abstract: A recent opinion poll has shown that 75 percent of the Japanese public think that former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka, who is on trial in connection with the Lockheed bribery scandal, should resign from Parliament.   Earlier this month, six opposition parties offered a resolution in Parliament calling on Mr. Tanaka to resign, asserting that his presence ''dishonors this house.''   The 64-year-old Mr. Tanaka has come under increased pressure to resign since prosecutors last month called for a five-year prison sentence on charges that he took bribes of over $2 million from Lockheed Aircraft while he headed the Government in the early 1970's.

headline: ZONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: JAPAN SHARPLY PROTESTS SOVIET PROPOSAL ON SHIFTING MISSILES TO ASIA
abstract: Japan protested to the Soviet Union today about remarks made by the Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, that Moscow might move some of its European-based SS-20 nuclear missiles to Asia.    Japanese diplomats said that Deputy Foreign Minister Toshijiro Nakajima had made the oral protest to the Soviet Ambassador, Vladimir Y. Pavlov, at a 70-minute meeting at the Foreign Ministry.   They said that the session had been acrimonious, reflecting Japanese dissatisfaction with several recent Soviet moves as well as with vituperative Soviet press coverage of Japanese military ties to the United States.

headline: U.S. HAILS DECLINE IN OIL PRICES
abstract: The Reagan Administration today hailed the decline in world oil prices as a development that could speed economic growth, reduce debt pressures and act as a jobs bill in the United States by putting as many as 500,000 peoples back to work.   President Reagan, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige cautioned in separate comments that there could be some short-term disadvantages, but in the President's words the decline ''provides more good news for the world economy.'' The President added that his domestic policies, meanwhile, were ''beginning to bring rich rewards.''

headline: HARD TIMES FOR TRUCKERS
abstract: Once again, troubles are piling up for the trucking industry.  Tonnage and revenues are down because of the recession. Scores of truckers, caught in rate wars following deregulation of the industry, have gone bankrupt. Washington has just imposed a new series of tax increases on truck fuel, truck parts, truck use and truck sales.   And once again, as they did twice in the last decade, the nation's 100,000 independent truckers - who haul 90 percent of the nation's fresh food and half of its steel - are threatening to strike. This time their aim is to persuade Congress to provide some relief from the new taxes. The stoppage is scheduled next Monday.   No one knows how many of the independents - drivers who own their own tractors but generally haul trailers provided by someone else - will heed the strike call or how many other drivers will honor the stoppage if it comes. But there appears to be wide support for some sort of action.

headline: East Bloc Again Warns West on New Missiles
abstract: Soviet bloc nations today issued a new warning of countermeasures if the North Atlantic Treaty Organization goes ahead with deployment of new nuclear missiles in Western Europe.   A communique issued after a visit to East Berlin by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, appealed to West Germany, where he had talks this week, to reconsider its acceptance of the cruise and Pershing 2 missiles.

headline: AIRCRAFT ENGINES: STIFF RIVALRY
abstract: A decade ago, the engine makers for the aviation industry were doing business in a far simpler world. Pratt & Whitney dominated the market, each plane model was matched with a specific engine from a specific company, and the demands of the airframe makers and the airlines were easier to meet.   Today, the Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group has two formidable competitors - Rolls-Royce and the General Electric Aircraft Group, which also has a joint venture with a French company - and each of the more efficient planes, the Boeing 757 and 767 and the Airbus A300 series, can be fitted with engines from at least two of the manufacturers.   ''Things are quite different today,'' said Robert J. Carlson, executive vice president of the power sector of the United Technologies Corporation, the parent company of the Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group. ''The risk is so much greater and the cost of development is so much greater,'' he said in an interview in his office in Hartford.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: DOW FALLS BY 21.96 TO 1,119.78
abstract: Stock prices plunged yesterday as interest rates rose and investors cashed in some of their recent profits. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 21.96 points, to close at 1,119.78.   ''The market is overbought and the profit taking today was overdue,'' said Eldon A. Grimm, senior vice president of Birr, Wilson & Company.   In the previous five sessions, the Dow climbed 29 points and made new closing highs each day, finishing at a record 1,141.74 on Monday.  The two other major market indicators also finished lower yesterday. The exchange's composite index of 1,500 common stocks fell 1.26, to 87.40, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 2.41, to 151.26. The composite index had closed at new highs in each of the last five sessions, while S.& P.'s index had registered four consecutive closing highs until Monday, when it ended unchanged.

headline: Dravo of Pittsburgh Fills a Top Position
abstract: Thomas F. Faught Jr., president and chief operating officer of the Dravo Corporation of Pittsburgh, has been named to the additional post of chief executive, succeeding Robert Dickey 3d. Mr. Dickey, who reaches normal retirement age this month, will continue as chairman through the company's annual meeting in April.   Mr. Faught, who is 53, has led Dravo since last April. He joined the company, a diversified worldwide engineering company, in 1974 as its chief financial officer. He will be the first non-Pittsburgh native to lead the 92-year-old company.

headline: Finnish Voting Starts For 1,331 Candidates
abstract: Finns began voting today in a two-day parliamentary election that will determine whether the opposition Conservatives can break up a center-left coalition that has governed since 1966.

headline: NORTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PATENTS; Three Steps Utilized To Recover Hormones
abstract: The Genex Corporation, a genetic engineering company with headquarters in Rockville, Md., received a patent this week for a method of recovering hormones that are helpful in certain chemical and biological processes within the body.

headline: Latin Production Off
abstract: For the first time in many decades, production in Latin America and the Caribbean declined last year, according to the Inter-American Development Bank. The production decline in the region was an average of 1 percent, the bank said today. Although production figures are not available for before World War II, officials said they believe it may have been the first decline since the Depression.

headline: China Puts Guards on Planes
abstract: China has posted security guards on all its airline flights after a hijacking attempt was foiled in a midair struggle over Shanghai in July, a Chinese airline official said today.

headline: TRAFALGAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REPORT SEES DROP IN U.S. ROLE AT U.N.
abstract: A report last month by a private research organization contends that United States influence in the United Nations has declined and that part of the reason is that the percentage of Secretariat employees who are Americans has declined.  The report has been challenged by some American employees here.   The report, ''Americans at the U.N.: An Endangered Species,'' was published Feb. 13 by the Heritage Foundation, a conservative Washington research group. The report's author, Juliana Geran Pilon, suggested that the decline in the American share of professional posts here, from 14.6 percent in 1972 to 12.6 percent today, made it more difficult to deal with anti-American stands.

headline: Ex-Envoy Denies Role In Guatemala Executions
abstract: Guatemala's former ambassador to the Vatican today denied his Government's claim that a Vatican appeal for mercy arrived in Guatemala too late to save six condemned men.   Ambassador Luis Valladres y Aycinena, whose dismissal the Government announced on Monday, said he was being made a scapegoat.

headline: McDonald's Plan
abstract: The McDonald's Corporation said it had agreed in principle to buy 55 percent of the shares of McDonald's Golden Arches Restaurants Ltd., the franchise holder in England.

headline: The U.N. Today; March 2, 1983
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Trade Law Commission, Working Group on International Contract Practices - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Working Group on International Standards of Accounting and Reporting - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: MCRAE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; De-Emphasis On Drug Issues
abstract: WALL STREET'S typical assessment of ethical drug stocks is that they can provide reasonably dependable earnings during a recession.  The label on this group, as a result, identifies it as a ''defensive'' type of investment. In the last two years, a period marked by a sluggish economy, drug equities have turned in a creditable market performance.   As defined by the Standard & Poor's index for drug stocks, the group rose 14.3 percent last year, about in line with the average of other industry sectors. In 1981, the drug stocks did even better, declining only 2 percent, while the S.& P. 500-stock index fell 9.2 percent.

headline: Delta Air Lines Reports a Loss
abstract: Delta Air Lines yesterday reported a loss of $5.6 million for its fiscal second quarter, ended Dec. 31, in contrast to a profit of $8.5 million, or 21 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARMS MEMO: TWO DEMOCRATS BARRED?
abstract: Senate sources disclosed today that an internal arms agency memorandum recommended that two members of Congress be kept away from arms talks in Geneva. Senator Paul E.  Tsongas, a Massachusetts Democrat, said the growing controversy over the document had prompted the majority of the Senate Foreign Relations committee to move for its public disclosure.   The unclassified memorandum, which has been turned over to the committee, is also said to contain sharp criticism of 18 agency officials. It has become a major point of contention in the confirmation battle over President Reagan's nominee to head the arms control agency, Kenneth L. Adelman.

headline: Nonwhite South Africa Group Is Split on Government Plan
abstract: South Africa's major nonwhite political grouping today suspended the membership of the Labor Party for agreeing to take part in the Government's proposed constitutional revisions.

headline: Lone Star Issues Downgraded
abstract: Lone Star Industries' senior debt issues were downgraded to a speculative BB category from BBB, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.   The rating agency said the cement company's financial condition deteriorated in 1982 because of lower profits and financing related to the acquisition of the Marquette Cement Company.

headline: U.S. Steel Sees '83 Cash Drop
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation is projecting a substantial negative cash flow from its steel operations in 1983, it said in its annual report.   A company spokesman said Friday that the company had made no projection of total cash flow including its Marathon Oil Company operations.

headline: Adelman Panel Will Question; Columnist on; 'Sham' Quote
abstract: Kenneth L. Adelman, making his third appearance on Capitol Hill in his fight for confirmation as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, will be confronted Thursday with a New York journalist who quoted him as calling arms reduction talks a ''sham.''   The Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that Ken Auletta, a columnist for The Daily News, had been called to testify at the same session as Mr. Adelman, now the deputy United States delegate to the United Nations.

headline: HIGH-TECHNOLOGY JOBS GOING OVERSEAS AS U.S. COSTS RISE
abstract: The decision by Atari Inc. last month to move 1,700 assembly jobs from California to Asia has raised questions of whether high technology will revive the American job market.   Many economists and other analysts expect more high-technology companies to follow Atari, a division of Warner Communications, overseas. The hope had been that these companies would provide assembly-line jobs for workers laid off from faltering smokestack industries.   But Atari's move, expected to be completed by July, has dramatically demonstrated that high-technology companies, like the auto concerns and steelmakers before them, are not immune to the higher cost of American labor, especially assembly-line labor. These 1,700 employees at Atari assembled home computers and video games.

headline: TANDYCRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Committee on Nongovernmental Organizations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Development Program Governing Council - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: 740 Suspected Marxists Go on Trial in Turkey
abstract: A mass trial of 740 suspected Marxists opened today, with the defendants facing murder, kidnapping and robbery charges stemming from an aborted leftist takeover of the Black Sea town of Fatsa, the state radio reported.

headline: Australia's Winner Calls U.S. Ties Essential
abstract: Australia's next Prime Minister, Robert Hawke, said today that his new Labor government would pursue a more independent foreign policy than that of Malcolm Fraser, whose conservative coalition was toppled in elections Saturday. But Mr.  Hawke asserted that his country's relationship with the United States was ''fundamental.''

headline: BANGOR HYDRO-ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RONYX CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: Oil Comments By Arab Aide   ABU DHABI, Jan. 26 (Reuters) - Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, oil minister of the United Arab Emirates, hinted today that Arabian Peninsula oil exporters might lower prices because of the failure of OPEC to agree this week on allocating production.   He said in a television speech that the exporters were no longer ready to bear the burden of defending prices set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: U.S. STEEL RELIGHTS A FURNACE
abstract: By dawn it was apparent for miles around that the long-awaited day had finally arrived.  Clouds of bluish-white smoke billowed from the carbon-caped stacks. And gleeful but skeptical workers, some returning from months of unemployment, asked, ''How did it go?'' as they ambled through the plant gates.   For the first time in 21 months, one of the aging blast furnaces at the United States Steel Corporation's Edgar Thomson Works is smelting iron ore, coke and limestone into pig iron. Shortly after 4 o'clock this morning, dozens of workers on the graveyard shift gathered around the furnace to watch the lighting, hoping they were witnessing the start of a lasting recovery in the feeble steel industry.

headline: COMPACT VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Budget Office Recovery View
abstract: The Congressional Budget Office predicted today that the nation's economic recovery would be stronger, at least in the short term, than the Administration itself projected in President Reagan's 1984 budget.   The new Budget Office forecast shows the economy growing by 4 percent between the fourth quarter of 1982 and the final quarter of 1983, compared with the Administration's expectation of only 3.1 percent growth.   The budget office also said it expected the economy to expand by 4.7 percent the following year, while the Administration predicted growth of only 4 percent.

headline: Patents; Classroom Computer Monitor
abstract: AN instrument for evaluating teachers and recording their classroom activities was patented this week. The device requires an observer in the classroom to punch a computer-connected keyboard to select and time various activities.

headline: AGS COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Le Monde Says Soviet Bars Paper's Reporter
abstract: The newspaper Le Monde said today that the Soviet Union had refused to accredit the paper's designated Moscow correspondent because he was too knowledgeable in Eastern European affairs.   Jacques Amalric, the foreign editor, said in an article that the Soviet authorities, ''after more than six months of evasion, finally refused to accredit the journalist that the management of the newspaper had designated to succeed Thomas Ferenczi.''

headline: THE GOOD NEWS ON OIL PRICING
abstract: As the reality of an oil price cut draws nearer, businesses are beginning to count their prospective savings and to anticipate the lift that lower oil prices could provide the American economy.   For some businesses, such as department stores and law offices, the changes may be relatively small. For others, such as airlines, utilities and even vacation resorts, the benefits may be substantial. The United States Postal Service alone would save $35 million a year for every dime gasoline prices are cut at the pump.   ''The oil price run-up was a very important part of the cost run-up for firms during the last 10 years,'' said William C. Dunkelberg, chief economist at the National Federation of Independent Business.  Cuts, he said, could represent ''a major cost saving.''

headline: IRAQIS SAY JETS ATTACKED IRAN
abstract: Iraqi planes bombed Iranian targets at Missan in the southern sector of the front today and new ground clashes were reported by the Baghdad radio.   The radio quoted a communique as having said that the jets made direct hits both at Missan and deep inside Iran.

headline: 9th Kenyan Sentenced to Die
abstract: A court-martial sentenced an air force corporal to death for treason today. He was the ninth man to receive the sentence on charges arising out of last August's attempt to overthrow the Government. More than 900 junior airmen have been sentenced to jail terms of up to 25 years on mutiny charges.

headline: Eurodollar Bonds Gain
abstract: The Eurodollar bond market, which has been flooded with about $5.5 billion in new issues this year, rose today in late trading but not enough to offset Wednesday's sharp drop.

headline: Norway to Open Border With the Soviet Union
abstract: Norway will reopen its border with the Soviet Union, which has been closed for nearly 20 years, to local traffic, according to a Foreign Office spokesman.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA CUTS BLACKS' TAX
abstract: The Government announced today that, beginning next March 1, blacks paying income tax in South Africa would no longer have to do so at higher rates than whites.   With few exceptions, the Government said, the change will mean that black taxpayers will be paying less than before. The announcement was made by Finance Minister Owen Horwood in presenting the Government's annual budget to Parliament in Cape Town.

headline: U.S. AND CHINA PLAN INITIAL STEPS TO REVIVE THEIR MILITARY CONTACTS
abstract: The United States and China agreed today on preliminary steps to revive high-level military contacts that were largely suspended after the Reagan Administration took office two years ago.   Defense Minister Zhang Aiping, in a meeting with Secretary of State George P. Shultz this morning, agreed with an American suggestion for closer military relations and with procedures that United States officials hope will lead to an early visit to China by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger.   A senior American official, in providing details on Mr. Shultz's meetings today, also said Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang told Mr. Shultz he would visit the United States and invited President Reagan to come to China. No dates were set for either visit.

headline: Semiconductor Deficit
abstract: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that it lost $18.5 million in its third quarter, ended March 6.

headline: Chattem's Quencher Moves to Marschalk
abstract: Having completed the acquisition of the Quencher line of lipsticks from A.H. Robins this week, Chattem Inc. announced yesterday that it is moving the products advertising assignment to the Marschalk Company, which handles the rest of its advertising needs.

headline: JAPAN'S BIOTECHNOLOGY PUSH
abstract: In a new red-brick research center here, 70 miles west of Osaka, Hayashibara Biochemical Laboratories Inc. employs 50,000 hamsters - half the number of lab hamsters in the world, the company says - in an unusual process for producing interferon and other experimental substances.   Interferon's effectiveness as an anticancer agent is uncertain.  One problem has been the difficulty of obtaining large quantities of it for clinical trials - a hindrance that the small Japanese concern's method may help solve.   ''Hayashibara has developed a unique, Japanese way of producing interferon,'' said Dr. Reisaku Kono, head of a scientists' group advising the Ministry of Health and Welfare on interferon.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S SPEECH TO LEGIONAIRES
abstract: Following are excerpts from the text of President Reagan's speech to the American Legion's annual conference today, as made available by the White House:   Pursuing a policy of honesty and realism toward the Soviets doesn't mean that productive relations between our nations are impossible.  What is required for such relations is restraint and reciprocity.Restraint must be demonstrated not only by words but by deeds. We respect international law and the independence of other peoples. The Soviets need only respond in kind.   Fortunately, America is far from alone in its quest for a peaceful, prosperous and humane international order. With us stand our friends and allies, in particular the democracies of Europe, Latin America, Asia and the Pacific. With us in spirit also are millions of people in Poland and other Soviet-dominated countries, as well as in the Soviet empire itself.

headline: Surge Seen In Housing
abstract: An interest rate war is ahead, and it could spark a ''major housing recovery'' with cheaper mortgages, according to Donald I. Hovde, an Under Secretary for the Department of Housing and Urban Development. He said banks and savings and loans are ''flushed with money'' since Congress changed banking regulations last December.

headline: Chilean-I.M.F. Accord
abstract: Chile has reached a preliminary agreement with the International Monetary Fund to modify the conditions that the fund attached to a $875 million loan it granted the country last January, Economy Minister Manuel Martin said today. He declined to give any details about the modifications that had been agreed to.

headline: ENVOY ASKS SALVADORANS NOT TO MISINTERPRET POPE
abstract: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador said today that the Pope's call for reconciliation and dialogue in this country should not be interpreted by different groups as support for their own ideas of what dialogue should encompass.   ''The Pope did not say what kind of dialogue he was talking about,'' the Ambassador, Deane R. Hinton, said during a visit to the city of Berlin in the southern province of Usulutan. The city was considerably damaged last month in a battle between leftist guerrillas and Government forces.

headline: Chrysler Canada
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said it wants the Canadian Government to provide $200 million in loan guarantees for the auto maker's 1984 model small-van project at a Windsor, Ontario, plant.

headline: FEW BONDS SCHEDULED THIS WEEK
abstract: Few corporate bonds or tax-exempt debt issues are scheduled for sale this week, and no new Treasury notes or bonds are planned.  Investment bankers noted that some corporate offerings might come to market, since dozens of companies have already registered debt issues with the Securities and Exchange Commission.   Last week six different note issues due in less than five years were offered in the corporate market with little advance notice. On Friday, a day when few issues are normally announced, investment bankers announced offerings of $100 million of Citicorp notes - in addition to the $150 million sold earlier in the week - as well as $100 million of R.J. Reynolds Industries notes - in addition to an earlier issue of the same size - and $200 million of General Motors Acceptance Corporation notes.

headline: SALVADORAN TROOPS REOCCUPY CITY AFTER WITHDRAWAL OF 500 REBELS
abstract: Salvadoran troops walked into this smoldering city Wednesday evening after 500 guerrillas who seized it on Monday withdrew southward, the commander of the Government operation said here today.   Fighting erupted, he said, as some of his 1,000 soldiers pursued the retreating guerrillas. He said 3 of his men were killed and 13 wounded, and put guerrilla casualties at 50. This southeastern city of 35,000 people in cotton-producing Usulutan Province was the largest to be taken by guerrilla forces so far.

headline: Amicon Backs Bid
abstract: The Amicon Corporation said its board had approved its previously announced acquisition by W.R. Grace & Company for $25 a share. The company also said it had filed with the Securities and Exchanged Commission its preliminary proxy materials for a meeting of stockholders to approve the transaction. The shareholders meeting is scheduled for the week of March 7, with closing expected soon after, Amicon said.

headline: Belgian, Thought Dead On Everest, Turns Up
abstract: A Belgian climber thought to have died on Mount Everest two weeks ago turned up safe here today.  Jean Bourgeois, 44 years old, an engineer from Dinant, Belgium, fell Dec. 30 while climbing with an 11-man French team.

headline: ANTI-U.S. FARM RALLY IN JAPAN
abstract: Thousands of farmers chanting ''Down With America'' marched past the American Embassy today to protest growing pressure from Washington on Tokyo to import more United States farm products. It was one of the largest anti-American demonstrations in years.   On Tuesday, 19 farm leaders presented the Government with a petition, which they said had been signed by more than nine million Japanese, urging rejection of an American request for removal of import quotas on 22 farm and fishery items, mainly beef and oranges.  The farmers argue that Japan's agriculture industry would be harmed by increased imports of products that are cheaper because they come from climates that allow more efficient farming.

headline: Shamir Coming to U.S.  To Confer on Lebanon
abstract: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel will go to Washington at the end of the week for talks with Secretary of State George P. Shultz on the negotiations with Lebanon.   Foreign Ministry officials said Mr. Shamir wanted ''to coordinate positions'' with the Americans on the negotiations, in which Israel has been demanding a normalization of relations and security arrangements with Lebanon in return for a withdrawal of troops.

headline: Texas Commerce Bank Fills Chairman's Post
abstract: Charles C. Beall, president of the Texas Commerce Bank in Houston, has been named the bank's chairman.  The bank is the flagship of Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc., a fast-growing bank-holding company with assets of $18.2 billion and 59 banks in Texas and offices in Denver, New Orleans, New York and overseas.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Avon Products Inc. said that it would seek to add 150,000 sales representatives to its current force of 440,000, and that the recruiting drive would be backed up with a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign.   * Data General Corp. announced that it had reduced prices on its 32-bit Eclipse MV/8000 9600 series and 8000 packaged system models by up to 18 percent to make the the units competitive with other 32-bit systems.   * Digital Equipment Corp. said it would refocus its retail store operations to provide more service and support for business and professional customers; the stores will be renamed Digital Business Centers.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: CHRYSLER SETS LARGE SHARE SALE
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation will issue 26 million common shares today, in an unusually large and complex deal intended to eliminate some $1.1 billion in preferred shares now held by Chrysler's creditors.   The announcement was made by Salomon Brothers, co-lead manager of the offer with the First Boston Corporation.  The shares, to be sold to the public at yesterday's closing price of 16 5/8, are expected to raise about $432 million as part of Chrysler's huge recapitalization plan. The proceeds from the sale - the third-largest industrial stock offering ever - plus some 10 million new Chrysler common shares are expected to be given to Chrysler's creditors in mid-May in exchange for $1.1 billion in face value of preferred shares and 10.6 million warrants.

headline: PLASMA-THERM INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Computervision Corp. said it had completed the acquisition of Cambridge Interactive Systems Ltd. of Cambridge, England, and its affiliated marketing organization, Applied Graphics Systems B.V. of Rotterdam, the Netherlands; terms were not disclosed.   * Dart Drug Corp. said it had no plans to make any acquisitions or be involved in any mergers; the statement followed queries about a sharp rise in the company's stock price last Wednesday to a 54 1/4 close, up 8 1/4 from the previous day.

headline: Elephantiasis in Indonesia
abstract: A local newspaper reported today that 24,600 people in northern Indonesia were suffering from elephantiasis, a chronic disease that swells the legs and hardens the skin. It is caused by a certain kind of mosquito bite. The newspaper, Sinar Harapan, said the epidemic was in Sumatra, where a mosquito eradication project is under way.

headline: North Korean Pilot Defects to the South
abstract: A North Korean pilot flying a fighter plane landed in South Korea today seeking asylum, the Defense Ministry announced.

headline: SUMITOMO BANK OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ANGOLA IS REPORTED WILLING TO RESUME PARLEY ON NAMIBIA
abstract: Angola is ready to resume talks with South Africa on independence for South-West Africa, or Namibia, despite the cutting short of negotiations last week, Angola's Interior Minister said Saturday.   A report from the official Angolan press agency, Angop, monitored here, quoted the minister, Lieut. Col. Alexandre Rodrigues, as having said Angola had not ''turned its back on the talks'' and was willing to restart negotiations ''at any time.''

headline: Lower Profits Seen by Socal
abstract: The Standard Oil Company of California, blaming reduced demand for petroleum products and the relatively high contract price it must pay for the oil it buys from Saudi Arabia, said yesterday that earnings in 1982 had falled almost 50 percent from a year earlier. It did not give details.

headline: KING RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WOMAN SAYS PLEA FOR A VISA COST HER A SOVIET CHESS TITLE
abstract: Anna Aksharumova says she believes that Soviet chess officials deprived her of the Soviet women's title because of her efforts to emigrate to Israel.   The winner of the tournament in Tallinn, as widely expected, was Nana Ioseliani, a grandmaster from Soviet Georgia. Miss Aksharumova came in third. She says a ruling by officials in Moscow gave Miss Ioseliani a critical victory over her, and without that ruling she would have been first.

headline: Amfac Acquisition
abstract: Amfac Inc., a diversified company based in Honolulu, said its Distribution Group had acquired the assets of three subsidiaries of Supply Corporation International of Houston. The units are the Tyler Dawson Supply Company, T-D Group and Mar-Ind Supply Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Bethlehem Mayor Bids P.L.O. and Israel Meet
abstract: The Mayor of the Israeli-occupied West Bank city of Bethlehem today urged the Palestine Liberation Organization to negotiate with Israel on the basis of President Reagan's peace initiative.   ''The P.L.O. is the official representative for the Palestinian Arabs,'' said the Mayor, Elias M. Freij, before meeting with Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali.

headline: CONROCK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Washington Watch; Tax Refunds Trail '82 Level
abstract: SOMETHING of a mystery has developed at the Internal Revenue Service. Although some Wall Street analysts have been expecting record tax refunds this year - one predicts they will total $65 billion, up from $55 billion last year - they say they seem to be running sharply behind the 1982 level.   This implies that the Treasury will be scaling down the amounts it must raise in the capital market in coming weeks. The question now, the analysts say, is whether there will be a later burst of refunds that will confirm their prediction, or whether they will prove to have overestimated.

headline: Bradford Suit On Executive
abstract: The Bradford National Corporation, a big bank and corporate services institution, has filed a suit in New York Supreme Court against the Security Pacific Corporation.

headline: Soviet's Top Defense Official Returns to Moscow Suddenly
abstract: Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov, who flew to Budapest this morning for talks with Janos Kadar, the Hungarian leader, returned unexpectedly later in the day.

headline: SHARON SAYS LEBANON POSTS WILL REQUIRE ISRAELI SOLDIERS
abstract: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon said today that the three warning stations that Israel wanted in southern Lebanon would not be mainly for electronic monitoring, as had been reported, but for more intimate intelligence-gathering by contingents of Israeli soldiers and other personnel familiar with the terrain, the language and the local population.   These functions could not be performed by Americans or Europeans, he said in remarks, in English, to a group of American Jewish spokesmen.   As described by Mr. Sharon, the stations would apparently involve a significant Israeli presence in Lebanon even after the main Israeli Army units are withdrawn. He did not disclose the exact number of personnel, but said it would be under 750. Other officials have said that the Israelis at the three outposts would coordinate with local, Christian-led militia in policing the southern part of the country, up to about 30 miles north of the Israeli border.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POST UNFILLED SINCE 1980 MURDER
abstract: On the eve of his departure on an eight-nation tour of Central America and Haiti, Pope John Paul II named a new Archbishop of San Salvador today to fill the post left vacant since the assassination in 1980 of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero.   Monsignor Romero was shot dead as he celebrated mass on March 24, 1980. His murderers have not been identified, but right-wing terrorists are suspected.

headline: American Bancorp Tie
abstract: American Bancorp said today that the Federal Reserve Board had approved the proposed consolidation of it and Central Penn National Corporation into a new multibank holding company to have its headquarters here.

headline: 'Butcher of Lyons' Says He Did His Duty
abstract: Klaus Barbie, the former Gestapo leader who was extradited to France eight days ago from Bolivia, said in a television interview today that he had forgotten his past and that the rest of the world should forget it as well.   Mr. Barbie, head of the Gestapo in Lyons from 1942 to 1944, said he was only doing ''my duty'' when he fought the French Resistance.''

headline: Nu-Med Purchase
abstract: Nu-Med Systems of Encino, Calif., said it would buy five acutecare hospitals, with 657 beds, and seven medical office buildings from Humana Inc., for more than $90 million. It said it expected to complete the acquisition in early April. The properties are in southern California.

headline: Canada Inflation Down
abstract: The inflation rate in Canada declined in December for the seventh consecutive month and finished the year at 10.8 percent, the Government said today. The drop in December, of one-half a percentage point, to an annual rate of 9.3 percent, was due largely to a fall in food and transportation costs, it said. Last summer mandatory wage and price controls were introduced for the public sector, pegging wages to a 6 percent ceiling for the first year and 5 percent for the second.

headline: DYNASCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A GAZA TOWN IS A CASUALTY OF THE PEACE
abstract: Ahmed Hammad stood in Israeli-held territory and gazed through four chain-link and barbed-wire fences, past a blacktop security road and across 50 yards of cleared no man's land into Egypt, where his brother's wife and children were waving to him.   He shouted greetings. They shouted back, the bigger boys lifting the little ones so they could see their uncle through the tangle of metal. ''It is very hard and very sad,'' Mr. Hammad said.

headline: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 9, 1983
abstract: Markets   Stock prices fell sharply as interest rates rose and investors cashed in on recent profits. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 21.96 points, to 1,119.78; in the previous five sessions, it had climbed 29 points, setting five consecutive highs. (Page D1.)   The British pound fell to a record low against the dollar. In New York, dealers quoted the pound at $1.495, a decline of 1.73 cents from Monday's close. The pound, valued at $4.80 at the end of World War II, has most recently been under pressure because of uncertainty over how much Britain can earn from its oil exports. (D13.)

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: G.M. Ohio Plant
abstract: Nearly a year after losing their jobs in a layoff that claimed the entire second shift, furloughed workers began returning to the General Motors Corporation's car assembly plant.

headline: COASTLAND CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Yr to Nov 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Anheuser-Busch
abstract: Dennis P. Long, president and chief operating officer of Anheuser-Busch Inc., said the brewery has earmarked $2 billion for capital expansion projects during the next five years. ''We have and will continue to finance such expansion in large measure through the reinvestment of earnings,'' he said. The company, which makes Budweiser and other beers, said it sold 59.1 million barrels of beer in 1982, up 8.5 percent from 1981 and an industry record.

headline: Dollar Bonds Firm in Europe
abstract: Fixed-interest dollar Eurobonds ended firmer today, but were below the day's highs because of disappointment that United States credit markets failed to extend Wednesday's late recovery, dealers said.   Seasoned issues finished around 1/8-point above Wednesday's close after showing gains of between 1/4- and 3/8-point this morning. The firmer trend in the morning reflected an easing in Eurodollar interest rates and the better than expected bidding at the Wednesday auction of 10-year United States Treasury notes, dealers said.

headline: British Water Workers Vote to Continue Strike
abstract: Britain's water and sewerage workers voted today to continue their six-day strike, ignoring Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's call for a return to work.

headline: Discounting
abstract: To the Business Editor: As noted in ''The Discount Brokers Storm Wall Street'' (Dec.26), discount securities dealers are here to stay. There is no evidence that the advice one buys from a full-service firm is worth its price, and in some cases it is worth less than nothing.

headline: Central Trust
abstract: The Central Trust Company of Toronto, which last month agreed to take over management of certain assets of the Crown Trust Company, which had been seized by the Ontario government, said it expected to make a small profit as a result of the transfer. Crown was one of three trust concerns seized by the government after an investigation into the financing and sale of 11,000 Toronto apartment units.  Central said it would repurchase some Crown Trust mortgages as they mature, and that it would endeavor to renew deposit liabilities as they come due.

headline: FIRST WISCONSIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Your Money; Debt Insurance After Job Loss
abstract: SHERRY ROBERTS is a millworker at the Mayr Brothers sawmill in the economically depressed town of Raymond, Wash. Her husband, Ray, is a dairy farmer. When they began to plan the purchase of dining room and bedroom sets, they looked around them.   They looked at Raymond, a lumber community that suffers a 22 percent unemployment rate, and at neighbors who had made large purchases only to find themselves laid off and hard pressed to make payments.

headline: NORTHERN TELECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Cornell Given Research Gifts
abstract: Three leading corporations are providing gifts and grants totaling $7.5 million for the new Biotechnology Institute at Cornell University, Cornell said in Ithaca, N.Y.   Eastman Kodak, Corning Glass Works and the Union Carbide Corporation will each provide up to $2.5 million over the next six years for basic research in the new institute. Cornell said it expects to provide about $4 million annually to support it.   Robert Barker, director of the Cornell Division of Biological Sciences and coordinator of the biotechnology program, said that the institute's initial focus would be in molecular genetics, cellular biology and cell reproduction.

headline: 11 Cabinet Members Resign in Mauritius
abstract: The left-wing coalition Government of this Indian Ocean island faced a crisis today after 11 Cabinet ministers resigned.

headline: I.B.M. Portable
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation is planning to equip its service personnel with a small portable computer terminal that lets them report to big home-office computers by radio. The terminal is being developed for I.B.M. by Motorola Inc. I.B.M.'s plans were disclosed when the Federal Communications Commission granted it a special waiver of commission procedures. The F.T.C.'s order says the company is planning to build a special digital-radio network with transmitters in 250 cities in the continental United States, Alaska, Hawaii and Puerto Rico.

headline: National Mine Control Is Set
abstract: A Scottish manufacturer of mining equipment announced that it had acquired a controlling interest in the National Mine Service Company of West Virginia.

headline: Internorth to Join A Pipeline Project
abstract: Internorth Inc., an energy conglomerate, said it would join the Energy Transportation Systems Inc. group in a coal slurry pipeline project. Under the project, a 1,400-mile pipeline costing an etimated $3.8 billion would be built to carry 30 million tons of crushed coal and water a year from Wyoming to plants in Southern states.

headline: Technology; Piracy in Era Of Computers
abstract: AFTER a number of false starts against the black market in computer software and hardware, efforts are under way to protect future computer products by making each one as distinctive as the person who uses it and thus harder to copy.   As a result, there may be gradual erosion of the difference between hardware and software and a significant change in the way ordinary users purchase and operate their computers.   Over the short run, manufacturers acknowledge privately, the battle against software pirates is already lost. Most software comes packaged on floppy disks, record-like pieces of plastic that store information. And most computers include utility programs making it possible for even a novice to make an exact electronic back-up copy of almost any commercially available program.

headline: POPE JOHN PAUL INSTALLS 18 AS CARDINALS
abstract: Pope John Paul II bestowed the scarlet skullcap and biretta of a prince of the Roman Catholic Church today on 18 cardinals whom he named last month, among them an American, Joseph L. Bernardin, Archbishop of Chicago.   The Pope's compatriot, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, Primate of Poland, also received the emblems of his new status, although as Primate he had already been exercising his right to wear a cardinal's red within Poland.   The next to the last of the new cardinals to be invested at today's consistory, held in the Vatican's Paul VI Hall before more than 6,000 spectators from all the continents, was 87-year-old Bishop Julijans Vaivods, the apostolic administrator of Riga, the capital of Latvia. Leaning heavily on the arm of a helping priest as he mounted steps leading to the gilt-and-white papal throne, the prelate became the first cardinal residing in the Soviet Union.

headline: Peru Orders Debt Renewal
abstract: Peru's central bank has ordered the renewal for 360 days of all short-term foreign loans of working capital falling due up to Dec. 31, and the renewal for 90 days of all short-term commercial debt maturing at dates up to May 31, according to the Government press agency, Andina.   Local borrowers will be required to pay the central bank the equivalent in local currency of these debt maturities on the day they fall due, Andina said on Wednesday.

headline: Harvard Replies
abstract: To the Business Editor: Dean Richard R. West and Prof. Dennis E. Logue of Dartmouth questioned our ideas about managers' role in our nation's faltering industrial competitiveness (''The False Doctrines of Productivity,'' Jan.9, and ''A Plea to Reject Economic Fashion,'' Jan.16). While we welcome debate on these issues, we believe that their comments are misleading in a number of important respects.   Their case rests on three main arguments: American managers cannot be criticized for short-term thinking because investment in plant and equipment has actually been increasing over the period we consider; the degree of management responsibility for our current industrial problems can be appraised through the analysis of a few financial indices, and such financial tools as discounted cash flow analysis cannot be blamed for our faltering competitiveness because they are in no way biased against long-term investment.   Mr. West and Mr. Logue begin by pointing out that the rate of growth in manufacturing investment was greater between 1972 and 1980 than in earlier years. They argue that this is evidence of United States management's long-term orientation, and chide others to ''look at the facts.'' Let's do that.

headline: PARLEY IN BERLIN COMPARES THE 80'S TO THE 30'S
abstract: An international conference to coincide with the 50th anniversary of Hitler's rise to power drew a parallel today between the current world financial crisis and arms race, and the Great Depression and rearmament that led to the rise of Nazism and World War II.   On the last day of a three-day conference, Prof. Karl W. Deutsch of Harvard University cautioned that the ''experience of 1929-1933 showed that there are traditional, accepted forms of economic policy that are meant to stabilize the economy, while destabilizing society itself.''   ''It was a problem then, it is a problem now,'' he said.  The often highly charged discussions, which took place in the reconstructed Central Hall of the Reichstag, a stone's throw from the wall that divides East and West Berlin, ended this afternoon with an emotional debate in which some historians aggressively defended postwar West Germany against the charge that it failed to come to grips with its Nazi past by repressing the memory of Nazi atrocities.

headline: Dome Petroleum
abstract: Dome Petroleum Inc. of Calgary, Alberta, said it had asked the National Energy Board to authorize construction of its planned British Columbia liquefied natural gas plant and related facilities at Grassy Point, on the north coast of British Columbia.

headline: MERGER ACCORD SET BY DATA TERMINAL
abstract: The National Semiconductor Corporation agreed to acquire Data Terminal Systems Inc. in a twostep transaction valued at up to $50 million, the companies said today. They said National Semiconductor would offer $8 a share for up to 4.31 million, or about two-thirds, of Data Terminal's shares.

headline: MILGRAY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 8 NATIONS PROPOSE A WAY TO BREAK THE EAST-WEST IMPASSE AT MADRID
abstract: Arguing that detente itself was at stake, eight neutral countries proposed a series of compromises today to break the East-West deadlock that has dogged the conference on security and cooperation in Europe, now in its third year.   But the proposals that they advanced before the 35-nation meeting appeared to fall short of what the West had been demanding to support human rights in the Soviet bloc. The initial response from Western representatives was guarded and cool.

headline: Oak Industries
abstract: Oak Industries, a cable-television equipment producer faced with slumping profits, said it was reshuffling its management and would lay off about 30 officers and staff employees. ''It's a fallout of the times,'' said Raymond W.  Peirce, 58 years old, the company's president and chief operating officer. The company has said its problems resulted from cable-TV production difficulties, a flat cable-TV market and three devaluations of the Mexican peso, which have hurt Oak Industries' Mexican operations.

headline: SUNSTATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: COMMODITIES; Cocoa Price Rise Marks Peak Chocolate Season
abstract: From Valentine's Day through Easter, more boxed chocolate is sold than at any other time of year. And if cocoa prices keep rising, this already expensive treat will become even more costly in the months to come.  Cocoa brokers would say that the expense is a function of the supply and the demand for the rich, brown cacao bean from which cocoa is made. And fear of short supply lately has propelled the price of cocoa for delivery in March from $1,383 a metric ton last Nov. 15 to $1,874 yesterday, up $29 for the day. A metric ton is 2,204.6 pounds.

headline: Price of Gas May Rise 25%
abstract: The Energy Department said today that the price of natural gas used in home heating would rise 25 percent in the first quarter from the comparable 1982 period. This would put the average price at $6.17 per thousand cubic feet - 20 cents more than the projection made three months ago.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Whittaker Project
abstract: The Whittaker Corporation said it had obtained a $1.4 billion contract extension from Saudi Arabia for health care services until August 1986. Whittaker said it would manage six hospitals, five outpatient clinics, three dental clinics, eleven dispensaries and a medical air evacuation operation requiring a staff of 6,000. Separately, the Rockwell International Corporation said in Dallas that its Collins Systems International subsidiary had received a $97 million contract to supply microwave equipment and services to Saudi Arabia.

headline: PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; Syria Says It Has Right To Deploy Missiles   DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 19 (Reuters) - Syria, in an apparent allusion to reports that it has acquired long-range Soviet antiaircraft missiles, said today that that it was a nation under threat and thus had ''a natural right'' to possess defensive weapons.    The comment, broadcast by the state-run Damascus radio, did not say whether Syria had taken delivery of SA-5 missiles from the Soviet Union.

headline: Xerox Net Falls 52.4%
abstract: The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday that its net income plunged 52.4 percent in the fourth quarter from the period a year earlier. It cited the weak economy, restructuring costs and currency fluctuations.

headline: THIRD WORLD NATIONS ARE URGED TO BE SELF-RELIANT
abstract: The Prime Minister of Malaysia called on third-world leaders here today to look to their ''own resilience'' to solve their economic problems and to ''stop deluding'' themselves about getting concessions from the industrialized countries.   ''As long as the poor economies are incapable of striking back, we are not going to have one bit of concession from them,'' the Malaysian, Mahatir bin Mohamad, said at a conference of leaders of 101 countries and organizations that call themselves nonaligned. The conference opened on Monday with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India appealing for more aid for the poor nations and for an international conference to overhaul the world monetary system.   ''If we are poor, let us be frugal,'' Mr. Mahatir declared. ''Let us conserve every little strength and resource that we have so that our needs do not exceed our means. If we lack the skills, let us acquire them from whatever source is available. The process is going to be slow and painful.''

headline: Kenneth L. Adelman
abstract: The man President Reagan has selected to head the nation's arms control agency is a 36-year-old Republican who has served as deputy representative at the United Nations, a post that carries the rank of Ambassador.   Kenneth L. Adelman has held that position since July 1981, having been recruited by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate, who was a teacher of his in graduate studies at Georgetown University.   While not known as an expert on arms control, Mr. Adelman served in 1976 and 1977 as assistant to Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld.  He also shares many of the Reagan Administration's skeptical attitudes toward the Soviet Union.

headline: MUBARAK ASKS ISRAELI MODERATION
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, in a speech last night to the Foreign Policy Association, a New York-based organization, called on Israel to show moderation toward the Palestinians.   The Egyptian President, who arrived in New York from Washington, said that ''Jewish communities in different parts of the world are becoming more supportive of Palestinian rights and aspirations'' and that he was ''gratified by the positive response of the Jewish Americans'' on Palestinian issues.   Mr. Mubarak repeated his past denunciations of Israel's invasion of Lebanon and said peace in northern Israel could be secured ''not through conquest, but through reducing tension and building bridges of friendship with Lebanon, Jordan and Syria'' and the Palestinians.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Analog Devices Inc., Norwood, Mass., announced that its board had declared a 3-for-2 stock split in the form of a 50 percent dividend, payable on April 4 to shareholders of record March 18.   * Eastern Airlines, Miami, announced that unaudited figures for the first two months of 1983 showed a net loss of $44.1 million, down from a net loss of $54.4 million in same period of 1982.

headline: TUESDAY, JANUARY 18, 1983; International
abstract: Business and labor officials urged President Reagan to press for a wide array of trade concessions when he meets today with Prime Minister Nakasone of Japan, who is in Washington for a four-day visit. The aim of the trip is to try to repair serious strains in the two countries' relations. (Page A1.) Alaska proposed a $31.72 billion project to carry natural gas from its North Slope fields to a port where it would be liquefied and exported to Japan. The proposal was timed to coincide with Mr. Nakasone's visit. (D13.)   A $20 billion emergency fund would be made available to help indebted countries, under an agreement reached by senior officials of 10 major industrial nations. This Group of 10, whose finance ministers are expected to approve the accord today, would use the fund to increase its current I.M.F. commitment, officials said. (D1.)

headline: PRECIOUS-METAL TRADERS CONVERT GAINS TO CASH
abstract: Prices of precious-metal futures yesterday ran into the inevitable profit taking that occurs after a long advance. Still, gold and silver futures managed to close with modest gains, while platinum finished with a small loss.   What was significant, brokers said, was that the profit taking consisted of converting some recent large gains into cash, rather than any move to sell the metals short. The action came after fresh buying had caused gold and silver to break through strong technical resistance barriers early in the day in New York.

headline: ISRAEL'S U.S. ENVOY IS BEGIN'S CHOICE AS DEFENSE CHIEF
abstract: Moshe Arens, Israel's Ambassador to the United States, has been appointed to succeed Ariel Sharon as Defense Minister, Prime Minister Menachem Begin's office announced today.   Mr. Arens, a 57-year-old aeronautical engineer who holds hard-line views on key questions of Israeli policy, is to leave Washington in a few days to return to Israel.   The appointment is expected to be approved by the Cabinet and Parliament after a week or 10 days of backroom bargaining. The Liberal Party, which belongs to Mr. Begin's Likud bloc, is reportedly asking for additional ministerial and deputy ministerial positions in return for its support.

headline: GASOLINE COSTS MORE, NOT LESS
abstract: In the week since the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced its long-awaited reduction in official crude oil prices, several American companies have made price changes of their own that may confound motorists: In many regions of the country, oil companies have quietly raised gasoline prices.   Industry officials maintain that the increases only reflect the sweeping changes that have taken place in their business.  For more than a year, refining companies have been lowering their prices for oil products faster than crude oil prices have fallen, and this has reduced their profit margins. This trend has developed as the refiners sought to maintain their shares of the market as overall demand declined and surplus refining capacity expanded.

headline: MANY PARTIES COMPETING IN SENEGALESE VOTE TODAY
abstract: Senegalese voters will choose from an array of parties and candidates in elections on Sunday, but President Abdou Diouf and the ruling Socialist Party seem likely to be returned to power.   A complex new electoral code based on the West German and other Western models is designed to assure some representation for the many smaller parties, but it basically insures that the Socialists will retain power, political sources said.   The eight parties and five presidential candidates offer a variety unusual in black African politics. Elsewhere in West and Central Africa, only vast Nigeria and tiny Gambia have multiparty systems.

headline: ALUMINUM PRODUCERS POST LOSSES
abstract: The three largest aluminum producers in North America yesterday reported substantial losses for the fourth quarter of 1982, making the quarter the worst in decades for the industry.   The losses were reported by the Aluminum Company of America and the Reynolds Metal Company, the two largest American concerns, and by Canada's Alcan Aluminium Ltd. The reports followed by a week a loss reported by the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Company, the thirdlargest American producer.   ''It's clear-cut by far the worst quarter'' since at least the days of the Depression, said Ronald Shorr, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company. ''The losses for all four of the aluminum companies were larger than my expectations.''

headline: MOSCOW INDICATES UNYIELDING STAND IN AFGHAN DISPUTE
abstract: The Soviet Union issued a statement through Tass, the official press agency, today declaring that its troops will remain in Afghanistan until longstanding Soviet conditions for their withdrawal are met.   The statement appeared to be intended to reassure the Soviet-backed Government of Afghanistan and to curb speculation in the West that the new Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, might be preparing to accept a face-saving settlement to extract more than 100,000 Soviet troops from a seemingly intractable war.   The statement, while not quite as authoritative as an official Government pronouncement, is regarded as a clear indication of Moscow's views. It reaffirmed the terms set out by the Afghan Government in May 1980 and August 1981, which have formed the Soviet position on the war. These are that Soviet troops will be withdrawn once ''foreign armed intervention,'' meaning Moslem guerrillas fighting with Western backing, is ended. In addition, the Afghan leaders have demanded ''dependable international guarantees'' against a resumption of the fighting.

headline: New Comex Chairman
abstract: The Commodity Exchange in New York elected Oscar Burchard chairman yesterday. Mr. Burchard is president of the Ore and Chemical Corporation, a major metals trader. He succeeds David T. Johnston, senior vice president for E.F. Hutton.

headline: BRITISH LABORITES OPPOSE CRUISE MISSILE PLAN
abstract: Britain's opposition Labor Party made public a party platform today that calls for cancellation of plans to station cruise missiles in Britain and for sharp increases in Government spending. It also reiterated a call for withdrawal from the European Economic Community.   The 15,000-word document is for the campaign in the next general election, which must be called by May 1984. The Conservatives have been in power since 1979.

headline: OIL CUTS LEAD EXPERTS TO SEEK AID
abstract: Less than two weeks after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries cut prices by $5 a barrel, some oil exporting nations are starting to line up for money from the International Monetary Fund and commercial banks.   The actions of such countries as Venezuela, Ecuador and Nigeria follow reports that Mexico, a non-OPEC member that recently signed a $10 billion I.M.F.-designed loan package, may need an additional $2 billion this year because of lost oil revenues.   Mexico could see its oil revenues fall by $3 billion this year as a result of lower oil prices, some officials have estimated.  But Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and international monetary authorities based here insisted last week that the situation is manageable.

headline: PRODUCER PRICES UP 0.1% IN DECEMBER
abstract: Producer prices rose by one-tenth of 1 percent in December, bringing the rate of increase for all of 1982 to 3 1/2 percent, the lowest in 11 years, the Government reported today.    The December rise was markedly below the increase of six-tenths of 1 percent in November and was the smallest one-month change since prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent in September.   Assessing the year's greatly improved inflation picture, economists pointed to the worldwide oil surplus, which has held down gasoline and heating oil prices; abundant harvests, and the lingering recession, which has driven the unemployment rate to 10.8 percent, the highest since 1940. Energy Prices Off in Year   The Labor Department's report said that energy prices actually fell one-tenth of 1 percent since December 1981. Such costs had soared by 14.1 percent in the preceding 12 months.

headline: FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RUMANIA'S EMIGRANT TAX IMPERILS TIES TO U.S.
abstract: The United States has reiterated a warning to Rumania that trade relations between the two countries may be cut back sharply if the Rumanian Government puts into effect a law that would restrict emigration, the State Department said last week.   The warning came amid reports received by the department that Rumania had begun carrying out the law. The measure, announced Nov.  1, would require those wishing to emigrate to repay the Rumanian Government for all state-provided education beyond the compulsory 10 years.   Officials in Washington said the tax, which they thought would prevent most citizens from emigrating, ranged from a few thousand dollars for the equivalent of a high school education to $40,000 for a graduate degree. Property of emigrants would also be confiscated.

headline: A FIELD WITH SOMETHING FOR EVERY BODY
abstract: THE sight of Lee Majors performing superhuman feats as ''The Six M illion Dollar Man'' on television every week for several years p robably stretched people's expectations of medical technology to u nrealistic levels. A ''bionic man'' is not yet on the drawing board.   But there is no doubt that replacement parts for the human body are becoming big business, for their makers as well as for distributors.  Artificial legs, joints, arms, kidneys and larynxes, along with pacemakers, heart valves, intraocular lenses and other medical developments have passed through the test stage into commercial distribution.   A survey of the industries that produce implantable medical devices, conducted by Creative Strategies International, of San Jose, Calif., found that total revenues for seven of the top-selling implantable items topped $1.5 billion in 1982, and projected a compound annual growth rate for the next five years of 22.9 percent.

headline: STRUGGLING TO SAVE THE LOCAL MILL
abstract: FOR decades, this mill town in the West Virginia panhandle was noted in American industry, first because it was one of the biggest company towns in America, then because Ernest T. Weir, the company's founder and a self made industrialist, so fiercely fought unions and the labor policies of Franklin Delano Roosevelt.   Today, the town is talked about for a new reason: Workers, townspeople and company executives have joined forces in an enthusiastic effort to put together what could be the largest Employee Stock Ownership Plan in the country. Under it, the Weirton steelworks, the state's largest employer and its biggest taxpayer, would be bought from the National Steel Corporation by the plant's workers.   Negotiators trying to set up an ESOP at Wierton are reportedly very close to an agreement, and ESOP leaders hope and that a plan can be completed within two weeks so that plant employees will be able to vote on it in March or April.   ''The only way out is to be competitive and that's what this ESOP is all about,'' said Jack Redline, president of the Weirton steelworks, who sees the plan as providing a lesson for industries where labor and management are at odds and which have lost competitiveness because of high labor costs.

headline: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GOLD FEVER IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Even Wall Street's heady performance in the past six months looks skimpy compared with the surge in prices of gold and other mining stocks on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange.   Since mid-1982, the price index of 58 South African gold mine stocks has almost tripled and the index reached a record high of 1,030 today.   The best performers have been a handful of low-grade mines that less than a year ago were closing large sections of their operations as the gold price dipped toward $300 an ounce. The share price of East Rand Proprietary Mines, which shelved a $350 million expansion program last year, has shot up from $6 last June 21 to more than $30 this week.

headline: MEDFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hostile Attempt to Buy Home Federal Cleared
abstract: An official of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has given a green light to a hostile takeover bid for the Home Federal Savings and Loan Institution of Palm Beach, Fla., in an action that could make takeovers of publicly traded thrift institutions easier.   Until now, the bank board, a Federal regulatory agency, has generally taken the position that anyone attempting an acquisition of a publicly traded thrift institution must first get advance approval from the board.   An action by Thomas P. Vartanian, general counsel of the bank board, appeared to modify this position. In giving clearance to the City Federal Savings and Loan Institution, a thrift unit with offices in Florida and New Jersey, to proceed with its hostile takeover bid for Home Federal, Mr. Vartanian said that advance approval was not needed for an acquisition so long as a merger application was filed with the bank board within 90 days of the acquisition.

abstract: Suntory, the Japanese brewer, said it had agreed with the Anheuser-Busch Companies to produce Budweiser beer in Japan starting early next year.

headline: Addendum
abstract: * Mal Ochs Associates, a new media research company, at 55 Whittington Road, White Plains.

headline: OIL STOCKS BATTERED IN A SELL-OFF
abstract: The prices of stocks of major oil companies declined sharply yesterday in response to news that members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Counties had failed to reach agreement on oil production levels and prices.   The sell-off of oil stocks, which left several major issues trading more than a dollar a share lower at the close of the session, was aggravated by the expectation of reduced fourth-quarter earnings for the largest American oil companies. The Exxon Corporation, the Mobil Corporation and several others are expected to report their earnings in the next two weeks.

headline: Market Place; Debt-Free Companies
abstract: THE Masco Corporation, which makes faucets and other products for home and industry, acquired Evans-Aristocrat Industries in December, and more recently it agreed to buy the Brass-Craft Manufacturing Company.   Evans-Aristocrat turns out measuring devices and leather goods.  Brass-Craft makes plumbing products. What these two companies have in common, however, is little or no long-term debt on their balance sheets.

headline: Economic Scene; Deficit-Cutters Vs. Tolerators
abstract: THIS is the time of year when - with the State of the Union Message, the Budget Message and the Economic Report of the President all coming toether in a rush - the Great Communicator must become the Great Bookkeeper. At this point, the public might welcome a guide on the economic consequences of major actions to cut the big budget deficit versus accepting the deficit in a time of high unemployment as a necessary or even a desirable thing.   The contention of the budget-shrinkers, in a nutshell, is that reducing the deficit will bring interest rates down further and thereby stimulate recovery. Lower interest rates, it is argued, will spur housing sales and construction, consumer spending on durable goods and business investment in new plant and equipment, and will aid exports by making the dollar cheaper.

headline: Canada Armory Firebombed
abstract: A group protesting United States aid to Central America has said it was responsible for a firebomb attack on a Canadian Forces armory on Monday. The police said two firebombs were thrown at the armory. A security guard put out the fire before any damage was done.

headline: GERMANS TO ELECT LEGISLATORS TODAY
abstract: West Germans are to elect a new Parliament Sunday in voting that is regarded here and in many foreign capitals as a watershed in this nation's 34-year-old history.   Economic preoccupations may finally sway the decisions of the voters, who are expected to participate extensively in the election.  But for the country's anxious allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization - and for an expectant Soviet Union - it is the crumbling of the foreign policy consensus between West Germany's two big parties that has invested Sunday's vote with such importance.   Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his conservative Christian Democratic Party have campaigned openly as friends of the United States and have warned that a victory by the opposition Social Democrats - in coalition with the anti-NATO Green Party - could lead West Germany on a neutralist course and threaten the Atlantic alliance.   The Social Democrats' underdog standard-bearer, Hans-Jochen Vogel, has replied that his party remains faithful to NATO and ''our American friends'' and dismisses the accusation that he is ''Moscow's candidate.''

headline: BOEING TO STRETCH THE 767 TO HOLD 254 PASSENGERS
abstract: The Boeing Company moved yesterday to close the last significant gap in its family of jet airliners by offering a stretched, 254-passenger version of its new twin-jet plane, the 767.   The move was widely viewed as the Seattle manufacturer's answer to the European A300 Airbus, which is now the only twin-engine wide-body in the 250-passenger class. The A300 has managed impressive world sales over the past decade.

headline: Advertising; Digest: Remember Tulsa!
abstract: IF the Reader's Digest has its way, Tulsa will become to the magazine crowd what the Alamo is to Texans.  That's because media use in that Oklahoma oil town proved that while cable television availability caused an erosion of prime time network television viewing, it had no effect on magazine readership.   To the management of the Digest, the nation's largest magazine - found in one of four homes - this means one thing: Magazines, and especially their magazine, are the marketers' natural addition to a media schedule that will make the almost-total national audiences of yesteryear available to an advertiser once again.   So, in a couple of weeks, a new ad campaign will begin with such headlines as: ''Tulsa is driving the networks nuts''; ''Tulsa is the wave of the present,'' and ''The future of TV can be seen today in Tulsa. And, like it or not, the future is arriving fast.''

headline: SOUTHERN UNION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **
