abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: CENTRAL JERSEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ANDROPOV, ON PLANT TOUR, TELLS WORKERS TO PRODUCE
abstract: Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, took his campaign for labor discipline to the shop floor today, where, according to Tass, he bluntly told workers that the only way store shelves will fill up is if they produce the goods.   Mr. Andropov's visit to the Sergo Ordzhonikidze machine-tool factory in Moscow appeared to revive the sort of sallies favored by Nikita S. Khrushchev. Although Leonid I. Brezhnev also visited workplaces from time to time, Mr. Andropov's visit today was followed by a detailed transcript in Russian that Tass, the official press agency, said would be published in Tuesday's newspapers.   With a bare minimum of the ideological fanfare and triumphant claims that usually accompany pronouncements by Soviet leaders, Mr.  Andropov told the workers that productivity was growing at rates ''that can't satisfy us.'' Statistics for 1982 recently made public showed that output per worker grew by 2.1 percent last year, while wages grew by 2.7 percent. ''You can probably sense for yourself that our economic affairs are not going as well as we'd like,'' Mr.Andropov said.

headline: SYSTEMS ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Soviet Aide Dismissed For Gross Corruption
abstract: The Soviet leadership has dismissed the Deputy Minister of Light Engineering for gross corruption and incompetence, the Communist Party daily Pravda said today.

headline: BRINGING THE WORLD INTO THE CLASSROOM
abstract: When John C. Burton became dean of the Columbia Business School last July, one of his first administrative decisions was to eliminate the school's international business division. But it proved to be the beginning of a series of steps to strengthen the international focus at Columbia.   ''We don't want to say that international business is something separate to study,'' said Mr. Burton in an interview at the Morningside Heights campus. ''Instead we're placing an international emphasis in each of the functional divisions,'' ranging from marketing to finance. Executives who earned degrees from Columbia, he said, would be better prepared to make business decisions at a time when the international economic climate affects even small companies.

headline: Times Co. Sells Educational Unit
abstract: The New York Times Company has sold its Educational Enrichment Materials subsidiary to the school division of Random House Inc., the two companies said.

headline: UNION PLANTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: I.M.F. PLAN HELPS EASE DEBT CRISIS
abstract: Last week the International Monetary Fund took a large step toward easing the world's latest financial crisis. Delegates meeting in Washington agreed to expand the I.M.F.'s lendable resources by $32.5 billion, or 47.4 percent. It is the largest increase in the organization's history, and the United States will have to contribute $5.8 billion of it.   That decision caps, for now, what has been a six-month race against time run by multilateral lending institutions, central banks, governments, commercial banks and debtor countries to stave off loan defaults amid the unexpectedly long and severe global recession.

headline: PENGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1983; International
abstract: Oil ministers from six Persian Gulf countries are to meet today to set a strategy for dealing with price reductions by North Sea producers and Nigeria. Algeria has also called for an emergency meeting of the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to try to avoid a price war, which could bring the price of oil far below the official OPEC price of $34. (A1.) Prices on the spot market for oil dropped further in expectation of a cut by Saudi Arabia and other major producers. (D12.)

headline: TUESDAY, MARCH 8, 1983
abstract: International   OPEC oil ministers who gathered in London postponed their first full meeting until today - and perhaps longer - after Iran insisted it would never agree to a cut in official prices. From the start, participants in the talks have assumed official prices would have to fall by up to $5 a barrel. The potential deadlock reinforced doubts that OPEC can restore its control over oil markets. (Page D1.)   The Bank for International Settlements will lend Yugoslavia $500 million, with $300 million available now, according to bank sources.  (D6.) In Yugoslavia, many experts say the country's widely praised system of industrial self-management has complicated its problems by fragmenting the economy. (D7.)

headline: LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: JAPANESE TO STUDY GUARDING SEA LANE
abstract: On his return Friday from talks in Washington with President Reagan, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone will set in motion a United States-Japanese study on how Japan can take charge of the security of sea lanes in the western Pacific.   Officials said here that the study would last about 18 months and result in the eventual transfer from the United States to Japan of military responsibility for a strategic body of water extending 1,000 miles south of Japan.   Mr. Nakasone, defining the area that Japan will take over from the United States Seventh Fleet, has said it will extend ''between Guam and Tokyo and between the Strait of Taiwan and Osaka.''

headline: Texas General Unit in Chapter 11
abstract: The Texas General Resources Corporation, based in Houston, announced that its Texas General Petroleum subsidiary had filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.   Subsequently, the American Stock Exchange said it had suspended dealings in Texas General Resources common stock, as well as its warrants expiring in 1983 and 1986, and 11 1/4 percent subordinated notes due in 1986.   Texas General Resources also said it expected a consolidated aftertax loss of more than $20 million in 1982 because of write-downs on oil and gas properties in the Anadarko Basin in Oklahoma, operating losses sustained by its drilling subsidiary, problem receivables and interest costs on debt.

headline: CHRIS-CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 31 REPORTED KILLED AS NEW ASSAM VIOLENCE FLARES
abstract: Violence erupted in two areas of the northeastern state of Assam today, reportedly leaving at least 31 people dead.   The incidents, which followed three days of relative calm, appeared to be a continuation of the violence that flared in Assam through last month in connection with the four-day state elections held between Feb. 14 and 21.   The All-Assam Students Union, which led a boycott against those elections as part of its campaign against immigrants, vowed today to topple the three-day-old state government of Chief Minister Hiteswar Saikia. A mostly Hindu political movement led by the students has been campaigning since 1979 for the deportation of hundreds of thousands of immigrants, mostly Bengali-speaking Moslems from neighboring Bangladesh.

headline: Seagram Earnings
abstract: The Seagram Company expects to report that its earnings for the quarter ended Jan. 31 declined from the total a year ago of $77.9 million (United States currency), its chairman, Edgar Bronfman, told reporters after a special stockholders meeting.

headline: 'Framework' Could End Quebec Workers' Strike
abstract: The Quebec government and the public employees unions striking against it announced today that an agreement had been reached on a formula for a solution.   Details were not disclosed but both union and government sources in Quebec and Montreal said the settlement would not erase the decrees by which the Government imposed contracts and ordered wage rollbacks.

headline: EXERCISING WITH VIDEO GAMES
abstract: In the already competitive video game industry, things got fiercer last week with the presentation of a slew of new home-video products. Among them:   * Foot-controlled video games. This summer the Amiga Corporation will begin distributing the Joyboard, a flat piece of hard, black plastic that is to the feet what a joystick is to the hands.

headline: Corning to Cut 1,000 Employees
abstract: Corning Glass Works said it was reducing its work force by more than 1,000 employees nationwide as part of a restructuring effort that will produce a $45 million after-tax earnings loss.

headline: 12 Senators Urge New Japan Car Pact
abstract: Twelve United States Senators, including the two from Michigan, home of the Big Three auto makers, today asked Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, to seek a new accord with the Japanese that would limit even more the number of the cars they send to the United States.   In a letter to Mr. Brock, the Senators said that they wanted a twoyear extension of the current one-year accord, which now limits the number of vehicles Japan can export to this country to 1.68 million - and a 400,000 unit reduction in the ceiling.   Mr. Brock was scheduled to leave Saturday for a trip to Japan to discuss the agreement, which expires March 31. Now in its second year, the accord was first negotiated in 1981, and was to run one year. But the Japanese agreed to extend the 1.68 million ceiling on car shipments for an additional year.

headline: WINTER, JACK, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Israeli Refuses to Take Envoy Post in London
abstract: Eliahu Lankin, who fought against the British as a member of the Irgun underground organization, has refused to accept the post of Israeli Ambassador in London because of the outcry over the appointment.

headline: K Mart Net Jumps 43.8%
abstract: The K Mart Corporation, operator of the nation's second-largest general-merchandise retailer after Sears, Roebuck & Company, reported yesterday that fiscal-fourth-quarter profits jumped 43.8 percent, despite a provision for the closing of certain stores.   K Mart said net income in the period, ended Jan. 26, increased to $165.2 million, or $1.28 a share, from $114.9 million, or 90 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

headline: London Police Capture Most-Wanted Man
abstract: The police caught Britain's most-wanted man tonight after a chase through a subway tunnel just hours after offering a reward for his capture.   The $1,500 reward offered for information leading to the capture of David Martin, 35 years old, wanted for the attempted murder of a policeman, was the first made by Scotland Yard in 17 years.

headline: REGAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NIGERIA TO JOIN OIL PRICE TALKS IN EUROPE
abstract: Nigeria announced today that it would join the flurry of diplomatic contacts among OPEC and non-OPEC nations aimed at preventing the collapse of world oil prices.   The announcement, made public here, confirmed earlier statements by other oil ministers that Yahaha Mallam Dikko, oil adviser to the President of Nigeria, would agree to discuss whether the West African nation would raise its prices by re-establishing the usual premium it charges over basic OPEC prices.   A sharp price cut by Nigeria 10 days ago, which brought its price $4 a barrel below OPEC's benchmark of $34, set off fears that a price war would develop among members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Such a conflict would put some of the heavily indebted members, including Nigeria and Venezuela, into serious financial difficulties.

headline: Big Rise in Failures Reported
abstract: Commercial and industrial business failures surged to 690 last week - the highest number since a record 696 in late August, Dun & Bradstreet Inc. said yesterday.

headline: Israelis Protest in West Bank
abstract: Several hundred Israeli leftists demonstrated in the half-completed Israeli settlement of Efrat in the West Bank today to protest the Government's settlement policy for the occupied area.

headline: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1983; The Economy
abstract: Several major banks reduced their prime lending rates by half a point, to 10 1/2 percent, the lowest level since November 1978. The move, which followed intense pressure by the Administration for lower bank rates, was hailed by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. But the banks, citing a sharp drop in the cost of their funds, denied they were responding to ''jawboning.'' (Page 1.)   A House panel adopted a $4.6 billion bill meant to create jobs and provide aid for the jobless. The bill, a supplementary appropriation for the current fiscal year, is to be debated on the House floor next week. (1.)

headline: MORO'S KILLERS AMONG 32 JAILED FOR LIFE IN ITALY
abstract: An Italian jury sentenced 32 members of the Red Brigades to life prison terms today for the kidnapping and murder of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro and other crimes.   The sentences were applauded by the Government as a major blow to the terrorist gang, which has been responsible for a decade of violence in Italy.   Other defendants among the 63 on trial received sentences ranging from four months to 30 years. Four were found not guilty.  Italy has no death penalty and juries are responsible for deciding verdicts and punishments in major criminal cases.  The defendants who attended the sentencing, held in cages with metal bars, remained quiet as Judge Severino Santiapichi of the Court of Assize read the jury's verdicts and the sentences.

headline: DECLINE IN BOND PRICES PARED
abstract: Interest rates declined slightly late yesterday and prices rose on renewed buying of Government securities after the Federal Reserve reported a smaller-than-expected increase in its basic measure of money available for spending.  However, the Fed also reported that two broader measures of money supply had grown more than many analysts had expected. That tempered the late price rise and it failed to offset the daylong decline prior to the Fed's announcement.  M-1, which measures currency and checking account deposits readily available for spending, grew by only $100 million, to $492.7 billion, for the week ended March 2, the Fed said. Most private estimates had been for an increase of $1 billion to $3 billion.

headline: PRETORIA'S FOES IN I.M.F. FOCUSED ON ECONOMICS
abstract: According to the confidential minutes of a closed-door meeting of the International Monetary Fund, opponents of a recent I.M.F. loan to South Africa sought to make their case against the loan strictly on economic grounds.   Though the opposition was presumably rooted in humanitarian objections to South Africa's racial policies, those who fought the loan argued that the country's request failed to qualify under the monetary fund's economic criteria and that some South African economic policies impeded free enterprise and free trade.   Executive directors of the I.M.F. who opposed the loan - which was approved last Nov. 3 over the objections of 68 countries - said that taxpayers were being unjustifiably required to support South Africa and also that the United States Congress might react by reducing support for the fund.   Opposition in the I.M.F. was led by the executive director from Saudi Arabia, joined by six other directors representing various regions of the third world, including the Indian subcontinent, as well as 15 Middle East nations and 17 African countries. The monetary fund has a total of 22 directors, although not all of them expressed a view on this loan.

headline: ZEN AND THE STANFORD BUSINESS STUDENT
abstract: PALO ALTO, Calif.  IN a darkened classroom, 25 students gather in a semicircle and listen to the soothing tunes of a Hindu musician. Eyes closed, the students sit on the floor, backs straight, hands on thighs, legs crossed. They chant in unison.   On another day, the students again sit on the floor and draw circles on paper. With brightly colored pens, the students create designs inside the circles. They are making mandalas, an art form from India more than 3,000 years old.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA RIGHTISTS UNITE IN KEY VOTE
abstract: A far-right party has withdrawn from a key by-election in South Africa, creating a unified right-wing challenge to the ruling National Party that could endanger its plans to bring nonwhites into the national Government.   The far-right Herstigte Nasionale Party decided Thursday not to run in the May 10 by-election in Soutpansberg, a conservative Pretoria constituency. The decision leaves South Africa's Manpower Minister, Stephanus P. Botha, facing a single challenger, Tom Langley, a Member of Parliament from the Conservative Party.

headline: EL SALVADOR TIGHTENING SECURITY FOR THE POPE TODAY
abstract: Salvadoran officials said today that heavier security than originally planned would be provided for Pope John Paul II because of concern that his visit Sunday might be disrupted.   Msgr. Gregorio Rosa Chavez, the Auxiliary Archbishop, said in a sermon last Sunday at the cathedral here that he knew of plans by an unidentified group to take over the cathedral during the Pope's visit. The Pope is expected to visit the tomb of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero, a critic of the military, who was slain, presumably by rightists, in March 1980 while saying mass.

headline: SAMBO'S FILES REORGANIZATION PLAN
abstract: Sambo's Restaurants Inc., which has been operating under Federal bankruptcy law since 1981, proposed today to settle its debts by giving its creditors control of the company.   Under a reorganization plan filed with the Federal Bankruptcy Court, Sambo's would issued 11.6 million new common shares that would replace its existing stock. The company's unsecured creditors would get about 6.8 million of the new common shares, or 58 percent, as well as $65.8 million in long-term unsecured promissory notes.

headline: Foster Grant Sunglasses In Morning TV Spots
abstract: Foster Grant sunglasses will be promoted in a 100-day television advertising campaign running only on NBC's ''Today Show'' and ABC's ''Good Morning America'' and featuring personalities from those two network shows. The promotion will run on one or the other of the programs five days a week beginning Feb. 28.

headline: THOMSON TO BUY AMERICAN BANKER
abstract: The International Thomson Organization, the Canadian-based energy, travel and communications company, announced yesterday that it would acquire American Banker and The Bond Buyer, the daily newspapers for the banking industry and the tax-exempt bond sector.   The $58 million purchase involves the acquisition of two New Yorkbased publishing companies from the estate of Charles Otis, who acquired them around 1910, and marks the end of a family publishing enterprise.   American Banker Inc., established in 1836, also delivers information to the banking industry through Innerline, a data base.  The Bond Buyer, established in 1891, also publishes The Weekly Bond Buyer, a newspaper covering all fixed-income markets, and the Directory of Municipal Bond Dealers. It also owns Munifacts, a nationwide information network that delivers news, municipal bond offerings and a syndicate service to dealers and institutions.

headline: MRS. KIRKPATRICK URGES U.S. TO ADOPT LATIN MARSHALL PLAN
abstract: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that Washington should initiate a major economic aid program for Central America similar to the Marshall Plan in Europe after World War II.   At the same time Mrs. Kirkpatrick, who has played a key role in shaping the Reagan Administration's policy toward Central America, said the region's leaders had voiced anxiety to her about ''the very large Soviet effort influencing the region.'' She said the leaders also expressed concern about ''subversion, terrorism and guerrilla warfare'' by the Nicaraguan Government.   ''They fear Nicaragua's goals and they fear systematic subversion by way of terrorism and guerrilla subversion,'' Mrs. Kirkpatrick said in an interview. ''They believe there's a plan, and El Salvador is the focus of it today.''

headline: Norfolk Profit Declines 44.2%
abstract: Fourth-quarter earnings of the Norfolk Southern Corporation plunged 44.2 percent, to $80.8 million, or $1.29 a share, from $144.9 million, or $2.34 a share, a year earlier, the company reported yesterday.

headline: Market Place; For Warner, Few Votes
abstract: WAS it a Rothschild who said, ''Buy to the roar of cannon and sell to the sound of trumpets''? That advice can pay off. When the Consolidated Edison Company omitted its quarterly dividend in 1974, the stock quickly plunged 70 percent in value. Later, Con Ed restored the dividend and its shares eventually rose to record highs.   Last spring, Teledyne Inc. tumbled after Carol Neves, a Merrill Lynch analyst, cut her earnings estimate. But Teledyne rebounded in the broad market rally starting in August and, earlier this month, Merrill Lynch rated the stock a ''buy'' for both the intermediate and long term.

headline: AUDIODISK: RECORD OF FUTURE?
abstract: Five years ago, the electronics industry brought out the videodisk, heralded as the future of home entertainment systems. This month, the digital compact disk audio system will make its way into American homes, looking much like its video predecessor and making similar promises.   But marketers of the audiodisk play down the kinship, with good cause: Sales of videodisks have been dismal. The compact audiodisk system, meanwhile, is expected by many in the industry to replace stereo turntables and albums as the industry standard within the decade.

headline: GREATE BAY CASINO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Burnup & Sims President Stays
abstract: Nick A. Caporella agreed today to remain interim president and chief executive officer of Burnup & Sims Inc., which is fighting a takeover offer from financier Victor Posner.   Mr. Caporella quit last September after telling the board he would not work for Mr. Posner, who had just acquired 29 percent of the company, but he returned a month later at the request of the board that he stay at the telecommunication company until Jan. 1.  Yesterday, he said, ''A solution to the Posner problem may well be at hand, either on an amicable basis or by court order.

headline: Arafat Says Israelis Showed Weakness in Siege of Beirut
abstract: Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that if a single Arab power had joined in the war in Lebanon last summer, ''Israel would have been defeated and we would have entered Jerusalem.''   Mr. Arafat, speaking at a congress of the Sudan's ruling Socialist Union, said he had never seen the Israelis so weak as during the siege of Beirut, when, he said, he had only 14,000 fighting men to their 170,000.

headline: CITY'S SAVINGS BANKS STRONGER
abstract: As a result of lower interest rates, New York City's savings banks have been cutting their losses and are financially stronger today than they have been in years.   Although a handful are still in danger of failing, it appears that most that have survived so far will not go under - so long as interest rates remain at or below current levels. Even if a savings bank is forced out of business as a result of its losses, depositors are protected by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.   ''Things are looking much brighter for us,'' said John W. Sapanski, senior executive vice president of the Dime Savings Bank. Dime's operating loss was halved, to $16.6 million, in the fourth quarter of 1982, from $33.5 million in the comparable period of 1981.

headline: SHINN TO LEAVE FIRST BOSTON
abstract: George L. Shinn surprised Wall Street yesterday with the announcement that he planned to resign in April from his posts at the First Boston Corporation at the age of 60.   ''It may have come as a surprise to some people,'' Mr. Shinn said, ''but for me it was a longstanding plan.'' In 1975, Mr. Shinn left the presidency of Merrill Lynch & Company to join First Boston, a Wall Street investment banking firm.  Mr. Shinn is chairman and chief executive of First Boston Inc., the holding company, and of the First Boston Corporation. He said he would retire from both firms at the shareholders' meeting scheduled for April 19.

headline: The U.N. Today; March 14, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M.  to 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Statistical Commission - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Dean Witter Sets Refunds to Clients
abstract: Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said it would reimburse clients who suffered losses by purchasing stock in Millicom Inc., a company it had recommended. But the firm said it considered the case to be unique and that it would not protect customers from losses on every investment.

headline: JUSTICES HEAR SEX-BASED PENSION CASE
abstract: A pension case that may have far-reaching implications for employees of state and local governments and nonprofit institutions reached the Supreme Court today. The Justices heard arguments on whether the Federal law against sex discrimination in employment outlaws retirement plans that pay women lower monthly benefits than men.   Women live, on the average, eight years longer than men. Insurance companies typically structure their annuity plans to give women a lower monthly payout in the expectation that women will live to collect more monthly benefits and will ultimately receive the same total as men.

headline: GROMYKO ASKS U.S. MISSILE OFFER
abstract: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said today in an interview in Pravda that there had been no change in the attitude of the West on medium-range missiles despite talk about adopting a more flexible position.   ''Regrettably, while there is talk, one fails so far to perceive any headway toward greater realism,'' he said.  Mr. Gromyko said there could still be agreement in the Geneva negotiations.  ''Objectively, such a possibility does exist,'' he said. ''The Soviet proposals are geared precisely to the attainment of an agreement. We are for an accord conforming to the principle of equality and equal security, and if Washington gives up its insistence on breaking parity and adopts a constructive approach, there can be no doubt that an agreement is possible. It is now the turn of the United States to speak up.''

headline: REAGAN INTENSIFIES DRIVE TO PROMOTE POLICIES IN EUROPE
abstract: The United States, alarmed by reports from its embassies of diminishing Western European support for many of its policies, is mounting an effort to improve its public relations in foreign affairs, Administration officials said today.   They disclosed two related decisions by President Reagan to meet what one official said was a problem in ''public diplomacy.'' William P. Clark, the national security adviser, has been asked to head a Cabinet-level committee to promote diplomatic, military and arms control policies in general.   In addition, as a specific response to mounting Western European opposition to the deployment of new American medium-range missiles, Mr. Reagan asked Peter H. Dailey, his 1980 campaign advertising manager and now Ambassador to Ireland, to lead an effort to win backing for American policy on the missiles.
*3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Irish Police Official Says Race Horse May Be Dead
abstract: A high-ranking police official involved in the search for the Aga Khan's stolen $13 million race horse said today that ''I must now take seriously the possibility that Shergar is dead.''   The official, Chief Superintendent James Murphy, taking part in the nationwide hunt for the armed gang that took the horse from the Aga Khan's Ballymany stud farm Tuesday night, said the police were reconsidering earlier judgments that a series of telephone calls to Northern Ireland last week were a hoax.   The callers told the wife of the trainer Jeremy Maxwell and the BBC's office in Belfast that the horse had been injured thrashing about in its trailer and had had to be killed.

headline: THE RISE IN WORKER BUY-OUTS
abstract: Last November, Honeywell Inc. announced mixed tidings for employees of its information systems unit. A total of 1,850 jobs were to be eliminated, but those employees who qualified could choose early retirement, pocketing a pension as well as cash payments equivalent to their Social Security benefits.   In the end, like thousands of workers in troubled industries across the country, 100 of the employees took the early retirement option.  They saw in the company buy-out program an opportunity either to leave the work force, living on their benefits, or to start another job with a supplemental income guaranteed.

headline: Harvester Venture
abstract: The International Harvester Company and Massey-Ferguson Ltd.'s French subsidiaries signed an agreement to consider a joint farm machinery venture, a Harvester spokesman said.  As previously announced, the companies had been holding preliminary talks about making farm equipment parts for each other, including tractor cabs and castings.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Article 247711 -- No Title
abstract: The American Motors Corporation lost $2.9 million in the fourth quarter of 1982, its 11th-straight quarterly deficit, bringing its losses for the year to $153.5 million, the auto maker said today.   The 1982 loss is higher than a year earlier, when the No.4 domestic auto maker lost $136.6 million. However, the fourth-quarter deficit is down sharply from the comparable period a year earlier, when the company lost $47.2 million, A.M.C. said.

headline: Toyota and G.M.  Set U.S. Venture
abstract: Toyota and the General Motors Corporation have reached a broad agreement on a joint venture to make between 200,000 and 300,000 front-wheel-drive cars a year, Toyota sources said.   They said production was expected to start in 1985 at an idle G.M.  plant at Fremont, Calif.

headline: CLOSING IN ON R.J. REYNOLDS
abstract: For the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, it has been a nice quarter of a century: with its array of Winston, Salem, Camel and Vantage, among other brands, it has sold more cigarettes in the United States than anyone else for 25 consecutive years. For most of that time, Reynolds was so far ahead of its closest pursuer that there was no need to look back.   The string, however, may be about to snap. Philip Morris Inc., which makes Marlboro, Benson & Hedges, Merit and Virginia Slims, has been gaining ground at such a breathless clip that it finished 1982 just a hair behind Reynolds.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Action Industries Inc., Cheswick, Pa., said a shareholder group had filed a suit against the company charging that it had misled shareholders about its condition.   * General Electric Co. said its General Electric Venture Capital Corp. unit had increased its stake in Gearhart Industries Inc. to 18.2 percent of the common shares outstanding, through open-market purchases.

headline: European Liberals Urge Release of Shcharansky
abstract: West European Liberals appealed to Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, today to free Anatoly B.  Shcharansky, the imprisoned dissident, and allow him to emigrate to Israel.   In a letter to Mr. Andropov, the Federation of European Liberals and Democrats and the Liberal group in the European Parliament said Moscow must respect human rights if it was to win the trust of the West on other issues.   The letter, delivered to the Soviet Embassy in Brussels, referred to the ''intense suffering'' of Mr. Shcharansky.

headline: A Greenpeace Trawler Seized in French Harbor
abstract: French officials, backed by policemen firing tear gas grenades, seized a trawler of the Greenpeace environmental movement today after it forced its way into this port in an attempt to prevent delivery of 24 tons of Japanese nuclear waste for reprocessing in France.   The 500-ton Sirius, with two dozen antinuclear activists and reporters aboard, was towed to the Cherbourg dockyard, where it was being held.

headline: Economic Scene; Gold, Inflation And Deflation
abstract: THE plunge in the price of gold to $400 an ounce this week, sparked by the unloading of bullion by Middle Eastern oil-producing countries, marks one more sickening lurch in the roller-coaster ride gold has taken since the Bretton Woods monetary system broke down in 1971.   After President Nixon shut the gold window in 1971, ending the convertibility of the dollar into gold at the official price of $35 an ounce, gold climbed to $197.50 in 1974, fell to a low of $103 in 1976, climbed to $850 in 1980, and is now more than halfway back to where it came from, ending yesterday at $414, a rise of $5.50 for the day. The drop in inflationary expectations, focusing on the oil price fall, is making gold dangerous to hold.   But what are the implications of the falling gold price for the world's monetary system and its economy? Some economists are worried that the post-Bretton Woods floating-rate system, with no dollar-gold link, has been first a breeder of the worst peacetime inflation the world has known and now is threatening serious deflation.

headline: NATIONAL DATA COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; Parker Brothers Diversifies
abstract: AS it moves with strength into its 100th anniversary year, Parker Brothers, the Beverly, Mass., games experts, is making a major diversification move into children's book publishing. And it plans to add an ingredient that it believes has been missing in the field up to now -aggressive marketing.   The venture is the first one from the company's recently formed new-business development unit that is headed by James A. Buchanan, and it comes while management is still euphoric over last year's exceedingly successful entry into the video games software business.   The new technology may be crowding in on the nursery, but as Mr.  Buchanan put it yesterday at a breakfast with the news media in the Helmsley Palace, ''Despite video, kids still like books and crayons and jumping up and down.''

headline: RYAN HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Marcos Calls Premier Most Likely Successor
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today described Prime Minister Cesar Virata as his most likely successor.  Mr. Marcos, 65 years old, said in an interview that if he were to die or be disabled before his term ended in 1987, the Prime Minister would have the support of the Cabinet, the military and the First Lady, Imelda Marcos. In such a case, a 10-member executive committee headed by the Prime Minister takes over the presidency until an election can be held.

headline: HUNGRY TIGER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 18
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Braniff-Eastern Deal Advances
abstract: An administrative law judge, Elias Rodriguez, recommended that the Civil Aeronautics Board approve an agreement to allow Eastern Air Lines to take over Braniff International's South American routes permanently.

headline: S.&P. Downgrades Metromedia Debt
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday announced a downgrading for Metromedia Inc.'s subordinated debentures to a speculative grade of BB+ from the investment grade of BBB.   The rating agency said the downgrading was related to the financing arrangements for the company's recent acquisitions of radio paging companies and television stations as well as 580,000 shares of its own stock.

headline: President of Hicks Comments on Industry
abstract: D. Edward Ricchiuto, president of Hicks & Greist, has some thoughts on last Tuesday's column of comments by high-ranking creative leaders on the state of their advertising art.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Yen Growing Stronger Again
abstract: The Japanese yen, after a dramatic and unexpected bout of weakness on the world's foreign exchange markets last year, is regaining strength.   Foreign exchange dealers said in Tokyo today that the yen could be worth 200 against the United States dollar within a few months, far above the low of 278.10 at the beginning of November.

headline: NAMIBIA REBELS' MOVES SEEM TO SNAG SOUTH AFRICAN-ANGOLAN TALKS
abstract: The infiltration of an unusually large number of insurgents into South-West Africa appears for now to have sidetracked talks between South Africa and Angola on a preliminary cease-fire in the disputed territory.   Negotiators for the two Governments held their third round of talks in a little more than two months on the island of Sal in Cape Verde this week, but they reportedly met for only three hours. This was long enough, official sources here indicated, for the South African representatives to make the point that Angola would be responsible for curtailing the military activities of the South-West Africa People's Organization if a cease-fire were to hold.

headline: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Reagan Is Said to Drop Arms Agency Nominee
abstract: President Reagan has decided not to go ahead with the nomination of Robert T. Grey as deputy director of the arms control agency, officials said today.   Mr. Grey, who has been acting deputy director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency under Eugene V. Rostow, said he had not been told of the decision. Mr. Rostow had told State Department officials earlier that if Mr. Grey's nomination was not pushed by the Administration, he would resign in protest.

headline: PRECIOUS METALS FUTURES TUMBLE TO DAILY LIMITS
abstract: All precious metals futures prices plunged their daily permissible limits in a selloff of gold, silver and platinum that brokers attributed to the sharp price cuts by several major petroleum exporters last week.   On the Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery plummeted $25.70, to close at $480 an ounce. In later trading, Republic National Bank quoted gold at $478.50, down $26 from Friday's late bid.   Precious metals traders reckoned that any significant decline in energy costs would delay the resurgence of inflation and strengthen the value of the dollar. Most investors buy preious metals to protect themselves from inflation and the related decline in the purchasing power of the dollar.

headline: Kaiser Aluminum
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had withdrawn its published prices for primary aluminum ingot and would price and sell the product on a transaction basis until further notice. Kaiser said it had taken the action because ''aluminum ingot is currently being traded like a commodity, making the published price for ingot a fiction.'' Kaiser's current transaction price for 99.7 primary aluminum ingot in the United States is 60 cents a pound; its published price for the product was 76 cents domestically and 82.6 cents internationally.

headline: SOVIET AND LIBYA PLAN AN AMITY ACCORD
abstract: The Soviet Union and Libya announced today that they had agreed in principle to sign a treaty of friendship and cooperation.   The announcement came in a joint communique after a visit by Maj.  Abdul Salam Jalloud, second-ranking Libyan leader after Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. The communique offered no details of the prospective treaty, but it attacked recent American moves, thus suggesting that the pact might have been spurred by Libyan concern over tensions with the United States.   The communique alluded to an incident in mid-February, when Chad and the Sudan said Libya was massing troops with the intention of invading Chad, the Sudan, or both. The United States shifted the aircraft carrier Nimitz from waters off Lebanon to waters off Libya and it sent four radar reconnaissance planes to Egypt. Colonel Qaddafi subsequently denied any intention of invading his neighbors.

headline: Black & Decker To Sell McCulloch
abstract: The Black & Decker Manufacturing Company, Towson, Md., said it had agreed in principle to sell its McCulloch Corporation operations for an undisclosed price to a new corporation formed by a group of McCulloch managers, and private investors.

headline: GULFSTREAM LAND & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Arab Delegation Plans Visit to London Friday
abstract: King Hassan II of Morocco has handed over the reins of a twice-postponed Arab League peace mission to Britain to King Hussein of Jordan, the Government said today.

headline: S.E.C. Examining Aetna Accounting
abstract: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company said the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun a formal investigation into the company's decision not to make adjustments for tax loss carry-forward accounting.

headline: New England Pact For Quebec Power
abstract: New England electric companies signed an 11-year contract today for importing Canadian electricity, a plan expected to save the region hundreds of millions of dollars.   Governors from Connecticut, Vermont, Maine and Rhode Island and Quebec's Premier, Rene Levesque, attended the signing ceremonies between Hydro-Quebec of Canada and the 64 electric companies in the New England Power Pool.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: UNITED STATES & FOREIGN SECURITIES CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FRANC OFF, MARK RISES; DOLLAR IS MIXED IN U.S.
abstract: The franc fell sharply today in response to the French Socialists' losses in Sunday's municipal elections.  In West Germany, bankers predicted that the mark would grow in value as a result of that country's elections, which returned Chancellor Helmut Kohl to power.   Stock prices on the Frankfurt exchange rose sharply, reflecting investor belief that Mr. Kohl's conservative coalition would hasten economic recovery by curbing Government spending and fostering business growth.   The Commerzbank stock index surged to 844.90 - its highest level since October 1978 - from 822.30 on Friday. Traders reported heavy purchasing across the board.

headline: U.S. and Canada in Air Fare Accord
abstract: The United States announced today a tentative agreement in its dispute with Canada about the sale of deeply discounted airline tickets, apparently ending weekend travel uncertainty for thousands of ticket-holders.   The settlement apparently met the United States Government's requirement that a domestic carrier, Continental Air Lines, be granted a route with a favorable fare from Canada to Australia with a stop in Los Angeles.   In a terse announcement, the State Department said that the two governments had ''reached an agreement in principle which resolves the specific air fare issues'' troubling the two neighbors. Details of the agreement were not disclosed.

headline: AMERICAN IN SWITZERLAND IS ACCUSED OF SPYING
abstract: An American who worked as a cocktail waitress at a hotel here has been ordered to stand trial on charges of spying for Libya, the authorities said todya.

headline: FOR MOROCCO, SAHARAN WAR APPEARS OVER
abstract: In 1975 Ahmed Douiri was 21 years old, living in the central Moroccan town of Sidi Kacem, with a chance to get a university education. But being ''an adventurer,'' he said, he took part in November of that year in the Green March of about 350,000 Moroccans charged with walking into this barren territory to put pressure on Spain to give it up.   For making the march, which King Hassan II called off soon after it began, saying it had accomplished its purpose, Mr. Douiri was issued a green card. This qualified him a few months later, when Morocco had taken over most of Western Sahara, as a settler at the sand-swept town of Aiun.

headline: ARGENTINA IS PARALYZED BY A ONE-DAY STRIKE
abstract: A one-day strike by Argentina's labor unions brought the country almost to a standstill today despite the military Government's declaration that the work stoppage was illegal.   Public transport was paralyzed, nearly all shops were closed and only a trickle of people turned up for work at factories, banks and Government offices.   The Interior Ministry said 85 percent of employees had stayed away from work.  The 24-hour strike was called by the General Confederation of Labor to demand better pay and to protest the economic policies of President Reynaldo Bignone's Government.

headline: Washington Watch; The Economy In a New Light
abstract: WASHINGTON JANUARY is economic numbers month here in the capital, with the White House set to produce the State of the Union address, the budget and the Economic Message.   Although prospects for economic growth in 1983 have been scaled back from earlier forecasts, Administration officials are still anxious that their numbers be shown in the best light. They are, therefore, emphasizing one set of statistics over another this year.   ''The conventional way of doing the forecast,'' explained Allen Sinai of Data Resources Inc., ''has been year over year.'' Until last week the Administration spotlighted this measurement, which measures the rate of inflation-adjusted change for the average value of goods and services produced by the economy between one year and the next.

headline: Exxon Cuts Prices On Oil and Gasoline
abstract: The Exxon Corporation, the nation's largest oil company, said yesterday that it was lowering its wholesale gasoline and home heating oil prices by between half a cent and 1 cent a gallon.   The reductions, effective immediately, were expected to continue a downward trend in consumer prices.

headline: E.F. Hutton Is Censured
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission censured the New York brokerage firm of E.F. Hutton & Company today for failing to supervise closely its employees in their dealings with credit and antifraud rules.   The censure came as part of a consent agreement in which the defendants settled an S.E.C. administrative complaint without admitting or denying wrongdoing.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HOW SURVEY WAS CONDUCTED
abstract: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Jan. 16 through Jan. 19 with 1,597 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.   The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country.

headline: Ex-Im Bank in India
abstract: The United States Export-Import Bank has offered India a loan of about $1.6 billion to finance purchases of American machinery and services, the bank's chairman, William Draper, said today. The 10-year credit, including $600 million for oil exploration, would carry a 10 percent rate. The Indian Government has not yet responded to the offer.

headline: Mexico Starts Jobs Program
abstract: The Government has announced a $2.7 billion emergency program aimed at generating up to 700,000 jobs in the face of some estimates that say 40 percent of the country's work force is unemployed or underemployed.   Carlos Salinas de Gortari, the Budget and Planning Minister, announced the project Tuesday, calling it ''indispensable to keep many Mexicans from losing their jobs'' and worsening the country's already serious unemployment problem.

headline: Emery's President Resigns His Posts
abstract: Gen. William G. Moore Jr. has resigned as president and chief operating officer of the Emery Air Freight Corporation, one of the nation's largest domestic air freight carriers.   General Moore, 62, joined the board at Emery in 1979 after his retirement as commander in chief of the United States Military Airlift Command. He was elected president in May 1981.

headline: ZIMBABWE'S PRESS, LIKE RHODESIA'S, IS UNADVENTUROUS
abstract: When Joshua Nkomo, this country's officially disgraced opposition leader, held a news conference recently to produce documents rebutting Government statements about him, no Zimbabwean reporters came to hear his side of the story. The omission, Mr. Nkomo said, showed that ''there is no press in this country.''   His comment may have been intended to mislead, for over the years Mr. Nkomo has shown himself as ready as many others in Africa to condemn the press and denounce reporters who did not take the line desired of them.   But there was a point: in the sad and violent events that have unfolded in Zimbabwe in recent weeks, the officially steered press, which calls itself Africa's freest, has accepted official statements without question, ignored or played down the evidence Mr. Nkomo has produced in response to questionable Government allegations and thus lent itself to a campaign of misinformation that damages its and the Government's credibility.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Centex Acceptance Corp., a Centex Corp. subsidiary, filed a shelf registration statement with the S.E.C. for up to $100 million of its G.N.M.A.-collateralized bonds.   * Commodore Corp.'s offering of 2.8 million common shares was priced at $8 a share, through Montgomery Securities.

headline: 3 SENATORS URGE CUT IN SALVADOR AID REQUEST
abstract: Three senators joined today in proposing a sharp reduction in the military aid for El Salvador requested by President Reagan and called for ''unconditional discussions'' with the Salvadoran rebels.   They emphasized, however, that they did not intend to force ''power-sharing'' with the rebels, but merely to have the Salvadoran Government make a good-faith effort to negotiate with them. Should the rebels decline, the three senators said, they would consider additional military aid.

headline: Rumasa Plan Approved
abstract: The Spanish Parliament, by a vote of 196 to 123, tonight approved the Government's decision of last week to expropriate all the holdings of the Rumasa conglomerate, including its 18 banks and more than 200 subsidiaries. Approval had been expected. Afterward, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez sought to assure businessmen that his Government, which came to power in December, had no intention of nationalizing other companies, too.

headline: PRESIDENT'S FORECAST IS REVISED
abstract: President Reagan's top economic advisers, Administration officials said today, have reached agreement on a revised economic forecast for this year that projects higher growth and lower inflation, both at rates of slightly less than 5 percent.   Normally, the Administration reviews its outlook for the year in July. But with the economy showing far greater strength in the early months of this year than White House economists expected, a revision became necessary to bring the forecast into line with current data.

headline: Technology; Compatible Computers
abstract: IMITATION may be the sincerest form of flattery, but in personal computers, it could also be good business: Since the International Business Machines Corporation introduced a personal computer in August 1981, numerous companies have come to market with computers that are compatible with the I.B.M. machine.   A compatible computer means, ideally, that a disk containing a program written for one computer can be used on another. It also means that one machine will be able to use printers, disk drives, game paddles and other attachments designed for the other.   It turns out, however, that many so-called compatible computers are not really that compatible. Indeed, figuring out what compatibility means for computers is perhaps as difficult as determining what it means for people. Computers can be compatible in some things and not in others.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Net Income   Percent

headline: American Cyanamid
abstract: The American Cyanamid Company said today that it had acquired the manufacturing assets of the privately held Electro-Metalloid Corporation of Irvington, N.Y., for an undisclosed sum. It said the purchase includes the world rights to technology for coating graphite fibers used in aerospace and electronics industries.

headline: New York Telephone Sets $400 Million Sale
abstract: The New York Telephone Company disclosed in a filing with the New York State Public Service Commission yesterday that it planned to raise $400 million in the debt market. It would be the company's first such offering since July 1981.

headline: AN ALTERNATE PLAN
abstract: UNDER pressure from his own advisers and the business community to r educe the largest deficits in our nation's history, President Reagant ook the opportunity in his State of the Union address to talk of ' 'bipartisanship'' and ''a fair, across-the-board freeze on G overnment spending.'' Sadly, that is all it was, just talk.  He calls for ''a fair, across-the-board freeze,'' but his 1984 budget discriminately cuts some programs, increases others. It provides a 9 percent real increase in the defense budget, leaves his extravagant tax program in place and gives us a $200 billion deficit. He calls for bipartisanship, but what he means is stay the course.

headline: GROUPS ASSAIL PLAN FOR BELL DIVESTITURE
abstract: State regulators and consumer-interest groups told the Federal District Court here today that terms of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's divestiture agreement would weaken local phone companies across the country and hit consumers with higher phone bills.   Local regulators and the states have raised doubts about the divestiture plan for months, but today they disclosed some of the details in their objections for the first time.   Various other parties, including competitors of A.T.& T., also filed comments on the divestiture plan at the request of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, which has charge of the antitrust agreement between A.T.& T. and the Justice Department.

headline: Market Place; General Public Turnaround
abstract: THE stock market's recent advance has been led by ''the generals,'' big-name companies such as General Motors and General Electric. But, in more modest fashion, another general has been advancing lately.   That's General Public Utilities, a company that made headlines in March 1979 because of the accident at its Three Mile Island nuclear generating plant near Harrisburg, Pa. The response of regulatory authorities was to remove the unit with the damaged reactor, TMI Unit 2, and its undamaged sister unit, TMI Unit 1, from the rate base.

headline: Data Terminal
abstract: The National Semiconductor Corporation announced that the tender offer by its subsidiary, the N.S. Development Corporation, to purchase up to 4.31 million shares of Data Terminal Systems Inc.  common stock appeared to be oversubscribed. The $7.25-a-share cash offer expired at 5 P.M. Monday.

headline: Dobrynin Departing?  Reports Discounted
abstract: Unconfirmed reports have been circulating that Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the long-time Soviet Ambassador in Washington, would soon give up his post to return to Moscow, but they were dismissed today by Soviet and American officials.   Vladimir S. Mikoyan, a spokesman for the Soviet Embassy, said: ''There is no indication that Ambassador Dobrynin is leaving.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Washington Watch; U.S. Dunning Is 'Not Nasty'
abstract: WASHINGTON EVERY month the dunning notices go out from the Comptroller's Office at the Commodity Credit Corporation to the Government of Poland.   ''They're not nasty - simply matter-of-fact updates on how much they owe us,'' says Rob A. Brammer, Acting Comptroller and Treasurer. ''I'm not sure you can work for the Government and be nasty.''   Mr. Brammer's March letter to the Bank Handlowy, the Polish national bank, said that as of the end of February, Poland owed the C.C.C. the sum of $859,803,205.08 - not including interest due. At the end of January the sum was $786,988,684.14.

headline: CHEMICAL LEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: OF OPTIONS, STOCK INDEXES AND FUTURES
abstract: PUTS and calls, stock options, market index futures, options on i ndex futures, market index not based on any established index. If i nvestors think they are confused by the new stock index markets, so a re many professional traders, analysts and brokers who understand t he simple mechanics of these instruments, but are still uncertain a bout how to use them profitably.   ''Conceptually and intellectually, most stock investors understand the index market investment products,'' said Stewart C. Elner, vice president-options at Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc., New York.  ''What usually confuses them is the market terminology and how to use each index instrument to suit a particular investing purposes.''

headline: RYAN'S FAMILY STEAK HOUSES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: News Analysis
abstract: At the midpoint in its term, the Reagan Administration has again raised El Salvador to the top of its foreign policy concerns with its appeal to Congress for agreement on providing $60 million in emergency military supplies to the Salvadoran Government.   Not only did President Reagan become personally involved today by calling together about 20 key members of Congress to discuss El Salvador, but Secretary of State George P. Shultz also seems to have been caught up in the Salvadoran situation with almost the same intensity as his predecessor, Alexander M. Haig Jr.   Mr. Haig made El Salvador a test of East-West dimensions because of the links he saw between the Salvadoran insurgents and the Soviet Union, Cuba and Nicaragua. Mr. Shultz came into office seemingly less ideologically motivated than Mr. Haig and less interested in Salvadoran issues. Although Mr. Shultz's remarks today contained fewer rhetorical flourishes, they had no less anti-Soviet content than Mr. Haig's warnings about what would happen if El Salvador fell to the guerrillas.

headline: SHOP & GO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Allied Stores Corp. has appointed Ronald D. Nichols president and division chief executive officer of Pomeroy's, Levittown, Pa., and Donald L. Triplett president and division chief executive officer of Troutman's, Greensburg, Pa.   * American Resources Management Corp., Denver, has appointed Robert D. Cox senior vice president in charge of operations.

headline: U.S. Aide Gloomy on Grain for Soviet
abstract: A senior United States agricultural official said today that the curtailment of American grain sales to the Soviet Union after its intervention in Afghanistan had done ''long-term damage to our trade'' in the Soviet market.   Alan T. Tracy, Acting Under Secretary of Agriculture, offered the assessment at a news conference that followed two days of American-Soviet grain talks. His view contrasted with the more hopeful tone struck publicly by other United States officials who have discussed sales prospects since the grain curtailment ended, including the delegation that came here for semiannual talks last September.   Their view was that the strengths of the American market would offset whatever misgivings the Russians might have in the wake of the curtailment.

headline: FIRST COMMERCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: INDIAN PLANT NOW PRODUCING WEAPONS-GRADE PLUTONIUM
abstract: India has begun producing weapons-grade plutonium at a nuclear reprocessing plant near Bombay, but the operation is being monitored by international inspectors instructed to warn if the plutonium is diverted to military use, United States Government officials said today.   Even though India has not signed the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons, it is obliged to accept inspection by the Viennabased International Atomic Energy Agency under contracts it has made with Canada, France and the United States for the supply of uranium, American officials said.   But these officials added that India has refused to place reprocessing under ''full-scope safeguards'' - meaning that the international inspectors may not be permitted to observe all the reprocessing operations in the future. However, in the case of the present operations at the Tarapur plant near Bombay, inspectors are on the scene.

headline: SUSQUEHANNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The U.N. Today; Jan. 5, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Council for Namibia - 10:30 A.M.

headline: Financial Services Get New Scrutiny
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company and other retailers may be forced to give up their new financial services businesses, William Isaac, head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, warned today. He told reporters that new rules are under study to roll back the way businesses not previously affiliated with finance have been selling financial services.

headline: SOVIET ANNOUNCES OFFER ON TROOP CUTS
abstract: Soviet officials held a news conference here today to announce a proposal presented Thursday at the talks on limiting conventional forces in Central Europe.   The proposal called for the withdrawal of 20,000 Soviet troops and 13,000 Americans pending further agreements. Viktor G. Komplektov, Deputy Foreign Minister responsible for United States affairs, described the offer as ''new in principle, simple and practical'' and one that would breach the ''figures barrier'' that has impeded the talks in Vienna for almost 10 years.   Mr. Komplektov announced the Soviet move at a news conference at which he was joined by Col. Gen. Nikolai F. Chervov, who has emerged as a military spokesman on disarmament matters.

headline: AMERADA HESS DOWN 9.5%
abstract: The Phillips Petroleum Company reported yesterday that special charges had caused earnings to fall 17.1 percent in the fourth quarter. Revenues dropped seven-tenths of 1 percent.   The company, based in Bartlesville, Okla., said net income in the latest three months declined to $154.6 million, or $1.01 a share, from $186.5 million, or $1.23 a share, a year earlier. Revenues slipped to $4.06 billion, from $4.09 billion.

headline: China Assails U.S. on Bank
abstract: China today accused the United States of blocking its application to join the Manila-based Asian Development Bank and reiterated that Taiwan should be expelled from the organization.   Qi Huaiyuan, head of the information department of the Chinese Foreign Ministry, condemned remarks by Alan Romberg, a spokesman for the State Department. Mr. Romberg said that China was qualified for membership of the bank but that the United States did not want to see Taiwan expelled.

headline: FOR CYPRIOTS, OLD DIVISIONS ONLY DEEPEN
abstract: The imaginary line that cuts across this island of 650,000 people divides it these days into two increasingly estranged worlds.   Although talks sponsored by the United Nations have been held on and off over eight years, the Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots seem to be moving further apart. Some young people in both sectors say they have never seen the people on the other side of the line and would not much care to.   Cyprus received its independence from Britain in 1960 and became a republic under the Greek Cypriot leader Archbishop Makarios. Even before independence it was troubled by ethnic hostilities and the traditional rivalries between Greece and Turkey.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Recent actions by President Reagan and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger have raised the question whether the Administration is tilting toward the Arab moderates and away from Israel.   At one level, the answer is no. Mr. Weinberger's decision against sharing Israeli military intelligence from the Lebanese conflict, Mr. Reagan's accusing Israel of delaying the Lebanese talks, and statements by both men dramatizing the confrontation between an American Marine captain and an Israeli tank commander were tough. But they can also be explained partly as personal irritation over the fact that the Lebanese talks are getting nowhere, and as a means of pressing Israel to make concessions. How to Deal With Conflicts   At a deeper level, the answer seems to be yes - that like the Carter, Ford, and Nixon Administrations, the Reagan team came to discover that difficulties in relations with Israel arose not just because the Israelis were tough negotiators, but reflected basic conflicts of interest between the two countries.

headline: U.S. Confirms General Met Sandinist Officials
abstract: The Pentagon confirmed today that Brig.  Gen. William E. Odom, Army assistant chief of staff for intelligence, met with Sandinist officials Wednesday in Nicaragua. A spokesman said the general was on a ''routine operational tour'' that would include stops in Panama, Honduras and El Salvador.

headline: Suits Against Phillips Dismissed
abstract: A Federal judge has ruled in favor of the Phillips Petroleum Company, dismissing lawsuits totaling $2 billion in the 1980 collapse of a North Sea oil rig operated by a company subsidiary.

headline: SHAMIR GOING HOME WITH HIGH HOPES ON LEBANON PACT
abstract: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel said today that as a result of hearing new American ideas for negotiations on Israeli troop withdrawal from Lebanon, he was returning to Israel convinced that ''we are nearer to a solution.''   A senior State Department official, in a briefing for reporters later, said, ''There is no breakthrough, but we do believe that progress is being made.''   Those were the most optimistic statements from either the Israeli or American side since intensive talks began here Saturday. The talks have also involved Lebanese-American discussions.

headline: State's Insured Bonds Yielding 4.25% to 8.75%
abstract: New York State's latest bond issue was offered yesterday through underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Bank, which sold the issue with the additional backing of an insurance policy bought from the Municipal Bond Insurance Association.   The state's budget difficulties - including estimated deficits of $579 million in the fiscal year ending March 31 and $1.8 billion in the next fiscal year - were a major reason for seeking the insurance, which assures the bondholders of timely payment of interest and principal.   At a time when many local governments are having financial troubles, the use of such insurance has grown rapidly. Last year the Municipal Bond Insurance Association insured $3.6 billion of bonds, up from $1.2 billion in 1981. New York's was the second state bond issue insured by the association in the last two months, following a Washington State issue on Jan. 19.

headline: FRENCH GENERAL OUSTED FOR DISPUTING CUTBACK
abstract: The chief of staff of the French Army was replaced today after complaining about planned cuts in the army's manpower and missions.   A statement by Defense Minister Charles Hernu said the chief of staff, Gen. Jean Delaunay, was being disciplined for having said in December that the reductions would ''lead to an army diminished in size, weakened in structure, aging in equipment, and affected in morale.''   ''There must be discipline in an army,'' Mr. Hernu said after a Cabinet meeting in which Gen. Rene Imbot was named to take over the post. ''One cannot be of another mind than the policy decided by the political authorities.''

headline: American Airlines
abstract: American Airlines reported that its traffic rose about 13 percent in January, to 2.7 billion passenger miles, from 2.4 billion passenger miles in January 1982. The airline, a unit of the AMR Corporation, also said its load factor rose 4.1 percent, to 63.3 percent, in January. The airline attributed the heavy volume to low fares and the return of many travelers from vacation.

headline: Oldsmobile Dealer Ads
abstract: Inspired by consumer research that shows that the average American automobile is nearly seven years old, Shaw & Koulermos, the agency for local Oldsmobile dealers, is creating a television commercial that ends with the line, ''Get your 1990 automobile - today.''   The commercial will run from Feb. 20 to April 11 on nighttime television.

headline: PRETORIA TAKES DIRECT CONTROL OVER NAMIBIA
abstract: South Africa dissolved the four-year-old National Assembly in South-West Africa today and announced that it was resuming direct rule.   The move followed the resignation of the Council of Ministers made up of members of a multiracial political front called the Democratic Turnhalle Alliance.   The Alliance was initially sponsored and promoted by the South African authorities as an alternative to a black nationalist insurgent movement called the South-West Africa People's Organization. The insurgents are seeking to turn the territory into the independent nation of Namibia, a name already frequently used for the territory.

headline: Accusations Exchanged At East-West Talks
abstract: Delegates from the Soviet bloc and the West failed to agree today on ways of speeding up the work of a 35-nation conference on detente, delegates said.

headline: Technology; Car's Air Bag: How It Works
abstract: WHEN Mercedes-Benz announced last week that it would offer an air bag restraint system in some of its 1984 cars, company officials said they knew the move would intensify a debate that has been under way for the last 14 years. But, they said, the technology that is at the heart of the argument has been tested successfully in more than 20 million miles of driving, and the only thing that remains uncertain is customer demand.   Air bags - devices that inflate to protect occupants in a head-on crash - seemed to be a good idea when they were proposed in the late 1960's. It was not long, though, before criticism and doubt began to pile up. In particular, critics said, the sodium azide that was used to generate the inflating gas was dangerous and, perhaps, carcinogenic. Further, it was said, the bags could inflict injury if they inflated inadvertently, and the cost of the complicated system would add greatly to the price of a car.

headline: REAGAN MAY RAISE EX-IM BANK FUNDS
abstract: In his budget for the 1984 fiscal year, President Reagan will propose bolstering the Export-Import Bank, the Government agency that aids American exporters by making loans to foreign purchasers of American goods.   According to Administration officials, the President will ask for an additional $2 billion in loan guarantee authority for the bank, to $10 billion, and may seek $2.7 billion more in the bank's direct lending authority.   This decision, and other trade actions Mr. Reagan is expected to take, signal victory for those in the Cabinet who want to create jobs and spur economic recovery through greater Government support of exports.

headline: Lionel Creditors
abstract: The Lionel Corporation, which with two subsidiaries is in Chapter 11 proceedings under Federal bankruptcy law, said its board had approved a reorganization plan that would provide creditors with cash payments of $70 million and a package of securities including preferred stock and warrants to purchase common stock when the plan is approved. No debt forgiveness is involved, Lionel said, but it would sell its 82 percent stake in Dale Electronics Inc. Its unsecured creditors hold $135 million in debt, the company said. It has no secured debt.

headline: GROWING FAST AT FINLEY KUMBLE
abstract: The fastest-growing law firm in the country is Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Heine, Underberg & Casey, a New York-based firm that was organized in 1968 and now has about 270 lawyers. Since 1979, Finley Kumble has expanded 296 percent - almost eight times the national average for the period. Most of that growth has come through mergers with other firms and by hiring away big-name partners.

headline: Pound Hits Record Low Against Dollar in U.S.
abstract: The British pound fell yesterday to a record low against the dollar. Currency dealers quoted the pound at $1.495 when banks in New York closed at 3 P.M., a sharp decline of 1.73 cents from Monday's close of $1.5123.   Earlier, futures contracts in British pounds for spot March delivery fell 1.6 cents, to $1.4965, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange when that market closed at 2:24 P.M. central standard time.   The pound, which was valued at $4.80 after World War II, has most recently been under pressure because of the disarray in the global oil market. Britain's North Sea oil has been an important export earner, and it has spared that nation the cost of imported fuel.

headline: Argentina Refinancing
abstract: Argentina will refinance $1.4 billion of short-term external debt falling due in the next few weeks over three years, Julio Gonzelez del Solar, president of the central bank, said in an interview reported today.   On Monday, the central bank suspended the repayment of all foreign loans taken out in the form of currency swaps, pending new regulations for their future management.   Mr. Gonzalez del Solar told a radio station Tuesday that these swaps would be refinanced over 36 months.

headline: Citicorp Lifts Payout
abstract: Citicorp said yesterday that its board had raised its quarterly dividend to 47 cents a share, from 43 cents, payable May 2 to shareholders of record March 30.

headline: Norstar Purchase Of Bank Stake Set
abstract: Norstar Bancorp Inc., Albany, agreed to buy Bank of Commerce's publicly held capital stock - 32.4 percent of the total - at $34 a share, or a total of about $16.7 million, the companies said.

headline: Italian Prison Warden Slain
abstract: Nicandro Izzo, a prison warden, was shot and killed in Naples today on his way home from work, the police said. In Rome, female prison wardens went on strike because of the killing of one of their colleagues on Friday.

headline: Afghans Are Reported Forming Guard Squads
abstract: Afghanistan's Marxist Government is ordering workers to form armed guard units to defend their factories and farms against attacks by anti-Government insurgents, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.

headline: Salvadoran Rebels Say They Downed a Copter
abstract: Leftist guerrillas said today that they had shot down an air force helicopter, captured a village in northern Chalatenango Province and kept Government forces pinned down in eastern Morazan Province.

headline: CHRYSLER ENDS SOUTH AFRICA ROLE
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation plans to sell its stake in a South African auto manufacturer in what is believed to be one of the biggest withdrawals by an American company from this country in recent years.   Chrysler has a 25 percent stake in the company, the Sigma Motor Corporation, the third-largest auto and truck maker in South Africa.  The stake would be sold to the Anglo American Corporation, the mining finance house. Anglo American and a subsidiary, the Anglo American Industrial Corporation, already own the other 75 percent of Sigma.

headline: MRS. GANDHI NAMES 12 NEW MINISTERS
abstract: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi formally accepted the resignations of seven central Government ministers and appointed 12 new ones today, some to newly created posts.   The dismissals and appointments were the first of several that are expected to take place in the next few days as part of Mrs. Gandhi's response to major electoral reverses for her Congress Party this month.   On Friday all 60 members of the nation's Council of Ministers, except Mrs. Gandhi herself, submitted their resignations. This included the 19 senior ministers who made up the Cabinet, and the resignations gave Mrs. Gandhi a free hand in trying to reorganize her Government and recoup the fortunes of her embattled party.

headline: Gulf Stressing Credit Cards
abstract: The Gulf Oil Corporation became the second major gasoline company this week to announce a new push to encourage the use of credit cards at its service stations.   Gulf said it was rescinding a 3 percent credit card processing fee charged to its United States dealers.

headline: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1983; International
abstract: President Reagan invited Prime Minister Nakasone of Japan to return today for a second meeting as they undertook to smooth out strained trade relations between the two allies. (Page A1.) The Administration will ask Congress to merge the various agencies dealing with foreign trade policy, according to officials. (D1.)

headline: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS; PECULIAR POLITICS AND DANGEROUS DEFICITS
abstract: IN fiscal 1982, the Federal Government's deficit exceeded $100 b illion for the first time in our history, surpassing the previous 1 976 record by more than 50 percent. In fiscal 1983, the 1982 record i s likely to be broken by at least another 50 percent as the deficit s oars toward $200 billion.  These mind-numbing figures are not easy to understand, because for most of us, numbers like $100 billion or $200 billion are metaphysical - far larger than the human mind can contemplate. There is a danger that we shall become insensitive and having broken the magic $100 billion barrier, we shall try for $200 billion or even $300 billion.

abstract: A Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that a 19-year-old Chinese tennis player who defected to the United States last summer would not be prosecuted if she returned home.   The player, Hu Na, said last week that threats from Chinese Communist Party officials frightened her into seeking asylum.
