headline: BELL WINS PLEA TO BLOCK AWARD OF $1.8 BILLION
abstract: A Federal appeals court today overturned a $1.8 billion antitrust award levied against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for trying to monopolize the long-distance telephone market.   But in a 2-to-1 decision of 205 pages, the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit agreed that there had been antitrust violations by A.T.& T. against the MCI Communications Corporation and ordered a new trial to set damages. MCI is A.T.& T.'s largest competitor in the long-distance telephone market.   The ruling threw out a 1980 District Court jury verdict that awarded $600 million to MCI. That judgment was later trebled, as permitted under antitrust law.

headline: PULLOUT BY ISRAEL URGED BY MUBARAK
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said today, after meeting with President Reagan, that ''top priority'' had to be given to bringing about the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon before time ran out on the latest Middle East peace efforts.   A senior State Department official told reporters later that Mr.  Reagan had told the Egyptian leader in their two hours of talks that he shared his concerns about the slow pace of the @Israeli-Lebanese negotiations.   ''President Reagan is very impatient with the lack of progress so far in the Lebanese situation,'' said the official, who refused to be named, ''and he wants to break them loose as soon as possible.'' Framework for a Withdrawal   He said that in the Administration's view, ''The key to this is the current negotiations between Israel and Lebanon.'' Once a framework is worked out for Israeli withdrawal, ''then you'll also be able to get Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization to withdraw in that time frame,'' the senior American official said.

headline: MONDAY, MARCH 7, 1983
abstract: The Economy   Industrial output last month rose at the fastest rate in 30 years, purchasing managers said. They reported that new orders also climbed, while the pace of deliveries slowed for the first time since May 1981, indicating a growing backlog of orders. (Page D1.)

headline: IRISH RACE HORSE HELD FOR RANSOM
abstract: Gunmen forced their way into the Aga Khan's stud farm in Newbridge, Ireland, during the night Tuesday and kidnapped Shergar, one of the world's top thoroughbred racing horses. They demanded a ransom of $2.7 million.   Racing experts said it was the first recorded kidnapping of a stallion at stud. Shergar, a 5-year-old dark bay with white socks and a white blaze, was the winner in 1981 of the Irish Sweeps Derby and the English Derby. That year he was voted European race horse of the year.

headline: NATO MINISTERS ENDORSE U.S. POSITION ON MISSILES
abstract: Supporting the American position, Western defense ministers agreed today that the elimination of all medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe should remain the prime objective of arms talks in Geneva. But they also upheld the idea of a flexible negotiating posture.   The ministers, gathered in a meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, affirmed the decision to start deploying American missiles in December unless an accord on limitation was reached with the Soviet Union.   The position, announced after a two-day meeting of the alliance's Nuclear Planning Group, was reached amid reports of pressure from the European allies for a compromise proposal that might break the deadlock in Geneva.

headline: West German Magazine Says Police Took Its NATO Papers
abstract: The West German police have seized top-secret NATO documents on nuclear strategy in a raid on the leftist satirical magazine Konkret, a spokesman for the journal said today.

headline: HARD BY BUSY DELHI, TIMELESS INDIA SLUMBERS ON
abstract: Before the first, faint pink of dawn shows in the east, the milk sellers of Mandi are well on their way to town.  With shiny cans hanging from the handlebars of their bicycles, they peddle along in groups of two or three through patches of fog, watching the road through the folds of the shawls they have wrapped around heads and shoulders against the January cold. Behind them, the lights of Mandi itself are strung out like jewels across rocky ridges that lie south of New Delhi.   As this village of 2,200 people awakens, swaying shadows move through the gloom, materializing as long-skirted women with brass waterpots on their heads making for the well. In some of the walled courtyards of thatched mud huts and simple stone houses that line the rutted dirt streets, late risers milk buffalo cows to the accompaniment of a rooster's song.   In a small compound on the topmost ridge, where a tethered camel yawns and snuffles, a 35-year-old farmer named Bullu strips a few pieces of straw from the roof of his house and arranges them in an outdoor earthen hearth. Shivering in the dawn chill, he sets them afire and adds fuel of dried buffalo dung.

headline: ARENS CONFIRMED AS ISRAELI DEFENSE MINISTER
abstract: Moshe Arens, the Israeli Ambassador to the United States, was confirmed as Defense Minister by the Israeli Parliament today. The vote was 61 to 51 with 2 abstentions.   Mr. Arens is due back in Israel Thursday and is scheduled to participate in the next Cabinet meeting Sunday.  In the two-hour debate before the vote, Mr. Arens's suitability was hardly the issue as critics concentrated their fire on the Cabinet decision to keep Ariel Sharon, the ousted Defense Minister, on the ministerial security committee.

headline: Yugoslav Refining Deal
abstract: Iran and Yugoslavia have agreed to an arrangement under which Iranian crude oil will be refined in Yugoslavia for the world market, the press agency for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said.

headline: GOLD REBOUNDS IN U.S.; TECHNICAL FACTORS CITED
abstract: Gold bullion, which had lost 20 percent of its value in a week, bounced back yesterday, with prices rising $12 or more an ounce in New York,largely as a result of technical factors. The rise was limited by the weakness of the silver market and the strength of the dollar, analysts said.   On New York's Commodity Exchange, the spot March gold futures contracts, which expire in a few weeks, closed up $11.90 an ounce from Monday, at $412.40. In later trading at Republic National Bank in New York, gold was quoted at $413 an ounce, up $12.50 from Monday. Gold had plunged $42.50 an ounce in New York Monday, to $400.50.  That was the biggest one-day drop in a slide that brought gold down more than $100 between Feb. 22 and Monday.

headline: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 12, 1983; The Economy
abstract: Leading banks, in an action that lagged behind the drop in the cost of their funds, lowered their prime lending rates by half a point, to 11 percent. They cited doubts about the cost of new money market accounts and the possibility of large losses from loan defaults. The banks had been paying about 8 1/2 percent for their funds and charging corporate customers 11 1/2 percent and more. (Page D1.)   Two sweeping tax reform proposals are being prepared by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan for possible inclusion in the President's State of the Union address. One concerns a flat-tax system; the other would concentrate on taxing spendable income and exclude savings and similar investments. (D1.)

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: The Army and the Air Force are developing a new operational strategy aimed at countering the Soviet Union's numerical superiority in men, guns, tanks and aircraft. The strategy stresses maneuverability, flexible leadership and advanced weapon systems. If adopted by the Pentagon - and officers here are confident that it will be - the strategy, called Airland battle, would break dramatically with current doctrine. Since the end of World War II it has centered on attrition, or the destruction of enemy resources through superior firepower.

headline: VENEZUELA CURBS PRICES AND EXCHANGE RATES
abstract: The Venezuelan Government imposed a three-tier exchange rate for the nation's currency today and ordered a 60-day price freeze.   The administration of President Luis Herrera Campins had said last week that exchange controls would be imposed. The Government decided that controls were necessary following a sharp decline in the country's currency reserves, problems linked to repaying its foreign debt and dim prospects for oil revenue, its principal source of revenue. The moves were announced today by Arturo Sosa Jr., the Minister of Finance.

headline: SOVIET REPORTING A CHINESE DETENTE
abstract: Soviet officials say Moscow has reached ''substantial detente'' with Peking because they do not think relations between China and the United States will ever again come close to what they view as the high-water mark of 1980.   With the latest round of talks on normalizing Soviet-Chinese relations still under way here, key Soviet officials presented the first authoritative account of how they want the world to perceive future Chinese-Soviet relations.   The officials characterized the evolving ties as ''irreversible, significant and indisputable.'' At the same time, they acknowledged real limits in the relationship and a long and hard road ahead in the negotiations.

headline: Trunk, Shea Aims At Health-Care Field
abstract: Trunk, Shea Inc. is a new specialty ad agency in the health-care field that has opened its doors in Clifton, N.J., and although it started without any business it got some yesterday. However, dePaul R. Trunk, the 44-year-old president, said that for the moment his lips are sealed as to the client's identity.

headline: WORLD BANK'S PROBLEM LOANS
abstract: In West Africa, near limestone quarries in southeastern Togo, the World Bank in the 1970's pumped $60 million into a plant that bakes ''clinkers.'' These bricks of limestone are then crushed and mixed with gypsum to produce cement.   The plant drew a further $20 million of loans from other institutions, including the European Development Bank. The plant was conceived as a bold undertaking that in one stroke would meet construction needs, lift exports and raise living standards in Togo and its neighbors, Ghana and the Ivory Coast. It is known as the Cimao project, after Ciments de l'Afrique de l'Ouest, the managing organization of the three co-owning countries,

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: Alabama plans to sell in early April more than $460 million of new bonds and use the proceeds to re-fund before maturity about $360 million of bonds sold last April when interest rates were much higher.   Based on current market conditions, the state could sell new bonds due in 2001 with a yield of about 8 3/4 percent, securities dealers estimated. That rate is down from the 11 7/8 percent yield for the 2001 bonds sold last April. The lower interest rates available now will reduce the state's interest expense, although no estimate for the savings was available yesterday.

headline: IRAQ SAYS IT BOMBED IRAN OIL PORT
abstract: Iraq said tonight that its planes had bombed Iran's main oil-export terminal at Kharg Island in the Persian Gulf and a gas plant near the southern Iranian city of Ahwaz, making ''accurate and effective'' hits on both.   A communique from the Iraqi high command said the attacks were made at 10 A.M. in retaliation for Iranian shelling of Iraqi cities.  (Iran said Iraqi planes struck at the city of Dehloran in the central province of Ilam, but its communique made no mention of any attack on Kharg Island or the gas plant.)

headline: SCM Lays Off 300
abstract: The SCM Corporation's Smith-Corona operations will end manual typewriter production and lay off 300 workers starting March 7, company officials said, bringing its area employment to 2,950, from a 1981 peak of 5,000. The company cited the economy and sales of foreign electric machines.

headline: 18 BOTTLERS SUING COKE OVER DIET SYRUP PRICES
abstract: Eighteen Coca-Cola bottling companies yesterday accused the Coca-Cola Company of overcharging for the syrup used to produce diet Coke.  In a suit filed in Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., the bottlers said they were being pressured to pay more for the diet Coke syrup than for syrup used in regular Coke - even though diet Coke syrup is far less expensive to produce.   One of the bottlers in the suit, William Schmidt, president of the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Elizabethtown, in Kentucky, said that the saccharin in a gallon of diet Coke syrup, the syrup's principal ingredient, is worth only about six cents.

headline: Utah Educator Named Thrift Agency Director
abstract: Dr. David W. Glenn, a University of Utah finance professor, has been named director of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.   Dr. Glenn will replace H. Brent Beesley, who announced his resignation last Thursday. Mr. Beesley's departure, which is effective April 20, follows the announcement earlier this month by Richard T. Pratt, the agency's chairman, that he, too, would step down in April.

headline: C.I.A. ANALYSTS NOW SAID TO FIND U.S. OVERSTATED SOVIET ARMS RISE
abstract: A dispute over Soviet military spending has erupted among intelligence analysts, according to Government officials, with specialists in the Central Intelligence Agency saying that the growth rate has been overstated for the last six years.   The C.I.A. specialists responsible for annual reviews of Soviet military spending now say that their previous estimates of increases of 3 to 4 percent each year, after inflation, may be wrong, and that the rate of growth may have been no more than 2 percent.   Their judgment is based on evidence that the Soviet Union has been producing less military equipment than was expected on the basis of the American figures for Soviet spending. Difference May Be in Billions   If the new assessment is accurate, the difference in growth rates would mean that the Russians are spending several billions of dollars less each year than had been estimated.

headline: STATEMENT BY REAGAN ON CHANGES
abstract: Following is a statement by President Reagan on personnel changes in the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency issued by the White House today:   As President of the United States, I have no higher priority or higher purpose than to reduce the risk and the means of conflict and to help bring a true peace with justice to the world we live in.  This Administration has undertaken a broad agenda for peace, including special efforts in the Middle East and a program of arms control more comprehensive and far-reaching than any other in our nation's history.   In the Start negotiations on strategic weapons, we have proposed a one-half cut in missiles and a one-third cut in warheads of the most destabilizing systems - intercontinental ballistic missiles.  Ambassador Edward Rowny will soon be returning to Geneva to resume the serious negotiations underway since last July at the Start talks. And Ambassador Paul Nitze will also be returning to Geneva in a few weeks where the I.N.F. talks will resume. In the I.N.F. negotiations on intermediate-range nuclear forces, we have proposed the elimination of the entire class of most threatening systems - longer-range land-based missiles. In both of those negotiations, we have been encouraged by the businesslike nature of the talks and believe a serious foundation for progress has been laid.

headline: PRAVDA AGAIN CRITICAL OF BONN
abstract: The newspaper Pravda today renewed criticism of the West German Government for its resolve to go ahead with plans to deploy American missiles if it wins the March 6 election.   An article by Pravda's Bonn correspondent, headed ''Sanity Must Prevail,'' said the main concern of the ruling Christian Democratic Party appeared to be how to distract the people from the antiwar movement.

headline: THURSDAY, MARCH 3, 1983
abstract: The Economy   Leading economic indicators rose 3.6 percent in January, the largest monthly gain in more than three decades, the Commerce Department reported. Economists saw the increase, the second-largest ever, as strong evidence that recovery is under way. The index has now risen in nine of the past twelve months. (Page A1.)   The Treasury agreed to ease some provisions of the law requiring withholding on interest and dividend payments by the banking and securities industries. Both had brought intense pressure on officials. Under the change, taxes on money market accounts will be withheld once a year instead of monthly or quarterly. (D1.)

headline: Secrets of Success In Product Licensing
abstract: It would seem that almost anything that is popular can be licensed, and, with clever use, advertising can transfer some of that popularity to products that may be totally unrelated.   Charles Tolep, vice president and general manager of the Licensing and Merchandising division of Viacom International, and Howard Berk, vice president, merchandising, have learned that along the way as they served as licensing agents for the characters in Terrytoons and the Lilliwinks, known only to folks much younger than yourself.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: IT'S A BIG SACRIFICE FOR JUNK-FOOD JOBS
abstract: FOR minimum-wage workers, purchasing power has been substantially e roded by inflation in recent years. The minimum wage would need to b e $4.14 an hour today to equal the buying power of the $2.65-an-hourm inimum wage in effect in 1978, the last time Congress changed the l aw. This loss of purchasing power greatly injures America's l owestpaid families, making them even more dependent upon Government s upport.  About five million workers now receive the minimum wage, and 70 percent are adults. But rather than proposing relief for these workers who are hardest hit, the Administration has proposed a subminimum wage. This scheme would pay workers up to age 22 at a rate of $2.50 an hour for five months a year.

headline: 4 Are Killed in India In Election Violence
abstract: Four people were killed and more than 100 injured today in election violence in the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh.   The turnout was heavy in voting for state assemblies in Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka and Tripura.

headline: Columbia Gas Appeals Decision
abstract: A unit of the Columbia Gas System asked the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to reverse a decision that it make refunds of some of the charges it passed on to customers from the high cost it paid affiliated suppliers. The unit, the Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation, is based in Charleston, W.Va.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Allis-Chalmers Corp., Milwaukee, said it had sold its Simplicity Manufacturing Co. division to Wesray Equipment Inc., a subsidiary of Wesray Corp., Morristown, N.J.; terms were not disclosed.   * Beefsteak Charlie's Inc. announced that discussions about the acquisition of Roma Corp., which operates a chain of restaurants, had been terminated; no further details were provided.

headline: Israelis Pressing Inquiry About Grenade Attack
abstract: The Israeli police have questioned ''many people'' in connection with a hand-grenade attack last Thursday at an anti-Government demonstration here, but no suspects have been detained, Meir Gilboa, a police spokesman, said today.   The Israeli radio reported that the army was assisting in ''intelligence gathering'' activities connected with the inquiry.

headline: 2 WEEK BAN ON CUBA AIRLINERS
abstract: Cubana Airlines has been barred from American airspace for two weeks because of two violations of traffic routings that Washington has termed a ''serious breach of air safety.''   The State Department said that Cuban officials in Washington had been informed of the suspension on Monday and that it was to take effect at 7 P.M. Eastern standard time last night.   The deviations from assigned routes occurred on March 4 and 5 and took the planes 27 and 13 miles east of the proper airway, which passes near Syracuse, according to Peter Bruce of the State Department's office of aviation.

headline: RUNNING AMERICAN: A FORMIDABLE TASK
abstract: When Robert L. Crandall took over as president of American Airlines in July 1980, the hard-driving executive who had made his mark in marketing and finance faced a formidable task. The airline had lost money in seven of the 11 preceding years.   American had opposed deregulation, which took effect in 1978. When Mr. Crandall arrived, the airline was only beginning to work out a plan to cope with the low-cost, nonunion carriers that were then emerging.

headline: Daily Auctions By Freddie Mac
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, a Government agency known as Freddie Mac, will begin auctioning mortgage participation certificates daily instead of weekly beginning March 15, Kenneth J.  Thygerson, president, said.   Participation certificates are backed by pools of conventional single-family home mortgages, whose interest and principal payments are passed through to the investor.

headline: TVI ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: INDIANS PRESS TRUDEAU ON RIGHTS UNDER NEW CHARTER
abstract: Canada's Indians and Eskimos have been trying for two days to tell Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau that God gave them the land that became Canada, and that it will always remain theirs. Mr. Trudeau was not entirely convinced.   ''God also sent Columbus across,'' the Prime Minister said. ''When do you stop reading history? Only when the white man came?'' The issue was at the core of a discussion between Indians, part-Indians and Eskimos and leaders of Canada's federal and provincial governments. The goal is to define the rights of these groups under Canada's year-old Constitution, something that has not been done in any form. The stakes include spiritual satisfaction, the status of Indian women and land claims potentially running into the billions of dollars.

headline: A Takeover Is Rumored Of Psychology Today
abstract: What would you think of Psychology Today magazine being operated by the American Psychological Association?  Well, there is an interesting rumor going about to the effect that the Council of Representatives of that national organization recently voted to take over the 15-year-old magazine.   Asked about it, Don Kent, a spokesman, would only say, ''Nothing of that kind was discussed in public sessions.''

headline: DIBRELL BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dow Chemical Loses in Suit
abstract: The Dow Chemical Company must pay more than $26 million to a bank because of a mortar additive that caused deterioration in the bank's headquarters building, a Common Pleas Court jury has ruled.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: OPEC is in disarray again as it struggles to regain control over the price of oil because it finds itself incapable of learning the lessons of the past.   Tonight, oil ministers representing the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended their fourth day of talks, claiming some progress on reducing oil prices, but no agreement on production quotas. Yet in today's glutted oil market, when much Middle East oil costs only $2 a barrel to produce, any credible pricing agreement must be supported by a watertight understanding on output.   Throughout most of this century, the price of oil has been controlled by cartel-like institutions that recognized that the free market could not be relied upon to set an appropriate price for a finite commodity.

headline: CITY CHAINS POST 5.7% SALES GAIN
abstract: Sales by seven major retail chains in New York City rose an average of 5.7 percent in February from a year earlier, according to a spotcheck conducted last week. But the overall average gain was sharply inflated by one store chain's 16.7 percent increase, and four of the seven respondents posted declines for the month.   Discounting the single large increase, the remaining six retailers as a group had an average gain of only six-tenths of 1 percent for the month. In January, the retailers reported an 11.6 percent increase, the biggest year-to-year gain since 1979. December's sales rose 4.8 percent from a year earlier.

headline: Article 228969 -- No Title
abstract: The International Monetary Fund decided today to increase its lending pool by $32.5 billion so that it can meet the demand for emergency loans from developing countries short of money to pay foreign debts.   The agreement increases the fund's basic lending pool by 47.4 percent, to $98.5 billion, from $66 billion. That percentage represented a concession to the Text of I.M.F. appraisal, page 31. United States, which had refused to go above 50 percent, as most other industrial nations wanted. The Reagan Administration had argued that it could not persuade Congress to approve this country's share of the increase - $5.8 billion - if the percentage was any higher.  The United States provides one-fifth of the agency's basic lending pool.

headline: Closings Friday
abstract: United States stock and commodity exchanges will be closed tomorrow in observance of Good Friday. Most exchanges abroad will also be closed. American banks will be open.

headline: Frankfurt Airport Accident
abstract: A Kuwait Airways airliner grazed a Pan American jet today as they were waiting to take off at Frankfurt Airport, causing extensive damage to both planes but no injuries, officials said.

headline: Texas Bank in Shift
abstract: The First National Bank of Midland, a major lender to the energy industry, announced today that it had increased its provision for loan losses to $50 million, or 3.67 percent of its loans outstanding at the end of 1982, up from $11.2 million, or 1 percent of its total loans at the end of 1981.

headline: Medlin & Associates Finds That Ad Pays Off
abstract: Five days after Medlin & Associates, Marina del Ray, Calif., lost the Alpine Electronics of America account on Jan. 2 to Kresser & Robbins, Los Angeles, it rushed an ad advising of its availability into the CES Trade News Daily of Jan. 7 for circulation at the Winter Consumer Electronics Show.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Bonanza for Depositors   Consumers, in a rare change, have been getting far higher yields on their deposits than big corporations, thanks to the deregulation of interest rates. Last week, when corporations were lucky to earn 8 1/2 percent on short-term deposits, many consumers were earning 11 percent or more.   The bonanza, however, is unlikely to continue. In California, where competition for consumer accounts is especially keen, interest rates offered on the new ''money market'' accounts have dropped substantially. The Bank of America, which competed aggressively for the new accounts, offering 11 1/4 percent plus bonuses ranging from $25 to $100, had cut that to only 10 percent last week, with no bonuses.

headline: SERVO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IN SURINAME 'THEY MAKE YOU FULL OF HOLES, MAN'
abstract: After the executions of 15 civic leaders here who were promoting a return to democracy, the military rulers of Suriname and a small group of leftist supporters appear well on the way to implanting a police state leaning toward Cuba.   They have ended freedom of speech in this former Dutch colony on South America's northern coast by burning down or closing all but one Government-controlled newspaper, radio station and television channel, banning all gatherings of more than three people, and creating a plainclothes militia to report to the authorities on the privately expressed views of citizens.   ''We've all had to take to lying because they're everywhere,'' said a Paramaribo taxi driver in the calypso English that many of the Dutch-speaking people of Suriname speak as a second language. ''Say the wrong thing and they call you in and make you full of holes, man.''   Although there is no evidence that people are routinely being murdered that way, there is widespread fear that that is the case, and this apprehension has given the military leader, Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse, and his 500 to 1,000 backers sway over Suriname's 350,000 residents.

headline: Puritan Fashions Chief Names Son as President
abstract: Andrew Rosen, the 26-year-old president of the Calvin Klein divisions of the Puritan Fashions Corporation, was named president and chief operating officer of the parent company yesterday. He is the son of Carl Rosen, Puritan's chairman, president and chief executive officer, who continues as chairman and chief executive.

headline: MURRAY OHIO MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 2 Officers Are Promoted In M-G-M/U.A. Changes
abstract: The M-G-M/U.A. Entertainment Company announced yesterday that Donald Sipes had been promoted to chairman and chief executive of its United Artists Corporation unit.   Separately, the company said that Freddie Fields, head of M-G-M/ U.A.'s worldwide motion picture production, was adding the title of president and chief operating officer of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company, the job Mr. Sipes held since November 1981.   Frank Rothman, chairman and chief executive of M-G-M/U.A., said in a prepared statement that the promotions brings an end to a series of high-level executive shifts at M-G-M/ U.A.   The shuffling began Sunday with the naming of Frank Yablans, 47, an outsider who formerly was an independent producer affiliated with the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, as Mr. Rothman's second-incommand as vice chairman and chief operating officer of M-G-M/U.A. Entertainment. Both the heads of M-G-M Film and United Artists will report to Mr. Yablans.

headline: PATENTS; Extracts from Horses To Control Blood Flow
abstract: Extracts from equine arterial tissue may be used to control bleeding in humans.

headline: Advertising; Food Insert To Benefit Easter Seal
abstract: THE March issue of Best Food Day Color Inserts from Newspaper Coop Couponing will be special in a number of ways: most important will be the approximately $1.5 million it will raise for the nation's handicapped through the National Easter Seal Society.   At the behest of the Chicago-based, 63-year-old charity, the Westport, Conn., subsidiary of the Marketing Corporation of America has pulled together 12 companies that will place in the 20 pages of this largely weekday newspaper insert ads containing cents-off coupons for 33 products. The insert will reach 37 million homes through 307 newspapers. A total of 1.3 billion coupons will be distributed, with the value in each insert coming to $8.12.

headline: Market Place; OPEC Sets Off 2 Reactions
abstract: JANUS, the ancient Roman god with two faces looking in opposite directions, could have symbolized part of the action in last week's stock market: airline stocks rose and oil issues fell in response to the same event.   The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries finished its meeting in Geneva Monday without agreeing upon production levels to bolster prices. Wall Street's reaction was that crude oil prices were likely to move lower - with bearish portents for oil-company profits - while airlines would benefit from lower jet fuel costs.   In any event, Salomon Brothers reported that industry group movements for the first four days of the week showed airlines as the strongest sector, with a gain of 6 1/2 percent, while domestic oils were the weakest, falling 5 1/2 percent.

headline: PATENTS; Simplifying the System For Automobile Wiring
abstract: A wiring system patented this week for the RCA Corporation is expected to offer advantages to automobile manufacturers and drivers.

headline: PHOSPHATE SLUMP IN BONE VALLEY
abstract: For an indication how far the troubles o f the world darm economy reach nowadays, come to Bone Valley, t he center of Florida's $3.5 billion phosphate industry.   In this five-county region where phosphate is strip-mined and chemically turned into fertilizer, mountains of unsold and unwanted phosphate rock wait for an upturn that analysts say may be as long as two years away.   The fate of the phosphate industry is intimately bound up with that of the world's depressed farm economies. And with supplies of grains that require a lot of fertilizer at record levels, analysts say, fertilizer sales are down sharply and demand for new phosphate is just about nil.

headline: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; A Goldbug's New Advice
abstract: LAST June 15, when the price of gold sank to $315 an ounce after having tumbled from its January 1980 record of $875, James Dines sent a telegram to subscribers of his investment advisory service.   ''Gold new low confirms silver downside breakout,'' the text read.  ''Therefore we decided to sell all precious metals in model portfolios. If you decide to hold, we urge hedging with puts.''

headline: Tremors in Yemen's North
abstract: Earth tremors shook Yemen's northern province of Sada last night but caused only minor damage, the official Saudi Press Agency reported today from Sana, the Yemeni capital. The Red Sea country has been jolted by earth tremors intermittently since Dec. 13, when an earthquake in Dhamar Province in the southeast killed some 3,000 people and left almost 400,000 homeless.

headline: Repeal Indexing
abstract: To the Business Editor: In the argument between Senator Dole and Representative Rostenkowski (''The Split Over Tax Indexing,'' March 6), Mr.  Rostenkowski has the better of the discussion in his call for repeal of the measure.   For support, let me refer you to Gregg A. Esenwein, economic analyst for the economics division of the Library of Congress, who writes:   ''Even though the statutory tax rate reductions enacted between 1981 and 1983 are roughly proportional (excluding the change in the tax rates applicable to unearned income), taxpayers in the upper income ranges receive relatively more benefits than do those in the lower-income range.

headline: Panhandle Fund
abstract: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation said it had established an after-tax reserve of $26 million, or 63 cents a common share, for the company's cumulative investment in the proposed Alaskan natural gas pipeline because of uncertainty surrounding the project. The charge is to be reflected in fourth-quarter earnings, it said. The company noted that the sponsoring consortium had been unable last year to complete a feasible financing plan for the project, which it estimates will cost $30 billion for the pipeline and related facilities.

headline: G.E. to Begin Engine Repairs
abstract: The problem that has led to the removal of some 10 of the General Electric turbofan engines that power the new twin-engine Boeing-767 airliner has been pinpointed and a solution worked out, a G.E.  spokesman said late yesterday.   A Government-approved modification will be made on all 76 engines that have been produced so far, the spokesman, Leonard Dalquest, said.

headline: THE NEW YEAR'S NEW TAX PROVISIONS
abstract: THERE have been so many changes in the tax laws in the last few y ears that it is almost impossible for the average person to keep on t op of them. And on Jan. 1, a host of further changes -including a n ew system for withholding taxes on pension payments - went into e ffect and will have a widespread impact on millions of taxpayers.  H ere's a rundown of some of those new provisions.   PENSION WITHHOLDING. The new withholding system for pensions and annuities, the provision that has attracted the most attention, is designed to make sure that pensioners and others do not escape paying the Government at least some of the taxes they owe. (Waiters and waitresses have also become subject to withholding on part of their tip income, and investors are scheduled to come under the collection net too, when withholding on dividend and interest income goes into effect on July 1).

headline: NICARAGUA ACCUSES EX-ENVOY ON FUNDS
abstract: Nicaraguan officals charged today that Managua's former Ambassador to the United States withdrew $668,000 from the embassy's account without authorization before he left office.   Manuel Cordero, the acting charge d'affaires at the Nicaraguan Embassy here, said his Government still did not know what had happened to most of the money. ''We are trying to find out more about this thing,'' he said.

headline: Dow Rises by 5.03, To Record 1,145.90; Institutional Buying Cited
abstract: Stock prices finished moderately higher yesterday after Wednesday's sharp advance, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 5.03 points, to close at a record 1,145.90.   Analysts noted that stock prices yesterday continued to benefit from the news on Wednesday that consumer prices last month fell two-tenths of 1 percent. On Wednesday, the 30 issues that make up the Dow average, soared 17.90 points.   ''The market's advance today was fueled by heavy institutional buying plus growing participation from many of the small investors who have remained on the sidelines for years,'' said Serge J. Enni, vice president of Edward A. Viner & Company.

headline: CHINA REPORTS BIRTH OF PANDA
abstract: China disclosed today the birth of another panda in captivity and said the orphaned cub has received round-theclock attention in a children's hospital and in a first-class army ward for the first five months of its life.   The official New China News Agency said the panda, a female named Xingyue - meaning Star and Moon - was the first baby panda to survive at the zoo in eight births since 1962, and the longest-surviving panda reared without its mother.

headline: Warwick Joins Alliance
abstract: Warwick Advertising, with its billings of $120 million, has become the United States partner in Alliance International, a new Swiss company based in Brussels. Alliance is jointly owned by six ad agencies and Lopex Ltd., a publicly owned British investment firm that specializes in communications companies and, indeed, owns a minority piece of each of the six agencies. The other agencies are the Kirkwood Company in England; CFRP in France; LVH & Partners in Belgium; Prad in the Netherlands, and Arks Ltd. in Ireland.

headline: ISRAEL PUTTING SEVERE CURBS ON CIGARETTE ADS
abstract: Israel, a nation of four million people in which smoking-related illnesses kill about 3,000 people a year, has decided to impose tight restrictions on cigarette advertising.   When it takes effect, six months from its approval last Monday by Parliament, the law will ban advertising of tobacco products on radio and television, in movie theaters and public transport and on any outdoor signs. A spokesman for Parliament said the measure would also prohibit sales promotions from displaying photographs of people who are younger than 40 or who are wearing sport clothes or uniforms of any type. Celebrities will be barred from apppearing in such advertising.

headline: Want Ads Up Again
abstract: The help-wanted advertising index rose five points in December, the fourth consecutive monthly increase, the Conference Board reported yesterday. But the index remained far below levels of a year ago, the business-supported research group said.

headline: Ball Is Bringing Vigor To Prudential-Bache
abstract: People meeting George L. Ball, the 44-year-old president and chief executive officer of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., are struck by his youthful looks. But for a man with the face of a Cub Scout, Mr.  Ball does not always act like one.

headline: Barnett Banks Cleared by Fed
abstract: The Barnett Banks of Florida Inc., of Jacksonville, said the Federal Reserve Board had approved three applications to acquire banks with assets totaling $142 million.   The banks are the State Exchange Bank of Lake City, the Treasure Coast Bankcorp Inc., owner of the Port St. Lucie Bank, and the Suncoast Bancorp Inc., owner of the Commercial Bank of Vero Beach.

headline: EGYPTIAN SAYS RADAR PLANES WERE SENT BY U.S. SOLELY FOR TRAINING
abstract: The Egyptian Defense Minister said today that four American electronic surveillance aircraft in his country were there for training purposes only and would leave when the training was over.   The Defense Minister, Abdel Halim Abu Ghazala, was asked about reports from Washington that the Airborne Warning and Control System aircraft, called Awacs, would leave Egypt on Tuesday.   ''The Awacs will not leave Egypt before Egyptian pilots complete their training on them,'' he said. ''We shall decide the date on which the training finishes.''

headline: PRIME CUT HALF-POINT, TO 11%
abstract: The nation's leading banks, in an action that lagged considerably behind a sharp drop in the cost of their own funds, lowered their prime lending rates yesterday by half a percentage point, to 11 percent.   The banks attributed the delay to uncertainty about the cost of new money market accounts for consumers and the possibility of large losses from loan defaults.   The prime rate cut was widely expected because of the unusually big gap between the interest rates banks have been paying for their own funds, about 8 1/2 percent, and the interest rates they have been charging on loans to their medium-size and small corporate customers, which range upward from 11 1/2 percent.   In response to the falling cost of money, the Chase Manhattan Bank lowered its prime rate to 11 percent as early as Dec. 28, but no other major bank followed until yesterday.

headline: THURSDAY, MARCH 10, 1983
abstract: Markets   Stock prices started climbing again, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 12.86 points, to 1,132.64. On Tuesday, the Dow fell almost 22 points. Most of the gain came as speculation spread that OPEC was near a price-cutting accord. The two other major indexes also rose. On the Big Board, advances outnumbered declines by 1,011 to 610, while turnover expanded to 84.3 million shares. (Page D1.)   Interest rates were little changed in quiet trading. (D7.) In early April, Alabama plans to sell more than $460 million of new bonds, using the proceeds to re-fund before maturity $360 million of bonds sold last April when interest rates were higher. (D7.)

headline: Advertising; Laxative Maker's Campaign
abstract: IF any of them had been watching the tube at the time, the announcement that each of the three dancing bottles of Phillips Milk of Magnesia were the viewer's ''true blue friend'' would have come as a major shock to Smurf fans. After all, how many blue friends can one have?   However, there is little danger of confusing the two fan clubs, since Smurf doll collectors tend to be very young, and Phillips users tend to be on the older side of the population curve.   As a matter of fact, the heavy users of laxatives are practically all in the same demographic segment: generally female, older than 55, lower income, retired and not highly educated. And they are brand loyal, terribly brand loyal, which accounts for Phillips still being the best seller in its category of the market 120 years after introduction. Not many package goods can make that statement.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;
abstract: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Feb. 11 (Reuters) - Canada's Energy Mines and Resources Ministry said it had concluded exploration agreements with BP Exploration Canada Ltd. and partners calling for investments of about $260 million for the drilling of six offshore wells covering 5.3 million hectares on the Grand Banks-Labrador Shelf.   The partners are BP Exploration, a BP Canada Inc. unit, Columbia Development of Canada Ltd., Petro-Canada Exploration, Chevron Canada Ltd. and Gulf Canada Resources Ltd.

headline: Renaissance Lenders in Pact
abstract: Owners of Phase I of the Renaissance Center have tentatively agreed to share ownership with its mortgage holders, officials said today.   Under the agreement, the five lenders would become partners in Phase I, which includes a 73-story hotel and four 39-story office towers, according to a statement by Philip Caldwell, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, whose subsidiary is a major partner in the Renaissance Center.

headline: GRIM SEARCH FOR LONDON MURDER VICTIMS
abstract: The police charged a 37-year-old Government employment service worker today with the murder of a young drifter, and searched for the dismembered corpses of other victims.   Scotland Yard said parts of three bodies had been found at the suspect's apartment building, and they expected to discover the bodies of up to 14 other victims.   The police charged Dennis Andrew Nilsen, a bachelor, with the murder of the only victim so far identified, Stephen Neil Sinclair, 20 years old, who was unemployed and had no permanent home.

headline: Washington Watch; Ocean Depots For Mariners
abstract: WASHINGTON THE Commerce Department, which a few weeks ago announced its intention to seek a private-industry buyer for the Government's weather satellites, has further plans for making certain services a business proposition.   John V. Byrne, head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, says the agency expects to begin creating a halfdozen or so ocean service centers that would be ''one-stop'' information depots for mariners. The centers would serve everyone from the Sunday afternoon sailboater to the captain of the largest tanker or luxury liner.   The idea is to gather the agency's data on such things as water temperatures, wave height, tides, currents, winds and cloud cover in one place where it would be more readily available to users. The prototype of these combination store-front, telephone-bank operations, staffed mostly by oceanographers and meteorologists, is to open in Seattle in July with two more to follow by the end of the year.

headline: Bribery at Kodak
abstract: ROCHESTER Jan. 18 (AP) - The Federal Bureau of Investigation said it was investigating a bribery scheme at the Eastman Kodak Company in which some jobs were ''sold'' to prospective applicants, The Rochester Democrat and Chronicle reported. It said applicants paid up to $500 to at least two company employees for jobs at Kodak's Apparatus division. Kodak called the F.B.I. six months ago after hearing of ''payment for jobs,'' a company spokesman, Timothy Elliott, said.

headline: Holiday Inns to K.&E.
abstract: Holiday Inns in Memphis confirmed yesterday the rampant rumors that Kenyon & Eckhardt would, effective immediately, be the ad agency for its $15 million domestic advertising account and would both create and place the ads. The last ad agency, Young & Rubicam, had just been doing the placement in recent months.

headline: Tear Gas Used on Pakistanis
abstract: The police fired tear gas at several hundred demonstrators today after Sunni Moslems tried to attack a Shiite Moslem place of worship that was guarded by armed policemen, witnesses reported. The incident occurred during a brief relaxation of a curfew imposed on West Karachi to end violence that broke out Sunday in a dispute between Sunnis and Shiites over ownership of a mosque.

headline: Arafat Asks Support in P.L.O.  For His Stand on Reagan Plan
abstract: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, conferred with leaders of the P.L.O.'s member groups in Aden today to seek backing for his cautious welcome to an American Middle East peace plan, Palestinian sources said.   It was not clear whether all eight P.L.O. groups were represented.

headline: CORPORATE KIDS
abstract: Until this year, Chemical Bank, like most companies, didn't have special child-care benefits. Employees with young children and working spouses had to pay for child-care costs out of their own pocket.   All that has changed. In January, Chemical, the nation's sixth-largest bank, introduced a flexible benefits program that permits workers to use benefits money for child care -money that might otherwise have gone for medical or dental insurance, for example.

headline: AMETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PNB MORTGAGE & REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; A TRIUMPH OF BIPARTISAN NEGOTIATING
abstract: THE compromise agreement on Social Security reached by the National Commission on Social Security Reform, if ultimately a pproved by Congress and the President, will go down in history as a l andmark in political statesmanship.  None of the 12 commission members who endorsed the agreement (three did not) did so without painful concession. But the fact that all 12 members, representing an extraordinarily broad range of philosophies, made concessions, and that both President Reagan and the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., concurred in the agreement, demonstrates bipartisanship at its best.  Until Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Senator Bob Dole in early January initiated the negotiations that led to the compromise, I was frankly disappointed with the way things were going. The Republicans on the commission had all but ignored a compromise put forward informally in November by the Democrats on the commission. It appeared that another protracted, rancorous fight in Congress over the future of Social Security was in prospect. That prospect was especially frustrating because we Democrats had gone along, in the interest of compromise and prudence, with a very pessimistic Republican assessment of the scope of need.

headline: AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: New HBO President Named by Time Inc.
abstract: Time Inc. said yesterday that it had named a new president and chief executive of Home Box Office Inc. and promoted the current HBO head to a newly created post of deputy group vice president for video in the Time organization.   James O. Heyworth, 40, the current head of HBO, which is Time's pay television subsidiary, will share in the management, planning and administration of the video group, the company said. The group was the largest contributor to Time Inc.'s profits last year.

headline: Key U.S. Trade Official, A Japan Specialist, Quits
abstract: David R. Macdonald, a specialist in Japanese trade issues, has resigned as deputy United States trade representative to return to private law practice, it was announced today.   The resignation, effective March 31, is the first of several expected as a result of proposals to centralize Government trade functions.

headline: UNITED STATES TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DEBT AGREEMENT FOR UNITED BRANDS
abstract: The United Brands Company said that it had reached an agreement in principle with its bank lenders to replace several revolving credit and short-term borrowing arrangements totaling about $200 million.

headline: Careers; Penn State Team's Majors
abstract: IT takes a lot of meat and potatoes to feed the 26 members of the Penn State football team (11 offensive players and 11 defensive players plus four kicking and receiving specialists).   These men, without padding and helmets, average well over 200 pounds apiece - mute testimony to their healthy appetites and gridiron prowess. But they are also students as well as athletes. Are they preparing for useful careers after their playing days are over?  What majors have they selected?

headline: MONSANTO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Polish Defectors in Sweden
abstract: A Polish military helicopter carrying two soldiers seeking asylum landed on Tarno Island in southern Sweden today, the police said.

headline: BANKS KEEPING LOAN RATES HIGH TO PROTECT EARNINGS, REGAN SAYS
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the banking industry was keeping interest rates high in part to protect itself from losses on problem loans.   In testimony before the Senate Appropriations Committee, Mr. Regan cited three reasons why interest rates had not fallen closer to the levels that might be expected in a sluggish economy with a low rate of inflation.   He said one reason was the financial community's uncertainty about the monetary policies of the Federal Reserve Board; the second was concern about huge borrowing by the Treasury to meet anticipated budget deficits.   ''I think the third one, being very candid, is bank earnings,'' Mr. Regan said. ''I think that banks, faced with a lot of problem loans, both domestic and international, are doing their utmost to keep their earnings by keeping their interest rates up.''

headline: Rite-Aid Net Climbs 86%
abstract: The Rite-Aid Corporation of Shiremanstown, Pa., a retail drug, grocery and specialty retailer, yesterday reported fourth-quarter earnings for the period ended Feb. 26 rose 86.7 percent, to $24 million, or $1.14 a share, from $12.9 million, or 61 cents a share, reported in the quarter a year ago. Sales rose 28.4 percent, to $371.6 million, for the most recent period, compared with $289.3 million a year ago.

headline: BUDD CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 5 U.S. MARINES AND 9 ITALIANS WOUNDED IN LEBANON
abstract: Units of the multinational peacekeeping force were attacked here Tuesday night and today, and nine Italian soldiers and five United States marines were wounded.   The Americans, who were part of a 12-man marine patrol, were said to have suffered superficial wounds this morning when a hand grenade was thrown from a second-story window in a southern suburb near the Beirut international airport.   This incident occurred eight hours after gunmen made two attacks on Italians in the same general area late Tuesday.  Six Italians were wounded, three seriously, when the gunmen fired rocket-propelled grenades at two Jeeps carrying Italian soldiers on a road leading to the airport. Other Italian soldiers who rushed to the area as reinforcements were also fired upon, and three more were wounded.

headline: Israel Firm on Putting Lookouts in Lebanon
abstract: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that Israel would continue to insist on operating early-warning posts in Lebanon until a peace pact was signed.   The statement came after five hours of talks over two days with Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, who is trying to speed up the withdrawal of foreign forces from Lebanon.   Asked over the Israeli radio whether Israel would agree to American staffing of the posts in light of Syrian and Lebanese resistance to a prolonged Israeli presence in Lebanon, Mr. Shamir said: ''We did not present this demand and include this condition in the security arrangements in order to abandon it.''

headline: ALLEGHANY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AMERICAN MEDICAL AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt   * American Motors Corp. said it had sold $50 million of subordinated debentures due in 2003 to Renault Holding S.A., Renault's Swiss holding company; the transaction does not affect Renault's 46.4 percent stake in A.M.C., the company said.   * Robert Bosch G.m.b.H.'s 50 million franc, or about $7.1 million, issue of 4 3/4 percent notes due in 1989 were priced at 99.75 on the Swiss capital market, through Union Bank of Switzerland.   * Comtech Telecommunications Corp.'s offering of 10,000 units, each consisting of $1,000 principal amount of notes due in 1991 and 80 warrants to purchase shares of common stock, is under way through Drexel Burnham Lambert.   * The Export-Import Bank of Japan is privately placing 150 million francs, or about $21.4 million, of 4 7/8 percent notes due in 1988 at par on the Swiss capital market through Union Bank of Switzerland.

headline: Brock Rejects Steel Plea
abstract: The United States trade representative, Bill Brock, today rejected the domestic steel industry's request to investigate what the industry charges is a secret international marketing cartel formed by Japan and West Europe.   Mr. Brock's office said that the industry petition did not contain all the information needed for an inquiry.

headline: GENERAL EMPLOYMENT ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ANDROPOV MEETS NICARAGUAN
abstract: Yuri V. Andropov met at the Kremlin today with Daniel Ortega Saavedra, coordinator of Nicaragua's junta.  The meeting was the Soviet leader's first announced engagement in 11 days and appeared to end the uncertainty that developed when rumors swept Moscow that he was ill. Some reports said Mr. Andropov, 68 years old, who succeeded Leonid I. Brezhnev as Communist Party leader in November, was suffering from a kidney ailment, but a senior official said it was nothing worse than influenza.

headline: WHEN THE GRAND MASTER IS A 'GHOST'
abstract: One shortcoming of most computerized chess games is that the computer can calculate its own moves but cannot make them itself.  The human opponent must move the computer's pieces in response to lights or other signals from the machine.   The Milton Bradley Company, however, has now come up with a chess game in which the computer can move its own pieces. In fact, the pieces just slide across the board, as if being moved by an invisible hand. And when the computer captures an opponent's piece, that piece just quietly glides to the side of the board.

headline: MAYNARD OIL CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. WILL CONTINUE TO PRESS JAPAN ON DEFENSE
abstract: Mike Mansfield, the American Ambassador, says that while Japan has made ''very significant'' efforts to raise military spending, the United States will continue to press for further increases.   In an interview Friday, Mr. Mansfield said Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, who took office in November, was ''entitled to a lot of appreciation'' for the Government's recent decision on a military budget of more than $12 billion for the year beginning April 1, an increase of 6.5 percent.   The former senator from Montana, who has served here since 1977, said the Japanese first proposed a 1983 increase in military spending of 5 to 5.1 percent, then 6 percent and finally, under American urging to go higher, settled on the 6.5 percent increase that was announced Dec. 30. In that final decision, Mr. Mansfield said, Mr.  Nakasone was ''the mainspring.''

headline: Salvador Weighs Freeing Prisoners for Pope
abstract: The Constituent Assembly will review cases of hundreds of political prisoners for possible release during Pope John Paul II's visit to El Salvador next month, two Government officials said today.   A Supreme Court source said the Constituent Assembly would review cases of some 700 people jailed under a 1981 martial law decree for possible release in ''a demonstration of good faith for the arrival of the Pope.''

headline: Market Place; Escalation in Stock Indexes
abstract: JUST when brokerage firms seemed to agree that phase one of the bull market in stocks was over, a strange thing happened: Several broad market indicators moved higher last week to finish at record levels.   And, in interviews on Friday, the chief investment officers of two major New York City banks managing more than $33 billion agreed that stocks and bonds - but decidedly not cash - are the best investments.    Setting new highs were the New York Stock Exchange's index of 1,517 common stocks, Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq barometer of 3,664 over-the-counter issues.   Even the American Stock Exchange's index of 824 issues finished close to its record high of August 1981. This recovery reflected some price improvement in energy stocks, as well as gains in technology and other sectors.

headline: From London, Wary Approval
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that a modest decline in oil prices was good for Britain because it would aid economic recovery and because the country was close to self-sufficiency in oil.   She told the Institute of Directors annual convention that because oil accounted for only 4 percent to 4 1/2 percent of Britain's gross national product, the direct effects of a price cut were smaller than for most other oil-producing countries.

headline: P.L.O. 'Personalities' Are Banned by Israel
abstract: The Israeli television and radio have been ordered to stop referring to ''personalities in the P.L.O.'' in newscasts because the term has positive connotations, a spokesman for the state-subsidized Broadcasting Authority said today.   The spokesman, Ariella Ravdal, said the decision was made because the Hebrew word ishim, meaning personalities or personages, is reserved for ''respectable persons, not for the leaders of international terrorism.''   She said the order to ban the word in referring to the Palestine Liberation Organization had been prompted by viewer protests.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: ATTACKING CAFFEINE CONFUSION
abstract: CANADA DRY Ginger Ale will spend $2.1 million in five weeks in television, radio and newspapers to declare that it is not now, nor has it ever been, a caffeine-containing member of the soft-drink fraternity.   ''There is both concern and confusion,'' said Francis I. Mullin, recently named president of Canada Dry U.S.A., who said he knows from consumer tracking studies that 15 to 20 percent of adult consumers think his product does contain caffeine.   And why shouldn't they? After all, they have lived through 1982, the caffeine-conscious year when the soft-drink crowd poured about $100 million into the promotion of caffeine-free, or almost caffeinefree, drinks.

headline: GLATFELTER, P H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SUPERIOR OIL PROFITS DROP 67.2%
abstract: The Superior Oil Company reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter plunged 67.2 percent, to $24 million, or 19 cents a share, from $73.2 million or 57 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1981. Revenues dropped 10.1 percent, to $504.1 million, from $560.5 million.   For the full year, the Houston-based integrated oil company said that net income dropped 38.2 percent, to $223.4 million, or $1.75 a share, from $361.3 million, or $2.84 a share, in 1981. Revenues for the year dipped 1 percent, to $2.04 billion, from $2.06 billion a year earlier.

headline: UP-RIGHT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Japan Critical Of Tax Move
abstract: Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe has criticized the United States for asking the Toyota Motor Corporation, ''without the Japanese Government's consent,'' to submit information on production costs and prices in connection with its United States subsidiary's taxes, Foreign Ministry officials said.   Mr. Abe replied Friday to a question in the parliament about the court dispute between Toyota and the United States Internal Revenue Service on cost and price information, the officials said.

headline: FORUM; A PLEA FOR IMMEDIATE WRITE-OFFS
abstract: THE average American business that wants to modernize its m anufacturing process is faced with a discouraging array of d isincentives. These disincentives - including the rate of d epreciation - are the result of a woeful lack of foresight by g overnment over the past 20 years.  The Economic Recovery Act of 1981, which included a 15-5-3 depreciation schedule, was enacted to correct the slow rate of growth in new plant and equipment investment. But this legislation, supported by the American Chamber of Commerce and most businessmen, was already five years out of date the day it was passed.

headline: POLL SHOWS LESSENING OF FEAR THAT U.S. MILITARY IS LAGGING
abstract: The Reagan Administration has begun a costly program to build more Trident submarines. Page 17. By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT   A recent sampling of national public opinion suggests a growing number of Americans no longer fear that the United States is lagging behind the Soviet Union in military prowess and feel the Reagan Administration is spending too much money on sophisticated new weapons systems.   In his proposed budget for the 1984 fiscal year, presented last week, President Reagan asked Congress for a 14 percent increase in military spending, and at the same time sought a freeze on spending for domestic programs. The Reagan Administration says the increase is necessary to counter a Soviet advantage in military power.

headline: Washington Watch; Lapse of Curbs Ends TV Saga
abstract: WASHINGTON FOREIGN policy controls barring American participation in the Moscow Olympics back in the summer of 1980 will quietly expire at the end of February. One result: the Russians will get a $14 million check from NBC.   The check is the final chapter in the saga of the contract to televise the Olympic Games that the network won in 1977 - only to rue the coup in 1980 when President Carter slapped on the export controls in response to the Russian intervention in Afghanistan.   NBC won the contract for $87 million, ending ABC's dominance of Olympic coverage, but it couldn't televise the games after the controls were imposed and it still had a contract to pay off. Even after insurance payments, mainly from Lloyd's of London underwriters, it took a loss of $34 million.

headline: Steel Industry Outlook
abstract: The annual production capability of the nation's steel industry will fall to an estimated 151.2 million short tons of raw steel in 1983 from 154 million in 1982, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today. Based on a December survey, the industry trade association said production capability reached a record 160 million tons in 1977 and had declined gradually, to about 154 million tons in each of the past three years.

headline: No Headline
abstract: UNDERGROUND ASKS POLES TO PREPARE FOR STRIKE   WARSAW, Jan. 28 (Reuters) - Five underground leaders of the banned Solidarity labor union have called on Polish workers to prepare for a general strike.   A leaflet containing such a call but specifying no date was made available today to Western reporters.

headline: Thrift Company's Suit Dismissed
abstract: A Federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit in which Financial Federation Inc. accused Severyn Ashkenazy, a developer and an owner of hotels, of illegally conspiring to gain control of the savings and loan company.   District Judge William P. Gray's ruling gave Mr. Ashkenazy a victory in his yearlong court battle to keep his stake in the company and retain his seat on its board.   Attorneys for the Culver City-based savings and loan company said an appeal of Thursday's decision was ''being considered.'' Mr. Ashkenazy was accused by Financial Federation of violating Federal banking, securities and racketeering laws and state banking law by assembling a controlling interest through a secret group of partners.

headline: NUCLEAR INDUSTRY: HURTING BUT HIRING
abstract: QUESTION: How many workers does it take to change a light bulb in a n uclear plant?  ANSWER: Four. One to change the bulb, a second to measure the r adiation exposure incurred on the job, a third to keep the records o f what was done and a fourth to file the appropriate report with theN uclear Regulatory Commission.   That cumbersome manpower problem is part of the reason that 102 nuclear plants have been canceled since 1972. But it has also meant growing employment.

headline: U.S. Restricting Visas Of North Koreans at U.N.
abstract: The United States is restricting the re-entry visas it issues to North Korea's United Nations diplomats in retaliation for the harboring by North Korea's United Nations Mission of a North Korean official wanted on a charge of sexual abuse, diplomats from both countries said today.   The United States has imposed the restriction because a North Korean third secretary, O Nam Chol, has refused to leave his country's mission at 40 East 80th Street since last September, when an arrest warrant was issued charging him with sexually abusing a woman in a park in Eastchester, N.Y. He can be arrested only if he leaves the mission.

headline: WITHHOLDING TAX ON BANKS: BID FOR REPEAL
abstract: The banking industry's drive to repeal a key element in last year's tax bill that subjects interest and dividends to 10 percent withholding has produced one of the hottest and, some say, nastiest debates in recent years.   The pro-repeal forces have charged, among other things, that savings accounts will be ''looted'' and that investors' earnings will ''disappear'' should the deductions, which are to begin July 1, take effect.   President Reagan said today that he thought the effort for repeal was ''entirely wrong.'' He added, ''I think that a great lobbying effort has resulted in much distortion.''   Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and a main defender of withholding as a way to catch tax cheats, complains that the bankers' ''unscrupulous'' war of words represents a ''historic low'' in lobbying tactics. Both he and Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan have implied that should the banks succeed, the Government would retaliate by seeking to increase their taxes.

headline: Geers Gross Picks Up $10 Million in Billings
abstract: Geers Gross Advertising, newly installed in quarters in The Daily News Building, has pulled in about $10 million in additional billings recently from both new and existing clients.   Leading the list with a $4 million budget is the Westgate Company, a subsidiary of South African Breweries, which is making its debut in the United States market.

headline: Wind Damages Guatemala
abstract: Winds with gusts up to 50 miles an hour struck the city today, blacking out most of the capital and destroying ramshackle hillside homes, the authorities said.  President Efrain Rios Montt declared a nationwide state of emergency.

headline: BankAmerica Revision: Income Much Lower
abstract: Under pressure from the Securities and Exchange Commission, the BankAmerica Corporation yesterday reported sharply lower net operating income for the fourth quarter than it had reported last month.   The revision reduced net operating earnings, before securities transactions, by $30.8 million, to $42.6 million. The bank had originally reported net operating earnings of $73.4 million.

headline: F.A.S.B. Issues Peso Bulletin
abstract: The Financial Accounting Standards Board yesterday issued a technical bulletin to provide guidance on how Mexican subsidiaries of United States companies should translate pesos into dollars for consolidation into the parent's financial statements.   The F.A.S.B. noted that its Statement 52 on foreign currency translation accounting requires that local currency, cash, receivables and other monetary items be translated into United States dollars at the current exchange rate.

headline: F-16's Reach Pakistan
abstract: The first 3 of 40 advanced F-16 fighter planes to be supplied by the United States to Pakistan arrived today, air force headquarters announced. A statement from the headquarters in Peshawar, capital of the northwest frontier province bordering Afghanistan, said 3 more would arrive in a few days.

headline: AUSTRALIAN VOTE: LABOR IS BUOYANT
abstract: Australians will vote March 5 in national elections called by Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser nine months ahead of schedule. They will choose between the Liberal-National Party coalition led by Mr. Fraser, which has governed this country for all but three of the last 34 years, and the Labor Party, headed by its newly elected leader, Robert Hawke.   Opinion polls in the last two weeks have shown the Labor Party with an 11 percentage point advantage, but a poll published today in the newspaper The Australian showed the Liberals narrowing that lead to 4 percentage points. Forty-five percent of those polled favored Labor and 41 percent the Liberals.

headline: LONE STAR OFF
abstract: The Halliburton Company reported yesterday that the sharp drop in domestic oil drilling caused fourth-quarter net income to plunge 46.8 percent and revenues to decline 32.6 percent.   The diversified, Dallas-based oil-well services company said that net income in the latest three months plummeted to $97.9 million, or 83 cents a share, from $184.1 million, or $1.56 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1981. Fourth-quarter revenues plunged to $1.59 billion, from $2.36 billion in the comparable period a year earlier.

headline: DeLorean Filing
abstract: John Z. DeLorean, founder and chairman of the bankrupt DeLorean Motor Company, filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court seeking repayment of more than $700,000 from his old company, a DeLorean attorney said.

headline: BRITAIN CANCELS PYM'S PERSIAN GULF TOUR
abstract: A proposed Persian Gulf tour by Francis Pym, the Foreign Secretary, was canceled today amid signs of worsening relations between Britain and the Arab nations in the area.   Officially, the trip was said to have been ''deferred.'' The Foreign Office insisted in a terse statement that ''the governments concerned have made it clear that their invitations to Mr. Pym still stand, and we will be in touch in due course about alternate dates.'' But Government and diplomatic sources made it clear that three countries - first Saudi Arabia, then Qatar and the United Arab Emirates - had told London Mr. Pym would not be welcome.

headline: NICARAGUAN SEES SALVADOR LINK IN REBEL ATTACKS
abstract: The Interior Minister charged today that the United States was trying to strengthen its hand in El Salvador by stepping up efforts to disrupt the Nicaraguan Government.   The minister, Tomas Borge Martinez, who is a member of the Sandinists' nine-man National Directorate, said at a news conference: ''In El Salvador, the war has reached the point of seriously endangering the Government, so the United States wants to create the idea of a civil war here, too. It would then hope to negotiate the two civil wars as part of a broad Central American settlement.''   Mr. Borge, who is in charge of state security, said rightist rebel activities posed no threat to the revolutionary Nicaraguan Government. He dismissed recent assertions by the Honduras-based Nicaraguan Democratic Force that its units had recently occupied several towns in Matagalpa Province, some 60 miles north of here.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * American Resources Management Corp., Denver, has named J.B. Kimo Smith vice president and general counsel.   * Atlantic City Electric Co. has elected E. Douglas Huggard executive vice president.

headline: Mrs. Allende Is Barred From Entering the U.S.
abstract: Hortensia Bussi de Allende, the widow of President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile, was denied a visa today to enter the United States, according to the State Department.

headline: BEEFSTEAK CHARLIE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 22
