headline: OPEC RIFT UNSETTLES MEXICO
abstract: Before Finance Minister Jesus Silva Herzog set off on a tour of Western financial capitals last week, Mexico's hard-pressed Government appeared to have worked out almost to the penny how it would cover import needs and interest payments this year.   But as Mr. Silva Herzog sought to pin down foreign pledges to lend Mexico a further $5 billion and to restructure some $20 billion in outstanding debt, the prospect of a new drop in world oil prices following last weekend's OPEC meeting sent dismayed officials back to their calculators.   ''Every $1 drop in oil prices means a loss of $500 million per year for us,'' said one senior official, who asked not to be named. ''But every 1 percent drop in interest rates brings a saving of around $700 million. We can only wait and see what happens.''

headline: IRAQI DRIVE AGAINST IRAN OFFENSIVE SAID TO GET OFF TO SUCCESSFUL START
abstract: Western intelligence sources said yesterday that Iraqi troops, supported by ground attack aircraft and helicopters, had begun what appeared to be an initially successful counterattack against an Iranian drive into the southeastern Iraqi province of Misan.   Iraq reported that its troops counterattacked and surrounded the main body of the attacking Iranian force yesterday morning after fighting through the night, and United States and other Western military sources said they believed that Iraqi reports were generally more credible than those from Iran.   The intelligence sources pointed out that Iran, in its battle reports, was saying nothing about the apparently heavy bombing raids by Iraqi planes against Dizful, an Iranian town at the center of a network of roads used to support the Iranian offensive.   Communiques broadcast by the Teheran radio said Iranian troops began a new phase in their offensive Wednesday night and ''destroyed'' the 12th Brigade of the Iraqi Third Army.

headline: Data Bank; March 6, 1983
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: PROSPECTS FOR NEW AIR FARES
abstract: After four years of intensive fare wars, most of the nation's airlines are rallying behind a proposal that would eliminate a good part of deep discounting in many markets and restore a simpler structure that resembles what existed before deregulation of the industry.   The new fare structure, combined with the recent upturn in traffic and continuing drop in fuel prices, could enable the industry to begin making money again after two years of heavy losses.   Some industry analysts warn, however, that the proposal remains fragile and that it would not take much to upset it. Pan American World Airways, according to sources close to the company, will announce today that it will not go along with the proposal, which could force exceptions to the new plan in some major markets.

headline: Holders Approve Pabst Asset Sale
abstract: Shareholders of the Pabst Brewing Company have approved the acquisition of part of the company by the G. Heileman Brewing Company.

headline: BUSINESS PRODUCTIVITY ROSE 2.7% IN 4th QUARTER
abstract: Productivity in American business, excluding agriculture, rose 2.7 percent in the last quarter of 1982, as declining output during the recession was more than offset by a reduction in working hours, the Labor Department reported today.   For the year, nonfarm business productivity rose at an annual rate of two-tenths of 1 percent, following a 1.4 percent gain in 1981, which had reversed two years of declining productivity.  Productivity, which measures the volume of goods and services the economy produces in each hour of paid working time, had fallen at an annual rate of 1.3 percent in 1979 and nine-tenths of 1 percent in 1980. There was a six-tenths of 1 percent gain in 1978.

headline: NEW-HOME SALES DROP BY 5.9%
abstract: Sales of new single-family houses declined 5.9 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported today. However, housing industry spokesmen were not discouraged, noting that sales were still far better than they were at the same time last year.

headline: ENVOYS SAY TRIPOLI STRIFE MAY SNAG PULLOUT TALKS
abstract: The fighting in the northern port city of Tripoli is being watched by diplomats here who say they are concerned that the clashes could further complicate the bogged-down talks between Israel and Lebanon on the withdrawal of foreign forces from Lebanon.   Lebanon's Prime Minister, Shafik al-Wazzan, went to Damascus today for talks for President Hafez al-Assad of Syria on the deteriorating situation in Tripoli.   Despite the announcement Wednesday that a cease-fire had been worked out between feuding pro- and anti-Syrian Moslem groups, shelling and gunfire has persisted in certain areas of Tripoli, Lebanon's second-largest city with a population of about half a million people. Shooting Resumes After Lull   After an overnight lull, the violence resumed today. The Tripoli police said 208 people had been killed and 587 wounded in seven weeks of on-again, off-again fighting. But no one really knows the precise fatality figure.

headline: Article 246579 -- No Title
abstract: Refco, a Chicago brokerage firm, and its chairman have agreed to pay fines totaling $525,000 relating to a complaint accusing the firm of violating Federal regulations on commodity speculation.

headline: UNCERTAINTY ON MONEY DATA
abstract: The importance assigned by the financial markets to changes in the nation's money supply has varied widely in recent years and is still in a state of flux.   The afternoon money supply announcement Friday had little effect on interest rates, which had increased modestly earlier in the day. But in previous days' trading, rapid money supply growth was worrisome enough to cause yields for notes and bonds to rise more than a quarter of a percentage point.   From October 1979 to October 1982, the weekly money supply annmouncement was often the biggest event of each week and would send prices up or down, depending on whether the money supply seemed to be growing slower or faster than the Fed's growth targets.

headline: EIGHT BELL UNITS RETAIN HIGHEST S.& P. RATING
abstract: Two weeks after most of its credit ratings were slashed by Moody's Investor Service Inc., the American Telephone and Telegraph Company received a qualified vote of confidence yesterday from the Standard & Poor's Corporation.   Standard & Poor's said it would retain its top-grade triple-A rating for eight Bell System operating subsidiaries. It left unchanged its second-highest, double-A-plus, for a ninth subsidiary.  The credit ratings of 11 other A.T.& T. units were lowered, but not by as much as Moody's had lowered them. And the credit quality of the lowest-rated Bell System company, Pacific Telephone & Telegraph, was raised.

headline: Layoff at Storage
abstract: The Storage Technology Corporation, Louisville, Colo., said it would lay off 500 people from its 8,135-worker Colorado operation, effective March 25, citing weak demand for disk data storage products.

headline: INVEST IN EGYPT, MUBARAK APPEALS
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt ended his visit to the United States yesterday with an appeal for increased American investment in his country.   Mr. Mubarak, addressing a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria of the Egyptian American Chamber of Commerce and the Egypt-U.S. Business Council, said: ''Today Egypt enjoys a degree of stability unparalleled in many other countries. Social tension is reduced to a minimum. Our economic policy is geared to serve that purpose.''

headline: SOVIET MOVES TO STRAIGHTEN OUT ITS RAILROADS
abstract: For the second time since Yuri V. Andropov took over as the Soviet leader in November, the Kremlin has convened a meeting in attempts to improve the performance of the nation's railroads, which have become a bottleneck in the Soviet economy.   The conference, held on March 11 at Central Committee headquarters in Moscow, called on regional Communist Party officials to enforce discipline and better organization and to observe schedules and safety rules, a possible allusion to past accidents.   Like the first meeting, at the Railroad Ministry in December, the latest session was attended by Geidar A. Aliyev, a 59-year-old First Deputy Prime Minister, whose responsibilities include transportation.    Mr. Aliyev, a career officer in the security police and then for 13 years the party leader of the Transcaucasian Republic of Azerbaijan, was brought to the center of power in Moscow as one of Mr. Andropov's first moves.

headline: Texas Monthly Leader Feels a Rebound Is Near
abstract: Among the formally garbed multitudes in the Waldorf-Astoria on Tuesday night when the Magazine Publishers Association honored Andrew Heiskell, retired chairman of Time Inc., was Michael R. Levy, the bearded young publisher of Texas Monthly.   The event, at which Mr. Heiskell received the Henry Johnson Fisher Award, more familiarly known as the Publisher of the Year Award, also gave magazine publishers an opportunity to discuss the economy.

headline: U.S. LIFTS EMBARGO ON MILITARY SALES TO GUATEMALANS
abstract: The Reagan Administration today lifted the five-year-old embargo on arms sales to Guatemala because of what it said were ''significant steps'' taken by the Government to end human rights abuses.   The State Department announcement allows Guatemala to buy from the Defense Department $6.3 million worth of spare parts and other equipment for its air force, mostly to rehabilitate American-made helicopters for use against guerrillas.   The move, while small in military terms, was viewed by the Administration and its critics as an important symbolic step signifying support for the Government of Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, who overthrew Gen. Romeo Lucas Garcia and seized power last March. 'Progress Has Been Made'   Guatemala has been accused by the United States and many human rights groups of repressive tactics and rights violations. But Administration officials have reported an improvement in recent months.

headline: People Express To Buy Used 727's
abstract: People Express Airlines said that it had signed a letter of intent with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to buy eight used Boeing 727-200 aircraft formerly owned by Alitalia Airlines. The aircraft are scheduled for delivery by mid-1984.

headline: Holiday Closings
abstract: Stock and foreign exchange markets were closed yesterday in Canada, Britain, Japan and Australia in observance of holidays.

headline: Survivors of Coal-Mine Blast In Turkey Charge Negligence
abstract: Survivors of Turkey's worst mine disaster in 50 years blamed official negligence today for two explosions that killed a hundred miners.

headline: Datril Takes Aim Again At Nonaspirin Market
abstract: Commercials last night on network TV marked the beginning of Datril's second attempt to take away a big piece of the nonaspirin pain reliever market from Johnson & Johnson's Tylenol, which Datril said has about a 95 percent share.   And Bristol-Myers, maker of Datril, thinks it knows how to do it - by pricing.

headline: Lebanese Said to Foil a Plot To Sabotage Talks on Pullout
abstract: The Lebanese Army foiled a plot to fire four Soviet-made rockets at American, Lebanese and Israeli negotiators conducting talks on withdrawing foreign forces in Lebanon, the military prosecutor, Assad Germanos, said today.

headline: TREASURY ISSUES FALL IN PRICE
abstract: Prices of United States Government securities drifted lower in quiet trading yesterday and yields rose as investors withdrew from the credit markets, taking a wait-and-see attitude about how low oil prices would fall before committing funds.  Most of the activity was in Treasury bills, where prices fell and yields rose as investors expressed discouragement at the Federal Reserve's sale of $1.2 billion in bills for a customer account. ''The bill market is flooded with supply,'' said one trader, who noted that dealers would have to pay for $9 billion in Treasury cash-management bills on Monday.  Also discouraging buying was the higher cost of overnight interbank loans. After trading most of yesterday at 8.375 percent, the Federal funds rate rose to 8.50 percent before the close.

headline: Article 002877 -- No Title
abstract: The International Monetary Fund approved today a $5.4 billion credit for Brazil as the key element in a package to help the country pay its bills, including its huge bank debt.   With $508 million of credits that the I.M.F. approved Dec. 22, the total commitment of $5.9 billion represents the largest ever to a single borrower. The previous record was $5.8 billion, approved for India in November 1981.

headline: Chairman of BTK Resigns From Post
abstract: BTK Industries, an apparel maker based in El Paso, Tex., said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive resigned after a $7.2 million loan that he took out to buy controlling interest in the company went sour.   Peter P. Dhawan, the 39-year-old executive, will continue as a director and a consultant but will have no operational responsibilties and no office in the building, BTK said.   Thomas J. Ahmann, executive vice president, said Mr. Dhawan bought some 30 percent of BTK stock in 1981 and as a result was named chairman. He took out the loan from the State National Bank of El Paso through his investment company, Raizada Investments Inc.

headline: ABC OFF 6.4%
abstract: The American Can Company said yesterday that net income in last year's fourth quarter plunged 83.2 percent because of weak demand for containers and packaging, polyethylene resins and forest products.   American Can, a diversified metal container producer and consumer products distributor, said that net income in the latest three months plummeted to $1.6 million, from $9.5 million. Revenue dropped 27.1 percent, to $918 million, from $1.26 billion.

headline: OCCIDENTAL SELLS PART OF CITIES
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, in a move to reduce its $4.1 billion of debt, announced today that it was selling the refining and marketing operations and certain gasoline inventories of its Cities Service Company subsidiary for $567 million.   The Southland Corporation, the nation's largest independent retailer of gasoline, is the purchaser; it will pay in stock for the refining and marketing operations and in cash for the gasoline.   Southland will also pay $360 million in cash to replace gasoline inventories that Occidental plans to sell to another company, and $40 million to purchase various receivables from Occidental. Southland will also invest $160 million in improvements at a Cities Service refinery that it is purchasing.

headline: PSA Seeks Braniff Landing Rights
abstract: The vice president of Pacific Southwest Airlines, George Shortley, told a Federal bankruptcy judge the merger between his airline and Braniff Airways Inc. would not take place unless Pacific was granted landing rights.   The merger agreement, reached in December and subject to the bankruptcy court's approval, is contested by several major airlines which would be required to surrender takeoff and landing privileges gained when Braniff ceased operation.   Mr. Shortley said that if the proposed merger agreement is not approved by March 1 ''at the very latest,'' Pacific will withdraw.

headline: AMERICAN AIRLINES GETS LABOR PACT CONCESSIONS
abstract: Members of the Transport Workers Union ratified a three-year contract with American Airlines yesterday that calls for concessions in work rules and wage rates for new workers in return for wage increases and greater job security for current workers.   The approval averted a strike that had been scheduled for midnight tonight. Leaders of the 10,000-member union, which represents ground personnel, had recommended that the proposal be rejected.

headline: RIGHTS GROUP CRITICIZES EGYPT
abstract: Amnesty International issued a report yesterday that said Egyptians suspected of opposing their Government faced years of imprisonment and repeated trials.   The human rights organization said that since 1971, when Egypt adopted its Constitution, hundreds of people had been imprisoned in Egypt for political beliefs or activities.

headline: DeLorean Delay On Reorganization
abstract: A Federal bankruptcy judge granted the DeLorean Motor Company until April 25 to reorganize the company after he was told that a group of investors wanted to buy the company's remaining assets and resume production.   The DeLorean Motor attorney, Lawrence Snider, had told Bankruptcy Judge George Woods that a California lawyer representing four investors was unable to meet the original deadline of Friday for coming up with a plan to pay off creditors and to salvage the company. He refused to identify the investors.

headline: MEDVEDEV, A DISSIDENT HISTORIAN, IS GIVEN FORMAL WARNING IN SOVIET
abstract: Roy A. Medvedev, the dissident Marxist historian whose writings on Stalin, Khrushchev and other Soviet subjects have been published in the West, has been formally warned to halt his ''political lampooning'' or face criminal charges.   Mr. Medvedev said he was summoned Tuesday to a meeting with a Deputy Prosecutor General of the Soviet Union. During the 40-minute session he was shown a document declaring that if he wished to remain out of jail he must cease all writings hostile to the Soviet system and turn to ''socially useful activities.''   The 57-year-old historian, perhaps best known in the West for his chronicle of the Stalin period, ''Let History Judge,'' said he regarded the warning as part of a crackdown on dissidents, shirkers and others who flout the Soviet system, initiated by Yuri V.  Andropov, the new Soviet leader. Mr. Medvedev said the action would in no way effect his activities, including his contacts with Western reporters.

headline: FINANCING DELAYED, MEXICO SEEKS A BRIDGE LOAN
abstract: Mexico will seek a $400 million to $500 million bridge loan from a group of leading Western banks because of delays in the completion of a planned $5 billion financing package, Finance Ministry officials said here today.   The officials said that Mexico's Public Credit Director, Angel Gurria, would meet Thursday in New York with a 13-bank advisory committee that represents Mexico's 1,400 international commercial creditors. The 13 banks, which include Bank of America, Chase Manhattan, Citibank and the Bank of Tokyo, will be asked to advance their share of the first $1.7 billion portion of the $5 billion loan, the officials added.

headline: Strike Snarls Argentina
abstract: A 24-hour strike by Argentina's trade union movement brought economic activity to a virtual halt throughout the country today.   Public transportation was paralyzed, nearly all shops were closed and few people went to work at factories, banks and government offices.   The stoppage, declared illegal by the Government, was called by both the moderate and hard-line wings of the General Confederation of Labor to demand better pay and to protest the military Government's economic policies.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Pan Am Trims Florida Fares   MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP) - Pan American World Airways said it would cut one-way coach fares between Florida and Newark to $69 beginning Friday through Feb. 10, when the fare will temporarily return to $99.    The lower fare will apply to flights to Newark from Tampa and Miami, with added service from West Palm Beach Feb. 1.

headline: Warner-Lambert Co.  Takes Delayed Payment
abstract: Warner-Lambert Company, a pharmaceutical company based in Morris Plains, N.J., has accepted payment for a $100 million issue of 10 1/4 percent Euronotes due in seven years that was sold through Morgan Stanley International last November at a price of 99 1/2 to yield 10.45 percent.   According to George Hromodko, senior vice president of Warner-Lambert, the company saved more than half a point from what it would have paid for a domestic issue of seven-year notes.   The notes were sold on a delayed-payment basis, meaning that investors did not have to part with any cash until this week. The delayedpayment feature is different from the partial payment technique, in which investors put up only 20 percent or 25 percent of the price and do not pay the balance for six or nine months. In most partialpayment issues, the investors do not have to pay the balance if the price of the security drops by more than the downpayment.

headline: U.S. Clothing Makers Groan About Imports
abstract: ONCE again, emotions are boiling over the imports of clothing and t extiles into the United States. While the vision of a potential o utpouring of goods from China has provoked the latest worries, the c oncern - expressed by both free traders and protectionists - is of a surge in imports from all over the world.   The battle lines seem to get clearer by the day. On one side are the American producers of apparel, textiles and textile fibers, as well as two major industry unions, all of which are strenuously urging more protection from imports. On the other side are the nation's retailers, who just as adamantly believe that consumers want - and should have - the imported products.

headline: Norstar Buys Bank Stake
abstract: As part of its agreement with the New York State Banking Board, First American Bankshares Inc., a bank holding company based in Washington, has sold its majority interest in New York's Bank of Commerce to Norstar Bancorp Inc. of Albany for $34.4 million.   An agreement in principle to sell First American's 67.6 percent stake to Norstar was signed Dec. 31.

headline: Soviet Priest Accused Of Antistate Activities
abstract: The official press agency Tass reported today that criminal proceedings had been brought against a Roman Catholic priest in Lithuania, the Rev. Alfonsas Svarinskas, for engaging in ''anticonstitutional and antistate activities.''

headline: REAGAN WEIGHING MORE U.S. ADVISERS FOR EL SALVADOR
abstract: President Reagan is considering an increase in the number of United States military advisers in El Salvador beyond the current limit of 55, a senior White House official said today.   The official, who met reporters aboard Air Force One as Mr. Reagan flew to California, said no decision had been made. He said an increase was under consideration as part of an overall review of policy in Central America.   The disclosure came hours after President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz voiced anxiety to Congressional officials about what they called the declining situation in El Salvador. Mr.  Reagan told a bipartisan Congressional group at the White House that El Salvador ''faces a difficult situation'' because of ''arms supplies coming into the guerrillas.''

headline: President Succeeds Jersey Utility Chief
abstract: New Jersey's largest public utility, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark, said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive officer would retire and named a successor.   Robert I. Smith, 65 years old, will retire in September and the board chose Harold W. Sonn, 61, currently president and chief operating officer, to fill his posts. Mr. Sonn will continue as president.   Mr. Smith joined the company 43 years ago and has been chief executive since 1965. Mr. Sonn, who has been with the company for 37 years, became a vice president in 1970 and president in 1980.

headline: CUTTING PRICE NOT PROFIT
abstract: Despite the efforts of some retailers, trying to stop the discounting of clothing brands is proving to be as difficult as trying to stop a runaway locomotive by standing on the tracks.  Discounting became a nationwide addiction and retailing's most striking characteristic in 1982, and many industry experts believe that it will accelerate in 1983.   The problem, however, is that the continuous price cuts have proved a barrier to maintaining profits. Given the poor retail showing at Christmas, retailers are trying to figure out ways of protecting - and perhaps increasing - profits, even as they offer lower prices.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; Iranian Official Admits Little Progress in War   LONDON, Feb. 14 (Reuters) - The Speaker of Iran's Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, said today that Iran was making slow progress in its latest military offensive against Iraq, the Teheran radio reported.   The Speaker said the slow pace of the operation launched this month on the southern front in the war was because of Iranian tactics rather than Iraqi resistance, the radio said.

headline: Market Place; Discovery Fund Is Patient
abstract: MONEY managers often pick trendy, fast-moving stocks for their portfolios. But Patrick Kildoyle is fond of slumbering, out-of-favor issues.   The portfolio manager of First Investors Discovery Fund, sporting a green carnation yesterday, explained his investment approach: ''We try to buy stocks selling at substantial discounts from their intrinsic value. Typically, this leads us to industries that are unpopular on Wall Street. It means sorting out groups with the poorest relative strength in the market.

headline: Peking Hotel Increase
abstract: Peking will have more than 10,000 hotel rooms for tourists, about double the present number, after 11 new hotels are completed by 1985, China's official New China News Agency reported today.

headline: HEAVY FIGHTING IN NICARAGUA REPORTED BY REBELS
abstract: A radio station run by rightist Nicaraguan rebels said today that heavy fighting was under way between guerrillas and Government forces in Nicaragua.   The radio said the fighting was taking place about 70 miles north of Managua, the Nicaraguan capital.  The report by Radio 15 de Septiembre, based in Honduras, followed charges by the Nicaraguan Government Saturday that at least 500 rebels had been dropped by plane into Nicaragua from Honduras.  Nicaragua said the rebels had arrived in the area six days earlier.

headline: TOYOTA ON G.M. DEAL: GIVING AID TO OPPONENT
abstract: The proposed joint venture between the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation to produce small cars in California by 1984 is a way of helping out an opponent in the Japanese tradition, according to a high Toyota official.   ''We understand that G.M. is facing hardship from the prolonged recession that has resulted in poor sales,'' said the official, Shigenobu Yamamoto, vice chairman of the board of Toyota.   ''We understand that what we are doing with G.M. is giving the medicine to stop the sneezing they are now suffering,'' he continued. ''We are helping revitalize them in a limited area.'' Mr.  Yamamoto was interviewed at Toyota headquarters, which are in the middle of a city so dominated by the auto company that it adopted the Toyota name. Toyota City is about 160 miles west of Tokyo.

headline: Gulf's Stations Cut in 2 States
abstract: The Gulf Refining and Marketing Company, a division of the Gulf Oil Corporation, said it would discontinue its branded marketing operations in Michigan and in 18 northwest Ohio counties.   Gulf said the action was an effort to streamline distribution and marketing operations and to concentrate efforts in areas where it has a stronger competitive position.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: President Reagan's denunciation of a nuclear freeze and of the Kremlin as the focus of evil in the world is viewed by some politicians as the keynote of a drive to induce Congress to approve a large rise in military spending and to deflect pressures for what Mr. Reagan sees as undesirable concessions to Moscow. Other politicians called his speech on Tuesday before a convention of Evangelical Christians in Orlando, Fla., ''a vintage Reagan performance,'' intended to mend fences with disgruntled right-wing supporters. Some said it might have a wider unintended impact.   There are Democrats who fear that the President's polemics may harm the arms-control negotiations with the Soviet Union. Others, rankled by Mr. Reagan's attack on a nuclear freeze as ''a very dangerous fraud,'' said his comments would further polarize the national debate on arms issues.

headline: East Germany Ousting West German Reporter
abstract: The East Berlin correspondent of the West German weekly magazine Stern, which on Tuesday reported an assassination attempt on the Communist Party leader Erich Honecker, was ordered today to leave East Germany within 48 hours.   The East German press agency said accreditation for the Stern reporter, Dieter Bub, was being withdrawn ''because of his gross breach of the legal stipulations of the German Democratic Republic, untrue and libelous reporting.''

headline: Satin Brand Cigarettes Are Going National
abstract: Having achieved a 1.4 percent share of cigarette sales in test markets in Denver and Milwaukee with Satin, its new female-oriented cigarette brand, in only 12 weeks, Lorillard, a division of Loews Theaters, has decided to go for national introduction. And the company that previously brought you the Kent line True, Newport, Old Gold and Max, says that, as far as ad budgets go, this will be its most elaborate and expensive introduction.

headline: ACCORD SET ON FORMAT FOR VIDEO RECORDERS
abstract: More than 120 companies have agreed on a common standard for the next generation of video cassette recorders.  Gathered at a special conference here Monday, electronics, tape and camera manufacturers from around the world settled on a format based on quarter-inch cassette tape. The current generation of video recorders uses half-inch cassette tape.   The agreement is the result of more than a year of discussions among the companies, led by the major Japanese manufacturers, which account for about 90 percent of world production today.

headline: Excerpts from speech, page A8.
abstract: President Reagan said today that he was prepared to explore alternatives to his proposed ban on all American and Soviet medium-range missiles in Europe if the principle of equality between the United States and the Soviet Union was respected.   In a wide-ranging foreign policy address here at the American Legion's annual conference, Mr. Reagan for the first time listed the requirements for his Administration to modify its ''zero option'' proposal for missiles in Europe, as some in Europe have asked him to do.   Under the zero option, the Soviet Union would be required to dismantle its medium-range missiles trained on Europe and Asia if the Atlantic alliance dropped its plan to install 572 American cruise and Pershing 2 missiles. Says 'Zero Option' Is Best   Mr. Reagan said the zero option ''remains the best and most moral outcome'' of the arms talks under way with the Soviet Union, but added that the United States is ''negotiating in good faith in Geneva, and ours is not a take-it-or-leave-it proposal.''

headline: More Philippine Troops Sent In to Fight Rebels
abstract: The Government of President Ferdinand E.  Marcos today sent 2,000 more troops into a counteroffensive against Communist rebels in the southern Philippines.   Lieut. Gen. Fidel Ramos, deputy chief of the armed forces, told the official Philippine News Agency that three army battalions and a company of scout rangers had been sent to assist three marine battalions dispatched two weeks ago.

headline: LEVI CLIMBS SHARPLY; GENERAL MILLS DOWN
abstract: Levi Strauss & Company reported yesterday that earnings for the fiscal first quarter ended Feb. 27 more than doubled, to $35.1 million, or 84 cents a share, from $17 million, or 41 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 8 percent, to $576.4 million, from $534 million.   Robert T. Grohman, president of the San Francisco-based clothing maker said the increase in profit margins was a result of higher domestic sales stimulated by new marketing strategies as well as an improved retail climate and the favorable impact of the company's productivity program put into effect last year.

headline: No Headline
abstract: BRITAIN'S LEADER VISITS FALKLANDS   STANLEY, Falkland Islands, Jan. 8 (By The Associated Press) - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher arrived here today for an unannounced visit ''to pay tribute to those who liberated the islands'' that Britain recaptured from Argentina in fighting last year.   It was the first visit by a British Prime Minister to this South Atlantic colony, and came nearly seven months after Argentine soldiers who had occupied the islands surrendered to British forces on June 14.   In London, Mrs. Thatcher's office at 10 Downing Street said the Prime Minister was accompanied by her husband, Denis; Adm. Sir John Fieldhouse, the Chief of Naval Staff, and four aides. After a secret 23-hour flight from a Royal Air Force base near London, she was greeted at the Stanley airport by Sir Rex Hunt, the civil commissioner of this South Atlantic archipelago 8,000 miles from Britain and 300 miles off the Argentine coast.

headline: LEANING TOWER OF PISA IS LEANING A BIT MORE
abstract: The Leaning Tower of Pisa leaned another five one-hundredths of an inch last year, and city officials say it is doomed to collapse unless a way is found to halt the ever-increasing tilt.   The Italian Government is spending $10.5 million to stabilize the 180-foot-tall marble monument, but the cause of its slant remains a mystery and Pisa officials are skeptical whether the rescue effort will succeed.   ''It's bound to fall some time if we can't find a way to control it, though we don't know when it's going to happen,'' said Giuseppe Toniolo, chairman of the city committee responsible for the tower.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The Administration calls its proposal for a three-year tax increase of some $135 billion a standby measure, an insurance policy to be used only if the nation's soaring budget deficits are not substantially reduced by mid-1985. President Reagan proposed the tax increase in his State of the Union address Tuesday night. Under the proposal, the Government would impose a surcharge on personal and corporate incomes and an excise tax of about $5 a barrel on oil. The taxes would not take effect unless a number of conditions were met, including a projected deficit for the fiscal year 1986 exceeding 2 1/2 percent of gross national product.   The Administration's current projections, however, indicate that it considers it most unlikely that the standby taxes can be avoided.  Even assuming a very strong recovery, one that would produce real economic growth substantially higher than the 3.5 percent average for the postwar years, the deficit would not be reduced enough to avoid the added taxes.

headline: The U.N. Today; March 10, 1983
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Statistical Commission - 10 A.M.  and 3 P.M.

headline: ISRAEL AND LEBANON TO STUDY 4 KEY ISSUES
abstract: Israeli and Lebanese negotiators, meeting today in the Israeli border town of Kiryat Shemona, announced the formation of four subcommittees to discuss the key issues growing out of Israel's invasion of Lebanon.   The subcommittees, which are to begin work next week in either Khalde, Lebanon, or Herzliya, Israel, are to deal with four issues.  These are the creation of a security zone in southern Lebanon, relations between the two countries, the withdrawal of foreign forces and guarantees of Lebanese security, according to an announcement by the Israeli Foreign Ministry.   The formation of the groups came amid intensive efforts by Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, to ''light a fire'' under the negotiations, as one official put it, to move them toward an early resolution.

headline: ACTION PLEDGED ON LOST G.I.'S
abstract: President Reagan today told families of American servicemen still missing in Southeast Asia that United States intelligence agencies were ''fully focused'' on the problem and that the goal of a full accounting was ''the highest national priority.''   ''The anguish you've suffered - the families of brave men listed as prisoners of war or as missing in action - is unspeakable, something the rest of us can never really know even in partial measure,'' Mr. Reagan said in an emotional meeting with more than 500 relatives, including wives, children and parents, of the missing Americans.

headline: HARTE-HANKS COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LONG-TERM U.S. ISSUES OFF
abstract: Light but persistent selling eroded prices of long-term Treasury debt issues yesterday, while rates on bills and other short-term paper closed steady to slightly lower. Prices of tax-exempt and corporate bonds finished with minor losses where changed at all.   Dealers said the fixed-income market has been marking time for the past week or so as it awaited the answers to three near-term questions.   One is whether the Federal Reserve would cut its discount rate before the Treasury announced the terms of its February re-funding on Jan. 26; the second is what the terms of the three maturities comprising that $14.25 billion re-funding would be, and the third concerns the results on today's Treasury sale of $7.25 billion of two-year notes and tomorrow's auction of $7.5 billion of one-year bills.

headline: 300 to Lose Jobs In Fairchild Cuts
abstract: The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation will close most of its plant in San Jose, Calif., putting 300 employees out of work, a company spokesman said.  The company blamed sluggish computer component demand for the action.

headline: GOULD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MERRILL TO STOP MAKING MARKET IN SOME STOCKS
abstract: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. said yesterday that it would stop making markets in certain exchange-listed stocks because the technology for execution of the orders was not efficient and the rules slowed the process.  John McCarthy, vice president of over-the-counter trading at Merrill, said the firm would end its market-making experiment begun two and one half years ago within two weeks. Several brokerage firms participated in a project to determine whether additional competition in making markets for stocks would improve the market. But only a few firms are still involved, and they are trading in only a small number of stocks.

headline: Polly Peck Shares Off
abstract: Shares in the international trading group Polly Peck fell sharply when trading resumed on the London Stock Exchange today. Trading in the shares had been suspended Monday in the midst of uncertainty about the company's interests in Cyprus.  The shares fell at one point by between $10 and $15 before bouncing back to $22.

headline: AMERICAN INSURER FINDS THE EAST BLOC IN A FERTILE TERRAIN
abstract: The chill over East-West business ties in recent months has failed to nip the growth of an unusual and lucrative insurance business run jointly by American International Group Inc., one of America's largest insurance companies, and several East bloc partners.   Though the market remains small, the American partner has made hard-won gains in virtually unexplored insurance terrain, collecting about $35 million to $40 million of an estimated $250 million in reinsurance premiums that East bloc insurance companies paid Western insurers in 1982.   ''Expansion now is going to depend on new products,'' said Nicholas C. Walsh, general manager of European American Underwriters, a joint venture of American International and its Eastern partners, in a recent conversation in Vienna.   Western European insurance executives said that American International's activity is unusual because the East's statecontrolled insurance companies usually cover only business involving ''hard'' or convertible currency, such as transport or airline service to the West.

headline: The U.N. Today; Feb. 7, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Oc- cean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Non-Use of Force - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Scientific and Technical Subcom- mittee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Committee on Nongovernmental Organizations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Rhone-Poulenc Plans
abstract: State-owned Rhone-Poulenc S.A. plans to step up investment to the equivalent of $450 million annually over the next three years from the equivalent of $300 million, a company spokesman said today.

headline: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Death Toll in Assam Put as High as 3,000
abstract: About 3,000 people may have been killed in election violence last month in India's northeastern state of Assam, the state's Chief Minister, Hiteswar Saikia, said today.

headline: SYRIAN ARMY SAID TO BE STRONGER THAN EVER, THANKS TO SOVIET
abstract: The Soviet Union has replaced all the Syrian Army equipment destroyed by Israel in the invasion of Lebanon and has rebuilt Syria's ruined air defense system, according to Western military analysts here.   Because the new equipment is more modern, the analysts say, the improvements have made the Syrian Army stronger than it was before the Israeli invasion last June.   The military analysts in Damascus cited several key areas in which they believe Soviet help has improved the Syrian Army. 2-Year Modernization Plan   In the area of military equipment, they said, the Russians have continued their two-year-old program of modernizing Syria's armaments. In the past the Syrians usually paid cash for their Soviet-supplied weapons, but the latest shipments are believed to have been provided either on very easy credit terms or as outright gifts.

headline: Home Sales Rise Sharply
abstract: Sales of existing single-family homes jumped 15.5 percent in January from December, for the largest monthly rise on record, the National Association of Realtors said today.

headline: RED LOBSTER LOOKING ABROAD
abstract: In the 15 years since the first Red Lobster opened its doors, the seafood restaurant chain has become one of the largest in the nation, with 350 establishments in 36 states. And now, with the opening of a restaurant in Japan, it is going international.   Executives at the General Mills subsidiary are hoping that the seafood-loving Japanese will take to the Red Lobster concept as readily as Americans have. Last year alone, the Orlando-based Red Lobster Inns of America reported serving 50 million pounds of seafood, and since the chain first opened it has dished out close to 600 million pounds.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Mowlem Bid for Buehler
abstract: John Mowlem & Company said today that it planned to raise the equivalent of $14.4 million through an underwritten two-for-seven rights issue at the equivalent of 2.6 cents a share, and that its Mowlem Inc. subsidiary had agreed conditionally to acquire the Buehler Group of companies of Lake Bluff, Ill,, for $24 million.

headline: AUSTRALIAN BRUSH FIRES KILL 55
abstract: Brush fires pushed by gale-force winds have swept along the parched southeast coast, and the authorities said today that at least 59 people died, many trapped in their cars or homes. The victims included 12 volunteer firefighters.   The fires raced along 500 miles of coastline in Victoria and South Australia, engulfing seven towns and encircling Adelaide.''We are resigned to the fact that more bodies will be recovered when we finally get inside cars which were trapped by the fires and houses where residents had nowhere to run,'' a spokesman for the fire authorities said.

headline: Quake Jolts Wide Greek Area; Italians and Yugoslavs Jarred
abstract: An earthquake shook a wide area of Greece today with tremors felt in Italy and Yugoslavia, a spokesman for the Athens observatory said.   The police and residents said some houses had been damaged, but there were no reports of injuries from the quake, which sent thousands of Greeks and Italians fleeing into the streets.

headline: GENERAL HOUSEWARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SMITH COLLEGE PLANS TO HONOR MRS. KIRKPATRICK IN ABSENTIA
abstract: Smith College, reversing its customary policy, said today that it would give an honorary degree in absentia to Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States representative at the United Nations, before the college's commencement exercises in May.   Mrs. Kirkpatrick withdrew as the Smith commencement speaker a week ago after she was informed that the college in Northampton, Mass., could not assure her security during possible demonstrations against her visit.   She had been scheduled to receive a Doctor of Laws degree during the commencement exercises on May 22.  Smith ordinarily does not grant honorary degrees in the absence of the recipient, the college's director of public relations, Ann Shanahan, said. However, she said, the board of trustees voted over the weekend to reaffirm its decision of last October to bestow the degree on Mrs. Kirkpatrick despite the changed circumstances.

headline: BALDWIN SELLS $250 MILLION IN BONDS
abstract: The Baldwin-United Corporation of Cincinnati has sold $250 million of tax-exempt municipal bonds from the portfolios of its insurance companies to eight securities concerns headed by Goldman, Sachs & Company, a company official confirmed yesterday..   The diversified financial services holding company has ''periodically'' sold securities in this manner, according to the spokeman, who asked not to be identified. But he acknowledged that the amount involved in the latest case was ''higher than usual'' He stressed, however, that Baldwin-United was not under any cash pressure and there were ''no abnormal'' circumstances that created the sale.   The timing and size of the sale, however, are considered unusual at this time in the bond market when year-end trading is much reduced and large sales are rare.

headline: OLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TUESDAY, MARCH 1, 1983; The Economy
abstract: The Supreme Court upheld the antitrust settlement under which A.T.&T. agreed to divest itself of its local operating companies. The vote was 6 to 3, with the dissenters arguing that the Court should not have ruled in the case without a full briefing. (Page D1.) A.T.&T. plans to raise $1 billion through a new offering of common stock. It will be the company's second huge offering since December.  (D1.)   The steelworkers' union and seven major companies agreed on a new contract containing significant wage and cost-of-living concessions.  The pact was submitted to 250 presidents of union locals. (A1.)

headline: Baxter Travenol
abstract: Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. said its Travenol Laboratories unit had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration for a new process of preparing hemophilia treatment that reduces the risk of hepatitis transmission. Travenol said its Hemofil T Antihemophilic Factor, which replaces a missing clotting protein in patients with classic hemophilia, uses a heat-treatment process designed to reduce the risk of transmitting viruses, such as hepatitis, through blood.  Travenol said it is the first company licensed by the F.D.A. to use such a process.

headline: Phone Officers Named
abstract: D.C. Staley, who will be chief executive officer of the company to be formed when the New York Telephone Company and the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company become a single unit, announced the appointment yesterday of six vice presidents for the combined entity.    The companies will merge next Jan. 1 when the American Telephone and Telegraph Company divests itself of its regional telephone companies under an antitrust settlement with the Justice Department.

headline: CONSUMER DEBT RISES SHARPLY
abstract: American consumers took on $2.93 billion more in new installment debt than they paid off during January, the biggest monthly increase in nearly two years, the Government reported today.   Most of the increase involved personal cash loans and financing for goods other than autos, the Federal Reserve Board report said.  Often, big increases in outstanding credit are read as signs that consumers are gaining confidence and therefore becoming willing to go a bit deeper into debt by buying new products. However, a separate Commerce Department report today indicated that retail sales declined five-tenths of 1 percent in January and four-tenths of 1 percent in February, hardly suggesting any surge in buying on credit.

headline: INDIA'S ARMY FANS OUT IN ASSAM IN AN EFFORT TO PUT DOWN VIOLENCE
abstract: Indian troops have been ordered to extend their control over Assam as a result of fighting in which at least 41 people were killed on Wednesday.   Prime Minister Indira Gandhi authorized the move and the state government said the soldiers were empowered to make arrests and conduct searches without warrants.   The move was intended to end the violence that erupted in February as a predominantly Hindu political movement opposed to the presence of mostly Moslem immigrants sought to prevent the holding of state elections in which the immigrants were allowed to vote.

headline: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AS OIL REVENUE FALLS, KUWAIT TIGHTENS ITS BELT AND WORRIES
abstract: Falling world oil prices are sending tremors of apprehension through this tiny state at the head of the Persian Gulf.  Kuwait's alarm is shared to varying degrees by all the other small oil exporters along the Gulf, from Bahrain down through Qatar and the United Arab Emirates to Oman.   For the first time since the big price explosion in 1974, the conservative, pro-Western rulers of these vulnerable Arab nations are learning that they can no longer count on constantly rising revenue to buy social peace at home. The Nation's Riches   Kuwait, like the other states, remains wealthy, with huge assets and few people to support. Its population of 1.4 million is sitting on 10 percent of the world's known oil reserves, and the Government has $70 billion to $100 billion invested overseas.

headline: Dreyfus Bank Allowed
abstract: The Government today gave the Dreyfus Corporation permission to set up a new national bank.  The action by C.T. Conover, Comptroller of the Currency, further blurs the distinction between securities and banking, and is likely to be opposed by the Federal Reserve Board, which earlier had expressed concern about the legality of any such approval.

headline: Soldiers in Bangladesh Restore Order in 2 Cities
abstract: Troops restored order today here and in Chittagong after five civilians were reported killed and more than 100 people injured in two days of demonstrations against the Government.   In Dhaka, the capital, the English spelling of which has been changed from Dacca to reflect the Bengali pronunciation, there were no more demonstrations by this evening and the normal curfew was restored everywhere except around the university.

headline: BEGIN RECEIVES MASSACRE REPORT
abstract: The commission investigating the killings of Palestinian civilians in Beirut delivered its findings to Prime Minister Menachem Begin Monday night and is scheduled to issue its report to the public today. A part of the document dealing with Israeli intelligence matters is expected to be kept secret.   The three-member commission, headed by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, Yitzhak Kahan, is charged with determining the scope of Israeli responsibility in the massacre last September of hundreds of Palestinian men, women and children by Lebanese Christian Phalangists, who were asked to enter Beirut refugee camps by the Israeli Army.

headline: Concern On Future Of C.F.T.C.
abstract: A week after Philip McBride Johnson announced his intent to resign as chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission by May 1, the industry was still in a state of shock, just as it was when he assumed the post on June 8, 1981. But this time, the reasons for the industry's concerns are vastly different.   In 1981, the industry could barely contain its joy at Mr.  Johnson's appointment for a five-year term. As legal counsel for more than a decade to the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's biggest commodity exchange, he had won high marks within the industry for his many battles with Congressional and Federal regulators. But the euphoria soon evaporated.

headline: Saudi Contract Rules
abstract: Foreign companies awarded contracts for development projects in Saudi Arabia now must give at least 30 percent of the work to Saudi contractors and use Saudi banking, insurance and other services, the Saudi press agency said today.

headline: A.M.C. TO OFFER $100 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: The American Motors Corporation, saying it does not expect to show a profit in the next two years, announced today that it will issue 15 million new shares of stock in coming weeks to generate $100 million for new products.   The fourth-ranked United States auto maker also said in a prospectus outlining the stock issue that it is seeking a buyer for its military vehicle unit, the AM General Corporation, which on Tuesday received a contract for the first year of a multiyear Army contract worth nearly $1.2 billion.   (An American Motors official was quoted by Reuters as saying that preliminary talks on the sale of AM General had been held with several companies, including General Dynamics, the nation's largest defense contractor. General Dynamics paid $239 million for the tank manufacturing division of Chrysler, which sold the unit because of a cash squeeze similar to A.M.C.'s.)   Joseph Broder, an analyst with Stuart Coleman & Company, said that the American Motors stock issue would temporarily depress the share price. However, he said that A.M.C.'s survival was at issue and over the long term the company could bring off a turnabout, as Chrysler had done.

headline: Negotiations on U. S. Bases Are Renewed With the Greeks
abstract: Greek-American talks on the future of four United States bases in Greece resumed today as visiting members of Congress told Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou not to expect more rent.   One of the legislators, Representative Larry Winn, Republican of Kansas, said they made ''very clear'' that the United States military budget was at a standstill.

headline: Portuguese Election Called for April 25
abstract: President Antonio Ramalho Eanes dissolved Parliament today and announced a general election for April 25.   The election was called to end Portugal's eight-week-old Cabinet crisis, which started when Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao resigned because of squabbling in his governing coalition.   Opposition Socialists and Communists had been pressing for elections on April 25, the ninth anniversary of the end of 50 years of dictatorship.

headline: Bangladesh Cholera Deaths
abstract: The death toll in a three-week cholera outbreak in Pirojpur, a southern coastal area, rose to 110 today, doctors said.

headline: A 'BLACK SPOT' VOWS TO DEFY PRETORIA PLAN
abstract: Hilda Gamede, an 82-year-old widow, says that whenever she goes to collect her state pension, officials tell her to ''go and get married'' instead.   ''They don't want to pay,'' Mrs. Gamede said as she sat in the parlor of her house in Driefontein, a village of black peasant farmers 200 miles southeast of here, near the town of Piet Retief.   Others in the parlor nodded, for many elderly women in Driefontein have had the same experience. ''They want the ladies to get married so the gentlemen must support them,'' said another Driefontein resident, Victor Mqele.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The Reagan Administration is in a mood of crisis over El Salvador.  Salvadoran officials share Washington's concern about how the war against the guerrillas is going, but not the sense of urgency, which seems to have grown out of the Administration's way of reacting to a crisis some officials saw coming months ago. The military situation in El Salvador deteriorated in the guerrilla offensive of January and February, which provoked few public expressions of concern by the Administration at the time. However, a recent nine-day trip to the region by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, at President Reagan's request led to what officials said was anxiety in the White House.   Congressional critics say that, in dispatching Mrs. Kirkpatrick to El Salvador, Mr. Reagan received exactly what he expected to hear: that the military situation was deteriorating and that the Salvadorans needed more arms. Mrs. Kirkpatrick has a reputation within the White House as an articulate and shrewd diplomat with a hard-line approach against dealing with the left, especially in Latin America. But White House officials say even President Reagan was caught by surprise at the depth of Mrs. Kirkpatrick's concerns about possible guerrilla advances in Central America.

headline: Poles Rush to Buy Soap As Rationing Ends
abstract: Rationing of soap ended in Poland today with Poles reacting as the Government had feared by buying up most of the supplies.   A Warsaw shop that normally sold 220 pounds of soap a day sold out its one-ton stock in a few hours as customers ignored Government appeals for restraint after 17 months of restricted buying.

headline: VELO-BIND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

headline: SALVADOR OFFICER REFUSES TO YIELD
abstract: The commander of the northern province of Cabanas said today that ''they will have to come in here and take me out dead'' to end his rebellion against the Defense Minister.   ''We are at a critical moment,'' the commander, Lieut. Col.  Sigifredo Ochoa Perez, said in an interview at the command headquarters here.   The 40-year old colonel, who commands 1,200 soldiers, refused to obey orders transferring him to the post of military attache at El Salvador's Embassy in Uruguay. He has demanded that the Minister of Defense, Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, resign.

headline: 13% DROP IN HOUSING STARTS
abstract: Slowed by bad weather, housing starts fell 13 percent in December, to an annual rate of 1.22 million, the Government reported today. For all of 1982, work was started on just 1.061 million units, the lowest number since 1946.   The December decline came after three consecutive months of sharp increases that brought housing starts from a seasonally adjusted annual rate of about 1 million units in August to a rate of 1.404 million starts in November. The November figure was 24.7 percent above October, the Commerce Department's report said, a slight downward revision of the 26.5 percent increase reported last month.

headline: Puerto Rico Tourism
abstract: There are reportedly six agencies in Puerto Rico making presentations for the Tourism Company of Puerto Rico account. They include the incumbent, Tromson Monroe Advertising. A decision is expected today.

headline: Gulf Sale to Shell
abstract: The Gulf Oil Corporation announced the sale of its marketing and refining interests in Switzerland to Shell Oil Company. Under terms of the transaction, to take place Jan. 31, Shell will acquire the shares of Gulf Oil (Switzerland), which has about 100 employees and some 8 percent of the Swiss oil products market. Shell Petroleum N.V. will acquire Gulf's 25 percent interest in a 65,000 barrel per day refinery, of which 75 percent is already owned by Shell, the companies said in a joint statement issued from Gulf's Pittsburgh headquarters.

headline: Saudi Riyal Devalued
abstract: The Saudi Arabian riyal was devalued to 3.45 to the dollar, from 3.44, effective immediately, a Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency spokesman said today in Riyadh. The riyal parity last changed on June 30, 1982, when it was devalued from 3.43. Dealers said the move had been expected for months, because the riyal had been far outside its 7 1/4 percent fluctuation range against the special drawing right, the value of which is determined by averaging current values of a group of major currencies.

headline: REDPATH INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: City Federal Ends Bid for Suburban
abstract: The City Federal Savings and Loan Association of Elizabeth, N.J., said that it had withdrawn its proposal for the acquisition of Suburban Savings and Loan Association of Wayne, N.J., and its mortgage banking unit, the Suburban Coastal Corporation, because changes in the market and continued losses at Suburban had made the merger proposal ''outdated.''   City Federal's chairman and chief executive officer, Gilbert G.  Roessner, said that ''too much time had elapsed'' since the offer was filed last September, but that City Federal would offer a new bid if invited to do so by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which had been seeking a merger partner for Suburban.   Mr. Roessner also said cited a ''volatile economic environment'' and ''the large number of professionals who have resigned from Suburban's mortgage banking subsidiary,'' in the decision to withdraw the bid.

headline: FRIDAY, MARCH 25, 1983
abstract: Companies    People Express air service from Newark to London won tentative approval from the Civil Aeronautics Board. The carrier said it would try to offer a $149 one-way economy-class fare starting in June. But British approval of the low fares is uncertain. (D1.)   Nine A.T.& T. operating subsidiaries retained their top-grade or near-highest credit ratings from Standard & Poor's, while another's low rating was lifted. The agency downgraded ratings for 11 more units, but not as much as Moody's had two weeks earlier. (D1.) Demand was strong for debt offerings by South Central Bell. (D5.)

headline: Fannie Mae Sells Certificate Issue
abstract: The Federal National Mortgage Association issued $401.7 million of 11 1/2 percent mortgage pass-through certificates. They were offered at a price of 97 1/2 to yield 11.78 percent through underwriters led by Warburg Paribas Becker.

headline: Briton Admits He Left Secrets on the Subway
abstract: A British information officer admitted today that that he lost secret Government documents in a London subway train.   Extracts from the documents, which the officer was taking to a European Economic Community meeting, were later published in a radical weekly London magazine.

headline: Several Italian Officials Warned of Investigations
abstract: Municipal officials in Rome and Milan were warned today that they were being investigated for possible abuses of office.

headline: INFIGHTING SLOWS SALVADOR'S PLANS
abstract: A political setback suffered last week by the leader of El Salvador's rightist coalition has strengthened the view of many officials here that the struggle over long-promised social and economic programs is far from over.   The battle between the different political factions has prevented either the far right or the center from seizing clear control of the country. A consequence of this, many officials here say, is that the squabbling has hindered progress toward a negotiated settlement of the three-year-old civil war or even a consensus on how the war should be fought.   While the political stuggle has led to periodic setbacks, a nascent, albeit fragile, democracy has evolved.  In March the country elected a 60-member Constituent Assembly to name a provisional president, write a constitution and determine the future of the initiatives started by the junta in 1979.

headline: People
abstract: * Eric Bogedal, Norman Carrier, and Claudia Horty appointed senior vice presidents at Jordan, Case & McGrath.

headline: LIBYAN CONGRESS ANNOUNCES 'SUICIDE SQUADS'
abstract: Libya has announced that it will remain on the offensive against both Israel and those ''symbols of treason'' in the Arab world that are aligned with the United States.   In a series of resolutions adopted at a six-day session in Tripoli, the Libyan capital, the 300-member General Peoples Congress, Libya's highest policy-making body, called for spending part of Libya's oil wealth on arms to equip all able-bodied men and women in the country. It also said the money would be used to purchase arms for ''all the revolutionary forces in the Arab and Islamic worlds.''   The resolutions, published Saturday in Libya and printed here today in the pro-Libyan daily As Safir, said ''suicide squads'' would be formed to press attacks inside Arab territory occupied by Israel ''and against the symbols of treason in the Arab arena who follow the imperialist camp headed by the United States, the leader of world terrorism.''

headline: Habib Is Honored
abstract: Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy to the Middle East, received the 1982 Human Assistance Award yesterday from the International Human Assistance Programs, a nonprofit agency that operates health, food and job-training programs worldwide. The award, which was presented in ceremonies at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, cited Mr. Habib's work in pursuing a Middle East peace settlement.

headline: DOW UP 3.91, to 1,092.82
abstract: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in heavier trading, buoyed by the growing conviction that interest rates will decline.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which lost more than 8 points in the previous three sessions, rose 3.91 points, to 1,092.82. For the week, the key average was ahead 6.32 points mainly because of its advance of 10.60 points on Monday, when it closed at a record 1,097.10.

headline: Summary; BUSINESS DIGEST; TUESDAY, JANUARY 25, 1983; International
abstract: The OPEC meeting in Geneva broke up in disagreement over production quotas, raising the possibility of further declines in oil prices. An earlier accord collapsed when Saudi Arabia insisted other members stop discounting prices. (Page A1.) Any oil price declines in the short term would be slight, energy economists said. (D17.) Oil company stocks fell sharply. (D16.)   Moscow is exploring the idea of applying for observer status at GATT, creating a problem for the West. Washington is uneasy with the Russians operating outside the trade organization's rules, the officials said, but it fears that, if allowed in, they would try to ''politicize'' it. (D1.)

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Basic Resources Corp. said it had purchased an industrial security product line - Security Access Control Systems - from TRW Inc.; terms were not disclosed.   * Bechtel Petroleum Inc. said it had been awarded an engineering, procurement and construction management contract for Energy Transportation Systems Inc.'s $3.8 billion coal-slurry pipeline project; the contract's value was not disclosed.

headline: ISRAELI-LEBANESE AGENDA STILL ELUSIVE
abstract: A dispute over an agenda for discussions between Israel and Lebanon remained unresolved today, but negotiators said they would try to end the impasse at their sixth meeting on Thursday.   ''I think the differences are narrowing,'' said Christopher Ross of the United States, which is a party in the talks together with Israel and Lebanon.   Today's meeting at Khalde, south of here, opened on an optimistic note that rapidly dissipated. The main stumbling block is that Israel wants broad talks that would include the issue of normalization of relations with Lebanon.

headline: JWT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOUTHWEST FOREST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SUPPORT FOR POLISH AUSTERITY PLAN IS SOUGHT AT RALLY
abstract: Poland's rulers called more than 2,000 workers and Communist Party activists to a rally today aimed at mustering support for the new three-year austerity plan.   It appeared to be a difficult task, since the plan, presented to Parliament last week, calls for hard work and a reduction of waste to make up for a shortage of labor and raw materials.   ''This meeting should find a lasting place in our history,'' Gen.  Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, said at the rally in the Palace of Culture and Science. ''Our road is bumpy. There are bitter thoughts and hard talk.''

headline: U.S. Curbs Rumania Trade
abstract: President Reagan revoked Rumania's trade preferences with the United States today because of its tax on emigration. Larry Speakes, a White House spokesman, called the tax ''a serious new barrier to emigration.''

headline: Economic Scene; OPEC Failing As Cartel
abstract: NO matter what the immediate outcome of the turbulent London meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, we have been watching a highly contentious and failing cartel. It now looks as though some sort of face-saving agreement will be put together to cut the price of OPEC's benchmark crude oil by $5 a barrel, to $29, and to assign quotas to member countries to limit total OPEC production to 17.5 million barrels a day. But OPEC cannot police this agreement and it seems likely that the price of oil will continue to decline.   The story of the rise and fall of OPEC is starkly illustrated in what has been happening to oil prices and to shifting supply and demand in the world market.

headline: Satellite-Home TV Ruling
abstract: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has rejected an attempt to delay construction of a satellite-to-home television system by a Comsat affiliate.

headline: RUSSIANS SEEK ROLE AT GATT
abstract: The Soviet Union is taking soundings to apply for observer status with the organization that sets global trade policy, posing a problem for the United States and other Western powers, Reagan Administration officials reported today.   The Geneva-based organization, the 88-nation Council of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, seeks to promote global prosperity through trade liberalization.   David F. Demarest, an official in the Office of the United States Trade Representative, said, ''The fact that the Russians have not indicated a willingness to ultimately join GATT or adhere to GATT rules gives us some measure of concern.''

headline: ARRON RENTS OF ATLANTA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS BUILD NEW, PRAGMATIC IMAGE
abstract: A political gibe going the rounds in Madrid says that President Francois Mitterrand of France has done a great service to European Socialism by giving Spanish Socialists a good reason to pursue conservative economic policies.   Eight weeks after Spain's Socialists were voted into power, the country's 40-year-old Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, and his equally youthful Cabinet are striving to develop a moderate, pragmatic image. That is especially true in their handling of Spain's deeply troubled economy. The Spanish view contrasts sharply with the doctrinaire left-wing policies that Mr. Mitterrand adopted when he took office in France 18 months ago.

headline: REAGAN DOUBTS RESTRUCTURING SOON
abstract: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, said today that he opposes the idea of contingency tax increases starting in the 1986 fiscal year.   Administration officials have confirmed that such a plan will be included in the budget President Reagan will announce next week.  The increases would go into effect if the Government's budget deficit is not shrinking rapidly enough by Oct. 1, 1985, when the 1986 fiscal year begins.   ''I don't close my mind altogether to a triggered tax increase or a triggered tax cut,'' said Mr. Baker. But the Tennessee Republican added that ''it is my personal view that that's not a very good idea.'' The Senator made his comments on ''Meet the Press,'' the NBC News television program.

headline: CONGRESS IS SKEPTICAL ON SALVADORAN AID
abstract: The initial reaction on Capitol Hill to President Reagan's request for more aid to El Salvador indicates that approval will be conditioned on assurances that El Salvador will take strong steps to curb human rights violations and broaden its political base, according to comments from both Democrats and Republicans.   These legislators said that for the President to succeed he would have to lobby intensely. They said he would have a much harder time in the Democratic-controlled House than in the Republican-controlled Senate.   ''There's just a strong feeling around here that it's another Vietnam situation,'' Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said. ''At the same time, nobody wants to see that country go Marxist.''

headline: WARSAW UNDERGROUND CALLS FOR MARCHES
abstract: Three underground leaders of Solidarity, the outlawed labor movement, have issued a call for a repetition of last year's May Day demonstrations, when tens of thousands marched through Warsaw's Old Town in defiance of martial law.   ''No one should dare to dissuade us,'' a leaflet said. ''No one has the right to take our holiday away from us.'' The leaflet, which reached Western journalists today, was signed by Zbigniew Bujak, Zbigniew Janas and Wiktor Kulerski of the Warsaw underground.

headline: SIZZLER RESTAURANTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for QTr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Pole Flees to Canada As Stowaway on Jet
abstract: A Polish airline mechanic fled to Canada over the weekend by hiding in the baggage compartment of a Polish jet for 14 hours. He said he had left Poland because the Government tried to blackmail him into signing a loyalty oath.

headline: Profits Fall at De Beers
abstract: De Beers Consolidated Mines said today that profits fell 24.9 percent last year, to the equivalent of $519 million, from $691 million in 1981. The recession has depressed sales, especially in the crucial American market.

headline: RATES JUMP AT WEEKLY SALE
abstract: Rates rose sharply at the weekly auction of new 90- and 180-day Treasury bills yesterday. The average discount rate on the 90-day bills climbed to 8.205 percent, from 7.944 percent a week earlier, while that on the companion six-month bills advanced to 8.171 percent, from 7.948.   As a result, the top rate on new six-month savings certificates offered by savings banks and thrift institutions today will be 8.671 percent; that at commercial banks will be 8.421 percent. The new maximum rate for three-month savings certificates offered at savings banks and thrift institutions will rise to 8.205 percent, from 7.944.

headline: CENTRAL PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SAILING THE SEA AND DEDUCTING THE COST
abstract: SOME call it ''the Loveboat bill.'' Others believe that it is an i mportant piece of legislation that will be a boon to American cruisel ines and provide more jobs for American workers.   However it is perceived, a new law that went into effect at the beginning of 1983 broadens business-expense deduction rules for the tens of thousands of Americans who attend out-of-town conventions, meetings and seminars each year. Such gatherings now may be held on American-flag ships sailing between American ports. The ruling extends an earlier one under which deductions from Federal income taxes were restricted to business functions held in North America, as well as in American possessions, and were not allowed for trips outside the continent or aboard ship.

headline: IMPERIAL OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DISTRESS SIGNS IN THE YUKON
abstract: In the 1898 Gold Rush, the Yukon seemed like the center of the world. A legend named Klondike Kate was the blue-eyed darling of the miners; booming Dawson fancied itself as the ''Paris of the North,'' and janitors were making small fortunes by panning barroom shavings for gold dust spilled the night before.   These days, all that glitters seems like fool's gold. For the first time since the Gold Rush, there is not a working mine in the Yukon; after more than eight decades of continuous operation, the colorful White Pass & Yukon Railway from here to the Alaskan coast is closed; the economy is sinking and people are fleeing.

headline: Argentina Gets More Jets
abstract: Argentina took delivery recently of about 20 more Mirage III fighter-bombers, bringing to more than 70 the number it has bought since the conflict with Britain over the Falkland Islands last year, diplomatic sources said today.

headline: Market Place; Evaluating Steel Stocks
abstract: FOR investors with patience and a desire to minimize down-side risk, now may be the time to consider steel stocks. In the last few months, a number of events have led some analysts and institutional buyers to view more optimistically the outlook for steel producers, which have seen demand slump dramatically in the past few years.  Indeed, part of the reason for the increased attention is the conclusion that conditions in the industry can't get much worse.   After a long wait, activity in the automotive sectors - one of steel's most important clients - is finally showing signs of life.

headline: BRUNSWICK MINING & SMELTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * AGS Computers had 1.1 million common shares priced for offering at $15.25 a share, through underwriters led by L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.   * Air Products and Chemicals filed with the S.E.C. for issuing up to 1.5 million shares of common stock, through Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb and Goldman, Sachs.   * Associates Corp. of North America will sell $50 million of 9.80 percent senior notes due Feb. 1, 1986, at 100 percent, through Prudential-Bache Securities.

headline: SAUDIS DELAYING AID TO LEBANON, SHULTZ DECLARES
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries were holding off giving large-scale reconstruction aid to Lebanon until they were certain that Israeli and other foreign forces had withdrawn from that country.   Testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Mr.  Shultz in effect acknowledged that the Administration's hopes of obtaining large-scale Saudi assistance for Lebanon now seemed dependent on whether the Saudis were satisfied with the American-led mediation efforts to gain Israeli, Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization withdrawals from Lebanon.   Most of Mr. Shultz's testimony dealt with broad international economic issues, but he was asked by the chairman of the Middle East subcommittee, Senator Rudy Boschwitz, Republican of Minnesota, whether the drop in oil prices prevented Saudi Arabia from fulfilling its plans to aid Lebanon. 'Not Broke by a Long Shot'   Mr. Shultz responded that despite the drop in prices Saudi Arabia had a ''very large'' buildup of assets from its previous oil income, and ''they are not broke by a long shot.''
