headline: Treasury Bill Rates Decline; Bond Prices Show Gains
abstract: Treasury bill rates fell and bond prices rose moderately yesterday in response to the Government's February re-funding terms, which were announced late Wednesday. But dealers said that trading was apathetic and that many investors and traders had seized upon even modest upturns to lighten their portfolios.   ''After spending days on the sidelines waiting for the re-funding terms, the market now seems to be waiting for the actual auctions to take place before making major decisions,'' said a trader at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. ''Meanwhile, investors and traders are repositioning their portfolios for the sales.''

headline: Italian Refiners Post Big Loss
abstract: Italian oil refiners lost 2,000 billion lire in 1982 after losing 2,300 billion in 1981, according to Achille Albonetti, president of the oil industry's trade association. Last year's loss is equivalent to $1.45 billion at current exchange rates.

headline: BEELINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NATO Chief Attacked For Comments on Finns
abstract: Pravda today attacked the NATO commander, Gen. Bernard Rogers, for criticizing Finland's military policies and accused him of trying to sour relations between Helsinki and Moscow.   The NATO military chief told the Finnish newspaper Helsingin Sanomat in an interview that Soviet forces were likely to move through neutral Finland to attack NATO bases in Norway in the event of war.

headline: MAJESTIC WILEY CONTRACTORS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CANADA-U.S. PACT ON MISSILE TESTS IS DELAYED
abstract: Political pressure from an increasingly assertive disarmament movement has delayed the signing of an agreement with the United States to permit testing of unarmed cruise missiles in northern Alberta.   The negotiations on the agreement were concluded nearly a month ago and the Prime Minister's office has authorized Allan Gottleib, the Canadian Ambassador in Washington, to sign an exchange of notes on the tests. At the same time the Canadians have asked the United States to be patient and wait while the Government here tries to sway public opinion to support testing.   American officials, who still expect the agreement to be signed soon, said they agreed but expressed bewilderment at the requested delay, noting that popular opposition was mounting here as church and antiwar groups focused on the cruise issue.

headline: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Harvester Accord
abstract: Officials of the International Harvester Company and the City of Rock Island have signed an agreement to sell $5.9 million of a $6.9 million bond issue intended to help the struggling farm-equipment manufacturer. The issue is intended to help finance the transfer of a Harvester production line from Louisville, Ky., to Rock Island.

headline: SHARON IS OFFERED CHANCE TO REMAIN IN BEGIN'S CABINET
abstract: Ariel Sharon, who resigned this morning as Defense Minister, can remain in the Cabinet as a minister without portfolio, a spokesman for Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today.   If Mr. Sharon chooses to accept such a position, one with Cabinet rank but no specific responsibilities, he would probably remain in the policy-making inner circle. He has not yet indicated his intentions.   As a result, the impact on Israeli-American relations and Israel's negotiations with Lebanon is not yet clear. Mr. Sharon has been an irritant in the relationship with Washington, and an adamant proponent of a significant Israeli presence in a southern Lebanese security zone, even after a withdrawal of the main Israeli forces. If Mr. Sharon, who only resigned from the defense post, not from the Cabinet, accepts Mr. Begin's offer, he would probably be influential in shaping Israel's positions.

headline: CHILE, IN SURPRISE MOVE, IS TAKING OVER 8 BANKS
abstract: The Chilean Government took over eight banks yesterday.  Bankers in New York said they were stunned by the move, and they predicted that it would plunge Chile into the same kind of liquidity crisis that has plagued other Latin American countries.   Despite its difficult domestic economic problems, Chile has been highly regarded by international bankers and has had no trouble raising funds from abroad. Its total foreign debt amounts to about $17 billion, of which about $11 billion is owed to private banks, an unusually high proportion. The rest is owned to foreign governments and nonbank institutions.

headline: STANHOME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

headline: Defeated Party's Chief Said to Quit in India
abstract: Former Foreign Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee resigned as leader of the rightist opposition Bharatiya Janata Party today after a heavy defeat in Delhi's local elections, party sources said.   Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party received majorities in both the 56-seat Metropolitan Council and the 100-member Municipal Corporation.   The Congress Party victory helped party morale after losses in two provincial elections last month. Mr. Vajpayee said he accepted responsibility for his party's defeat and had decided to quit as party president.

headline: Swissair's Net Falls 29%
abstract: Swissair said today that earnings fell 29 percent last year, to $18.79 million, from 1981's $26.51 million.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Anderson Strathclyde P.L.C. of Scotland said it had raised its offer for National Mine Service Co. to $13 a share from $12.50; National, also being sought by Longyear Co. for $12.50 a share, has approved Anderson's offer.   * Black & Decker Manufacturing Co. said it had filed suit against Sanyo Electric Inc., charging infringment of patents on Black & Decker's Dustbuster and Car Vac vacuum cleaners.   * Bristol-Myers said its board had voted to raise the quarterly dividend to 60 cents a share from 52 1/2 cents, and to propose a 2-for-1 stock split to shareholders at the annual meeting on April 21.

headline: Saudis May Give $6 Billion to I.M.F.
abstract: The International Monetary Fund is expected to receive $6 billion in new credits from Saudi Arabia to bolster its financial resources, monetary officials said today.   The officials said the Saudis will probably loan $2 billion of this amount to an expanded accord known as the General Arrangements to Borrow. The General Arrangements is a special fund set up by the 10 largest industrial nations and its $6.3 billion in resources is used only for loans to these nations. Under the planned expansion, the Saudis would become members of the General Arrangements, loans would be made to any of the 146 I.M.F. member nations and the amount available for lending would be expanded to between $15 billion and $20 billion.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Ford Is Recalling 1,350 Employees   DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 26 (Reuters) - The Ford Motor Company will recall 1,350 employees from furlough at a car assembly plant in Dearborn Feb. 7 as it increases production of small cars, a company spokesman said He said the recall would be for a second work shift at the factory to rebuild inventories of the Ford Mustang and Mercury Capri models. The Ford spokesman attributed the move to sales, which ''are starting to pick up.''

headline: Advertising; Parker Pen Job Widens For Ogilvy
abstract: THE Parker Pen Company, which last summer moved the responsibility for its domestic advertising and some of its Far East advertising to Ogilvy & Mather, last week threw in the rest of the non-Communist world. That increases the company's billings and its distributors' billings in this agency from $5 million to about $20 million.   But more important, it will pull together advertising responsibility that had been handled by the 34 different agencies retained by 22 Parker subsidiaries or distributors. Each was creating its own advertising with its own look, message and direction. ''And that doesn't help in this shrinking world,'' said Manville Smith, for almost a year the president of Parker's writing-instrument division.

headline: ISALY CO reports earnings for Yr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SPRINKEL'S REMARKS STARTLE REGAN
abstract: The first that Treasury Secretary Donald T.  Regan knew about the comments of his errant Under Secretary was early Monday, when Jacques de Larosiere, the managing director of the 146-nation International Monetary Fund, telephoned from Paris.   Mr. de Larosiere wanted to know whether the remarks of Beryl Sprinkel, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, signified a major change in American policy - from one of emphasis on controlling inflation to one that gave priority to economic growth, even if such a policy ignited inflationary forces again.   Mr. Sprinkel made his comments at a news conference in Paris on Sunday.  Official sources here, who declined to be identified, recounted the story, which sheds some light on relationships in high places in the Treasury at a time of policy ferment in the Reagan Administration.

headline: Yugoslavia Discussing Debt Aid
abstract: Yugoslavia held talks today in Zurich with its creditor banks, starting a round of discussions expected to bring it relief from serious debt repayment problems, Swiss banking officials said.   Representatives of about 50 banks from several Western countries who met with Yugoslavia's Deputy Finance Minister, Gavra Popovic, were expected to reach broad agreement on an aid package to insure that Yugoslavia can make payments on its foreign debt of $18 billion, the officials said.

headline: Nigeria Says 1.2 Million Have Been Expelled
abstract: About 1.2 million West Africans have left Nigeria since the Government ordered the expulsion of foreign workers four weeks ago, Internal Affairs Minister Ali Baba said today.   The Minister said at a news conference that about 700,000 were from Ghana, 180,000 from Niger, 150,000 from Chad and 120,000 from Cameroon.   Mr. Baba blamed Ghana for any suffering that had occurred during the exodus because of what he called its refusal to open its borders until three days before the expiration of Nigeria's two-week deadline for the departure of unskilled and unemployed people.

headline: SALVADORANS ADMIT PROBLEMS
abstract: Some Salvadoran officials said today that they considered their country's military situation ''serious'' but not so bleak as described by Reagan Adminstration officials at a Congressional hearing in Washington Tuesday.   They said El Salvador needed more military assistance from the United States in the form of supplies and training. There also is a need for a change in the strategy for fighting the guerrillas, they said.   But the officials dismissed the statement made at the Washington hearing that Salvadoran soldiers would run out of military supplies in 30 days unless the United States provided $60 million immediately in additional military aid. They also dismissed what they said was the impression that Washington seemed to have that El Salvador was about to be taken over by the guerrilla forces.

headline: 3 in Egypt's Cabinet Accused by a Court In a Corruption Case
abstract: Three members of the Egyptian Cabinet were accused of corruption today in a case related to the judicial proceedings against Esmat Sadat, half-brother of Anwar el-Sadat.   The Cairo Court of Ethics, in a 161-page finding, said the three Cabinet members were part of a corrupt network headed by Esmat Sadat, calling it ''a Mafia gang which sprang up and spread corruption everywhere at a time when the Egyptian people were suffering hardship.''

headline: A.M.C. to Offer 11.9% Financing
abstract: The American Motors Corporation said it would follow the lead of the Big Three auto makers and offer 11.9 percent financing for buyers of 1983 A.M.C., Jeep and Renault vehicles except the Jeep Wagoneer and all leftover 1982's.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: New Managing Partners Chosen at Lord, Abbett
abstract: Lord, Abbett & Company, manager of pension and mutual funds, named Ronald P. Lynch and John M. McCarthy as managing partners.  The change follows the death on Jan.7 at age 69 of Alvin H. Berndt, who had been managing partner and chief executive. Mr. Lynch, 47, and Mr. McCarthy, 55, had worked closely with Mr. Berndt.   ''We had a triumvirate,'' Mr. McCarthy said, ''with Al at the top and Ron and I running underneath him.'' Lord, Abbett, which has its offices in New York, moved into pension fund management in 1975 and established itself as a major force.  ''We went out in 1975 and called on 250 companies - three or four calls at every corporation,'' Mr. McCarthy said. ''Within a three- to four-year period we developed 23 major corporate accounts.''

headline: KIN OF LOST AMERICANS MARK INDOCHINA ACCORD
abstract: Mary Rose of Birmingham, Ala., still wakes up in the middle of the night and imagines that her son, Capt. Scott Ketchie, is alive in a prison camp in Vietnam.   ''He was a navigator on an A-6, shot down in 1972 over the Ho Chi Minh trail,'' Mrs. Rose, who is no longer married to Scott's father, said quietly. ''The pilot was rescued, parachuted out of the plane with Scott. But Scott was never found.'' She shrugged. ''Death is final, I could live with that, but Scott was my only child and, well, I guess I'll wait and hope forever.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Express Co. has elected Gary A. Beller executive vice president.   * American Plan Corp., Woodbury, L.I., has named James A. Rowan Jr. to the newly created position of senior vice president-insurance.

headline: No Headline
abstract: EL SALVADOR WEIGHING PLAN TO OFFER LIMITED AMNESTY TO GUERILLAS   SAN SALVADOR, March 19 (UPI) - The Salvadoran Government is considering a partial amnesty plan for guerrillas that would allow them to participate in national elections in December, according to a copy of the plan obtained today.   On Thursday a special panel gave the Provisional President, Alvaro Magana, the proposed amnesty plan.  Under the proposal, rebels would have two months after enactment to turn themselves over to an amnesty board.  ''The granting of amnesty would be given in favor of those who have raised arms or participated in subversive activities who voluntarily receive the benefits of this law without the existence of cases against them,'' it said.

headline: T.W.A. Sees A Sizable Loss
abstract: Trans World Airlines said it could not expect its first-quarter results to improve from the $110 million pretax loss it reported in the first quarter of 1982.   The airline, a unit of the Trans World Corporation, made the disclosure in a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a stock offering.

headline: POPE APPEALS TO MODERN WORLD IN HOLY YEAR
abstract: Striking three times with a gilt-and-ivory hammer on the bronze Holy Door of St. Peter's Basilica, Pope John Paul II today ushered in an exceptional Holy Year that will last until Easter 1984. The year commemorates the 1,950th anniversary of the crucifixion of Christ.   In his homily during a mass after he had entered the basilica, the Pope dedicated the Holy Year to changing the direction of the world, which he has said is heading toward catastrophe.

headline: CONTINENTAL GROUP OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BUSINESS TALKS BACK TO REAGAN
abstract: A NEWSPAPER advertisement calls the Reagan fiscal policies ''senseless.'' On national television, the President is said to have ''missed the chance.'' And in an interview, a top official blames Mr. Reagan for ''exponentially expanding deficits of gargantuan proportions.''   These are not the words of the far left, or even the Democratic opposition. Rather, they come from bastions of the business community: Five former Treasury Secretaries and 500 prominent businessmen who have formed a new organization to bring changes in Mr. Reagan's economic program, and such leading business groups as the American Business Conference and the National Association of Manufacturers.   After two years of giving President Reagan their staunch support, business and financial executives - who had hailed the sweeping tax cuts of the President's first year and stuck with him as the recession deepened in the second -are now raising their voices to criticize his policies and, in some cases, even call for increased taxes. They are not abandoning the President but they are recommending that the course be changed, not stayed.

headline: Pravda Assesses Blame On Food Output Woes
abstract: The Soviet Communist Party criticized the country's agriculture industry today, citing chronic problems of poor soil preparation, broken tractors and improper distribution of seeds and fertilizers.   The criticism, in a front-page editorial in the party newspaper Pravda, indicated the importance that the new Soviet leader, Yuri V.  Andropov, places on increasing food output.   Pravda specifically blamed the Agriculture Ministry, the State Committee for Agricultural Machinery, fruit and vegetable enterprises and many party and Government organizations ''for not creating the necessary work pressure in preparation for the spring.''

headline: HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 25
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AUSTRALIAN MINING COMPANY REGROUPS
abstract: A year ago, Arvi H. Parbo, chairman of Western Mining Corporation Holdings, was reveling in Australia's resources boom. Earnings had hit a record $58 million (Australian) on revenues of $303.6 million for the year ended June 30, 1981.   Of Australia's mining companies, Western Mining was the leader, a glamour company that was considered the most likely among its competitors to survive in a downturn. With companies like Western Mining producing nickel and gold, many people believed that Australia could weather the recession and still have money to spare.

headline: TAKEOVER IS ARRANGED FOR FAILED COAST BANK
abstract: Five California banks agreed to assume the assets and take over the management of the seven branches of the failed American City Bank, the California State Banking Department announced tonight.   American City was closed by the department's acting superintendent, Harold D. Doyle, at 6 P.M. last Friday, following news reports of the bank's mounting loan losses. It was the second-largest bank failure in California's history.   Most of the bank's seven branches were expected to reopen sometime Monday. A hearing before the Los Angeles Superior County Court, whose approval was required to complete the bank's asset transfer, was set for late tonight.

headline: British Steel May Buy in U.S.
abstract: The British Steel Corporation is discussing the purchase of an American steel plant so it can import more steel into the United States than is currently allowed, Scottish Secretary of State, George Younger, said today.   Mr. Younger did not specify at a news conference which American plant was involved, but British newspaper reports have identified it as being owned by the Pittsburgh-based United States Steel Corporation and that the proposed purchase price is about $146 million.

headline: SATURDAY, MARCH 12, 1983; The Economy
abstract: President Reagan promised to veto the $3.7 billion jobs bill if it still contains a rider repealing tax withholding for interest and dividends income when he gets it from Congress. He was clearly angered by an anti-withholding drive of the banking industry. (Page 1.) Senator Bob Dole suggested enacting a special excise tax for banks to help pay the cost of the U.S. participation in the I.M.F.  Mr. Dole was opening Finance Committee hearings into what he described as the ''unusually low'' income tax rates enjoyed by banks. (9.)   Business inventories dropped 0.6 percent in January to the lowest level in nearly two years, the Commerce Department reported. It said that with sales up a brisk 1.8 percent for the month, the value of the unsold goods declined to $501.02 billion. The ratio of inventories to sales fell to 1.47, the lowest since last May. (21.)

headline: WEIBOLDT'S CHIEF DEFINES ROLE
abstract: Jerome M. Schottenstein, an expert at liquidating failing retail stores, maintains he has been unfairly tarred over the years as a kind of exploiter of others' misfortunes. But now, in his new role as chairman of Wieboldt's, the venerable Chicago department store chain, he has a chance to show he can also nurse an ailing business back to health.   Liquidators, who buy a troubled company's inventories and sell them at reduced prices, sometimes get ''a bad rap,'' as Mr. Schottenstein put it, because some people blame them rather than management for the closing of stores or other businesses.   Thus his appointment at Wieboldt's may seem odd and even portentious to some. But the chunky, intense Mr. Schottenstein disagrees. For one thing, he says, his company, the Schottenstein Stores Corporation, acquired a 15 percent stake in Wieboldt's as part of a group that won control of the chain in a proxy fight.

headline: Semiconductor Accord
abstract: The National Semiconductor Corporation and the Standard Microsystems Corporation said today that they had signed an agreement covering the cross-licensing of each other's patents.

headline: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THURSDAY, JANUARY 20, 1983; The Economy
abstract: A group led by five former Treasury Secretaries urged the Reagan Administration and Congress to halve Federal budget deficits through severe cuts in Government spending and large tax increases. It voiced concern that the current fiscal course might ''lock the economy in stagnation'' for the rest of the century. The group -organized and led by Peter G. Peterson, who served as Secretary of Commerce during the Nixon Administration - includes 500 government, business and academic leaders. (Page A1.)   President Reagan hailed the new accord on Social Security and called for further bipartisan cooperation in handling the budget. In an Illinois speech, he also promised to introduce new job training proposals. (A1.) The main effect of proposed Social Security changes, experts believe, would be to stem the exodus of nonprofit institutions from the system. (D16.) Mr. Reagan, like his predecessors, is starting to seek advice from outsiders. (D17.)

headline: Burnup & Sims
abstract: Burnup & Sims INc., a Fort Lauderdale-based telecommunications companuy, said it has been advised that San Diego County had canceled a contract valued at $25 million for the purchase, installation and maintenance of a new microwave telephone system. Gene Strul, a spokesman for Burnup & Sims, called the contract cancellation a "major occurrence," but said the company did not see it as a loss becuase it was "bound for litigation." He said that the company would not consider its impact until the courts ruled.

headline: GREYHOUND LINES OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A 5-NATION VENTURE TO BUILD JET ENGINE
abstract: Industrial companies from five nations today announced the formation of a corporation to develop a line of jet engines. The engines would be for use in a 150-seat airliner currently in the design stages.

headline: AGAIN, FOR HIGHLAND SCOTS, THE SPECTER OF EVICTION
abstract: A century after hill farmers here on the Isle of Skye resisted eviction and helped end the infamous clearances, the people of this area and other parts of the rugged Scottish Highlands still cling to the land with fear and suspicion.   The folk memory of that time, when poor tenant farmers called crofters were swept off the land by agents of landlords and forced aboard ships that took them to North America or Australia, has been passed on for generations.   The rights of tenancy were secured by the Crofters Act of 1886, enacted four years after tenant farmers on Skye battled policemen who were seeking to evict them from their crofts, or small rented farms.  But holding the land can be a never-ending battle, as can be seen in a current dispute over a valuable piece of mainland called Knoydart.

headline: REAGAN CRITICIZES BANKS OVER RATES
abstract: President Reagan suggested today that banks were keeping interest rates too high and that they should be able to bring them down ''another notch or two.''   The President's remarks were the strongest criticism of banks and interest rates made by the Administration. Unlike some previous remarks, the President did not also attribute fears of inflation, Federal budget deficits or the Federal Reserve to the high level of interest rates.   ''To me it is more direct than recent criticism,'' said Robert T.  Parry, chief economist for the Security Pacific National Bank of Los Angeles.

headline: 10.9% Jobless in Europe
abstract: Unemployment in the European Economic Community in January broke a record at 10.9 percent, up from a revised 10.3 percent in December and 9.3 percent in January 1982, the statistical agency Eurostat reported today. The number of jobless in the 10 member nations rose to 12.4 million from 11.8 million a month earlier and 10.7 million a year earlier, Eurostat said.

headline: FRIDAY, JANUARY 28, 1983; Companies
abstract: Western Electric will close its Kearny, N.J., plant as part of a plan to reduce idle capacity. The decision will eliminate 4,000 jobs at Kearny, while cutbacks at two other sites, including the Hawthorne Works in Cicero, Ill., Western's oldest plant, will cost 2,700 jobs.  The streamlining by Western reflects the impact of the recession as well as a desire to become more competitive now that it is no longer assured of business from Bell's subsidiaries. (Page A1.)   General Electric plans to sell its Utah International unit to the Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Australia for $2.4 billion in cash. (D1.)

headline: Economic Scene; The Hazards Of Forecasting
abstract: THE forecasting by the Reagan Administration during its first two years could scarcely have been worse, as the Administration's new budget for the fiscal year 1984 acknowledges. It says that ''the unanticipated recession of 1981-82,'' the projected modest economic recovery for 1983 and the rapid fall in inflation have resulted in a ''drastic shortfall'' of nominal gross national product, which it now expects to be $482 billion lower by the fourth quarter of this year than it expected in March 1981.   Last year's budget forecast of a deficit of $91.5 billion for the fiscal year 1983 - which Congress refused to accept as too big - has ballooned into a deficit of $207.7 billion. Adding in the off-budget deficit, the Administration says that the gap between receipts and expenditures has now become so large - $225 billion, or 7 percent of the G.N.P. - that it ''threatens to gain self-reinforcing momentum.''

headline: PATENTS; Patent Office Workers Receive an Award
abstract: The Department of Commerce presented an award for distinguished public service this week to employees of the Patent and Trademark Office, which is a division of the department.  The presentation was made at a ceremony and reception Thursday by Guy W. Fiske, Deputy Secretary of Commerce.

headline: Trudeau Asserts NATO Relies On Canada for Missile Tests
abstract: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, commenting on the controversy over the proposed American testing of low-flying cruise missiles in Canada, says the Government will let down its alliance partners if it refuses to permit the tests.   ''We Canadians are members of an alliance, and we have been carried pretty well and have been pretty well protected by the United States,'' he said. Mr. Trudeau, referring to the missile tests, said, ''We'd be pretty poor partners of an alliance if we didn't do that.''

headline: Mexico Plans Help on Debt
abstract: The Mexican Government announced a new plan today to help privately held companies pay foreign creditors, but it said the creditors must cooperate by extending repayment schedules.

headline: U.S.-Soviet Sessions Held
abstract: American and Soviet negotiators met today for two hours and 25 minutes in the 63rd session at the talks on limiting medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe. The next meeting was set for Thursday. Negotiators at the parallel talks on strategic, or intercontinental, missiles held their 38th session, with the meeting lasting an hour and 25 minutes.

headline: COMPANIES ARE BUYING PREFERRED STOCK HEAVILY
abstract: The credit market is faced with a flurry of adjustable rate preferred stock financings, more than $900 million of which have come to market in the last three days, while $550 million more was announced yesterday.   The heavy supply has been sought by corporate investors who are attracted by the favorable tax treatment for the securities. For corporate investors, 85 percent of preferred stock dividends are not considered to be taxable income.

headline: Sohio Sees Drop In Results for 1983
abstract: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said 1983 results are unlikely to equal 1982's because of reduced oil production and lower petroleum prices.

headline: Banks Cool To Latest Account
abstract: Beginning Wednesday, many banks across the nation will start offering checking accounts free of interest-rate ceilings, but neither banks nor consumers are expected to show much enthusiasm for the new product.   Within the banking industry, the new checking accounts are known as "Super NOW's" because they are expected to offer significantly higher yields than the regular NOW, or negotiable order of withdrawal, accounts on which the banks can play a maximum of 5 1/4 percent interest.   Few banks have announced what they will pay on the Super NOW's, but the return is expected to range between 6 percent and 9 percent.   Those rates, however, will no reflect the final yield to consumers, because most banks are expected to charge hefty fees to offset the costs of the service. Under the regulations, customers must keep at least $2,500 in the new accounts. If the balance falls below that level, the interest paid drops to 5 1/4 percent. 'Not So Super'

headline: Turk Dies in Belgrade; Two Gunmen Held
abstract: Turkey's Ambassador to Yugoslavia, Galip Balkar, died today of wounds received when two gunmen shot him from ambush in central Belgrade two days ago, the Turkish Embassy said.   The Yugoslav police said Thursday that both gunmen were under arrest.  Mr. Balkar is the latest victim in a 10-year campaign by Armenian militants against diplomats and other Turks living abroad. At least 25 people have been killed in the campaign, which seeks to avenge the death of countless Armenians at the hands of Turks in the World War I years.

headline: Manville Purchase
abstract: The Manville Corporation, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, said its Forest Productions subsidiary had purchased a plywood and sawmill facility in Joyce, La., from the Crown Zellerbach Corporation for an undisclosed amount. Manville said the plant, which employs 372 workers, has a current annual production capacity of 200 million square feet of plywood and 85 million board feet of lumber and studs.

headline: Market Place; Oil-Related Stocks Viewed
abstract: WHEN the price of crude oil was rising in the 1970's, oil service and drilling companies hitched their wagons to this star and scored stunning gains in the stock market.   But now the scene has changed dramatically because of uncertainties swirling about the price of oil. Today the critical question is this: How far will the price of Saudi Light, the benchmark for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, drop from $34 a barrel?   There also is an ancillary question that nobody can answer now.  When OPEC finally agrees on some price, as it is trying to do at a London meeting, how long will it hold firm at that level?

headline: SOVIET IS MAKING MORE USE OF CAM RANH BAY
abstract: American naval officers say the Vietnamese port of Cam Ranh Bay, which was built up by the United States during the Vietnam War, has become a fulltime naval operating base for the Soviet Pacific Fleet.   On a recent day, the officers said, 20 Soviet ships were in the bay, the largest number spotted since Soviet ships began calling there three years ago.   About half the vessels were said to be combatants, including the aircraft carrier Minsk, several cruisers and destroyers, and two submarines. The others were supply ships, oilers and repair tenders, they said.

headline: Ecuador at a Standstill Because of Union Strike
abstract: A general strike called by Ecuador's major unions brought the country to a standstill today, Labor Minister Vladimiro Alvarez Grau said.

headline: U.S. Flour Sale Angers E.E.C.
abstract: An American plan to sell a million metric tons of flour to Egypt below market rates provoked anger and dismay in the European Economic Community today.   Common Market officials said they were taken completely by surprise by Agriculture Secretary John R. Block's announcement Tuesday of the sale.

headline: Large I.M.F.  Infusion Urged
abstract: Finance ministers of developing countries called today for a major infusion of money and credits to bolster their economies and help them repay mounting debts.   During a conference of the International Monetary Fund, the ministers urged a doubling of lending resources in the 146-nation agency and said they would seek another allocation of special drawing rights, used by countries to pay bills. They met as the Group of 24, a body that represents most of the developing world.

headline: FAILED MUTINY IS REPORTED IN TANZANIA
abstract: A small-scale army mutiny in northern Tanzania this month underlined that nation's economic malaise but apparently failed to dent President Julius K. Nyerere's grasp on the country.   Diplomats said the uprising involved officers from the Haya tribe, a relatively prosperous group from the Bukoba area on Tanzania's Lake Victoria border with Uganda in the north.   The mutiny, directed against President Nyerere's leadership, was rapidly quashed by loyalists. One of those reportedly detained was Christopher Ngaiza, a former presidential aide who had been linked to a prominent Tanzanian dissident, Oscar Kambona, now in exile in London. The uprising was short-lived and confused, the diplomats said.

headline: The U.N. Today; March 16, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Council for Namibia - 3 P.M.   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Statistical Commission - 10 A.M.  and 3 P.M.

headline: Italy Reports Crime Link To American Gangs
abstract: Proof of links between Italian gang bosses and associates in the United States and France has been uncovered by a nationwide police drive against organized crime, Italian Justice Ministry officials said today.

headline: American Express Completes Deal
abstract: The American Express Company and Trade Development Bank Holding S.A. of Luxembourg said that American Express had completed the $550 million acquisition of the European company's non-United States banking business.

headline: SOUTH LEBANON: REJECTED, NEGLECTED AND OCCUPIED
abstract: Adib Basmas sat in a small cafe across from his supermarket and surveyed this battered southern Lebanese port. ''It's quiet,'' he said. ''Quite a lot of people have returned to repair their houses.''   Riven by years of internal strife and heavily hit during the Israeli invasion last June, Tyre and Sidon and small towns in southern Lebanon are beginning to recover.   But in interviews in both cities and in villages in the south there is a pervasive feeling that the central Government in Beirut, which so far really only controls the capital city with the help of a multinational force of 4,000 soldiers from Italy, France and the United States, is not very concerned with the problems of southern Lebanon.

headline: Late Rally Lifts Dow 10.07
abstract: A late rally, led by some of the blue-chip and technology issues, gave the Dow Jones industrial average a solid gain yesterday. The overall stock market, however, advanced only slightly in continued sluggish trading.   The Dow average, which was up less than 1 point at 2:30 P.M., closed with a rise of 10.07 points, at 1,1124.52. On the New York Stock Exchange, advancing issues outnumbered declining stocks by 840 to 730.

headline: FROZEN FOOD EXPRESS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * American Medical International filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $300 million of debt securities through Goldman, Sachs & Co.   * Credit Commercial de France said it would issue retractable floating rate notes to raise $200 million on the international capital market. About $100 million consists of 15-year notes, with interest set a quarter point above the mean bid and offered rates for six-month Eurodollar deposits. The other $100 million in notes matures in 1995, with interest a quarter point above the London interbank rate.

headline: SOVIET CITY PUTS BREZHNEV ON THE MAP
abstract: The news that their city had been renamed came as a total surprise to the people here.  Nadezhda S. Akepsimova, a Deputy Mayor, learned about it from the evening television news. Even Gennadi S. Bashtanyuk, a 33-year-old truck plant foreman who is a candidate member of the Communist Party's Central Commitee and was at the meeting in Moscow where the decision was taken, did not know in advance.   The way they tell it here, the local party organization plunged that night of Nov. 22 into a feverish effort. Local officials were turned back from the airport, telephones jangled and, by morning, 50,000 people were at a rally outside the Tatarstan Hotel to greet the tidings with appropriate speeches.

headline: Rebels in Angola Offer Prisoner Trade
abstract: Angolan insurgents said today that they had captured 64 Czechoslovaks and 20 Portuguese and offered an exchange to obtain the freedom of convicted British mercenaries imprisoned by the leftist Government in Luanda.   In a communique issued here, the Union for the Total Independence of Angola said its guerrillas had killed 174 Government soldiers and 13 Cubans in separate attacks this weekend.

headline: REAGAN'S LETTER TO EUROPEANS
abstract: Following is the text of a letter that President Reagan addressed to the people of Europe and that Vice President Bush read today in a speech in West Berlin:   American and Soviet officials have just resumed negotiations aimed at reaching an agreement to control intermediate-range nuclear weapons. We have proposed and will continue to urge the Soviets to agree to ban altogether both their intermediate-range land-based nuclear missile weapons and those we intend to deploy in response to their buildup.

headline: Todd Layoffs
abstract: The Todd Pacific Shipyards Corporation will lay off 150 workers at its San Pedro, Calif., yards this month and may lay off all 5,000 of its employees there by mid-1985 unless it receives new Navy contracts, a spokesman said.

headline: PATENTS; Classroom Signals For Deaf Students
abstract: A method to improve the teaching of deaf students in a class with students with normal hearing was patented this week by Prof. Robert Sapora, who teaches English at Western Maryland College in Westminster.

headline: AIDES SAY REAGAN IS READY TO OFFER ARMS COMPROMISE
abstract: President Reagan has made a preliminary decision to propose to the Soviet Union an interim agreement limiting but not eliminating intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe, according to Administration officials and diplomatic sources.   The officials and diplomats said that at a White House meeting last week, Mr. Reagan indicated he would propose that the Soviet and American sides each be limited to 100 missile launchers with a total of 300 warheads. One key official said it was his understanding that this interim offer would be dependent on Moscow's ultimate acceptance of Mr. Reagan's so-called zero option, which calls for the elimination of all intermediate-range missiles in Europe. Arguments by State Department   The officials and diplomats explained that Mr. Reagan agreed with State Department arguments that he had to temper his zero-option approach or risk growing West European belief that he was not seriously pursuing arms control.

headline: FRIDAY, JANUARY 7, 1983; The Economy
abstract: The I.C.C. dropped a 48-year ban on railroads entering the commercial trucking business. The action will allow the railroads to move closer to becoming complete transportation companies. The trucking industry immediately challenged the decision and threatened court action. Analysts said that in time, many railroads would probably operate large trucking subsidiaries. (Page A1.)   The Administration is undecided on key budget questions, with a wide range of strategies still under study. The options were said to include a possible freeze of some spending levels to deal with the record Federal deficit. (A1.) President Reagan signed a bill providing the first increase in Federal gasoline taxes in 23 years.  (B5.) The promise of a sustained recovery is now being threatened by huge deficits that would not disappear even if the economy started growing strongly again. (A1.)

headline: WOMETCO NAMES 2 TO REPLACE FOUNDER
abstract: Wometco Enterprises Inc., a Miami-based leisure-products company, said yesterday that Van Myers had been elected president and chief executive officer and Elton M. Cary had been named chairman. The two executives succeed Mitchell Wolfson, the company's founder who died last Friday at the age of 82.   Mr. Myers, who is 65, has been an executive vice president responsible for the company's soft-drink and food operations. He joined the company in 1940 after graduating cum laude from Harvard.  Mr. Cary, who is 54, is president and chairman of the General Insurance Company and has been a Wometco director since 1972.

headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS; A NEW BUOYANCY STIRS THE ECONOMY
abstract: Euphoria swept over the economy last week. Investors, bond traders and Government officials decided - at least for the time being - that plummetting oil prices meant better times ahead. And they became even more enthusiastic over news that the nation's leading indicators had climbed 3.6 percent in January, the largest monthly gain since July 1950. An 8.9 percent rise in construction spending during the month - the biggest since March 1946 - and a 9.9 percent increase in single-family home sales seemed proof positive that the recession was over.  The stock market marched higher. The Dow Jones Industrial average set records almost every day on the strength of high-tech, bluechip, retail-store and rebounding oil stocks. It finally closed Friday at 1,140.96, up 20.02 points on the week. Even gold stocks recovered from the losses they suffered after bullion fell $100 an ounce on fears that slumping oil revenues would force Arab nations to sell their gold. Though the soaring economic barometers were warmly welcomed, falling oil prices still carried the day. Said one Wall Street analyst of oil's decline: ''It's the most important economic event of the year.''

headline: EAGLE CLOTHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IRAQ SAYS ITS NAVY UNITS DESTROYED IRAN OIL RIGS AND 5 SHIPS IN GULF
abstract: Iraq said today that its naval units had attacked and destroyed Iranian offshore oil installations and five ships in the northern areas of the Persian Gulf.   The attack, reportedly carried out today, was said to have been against installations in the Nowruz Field, about 50 miles northwest of Kharg Island, Iran's main oil export terminal. There was no confirmation from Iran.

headline: BARTERING AIDS POOR NATIONS
abstract: When the International Commodities Export Company of White Plains recently received a $127 million fertilizer order from Indonesia, the company went through with the deal even though it knew it would not get any cash from the customer. Instead the company accepted payment in goods.   The fertilizer exporter received cement, rubber, cocoa, coffee and other Indonesian products. It immediately exchanged these for goods from other countries with similar cash problems. After several other so-called countertrade exchanges, International Commodities Export finally obtained goods it could sell for dollars.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MCI Bolstering Communications
abstract: The MCI Communications Corporation announced plans to invest $1 billion in its communications network during the fiscal year that begins April 1, up from $600 million in the current year.

headline: A New Bank for Ohio
abstract: The Citizens Fidelity Corporation, a Kentucky bank holding company, said today that it had received approval from the Comptroller of the Currency to start a limited-purpose bank in Cincinnati.

headline: U.S. HINTS JORDAN IS READY TO TALK
abstract: Administration officials said today that they were counting on King Hussein of Jordan to declare his readiness to join in negotiations on Palestinian self-rule by the end of next month, provided he receives stronger backing than he has received up to now from Saudi Arabia.   The officials cautioned, however, that his expected statement would probably translate into actual negotiations with Israel and Egypt only if there was progress on removing foreign troops from Lebanon and if Israel agreed to some good-faith gesture such as a temporary halt in establishing new Jewish settlements in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.   Also important to King Hussein, the officials said, is the attitude of the Palestine Liberation Organization leadership, which has been discussing with him the makeup of a possible joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation to the talks. With all these uncertainties, officials said, it is possible that the American effort to persuade King Hussein to join the negotiations may fail.  But for the moment, officials said, the timetable looks encouraging for late next month.

headline: CONRAIL ADVANCE
abstract: The Consolidated Rail Corporation said yesterday that it earned $54.6 million, or $2.14 a share, in the fourth quarter, more than double its profit of $26.4 million, or $1.03 a share, in the 1981 period. Earnings for the latest quarter were after special gains of $63.5 million.

headline: Your Money; Alternative Minimum Tax
abstract: BEGINNING this year, the alternative minimum tax - a term that a relatively small number of Americans have been aware of, and a tax that relatively few have paid thus far -will have an effect on many more Federal income taxpayers. That is because the rules for computing this tax were changed by the 1982 tax law, and a number of new strategies are being devised to reduce tax liabilities that might otherwise be due.   The general intent of the alternative minimum tax, or the A.M.T., is to require some payments from every taxpayer with substantial income, even if part or all of such income would not ordinarily be taxable, as in the case of long-term capital gains. It is calculated separately from the regular tax, and the portion of the alternative minimum tax payable is the excess over that regular tax.

headline: BRITISH OIL MAY CUT PRICE BY $3
abstract: Industry sources said today that the British National Oil Corporation would lower its North Sea oil prices by between $3 and $3.50 a barrel Friday. It would be the most significant price break since OPEC members failed last month to reach agreement on prices and production quotas.   Such a decline, coming on the heels of reductions in the Soviet Union, the United States and Egypt, would put extreme pressure on Nigeria and Libya, whose oil most resembles North Sea crude. Oil traders and stock analysts here agreed that Norway would immediately follow the lead of the state-owned B.N.O.C. and that members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would also lower prices in a matter of weeks.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues   * Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day paper drew an average interest rate of 9.093 percent, up from 8.668 percent last week.  Citicorp accepted $125 million of the $870.5 million in bids.   * General Tire and Rubber's 60,000-unit offering was priced by underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody. The offering today consists of $60 million of 11 7/8 percent notes due in 1993, priced at par, and common stock warrants exercisable at $40 a share. Each unit consists of one note and 12 warrants.

headline: COMPUTER ROUTE TO THE EXECUTIVE SUITE
abstract: MARIO NIGRO is an exemplar for ambitious students of computers. He i s the senior vice president of operations at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, F enner & Smith Inc., the nation's largest brokerage firm. He sits on i ts board of directors and has more than 7,800 people in his charge a nd a spacious office on the 37th floor of One Liberty Plaza in l ower Manhattan. Mr. Nigro is, in fact, a paradigm for his p rofession - a one-time computer programmer who was able to break o ut of strict information processing and into high-level management o f a major corporation.   The prospects for management-level jobs for computer programmers and systems analysts have, in the past, been limited almost entirely to computer departments. But this seems to be changing. As computers enter almost every corner of business, the executive with a broad grounding in the area will have more and more of an edge over his or her uninitiated colleague. Moreover, the explosion in demand for computer systems is creating a disproportionate number of new managerial positions in what is often called management information services, or M.I.S.

headline: People
abstract: * Paula Drillman, formerly of Marschalk, named executive vice president and research director of McCann-Erickson, U.S.A.   * Scott Alden Rossborough promoted to senior vice president at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample Inc.

headline: IMPORTERS WELCOME OPEC CUT
abstract: The cut in oil prices by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries could save major importers such as Japan billions of dollars, but some smaller countries that provide services and receive foreign aid from the Middle East expect losses in income.   Economists say the price cut will further strain the budgets of such heavily indebted oil producers as Mexico and Venezuela.  Mexico, which is not a member of OPEC but which also lowered its oil prices to remain competitive, is expected to lose up to nearly $3 billion annually, according to some estimates. For Venezuela, an OPEC member, the loss could be $3 billion to $3.5 billion.

headline: Iranian Team in London For OPEC Price Parley
abstract: An Iranian delegation arrived here today to join the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' consultations on prices, raising hopes of averting a world oil price collapse.   Eight ministers of the oil exporters' group have been talking informally, trying to narrow differences on how to prevent a price war in the glutted oil market that has led one member, Nigeria, to slash prices well below agreed levels.

headline: CENCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

headline: SADAT'S HALF BROTHER IS SENTENCED TO JAIL
abstract: The half brother of President Anwar el-Sadat and three of the half-brother's sons were sentenced today to one-year prison terms for corruption.   The Cairo Court of Ethics also ordered that property belonging to the four and that of seven other family members be confiscated.  The prosecutor general, Abdel-Kader Ahmed Aly, said Esmat Sadat, 59 years old, and his sons, Galal Esmat, 37, Talaat Esmat, 29, and Mohammed Anwar Esmat, 27, had committed ''acts harmful to the interests of the community.''

headline: The U.N. Today; March 7, 1983
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Statistical Commission - 11 A.M.  and 3 P.M.

headline: BRITISH LABORITE WINS KEY BY-ELECTION
abstract: Britain's opposition Labor Party, which has suffered an almost unbroken series of splits and setbacks in the last four years, appeared headed tonight for its most important by-election victory since Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher took office in 1979.   After trailing in the early stages of the campaign, Ossie O'Brien, the Labor nominee at Darlington, an industrial town in northeast England, overtook Tony Cook, the candidate of the Liberal-Social Democratic alliance, in several late opinion polls. The Conservative, Michael Fallon, also appeared to have closed fast but was generally expected to finish third. The voting was fairly heavy, despite some snow flurries.

headline: Brazilian Cleric Reports 7,291 Argentines Missing
abstract: The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Sao Paulo released the names today of 7,291 people who he said had disappeared in Argentina in recent years.   The Archbishop, Paulo Evaristo Cardinal Arns, said the list was published ''so that others do not disappear.''

headline: CRITICS CITE BANKS' AID IN ELECTIONS
abstract: Political action committees representing the banking industry, which is seeking repeal of a new law requiring that taxes be withheld on interest and dividend payments, contributed more than $3 million to the campaigns of most members of Congress, according to Federal Election Commission records.   Critics of the repeal effort contend that the large contributions from the bank ''PAC's'' are a major factor in the repeal effort. More than 300 of the 435 members of the House of Representatives and more than half the 100 Senators have co-sponsored repeal bills.   However, many members of Congress assert that contributions from political action committees do not influence their votes. Further, the political action committees object vigorously to allegations that their large contributions have enabled them to influence votes on the withholding issue.

headline: NO BREAKTHROUGH IS SEEN IN SOVIET-CHINESE TALKS
abstract: The chief Chinese delegate at the Soviet-Chinese talks on improving relations met today with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko amid indications that the discussions had produced no breakthroughs on the issues separating the two nations.   A report by the official press agency Tass said that Mr. Gromyko and Qian Qichen, a Chinese Deputy Foreign Minister, had agreed on ''the positive importance of the fact'' that the two Governments were having ''a political dialogue.''   The Tass item was one of a very few reporting on the talks since they resumed here March 1, following initial discussions held in Peking last fall. The reluctance of the two sides to disclose much of substance has led some Western diplomats to believe that they may be moving cautiously toward a limited accommodation on the one issue that seems susceptible to compromise, the tensions between military forces arrayed along their common frontier.

headline: VIOLENCE SEEMS TO GROW IN INDIA'S TROUBLED STATE
abstract: Violence appeared to be spreading rapidly today in the countryside of Assam, this northeastern state where elections now under way have been marred by ethnic and religious fighting.   As efforts were made to conduct the second stage of elections for a new 126-seat state legislature and 12 members of the national Parliament, reports from around the state told of new fighting between Moslem immigrants and Assamese Hindus. At least 150 people are believed to have been killed in the last two weeks.   (Twenty-two more deaths were reported in fighting on Thursday, according to Reuters, which said some estimates on the total killed this month had reached 250. In one incident Moslem immigrants were said to have attacked villagers with arrows, spears and guns, killing eight people in the area around the town of Magaldai, scene of a massacre by tribal gangs last weekend.)

headline: Reagan to End Boycott Of Nuclear Agency
abstract: President Reagan has decided to lift a United States boycott of the International Atomic Energy Agency imposed six months ago after it rejected Israel's credentials, the State Department announced today.   It said the President had decided the United Nations agency was critical to American national security interests and the United States policy of preventing the spread of nuclear weapons.

headline: Spanish Bishops Fight Abortion Law Changes
abstract: The church has declared its opposition to easing Spain's strict antiabortion laws, setting the stage for a showdown with the Socialist Government.   Spanish bishops, in a strongly worded document issued Saturday night, said abortion under any circumstances was murder and called proposed legislation to legalize abortion ''gravely unjust and totally unacceptable.''

headline: Israeli Unit to Needham
abstract: Needham, Harper & Steers's Issues and Images unit has just won the Israel Government Tourist Office, which has a budget of around $1.5 million and for the last 25 years has been an account of Doyle Dane Bernbach -most recently of its Group Two unit.

headline: SBE INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31

headline: AETNA CITED ON DAMAGE TO CLIENT
abstract: A New York Federal court jury yesterday awarded what is believed to be the first punitive damages ever assessed against an insurance company for its refusal to pay a claim.   After a six-day trial before United States District Judge Henry Werker, the Source Commodities Corporation won a $300,000 judgment against the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company for Aetna's refusal to pay a claim under a policy insuring Source against losses caused by the dishonest acts of its employees.   The judgment against Aetna Casualty, a unit of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, includes $100,000 of compensatory damages and $200,000 for punitive damages.

headline: Tribune Seeks To Go Public
abstract: The Tribune Company is asking its shareholders to approve measures for making it public after more than 120 years as a closely held concern.   The diversified communications company, which publishes The Chicago Tribune and The Daily News in New York and owns the Chicago Cubs baseball team, is taking steps to change its charter and clear the way for a public stock offering.

headline: National Medical Gains
abstract: National Medical Enterprises Inc. reported yesterday that its earnings for the fiscal second quarter, ended Nov. 30, rose 28 percent, to $21.5 million, or 45 cents a share, from income before nonrecurring credits of $16.8 million, or 36 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier.   The company, which owns, operates and manages 359 acute-care hospitals and nursing homes, reported a 63 percent increase in revenues, to $517.4 million, from $318.3 million in the quarter a year ago.   In last year's second quarter, the company had nonrecurring credits of $5.5 million after taxes, which resulted in net income of $22.3 million, or 48 cents a share. These credits resulted from the exchange of a sizable portion of the company's 12 3/4 subordinated debentures for its common stock and from the sale of common stock of Cenco Inc.

headline: Dow Retreats 11.77, to 1,075.33
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 11.77 points yesterday, to 1,075.33, as investors cashed in some of their recent profits.  ''The market was overbought and ripe for a pullback,'' said Ralph J. Acampora, vice president and head of technical research at Kidder, Peabody & Company.   In the previous 11 sessions, the 30 component stocks of the Dow average soared 34 points, mostly because of the growing conviction that the recession was ending and that interest rates would move lower.   ''Many stocks are now so high it will be difficult for prices to keep advancing,'' said Keith Pinsoneault, an analyst with Blunt Ellis & Loewi of Milwaukee.

headline: Governor of Bermuda Resigns in Dispute
abstract: Britain's Governor of Bermuda, Sir Richard Posnett, has resigned after denying allegations by Bermuda of involvement in financial irregularities, the Foreign Office said today.   ''The publicity which has been generated has created an atmosphere in which it would no longer be possible for me to carry out the reponsibilities entrusted to me as Governor,'' the career diplomat said in a letter of resignation, dated last month.

headline: Egypt Says Libyans Have Pulled Back
abstract: The Egyptian Government said today that Libyan troops who had massed along the Egyptian-Sudanese border had pulled back.   The announcement was made by Mohammed Rashwan, Minister of State for Parliamentary Affairs, who quoted President Hosni Mubarak as saying there was ''complete political stability'' in the Sudan.   Last week President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan said that Col.  Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, had planned a coup for Feb. 18 but that it had been discovered by the Sudanese.

headline: China Car Rentals
abstract: National Car Rental System Inc. of the United States now has a representative in China that will accept National's credit cards and advance reservations from its worldwide system, officials of Minneapolis-based National said. Starting Feb.  15 in Peking and other major cities, National customers will be able to reserve a car with driver. China does not have rental cars that can be driven by the customer.

headline: CHINESE THREATEN TRADE REPRISALS IF U.S. CURBS IMPORTS OF TEXTILES
abstract: China said today that it would retaliate economically against the United States if the Reagan Administration carried out a threat to curb imports of Chinese textiles unilaterally later this month.   The Administration announced last Tuesday that it would act to curb Chinese textile imports on Jan. 15 if the two sides could not resolve the dispute in negotiations that are expected to resume here later this week.   The New China News Agency today quoted an official of the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations and Trade as saying that China ''cannot but respond strongly in order to safeguard our own interests'' if the Reagan Administration carried out its threat.   Should the trade skirmish escalate, the unidentified official added, ''the U.S. side would bear all the consequences.''

headline: FROM FILMS TO CEMENT
abstract: Burt Sugarman, a Hollywood producer of films and television programs, is also an investor. He has moved into cement in a big way.  Mr. Sugarman owns 10 percent of the common stock of the Giant Portland and Masonry Cement Company of Columbia, S.C., which has been suffering losses in recent years.   Last year Giant Portland, to raise money, sold him $3 million of convertible preferred stock. This gave Mr. Sugarman the equivalent, upon conversion, of a 28 percent stake in the company's common shares, which are listed on the New York Stock Exchange. In yesterday's trading, they closed at 7, up 3/8.

headline: Gerber Products Names President and Chairman
abstract: The Gerber Products Company named a chairman and president yesterday in changes that it termed part of an orderly succession.  Carl G. Smith, the company's 62-year-old chief executive, was named to the additional post of chairman.

headline: SHULTZ DENOUNCES SALVADOR'S REBELS AS 'CREATING HELL'
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Salvadoran insurgents were ''creating hell'' with Soviet-supplied weapons and that the United States would never support negotiations allowing them to ''shoot their way'' into the Government.   In unusually sharp remarks, Mr. Shultz seemed to show irritation at members of Congress who urged negotiations. Mr. Shultz said the rebels had tried to use force to block the elections in El Salvador last March.   ''And to now say, let them shoot their way into that Government,'' Mr. Shultz said. ''No dice!'' Mr. Shultz ran into tough questioning while testifying before the House Foreign Affairs Committee on a $14.5 billion foreign aid package for the fiscal year 1984 and for a supplemental bill of $1.2 billion for the current fiscal year.

headline: DANA CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31

headline: CHINA, UPSET BY U.S. TRADE CURB, HALTING IMPORTS OF 3 COMMODITIES
abstract: China announced today that it was banning further purchases this year of cotton, soybeans and chemical fibers from the United States. The move was in retaliation for curbs imposed by the Reagan Administration on textile imports from China.   The announcement, circulated by the official New China News Agency, also quoted Shen Jueren, director of the Foreign Trade Administration, as saying that China would reduce its planned imports of other American agricultural products, but he did not specify which ones. Restrictions on Textiles   The ban comes four days after Washington imposed its restrictions because the two countries had failed to reach a new agreement governing China's textile sales to the United States. It also comes two weeks before Secretary of State George P. Shultz is to arrive in China for his first official visit.

headline: BURLINGTON MOVE IS REBUFFED
abstract: The chairman of Burlington Northern Inc., asked the El Paso Company yesterday to give his company an opportunity to outbid any offer made for El Paso's assets.   Burlington Northern, which received nearly 50 percent of El Paso's stock last Thursday in response to its tender offer, yesterday released the text of a letter sent by Richard Bressler to Travis H.  Petty, the chairman of the board of El Paso.   Commenting on El Paso's statement Friday that it was negotiating with a number of companies in an attempt to dispose of its oil and natural gas assets, Mr. Bressler said, ''We would be distressed if the considerable business advantages that presently flow to El Paso, its shareholders and markets were dissipated by a hasty sale of assets at distress prices.''

headline: Florida Bank Link
abstract: Barnett Banks of Florida Inc., based in Jacksonville, said it had agreed to acquire the Boulevard Bank in Key West for about $4.7 million in stock.

headline: MOSCOW OUSTS A U.S. DIPLOMAT, CALLING HIM A SPY
abstract: The Soviet Union today ordered the expulsion of an American diplomat who it said had been caught ''red-handed'' while in possession of equipment that included a portable electronic transmitter and notes written on special soluble paper.   An announcement in the Government newspaper Izvestia said the diplomat, Richard Osborne, who was identified by the United States Embassy as a first secretary in the economic section, was detained here Monday. The announcement said Mr. Osborne had been declared ''persona non grata for actions incompatible with diplomatic status.''

headline: IRAQ REPORTS FRANCE WILL BUY MORE OIL AND CONTINUE AID
abstract: Tareq Aziz, a Deputy Prime Minister of Iraq, said today that France was increasing its purchases of Iraqi oil and continuing military aid on what he called a ''vast scale.''   Mr. Aziz spoke of French aid in general terms at a news conference and in a newspaper interview after five days of talks with French officials, including President Francois Mitterrand.   French military sources said the Government was considering credit arrangements that would permit Iraq to go on buying French arms while France triples its purchases of Iraqi oil. In the first 10 months of 1982, France bought 1.6 billon barrels of oil from Iraq, or about 2.5 percent of its total needs

headline: Funding Concom
abstract: To The Business Editor:   Charles Maechling Jr. is correct. The way to slow the flow of technology to the Soviet Union is through ''Closer Cooperation With Our Allies'' (Feb.13).

headline: U.S. Steel Plans 5% Cut in Pay
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation has informed general management and salaried employees of a 5 percent pay cut, effective Feb. 1. The cut would be the second 5 percent reduction in seven months.

headline: AIM IS TO REASSURE ALLIES ON ARMS
abstract: Vice President Bush arrived here tonight on the first leg of a seven-nation West European visit that is aimed at affirming to America's allies the Reagan Administration's commitment to arms reduction.   ''For nearly four decades we and our NATO allies have kept the peace in Europe,'' said Mr. Bush in a statement read at the Cologne-Bonn airport. ''We have done it by maintaining our strength and our will to defend ourselves; by linking U.S. and Europe's security; by being open to dialogue that aims to reduce tensions with the East, and by being committed to genuine arms reduction.''   ''And that is why,'' said the Vice President, ''I am confident that my discussions with our allies will affirm our unity on a policy that has given us the longest period of uninterrupted peace in Europe for more than a century.''

headline: REAGAN DEFENDS MARINES IN DISPUTES IN BEIRUT
abstract: President Reagan today defended American marines involved in recent disputes with Israeli troops in Beirut and said the incidents underlined the need for foreign forces to withdraw entirely from Lebanon.   ''I think our forces are behaving very well,'' the President declared at a news conference at which he was asked about the latest incident Wednesday, when a Marine captain drew and loaded his pistol in ordering an Israeli tank commander to withdraw from a disputed patrol area.   ''In my view, the Marine officer did the only thing he could do,'' Mr. Reagan said, contending that Israeli troops had made ''repeated efforts'' to journey beyond agreed-upon lines. He added that Israeli and American diplomats had since worked out a clearer agreement to avert future confrontations.

headline: VATICAN AIDE HINTS POPE WROTE LETTER TO BREZHNEV
abstract: A senior Vatican official today repeated a denial that Pope John Paul II had written Leonid I. Brezhnev threatening to return to Poland to lead a resistance movement in the event of a Soviet invasion.   But the official hinted that the Pope did write a letter to the Soviet leader, who died last November, presumably to express his concern over the possibility of Soviet action in Poland in the winter of 1981 and 1982. At that time tension was high over the possibility of Soviet moves to curb the independent labor movement Solidarity.   Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York, said last month that he had been reliably informed by a Vatican source that the Pope had threated to lead a resistance movement in his native Poland in the event of a Soviet invasion.

headline: WITHHOLDING FIGHT STIRS SCRUTINY OF BANK TAXES
abstract: The imbroglio over withholding Federal income taxes from interest and dividend payments, which has delayed the emergency recession relief bill now being debated by the Senate, threatens to create some nasty political fallout for the nation's financial institutions.   These institutions - commercial banks, mutual savings banks, savings and loan associations and credit unions - have been leading the fight against the withholding law, and angering some members of Congress in the process.  It is too early to predict the reaction of Congress to the industry's intense lobbying tactics, which have drawn criticism even from President Reagan.  The whole affair might blow over. On the other hand, Congress could impose new regulations on the institutions or mandate a significant increase in their Federal taxes. Commercial banks and thrift institutions now enjoy important tax advantages, while credit unions are entirely tax-exempt.

headline: Saudi Arabia Finds Coal
abstract: Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, said today that it had discovered coal for the first time. It said exploration was being conducted around Mujamma in the north.

headline: Kodak Product
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company announced what it called ''the world's most advanced system yet'' for computerized storage of documents on microfilm. The Kodak KAR-4000 uses a computer, a cathode ray tube, a printer and a software package.

headline: DEMOCRATS ASSERT REAGAN IS USING 'STAR WARS' SCARE TO HIDE BLUNDERS
abstract: Congressional Democrats accused President Reagan today of using a ''Star Wars scenario'' to stir fear of the Soviet Union among the American people and distract them from ''the dismal failure'' of the Administration's economic program.   The Democrats also accused the President of ''selective declassification of information for political effect'' in his release of intelligence photographs to bolster his accusations about the Soviet threat.   Taping his delivery of the Democrats' response to the President's televised address Wednesday night, Senator Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii contended that ''the President left the impression that the United States is at the mercy of the Soviet Union.''

headline: Costa Rica Debt Upheld
abstract: A Geneva Court has rejected efforts to have Costa Rica formally declared in default on a loan, a spokesman for Costa Rica's lawyers said today.

headline: Your Money; A Tax Shelter For Employees
abstract: THE name may not have a comfortable or familiar ring, but 401(K) plans have become one of the most talked-about subjects in employeebenefit circles these days. As a result, these plans - a type of savings plan that allows workers to shelter income from taxes - have been adopted recently at many companies.   The programs, often referred to as salary reduction plans, derive their name from Section 401(K) of the Internal Revenue Code, which became effective in 1978. But it was not until last year that they began to get widespread attention from the corporate community. This followed the issuance by the Internal Revenue Service of proposed regulations in November 1981, and an announcement in February 1982 that these early proposals could be used by companies considering setting up such a plan.

headline: ISRAEL SAYS U.S. DID NOT HONOR PACT ON PATROLS
abstract: Israel accused the United States today of failing to honor an agreement on delineating military patrol zones in the Beirut area.   An Israeli statement charged that all the incidents between United States marines and Israeli soldiers had occurred outside Marine areas, in zones designated as Israeli-controlled.   (In Washington, a Pentagon official said Defense Minister Moshe Arens of Israel told Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger that Israeli forces in Lebanon were under ''strict instructions'' to avoid incidents with American marines. Page 3.)

headline: THURSDAY, MARCH 24, 1983
abstract: The Economy   Consumer prices fell 0.2 percent in February because of steep declines in gasoline prices and stability in food and housing costs.  The drop brought the inflation rate for the past 12 months to 3.5 percent. (Page A1.) Prices in the New York area were unchanged. (D2.)    The House approved the Democrats' budget for fiscal year 1984 by a vote of 229 to 196. The package proposes $863.6 billion in spending for the year beginning next Oct.1, compared with President Reagan's $848.5 billion request. (A1.) The vote establishes the Democrats' control over the House. (A27.)

headline: Soviet-Chinese Talks
abstract: Deputy Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, the head of a Chinese delegation that has been holding talks on improving relations with the Soviet Union, has left Moscow for a four-day trip to Soviet Uzbekistan, the official press agency Tass reported. His Soviet counterpart, Deputy Foreign Minister Leonid F.  Ilyichev, made a similar trip outside Peking during the first round of talks last October in China.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; COMPETITION WILL CUT SHIPPING COSTS
abstract: IN recent years, Congress has been working to remove the yoke of a c entury of regulation from the railroads. A major step was taken in 1 980 with the passage of the Staggers Rail Act, which gave the r ailroads new freedom in setting rates, streamlining operations and e ntering into long-term contracts.  The law is a good one, restoring needed financial strength to the rail industry. However, actions of the Interstate Commerce Commission have left shippers, who are captive to the railroads, highly vulnerable to unreasonable pricing for shipment.

headline: UNITED SOUTHERN BIDS FOR BUTCHER HOLDINGS
abstract: United Southern Bank of Nashville said yesterday that it has begun negotiations to buy a major portion of the banks owned by C.H.  Butcher Jr. and his brother, Jake.   The announcement was the lastest in a series of developments that has threatened the financial empire of the Butcher brothers. On Tuesday, C.H. Butcher's Southern Industrial Banking Corporation, a large finance company, said it was being forced into bankruptcy proceedings. Last month Jake Butcher's United American Bank of Knoxville failed because of bad loans and was sold.

headline: WHAT RECOVERY?
abstract: To the Business Editor:   Yes, I too have sniffed something new and refreshing in the air blowing from Washington these days. But it is not economic recovery as Mr. Silk suggests.

headline: Needham, Harper Loses S.C. Johnson & Son
abstract: In a terse announcement, Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, said it had resigned the S.C. Johnson & Son Inc. business, ''due to the recently enunciated competitive conflict policy.''   The billings are about $9 million and involve Soft Sense skin lotion, Agree Shampoo and Conditioner, Enhance Shampoo and Conditioner, and Glade Air Freshener.

headline: IN A RUHR STEEL TOWN, PLEAS FOR HELP
abstract: Wearing a funny hat, Helmut Wieczorek, Member of Parliament for the Social Democratic Party, told a fairy tale to 300 beer-tipsy carnival celebrators who had met at a tavern for some merrymaking spiced with politics.   It was a fairy tale about a fool named Helmut-Who-Was-The-Worst-One. Everybody got the allusion to Chancellor Helmut Kohl. After stretching the metaphor for a long time, Mr. Wieczorek came to a predictable punch line: ''When the question is put on March 6 -'Do you want this carnival to go on any longer?' - the answer should be no!''

headline: Inflation's Slowing
abstract: To the Business Editor: In ''The Moderation of Inflation'' (Dec.5), Jonathan Fuerbringer characterizes ''the dramatic slowing of inflation'' as ''the outstanding achievement of President Reagan's economic policy.'' The fact is that the President's policies have virtually nothing to do with the current moderation of inflation. Disinflation is characteristic of depression regardless of the party in power.
