headline: NO REQUEST FOR CANADA ARMS TEST, BUSH SAYS
abstract: Vice President Bush said today that the United States had not asked Canada to allow testing of the low-flying cruise missile over its territory.   His statement came in the face of growing Canadian opposition to testing the missile over northern Alberta, whose terrain in part resembles the Soviet Union's.   ''Canada is not commited to any specific testing,'' Mr. Bush said at a news conference.  He added that he ''did not formally propose'' such testing in talks today with Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and other Canadian leaders. But he said it was ''no secret'' that Washington is eager to test the missile in Alberta.

headline: AID GROUPS IN U.S. WORRY OVER FUNDS
abstract: Leading private aid organizations in the United States are experiencing a time of disquiet over dwindling resources and their changing relationship with the Federal Government.   The agencies - in foreign aid circles they are commonly referred to as the ''P.V.O.'s,'' meaning private, voluntary organizations - spend $1.8 billion a year overseas in carrying out foreign aid programs in at least 100 countries.   But officials are increasingly concerned about stretching limited funds to meet increasing demands for food, medicine and other commodities. They say they are uneasy about the growing competition for the charitable dollar. The groups, esteemed abroad for decades of humanitarian help, worry that the value of their work goes unnoticed by Congressional budget makers and private donors because they lack ''visibility''on the domestic scene.

headline: Calendars Seized in Java
abstract: The police in East Java confiscated at least 100,000 calendars that carried the Communist symbol of the hammer and sickle, the official Antara News Agency reported today. The Communist Party and all printed materials related to Communism have been banned since a Communist coup attempt in 1965.

headline: Chairman of Miles Plans to Step Down
abstract: Theodor H. Heinrichs, chairman and chief executive of Miles Laboratories Inc., said yesterday that he planned to step down at the March meeting of the board of directors.   Mr. Heinrichs, 55, who will stay on the board and be available as an adviser, will be succeeded by Dr. Franz J. Geks, a Miles director and a member of the board of management of Miles' parent, Bayer A.G.  of West Germany.   Until Jan.1, Mr. Heinrichs was also chairman and chief executive of Cutter Laboratories Inc., another Bayer unit. On that date, Cutter became an operating group of Miles and its headquarters was moved from Emeryville, Calif., to Elkhart, Ind., home of Miles.

headline: TOYOTA: INNNOVATIVE AND CONSERVATIVE
abstract: For the Toyota Motor Corporation, the joint venture with the General Motors Corporation is a comparatively lowcost, low-risk way to begin producing cars in the United States.   As such, the strategy chosen by Toyota, Japan's largest car maker, is in sharp contrast to that of two other major Japanese producers, the Nissan Motor Company and the Honda Motor Company, which have decided to build costly new plants in the United States by themselves.   ''It's a smart thing for Toyota to go into the U.S. with a partner,'' said Kenichi Ohmae, managing director of McKinsey & Company in Tokyo. ''The risk of going in alone is enormous.''

headline: DUPLICITY CHARGES TRADED BY ISRAELIS AND PHALANGISTS
abstract: The longstanding relationship between Israel and Lebanon's Christian Phalangist militia has sharply deteriorated in recent weeks, with each side accusing the other of breaking promises and ''double-dealing.''   Two independent Israeli military analysts, in direct contact with senior officials of the Israeli Army and intelligence agencies, say that there is mounting repugnance among Israeli officers over working with the militiamen in light of the Phalangists' massacre of Palestinians in Beirut refugee camps.   This is coupled with a growing feeling among members of Israel's military and political establishments that the Phalangists used the Israelis to do their dirty work but failed to ''deliver the goods'' in the form of a peace treaty between Lebanon and Israel - even though their party's candidate, Amin Gemayel, is President of Lebanon. 'Perfumed Soldiers'   ''The view of the Phalangists among Israeli officers,'' the military analysts said, ''is that they are 'perfumed soldiers,' ready to fight to the last Israeli.''   Today's resignation of the Israeli Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, is expected by Israeli military analysts to erode relations further between the Phalangists and the Israeli Army. The Phalangists and other Christian politicians have complaints of their own about the Israelis. ''The friendly relations that used to exist between Israel and the Lebanese Christians are not there anymore,'' former President Camille Chamoun, a Phalangist ally, said in an interview.

headline: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: STATUS CALLING? PICK UP THE PHONE
abstract: There have been designer clothes, designer fragrances and designer candy. Now comes the designer telephone.  Pierre Cardin Electronique unveiled a new line of stylized telephones at the Consumer Electronics show. The company, a division of the Arrow Trading Corporation, a New York importer, entered the designer electronics business a year and a half ago, when it came out with its Pierre Cardin calculators, which were followed by Pierre Cardin clocks and radios.

headline: EGYPT CUTS PRICE
abstract: The Gulf Oil Corporation has reduced its purchases of North Sea oil in a move intended to put pressure on Britain to reduce oil prices, traders said yesterday.   The traders also said Gulf Oil had begun to offer large quantities of oil on the spot, or noncontract, markets at steep discounts.  Officials at Gulf Oil, the nation's fifth-largest oil company, declined to comment on the widespread reports beyond saying that purchases from Britain were on a ''shipment-by-shipment basis'' and that price negotiations would begin soon with the British National Oil Corporation, the Government trading company.   Gulf Oil has been purchasing about 50,000 barrels a day of Britain's North Sea crude at $33.50 a barrel, or about $4 above the price the same oil is being sold for on the spot market.

headline: Japan's Steel Output Off
abstract: Japan's production of crude steel totaled 99.549 million metric tons in 1982, slipping below the level of 100 million tons for the first time in 10 years, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation announced today. A metric ton is about 2,204 pounds.

headline: TOKYO IS CLOSE TO A BIG AID PACT WITH SEOUL
abstract: Japan will conclude a multibillion dollar aid agreement with South Korea in time for a visit to Seoul next week by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, according to the Japanese Foreign Ministry.   The economic aid package - described by diplomats as the largest ever given by Japan to another country - is in the final stage of negotiations that have lasted almost two years, Foreign Ministry officials said.   ''There is a prospect of full accord during the Prime Minister's visit or even just before,'' Shiro Amaye, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said.

headline: STATE STREET BOSTON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CELANESE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GAF Files Suit
abstract: The GAF Corporation, a maker of chemicals and building materials, has filed suit in Federal court in an effort to prevent an insurgent slate of candidates for directors from voting their shares or soliciting votes in a proxy battle for control of the company. The outcome of the proxy fight, which began last month, is likely to be determined at the company's annual meeting, scheduled for April 28.  The dissident director candidates are led by Samuel J. Heyman, a Westport, Conn., real estate developer who owns or controls about 4.7 percent of GAF common stock.

headline: Newly Created Post At Lloyd's Is Filled
abstract: Ian Hay Davison, a 51-year-old senior partner in Arthur Andersen & Company, will become Lloyd's of London's first independent chief executive on Feb. 1. The appointment was made yesterday at the first meeting of the new 27-member governing council that has taken over responsibility for the three-century-old insurance market from a 16-member committee composed entirely of brokers and underwriters.   Mr. Davison, who is taking a leave of absence from Andersen, will also become deputy chairman at Lloyd's and a member of the governing council. He said that his first priority would be adoption of new rules requiring all working members of Lloyd's to disclose any potential conflicts of interest and where insurance risks placed at Lloyd's have been reinsured.

headline: Foremost's Planner Of Drug Takeovers
abstract: Since 1967, Foremost-McKesson Inc. has been restricted in its attempts to acquire drug-related companies. But that has changed, and Kenneth L. Larson expects to be spending more of his time mapping acquisition strategies.   Mr. Larson, 56 years old, is president of Foremost's drug and health care group, and as such will be playing a key role in the company's plans. The company has announced that a Federal Trade Commission ruling makes it easier for it to acquire drug manufacturing or wholesale distribution companies, and as a result is likely to be more aggressive in seeking acquisitions.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TACOMA BOATBUILDING CO reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Thrift Units Get 21 Billion
abstract: The new high-interest accounts designed to help banks and thrift institutions compete with money market mutual funds attracted an estimated $21.8 billion to savings and loan associations in the first week they were offered, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.   The bank board estimated, however, that only about $3.2 billion, or 15 percent of the initial influx of money into savings institutions, came from outside sources.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BISHOPS IN VATICAN FOR NUCLEAR TALKS
abstract: Roman Catholic bishops from the United States who are drafting a pastoral letter opposing the use of nuclear weapons met today with European bishops and Vatican officials to obtain their views on the issue.   Church sources said before the two-day meeting began in the Vatican that at least some European bishops would urge the Americans to be prudent, cautious and moderate in dealing with the morality of nuclear weapons in the pastoral letter, which is due to be made public in the spring. Participants in the conference include prelates from Britain, France, West Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and Italy.

headline: CABINET IN ISRAEL RETAINING SHARON ON 2 KEY PANELS
abstract: The Israeli Cabinet voted today to retain former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon on two important Government bodies, the steering committee for the negotiations with Lebanon and the larger of two ministerial panels on defense.   Officials said the decision, made at Prime Minister Menachem Begin's request, appeared to mean that Mr. Sharon would continue to have a major role in shaping Israeli positions in the talks with Lebanon.   Some officials here and in Washington had expected this to be the one area in which Mr. Sharon's resignation would bring a new spirit of Israeli flexibility and compromise.   His position on the defense committee is regarded as less significant, however, because it is a fairly extensive body of about a dozen ministers, created largely to satisfy the demands of coalition factions for a visible role in policy deliberations.

headline: French Internists on Strike
abstract: Thousands of internists marched through central Paris today as part of a week-old strike that has crippled hospital services throughout the country. The doctors are protesting the growing difficulty in finding permanent jobs in France's university hospital network and in private practice.

headline: ERIC ERICKSON, WARTIME SPY
abstract: Eric Erickson, a Swedish businessman who worked for American intelligence during World War II, has died at the age of 92, family members announced today.   Mr. Erickson, an oil expert with international business contacts, visited Nazi Germany repeatedly during the war, gathering information about synthetic oil plants.

headline: PATENTS; Universal Radiator For Automobiles
abstract: A universal radiator assembly patented this week by John J.  MacIntosh of Hesperia, Calif., is intended to simplify the replacement of radiators in thousands of automobile models.

headline: Truck Output to Rise
abstract: Domestic auto makers plan to build 174,000 trucks next month, the most since February 1980, when 174,000 also were assembled, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. Last February's output was 145,000 trucks.

headline: BETHLEHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WOMETCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: STRAINING TO BE MORE THAN JUST SOUP
abstract: FOR the Campbell Soup Company, last April's directors' meeting was an affair that would not soon be forgotten. Instead of gathering in the 114-year-old company's corporate board room, R. Gordon McGovern, Campbell's president, carted off his directors to two New Jersey supermarkets.   His message was simple: The competition in the aisles was fierce, and while Campbell understands and dominates the market for condensed soup, the same can't be said about Campbell shrimp, spaghetti, scallops, scrambled eggs and a whole litany of other new products.   Mr. McGovern has been trying to shake up the sleepy company ever since the grocery store rendezvous, concentrating on the company's lagging marketing operations while at the same time embarking on a $75 million acquisition drive that has added more than 100 products to Campbell's list over the last two years.   ''I want to be across the whole store, as well as in the institutional and restaurant businesses,'' said the lanky 56-year-old Mr. McGovern, who has been trying for two years to shed the company's soup-only image and to regain ground that Campbell has lost to its archrival - H.J. Heinz.

headline: ALUMAX INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Banks to Aid Yugoslavia
abstract: Yugoslav officials and a committee representing international bank creditors have reached an agreement on a $2 billion finance package, a committee spokesman said today.   Two days of negotiations here led to an agreement on $1.4 billion in debt rescheduling and $600 million in new loans to be guaranteed by the federal Government, while the National Bank of Yugoslavia will guarantee a related two-year extension of short-term credits.

headline: STEELMAKER MIRRORS AUSTRALIA'S HEALTH
abstract: A cartoon in a business weekly recently showed an overweight steelworker with the initials of Australia's largest concern, the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, on his sweatshirt, pleading with a caricature of Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser.   ''Please protect me,'' the kneeling giant says. ''Big boys don't cry,'' replies the Prime Minister, walking away.  Since its founding 100 years ago, B.H.P. has maintained that what is good for the company is good for Australia. So, when out-of-work B.H.P. laborers marched on Parliament in Canberra in late 1982 demanding that the Government do something to help workers at Australia's only integrated steel company, James C. McNeil, B.H.P.'s chairman, waited with interest for the Government's response.

headline: FAIR LANES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 3M OFF
abstract: The St. Regis Paper Company yesterday reported a substantial loss in the fourth quarter of 1982, compared with a profit the year before. For the full year, however, the large, diversified forestproducts company managed to report a profit, but a weaker one than in 1981.   Along with recessionary factors, the company attributed the decline to $50 million in reserves set aside for losses anticipated from the disposal of some assets and for some other charges.   For the fourth quarter, St. Regis reported a loss of $49.2 million, compared with a profit of $36.6 million, or $1.07 share, in the 1981 period. Revenue declined 8 percent, to $605.9 million, from $658.7 million, in the comparable quarter a year earlier.

headline: People
abstract: * Richard L. Matthews named vice chairman/management committee of Kornhauser & Calene Inc.   * William Siegel and Marshall Simon have been named senior vice presidents at Medicus Intercon International, a subsidiary of Benton & Bowles.

headline: WCI CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Associated In Pact to Buy Chain
abstract: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation plans to acquire Loehmann's Inc. for $96 million under a letter of intent signed yesterday by the two companies.   Loehmann's is one of the country's largest discounters of higherpriced women's apparel. It would become a subsidiary of Associated, the huge retailer, in about 60 days, when the agreement is to become final. In the year ended Jan. 24, the 61 stores operated by Loehmann's had sales of about $260 million. The chain, which is closely held and based in New York, operates in 25 states.

headline: Conoco Gas Sale
abstract: The Transco Energy Company and an American Natural Reourses Company unit announced their purchases of gas reserves and rights in the Mustang Island Block A-85 from the DuPont Company's Conoco Inc.  subsidiary. Transco said it had paid $17 million to increase its interest in the block to 46 percent from 33 percent. American Natural Resources said it had increased its stake to 46.7 percent from 33 percent for $17.6 million.

headline: KEY TOPIC AT WORLD ORGANIZATION: 'SALIENCE'
abstract: Salience, meaning emphasis or prominence, has come into vogue at the United Nations as a synonym for relevance, as in ''this scheme must have salience for rural development.'' Some diplomats here have expressed concern over what, accordingly, they call ''the lack of salience'' of the world organization.   This week, after Iran began a new miltary offensive aginst Iraq, the Baghdad Government did not bother to seek a Security Council meeting. Last year Baghdad did so twice, won resolutions urging a withdrawal of forces, a cease-fire and negotiations, and came away from the Council chamber with nothing but a paper victory.

headline: PRESIDENT IS NAMED BY AVIS
abstract: Norton Simon Inc.'s Avis division, the nation's second-largest car rental company, said yesterday that it had named Joseph V. Vittoria as president and chief operating officer, to succeed Howard C. Miller Jr. It said Mr. Miller is resigning at age 56 ''to pursue personal business interests.''

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Net Income   Percent

headline: AT A BORDER CAMP IN HONDURAS, ANTI-SANDINISTS ARE WARY OF VISIT
abstract: Nicaraguans described as insurgents fighting to overthrow the Sandinist Government in Managua appear to be operating from a camp in the hills above this hamlet near the border.   The camp, to which a reporter was directed on Saturday by local residents, is in the province of El Paraiso, about a mile off a dirt road that runs from the border village of Cifuentes to the region's principal town, Danli. It is about eight miles from the border with Nicaragua if one walks overland, according to nearby residents.   The encampment consisted of more than a dozen large tents, near an earthen hut packed to the rafters with unopened crates labeled as United States-made armaments. According to English markings on the crates, their contents included fragmentation grenades and mortar shells.

headline: ISRAEL CONSIDERING CURBS ON SETTLERS
abstract: After years of tolerating political violence by Jewish settlers in the occupied West Bank, the Israeli authorities are considering whether to crack down.   The first indications of a toughened policy, involving swift arrests and the preparation of serious charges, emerged during a recent spate of attacks and plots by settlers against Arabs. Some officials are reported to have become alarmed at the growing specter of Jewish terrorism. Some are also worried that a fringe of Jewish militants are discrediting the settlement program, both here and abroad.

headline: Tiger International Loses $82.3 Million
abstract: Tiger International Inc., burdened by slack demand for its commercial transportation services and by heavy debt, today reported an $82.3 million loss for last year's final quarter, and a $136.2 million loss for the full year.   The losses compared with deficits of $22.1 million in final quarter of 1981 and $16.6 million for the entire 1981 fiscal year. Revenue in the quarter fell 8 percent, to $385.7 million from $420.5 million.  For the year, revenues dropped nearly 10 percent to $1.45 billion from $1.55 billion.

headline: Loan for Colombia
abstract: Colombia is seeking an $80 million, eight-year loan from private banks, according to banking sources.  Colombia will probably have to pay at least 1 1/4 percentage points over the London rate, compared with 5/8 to 3/4 point in the second half of 1982, they added.

headline: PRESIDENT RESIGNS POST AT WARNER AMEX CABLE
abstract: John D. Lockton, 44, has resigned as president of Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. ''to pursue other business interests,'' the company announced yesterday.   Mr. Lockton's resignation comes less than six weeks after Drew Lewis, former Secretary of Transportation, joined the company as chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Lewis, 51, will add the duties of president, including day-to-day operations of the company, Warner Amex said.

headline: Time-Life Books Reducing Its Staff
abstract: Time-Life Books Inc., reeling from a plunge in income from $21 million in 1981 to $1.6 million last year, will reduce its editorial staff at its headquarters by 26 percent, a company official said.   Nicholas Benton, vice president for public relations, said the company is laying off 54 of 200 editorial staff members as a way to make the company profitable, and as a result of the simultaneous completion of three series published by Time-Life Books.   The international publisher has offices in 10 cities throughout the world and employs 1,243 people worldwide.

headline: No Headline
abstract: COMPANY NEWS; OCCIDENTAL WRITES OFF VENTURE   (By Reuters) - The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it would take an $85 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings for the termination of chemical operations in Italy and would break even for the period.   The company also said that it had repaid $1 billion of bank debt borrowed to finance its acquisition of the Cities Service Company and said it would repay the remaining $900 million by the end of the summer.   Occidental said the $85 million charge resulted from the termination of its participation in the chemical business of a joint epoxy venture with Italy's national oil company.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Waste Recovery Bonds Issued in Massachusetts
abstract: A $161.7 million issue of North Andover, Mass., resource recovery bonds was tentatively priced for sale through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company with yields of 10 1/8 percent for bonds due in 2002 and 10.18 percent in 2006. The bonds will finance a plant for generating electricity from garbage.

headline: GULF OIL BOWS OUT OF EUROPE
abstract: The Gulf Oil Corporation, which has expanded throughout Europe, the Middle East and North America for more than three decades, is engaged in a sweeping restructuring aimed at concentrating its businesses in North America.   Gulf Oil also appears to have taken the lead among major companies in applying downward pressure on oil prices: Last week, it was the first of a large number of companies to announce that it was lowering the price it was willing to pay for oil produced in the United States, reflecting what many analysts regard as an aggressive corporate posture that Gulf Oil rarely displayed in the past.   ''The difference between crude and refined product prices has just gotten too small, and we're determined to turn that around,'' said Ronald E. Hall, Gulf Oil's senior vice president for marketing. He added that the company had not ruled out another reduction soon for its posted price for domestic crude, and would be ''dealing very hard'' for lower prices from foreign producers.

headline: Lackawanna Plant
abstract: Kenneth E. Lipke said he is confident he can find investors to join in a package deal to buy most of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation plant in Lackawanna. Mr. Lipke said a month ago that he was quitting as chairman of the Gibraltar Steel Corporation to raise $250 million to buy the plant. Bethlehem plans to close the basic steelmaking there this year. A shutdown would mean permanent loss of 7,300 jobs at the Lackawanna works and another 8,000 jobs in a ripple effect on other businesses in western New York.

headline: South African Gold
abstract: South Africa's gold output rose to 664.2 metric tons in 1982 from 656.9 tons the previous year, the Chamber of Mines said today.

headline: Simplicity Pattern Picks Diversification Officer
abstract: The Simplicity Pattern Company, the leading maker of paper patterns for home sewing, has hired Robert E. Rosen as a vice chairman and has given him the job of figuring out how the debt-free and cash-rich company should diversify.   The market for sewing patterns has reached a plateau with more women joining the work force. As a result, the company has seen earnings fall and the dividend was omitted last June.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Norton Cutbacks
abstract: The Norton Company of Worcester, Mass., which employs 11,000 in the United States and 9,000 abroad, said it was cutting its worldwide work force by 650 employees. Most will be in administrative, technical, professional and management positions. The company makes abrasives, diamond drill bits and other products for the petroleum and mining industries, as well as being a principal producer of performance plastics and other chemical and health-care products.

headline: KAISER MAY CLOSE STEEL PLANT
abstract: The Kaiser Steel Corporation yesterday announced that it would close its Fontana, Calif., steelworks unless it could find a buyer or partner by the time its inventory of raw materials ran out, probably late this year.   ''We have stated that we could not remain in steel production and finishing at Fontana without substantial improvement in the market and a significant reduction in labor costs,'' said Stephen A. Girard, the chairman and chief executive of Kaiser. ''Unfortunately, neither has happened.''

headline: RETAILERS' PRINTOUT SHOWS DATA BOOM
abstract: RETAILING, the field that employs the largest number of Americans 16 million - is so vast, so segmented and so far-flung that opportunities inevitably arise as others are foreclosed. This holds true for data processing, a technical area that is increasingly indispensable to the widespread sales and inventory requirements of retailers.   While the processes may be similar, corporate policies may vary widely. For example, Sears Roebuck & Company, the world's largest retailer, will be hiring between 40 and 100 new people a year in the next few years for its data-processing operations. But few will need computer-science degrees, since Sears has found that math, English and home-economics majors - and its own people - fit its training and salary requirements better.

headline: IN VENEZUELA, GOOD TIMES ARE GOING
abstract: ''La fiesta ha terminado.'' Among Venezuelans, from cab drivers to men of letters, field hands to presidential candidates, this saying, ''The party's over,'' is the most repeated in Venezuela today.   Because of falling oil prices and the drying up of foreign exchange, this oil-producing country, the richest nation in South America and its most durable democracy, is caught up in an economic crisis as full blown as those that had previously seemed the fate only of far-off lands.   ''I have a hollow spot in my chest as I discuss these things,'' said Carlos Rangel, a writer and noted conservative intellectual.  ''Suddenly we're talking about my country.''

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Loan Request By Argentina
abstract: Argentina is seeking a $500 million loan from the Bank of International Settlements, bank officials said today.   Argentina, one of Latin America's most indebted countries, owes foreign banks an estimated $40 billion. Its latest large borrowing was in December - a $1.1 billion, 15-month credit from 250 commercial banks.

headline: FARMERS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AN OILMAN TRIES INTERSTATE BANKING
abstract: WHEN Frederick I. Shaffer Jr., chairman of Kansas Crude Inc., speaks before service clubs in this city of 40,000, he usually brings along his prize possession the bat that ex-Yankee Reggie Jackson used to belt three World Series-winning home runs.   ''I use it to make a point about follow-through,'' says Mr.  Shaffer. ''Even after you hit that big home run, you still must touch all four bases.''   The 60-year-old Mr. Shaffer is now concentrating on his own follow-through. After a successful career as an independent oilman, broadcaster and real estate developer, he and two of his four sons - Ronald and John -are trying to set up a chain of national banks in the wealthiest locales in 25 states. And the prospect that this unknown from central Kansas might be able to connect many of banking's most lucrative bases has already upset Federal regulators - not to mention the competition.

headline: MADRID'S NEW WORKING CLASS: THE BUREAUCRATS
abstract: In Spain the title of civil servant has long been a misnomer. They are civil enough. But they rarely serve.  Bureaucrats practiced moonlighting to such an extent it turned into sunlighting. It was not unusual for them to hold down two, sometimes three - and in one case, a reliable source swears, four - separate jobs.   Walk into any ministry after 12 noon, people would say, and if you found someone at his desk it was because he had been locked in for the night.

headline: Chessie Replies In Conrail Dispute
abstract: A rate dispute involving Conrail and the Chessie System is the result of anticompetitive steps by Conrail, according to a spokesman for Chessie who was responding to similar accusations from Conrail.

headline: FLORIDA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Thousands of Workers Quit Quebec Strike
abstract: A strike of Quebec government workers, protesting wage cuts of up to 20 percent, started falling apart today after thousands of hospital workers returned to their jobs.

headline: Lehman Brothers Signs With Albert Frank
abstract: After an eight-year stay uptown with Doyle Dane Bernbach, Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. has decided to return to the Wall Street area and that financial area fixture, Albert Frank-Guenther Law.   Lehman Brothers and Kuhn Loeb, as independent companies, had been clients of Albert Frank for about 40 years.

headline: GERMAN STEEL PLAN LOSES KLOCKNER
abstract: Klockner-Werke A.G., West Germany's fourth-largest steel company, said today that it had pulled out of efforts to rescue the nation's ailing steel industry by reorganizing it into two giant steelmaking groups.   But industry officials said that the reorganization, proposed in January by an independent panel of three experts, would proceed anyway.

headline: Market Place; Stock Surge Vs. U.S. Deficit
abstract: THE stock market continued to confound its doubters yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average sprinted 16.28 points, reaching a record high for the third consecutive trading session.   Trading volume was once again above 100 million shares, for the 28th time since the stock market rally began in mid-August. Not only did the Dow rise, reaching 1,092.35 points, but 2 of every 3 issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange went up in price.   But what about the Federal deficit, which, according to some forecasts, could tower above $200 billion in the fiscal year 1984?  How can equity prices continue to climb in the face of such a formidable obstacle?

headline: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD UP 9.3 MILLION SHARES
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 7.5 percent, or 9.3 million shares, in the month ended March 15, to 133.8 million shares. Last year the short interest totaled 85.7 million shares.   In the latest period, the short interest on the American Stock Exchange was up about 298,600 shares, to 12.7 million.  A short position can result from the sale of borrowed stock in the hope of buying the same issue at a later date and at a lower price to cover the sale.   The following Big Board companies show large changes:

headline: Text of letter, page A8.
abstract: President Reagan, in an open letter read here tonight by Vice President Bush, called on Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, to meet him to sign a treaty banning all intermediaterange, land-based nuclear missiles.   Addressing the people of Europe, Mr. Reagan's message said he would meet with Mr. Andropov ''whenever and wherever he wants'' to conclude an agreement totally eliminating the weapons. ''I make this offer,'' the President said, ''out of the conviction that such an agreement would serve the interests of both sides, and, more importantly, that the people of Europe want nothing more.''   (In Washington, a deputy White House press secretary, Lyndon Allin, said Mr. Reagan was not making a new proposal but was simply stating a willingness to sign a pact with Mr. Andropov if the Soviet Union accepts the United States so-called zero-option proposal.   (In Tokyo, Secretary of State George P. Shultz told Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone that the United States would never negotiate an agreement on reducing medium-range missiles in Europe at the expense of Japan's security. Page A9.)

headline: TUESDAY, JANUARY 11, 1983; The Economy
abstract: President Reagan will probably accept a special package of contingency tax increases if budget deficits are not declining sharply enough by 1985, according to Administration officials. (Page A1.) Despite widespread opposition, Mr. Reagan may also propose a tax on health insurance benefits, a White House adviser said. (B9.)   Retail sales, in real terms, will rise 2 to 3 percent this year over last, speakers at a national meeting predicted. They said profits should be ''quite good'' because of inventory cuts and expense controls. But they estimated that sales in the 1982 retailing year, through the end of January, will fall 1 percent from the previous year. (D1.)

headline: 6 Whites and a Black Slain in Zimbabwe
abstract: Six whites and a black were killed Friday in two attacks by dissidents in southwestern Zimbabwe, the police and relatives said.   Five whites and a black were killed in an ambush outside Bulawayo, the Matabeleland provincial capital.

headline: PAPANDREOU PLAN LURING SOME COMMUNIST EXILES
abstract: A few thousand of the 30,000 Greek Communists still in exile in Eastern Europe are reportedly applying for permission to return under a repatriation program announced in December by Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou.   But, refugee groups here say, many others are reluctant to do so unless they are assured of being able to meet their minimum economic needs in Greece. According to one Government official, the Papandreou program may result in bringing back one-third of the Communists still in places of exile to which they fled after losing the Greek Civil War of 1946 to 1949.

headline: ATHENS PROCLAIMS 'FINAL' STAND ON U.S. BASES
abstract: The Government announced this week, without elaboration, that it had formulated its ''final'' position on the future of United States military bases in Greece.   The position, drawn up in preparation for the resumption of talks with American representatives later this month, was formulated Thursday night at a meeting of the Government's Defense Council, presided over by Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, with top military leaders also taking part.   Details were not disclosed, but a prominent Greek diplomat said later that ''a critical point, a turning point in Greek-American relations,'' had been reached.   The talks, which are to resume around Jan. 20, have been in recess for a month for consultations, with both sides saying that they are still far apart. Nevertheless, official sources close to the two parties have said that both the Greek Government and the Reagan Administration have shown a willingness to reach an agreement.

headline: DOW OFF 1.19 AS VOLUME RISES
abstract: The stock market ended mixed yesterday in accelerated trading, with some of the depressed domestic energy issues making the best gains.  The Dow Jones industrial average ended the session down 1.19 points, at 1,044.89, after climbing 19.04 points on Tuesday. In the overall market, however, stocks that advanced on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that declined by 1,049 to 554.

headline: COMMERCIAL DECAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TAX MAIL ANNOYS LAWMAKERS
abstract: The battle over whether to repeal the 10 percent withholding tax on dividends and interest payments is being fought not only in the lobbies and committee rooms of Capitol Hill.It is also being fought in the mailroom.   For the past several weeks, hundreds of thousands of letters have inundated Congressional offices, bringing renewed intensity to the withholding issue, prompting many members of Congress to hire additional staff members and deluging the Senate Post Office to the extent that at times it has fallen far behind in its sorting operations.   The volume of mail, in fact, is so heavy and the tone of the protests considered so shrill that it has begun to infuriate some leaders on Capitol Hill. This week Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas and chairman of the Finance Committee, complained to the American Banking Association of a campaign of ''disinformation'' being waged in the form of ''thousands and thousands of misleading postcards.''

headline: ISRAEL SHUTS SCHOOL IN WEST BANK
abstract: The Israeli military said today that it had closed a high school for a month in the occupied West Bank town of Nablus after one policeman was lightly wounded during the third day of clashes with Arab youths.   Soldiers also sealed off the market area for the third day after dispersing stone-throwing protesters with tear gas, the spokesman said.

headline: Suit by Compaq
abstract: The Compaq Computer Corporation, a small Houston company that makes a portable computer compatible with the popular International Business Machines personal computer, filed a countersuit in Federal court against Texas Instruments Inc. Compaq, founded largely by former Texas Instruments employees, charged that Texas Instruments had sued to harass Compaq and deter further defections. In its suit last month, Texas Instruments charged that the former employees stole trade secrets and infringed on patents. Texas Instruments declined to comment on the suit.

headline: CHASE IN TALKS TO BUY A DISCOUNT BROKERAGE
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Bank is negotiating to move directly into the stock brokerage business by acquiring Rose & Company, a discount brokerage firm based in Chicago, according to Steven A. Rautenberg, a Chase vice president.   It would be the first acquisition by a New York commercial bank of a discount brokerage firm, although two major banks in California, the Bank of America and the Security Pacific National Bank, have done so.   Sources in the bank said Chase would use Rose & Company, the country's fourth-largest discount brokerage firm, to round out the services it offers to its clients throughout the United States. The main purpose would be to enable Chase to provide its customers with as complete a range of services as is offered by securities firms.  Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, for example, offers its Cash Management Account, which includes a money market mutual fund, checking privileges, a Visa card and brokerage services.

headline: SOVIET CITES SLOW '82 OUTPUT
abstract: Economic indicators for 1982, published today in major Soviet newspapers, confirmed a continuing slowdown in most key industrial and agricultural sectors of the Soviet Union.   The figures, issued by the central statistics board, showed that industrial output grew only 2.8 percent last year and that national income - somewhat akin to the gross national product of other countries - rose only 2.6 percent. Both were the smallest gains since World War II and were well below Moscow's modest targets of 4.7 percent and 3 percent, respectively.   The figures came as little surprise to Western analysts who have been following the sluggish pace of the Soviet economy in monthly tabulations. They heard comparable estimates last November from Nikolai K. Baibakov, the state planning chief. Nor were the figures any worse than the performance of many Western nations, shackled by recession.

headline: More U.S. Farm-Export Aid Pledged
abstract: The United States will press its campaign to end European Economic Community subsidies of farm exports, which take markets away from economically depressed American farmers, two Administration officials told Congress today.   Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, and Agriculture Secretary John R. Block indicated that the United States will strike at the Europeans with more subsidized sales of American commodities to bring the Common Market to the negotiating table. ''We are tooling up to go after markets wherever they may be,'' Mr. Block said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Asarco Inc. said it had sold its entire interest in Revere Copper and Brass Inc. - 1.9 million Revere common shares and $22.8 million principal amount of debentures - to Bear, Stearns & Co. for $17 million in cash.   * Compaq Computer Corp. said it would sell its portable computer, which is capable of running all major software available for the I.B.M. personal computer, through Computerland Corp.'s network of retail stores, beginning next month.

headline: MUSE AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Baxter Travenol Official Named to Additional Job
abstract: Wilbur H. Gantz, executive vice president at Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., has been named to the additional post of chief operating officer.   Mr. Gantz, 45, will assume the title now held by Vernon R. Loucks Jr., 48, who continues as president and chief executive.

headline: STRAUSS REJECTS A CABINET POST
abstract: Franz Josef Strauss will not accept an offer by Chancellor Helmut Kohl to join the coalition Cabinet in Bonn, but will stay in Munich as Bavarian state premier, a party spokesman said today.   The announcement ended weeks of speculation about what Mr. Strauss planned to do after the March 6 election victory of Mr. Kohl's Christian Democrats and their Bavarian sister party, which is headed by Mr. Strauss.

headline: WOOING POLES TO NEW UNION NO EASY TASK
abstract: It is not easy to be a labor organizer in Poland these days, especially when your union is one the Government is trying to organize.   At the Polski Fiat auto plant, Henryk Kordleczek and Janusz Czakow, the chief organizers for the new Government-sponsored unions that are to take the place of Solidarity, the banned independent labor organization, say their fellow workers have painted their doors red, made threatening telephone calls and sent them nasty letters.   Then, when they passed on a grievance from the workers over proposed legislation that would reduce paid sick leave for absences of three days or less, the authorities brushed them aside and the unpopular bill was enacted anyway.   ''People who have weak nerves would have to leave this task,'' Mr.  Kordlec@zek, a welding foreman, said.

headline: BEIRUT SEEKS AN END TO HARASSMENT OF PALESTINIANS
abstract: Lebanon has asked the United States to intervene with Israel to halt a campaign of intimidation against Palestinians in southern Lebanon by Christian militiamen.   The Beirut radio quoted Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan as saying that he made the request at a meeting here Saturday with Philip C.  Habib, the special United States envoy.   ''We are exerting every effort to stop the campaign of intimidation against Palestinians and Lebanese in southern Lebanon,'' the Prime Minister said.

headline: Product-Oriented Ads Are Planned by Shell
abstract: With the OPEC ministers recently in Switzerland trying to figure out a way of beating the oil glut in the United States, back home the oil companies are trying to come up with ways of moving the stuff.   For some, like Shell, it means the first product-oriented advertising since the oil embargo a decade ago.

headline: THE BOOM IN MUNICIPAL BONDS
abstract: Local governments, which are struggling to keep their budgets in balance, have found that, despite their problems, they still have access to the capital markets.   Strong demand from individual investors has sustained the taxexempt bond market and enabled local governments and their authorities to sell record amounts of short-term notes and long-term bonds. In 1982, for example, bonds sales were 62 percent higher than in 1981. The heavy volume continued in the first two months of 1983, with $9.2 billion of bonds sold.

headline: ATLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: French Official Off to U.S.
abstract: Defense Minister Charles Hernu left for Washington today after warning that the United States was in a position of inferiority in the arms race with the Soviet Union.

headline: No Headline
abstract: SYRIA SAID TO BUILD NEW MISSILE BASES   TEL AVIV, Jan. 4 (AP) - The Israeli Army said today that Syria was building two bases deep inside its territory for advanced Soviet SAM-5 antiaircraft missiles.   The state radio indicated that the missiles would jeopardize Israeli reconnaissance flights over Syria.  The army's report came as Israeli officials expressed new concern about a buildup of Soviet weapons in Syria. Israeli and Syrian soldiers still face each other across a cease-fire line in Lebanon.

headline: U.S. Official to Visit Haiti
abstract: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 7 (Reuters) - Thomas O. Enders, United States Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, will begin a 48-hour visit to Haiti on Sunday, the Foreign Ministry said today.

headline: I.B.M. Plans Shifts In Top Management
abstract: Frank T. Cary announced plans yesterday to step down as chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation. The board named 58-year-old John R. Opel, currently president and chief executive, to succeed him. It also named a new president and a vice chairman.

headline: Europeans Set Venture in U.S.
abstract: Pargesa Holding S.A. of Switzerland and Groupe Bruxelles-Lambert of Belgium plan to form a new financial holding company in the United States with share capital of $300 million, a Pargesa spokesman said.   Swiss Bourse analysts said the move marked a third step in the creation of a major new international financial group led by Albert Frere, a Belgian industrialist.

headline: VAGABOND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NEW MARCH OF TOY SOLDIERS
abstract: Toy buyers from across the country converged on New York last week to wade through acres of dolls, games, popguns, construction kits, swing sets and model cars at the 80th annual American Toy Fair. The buyers' goal: deciding what will be big in 1983. Executives from video-games companies were all smiles at the show. The retail market for video toys nearly doubled last year, reaching about $3.1 billion, and it is expected to climb to $4 billion this year. The folks who make toys that are not electronic had less to be happy about. Their overall

headline: Cable Account Goes to Jordan
abstract: What's the best way for an ad agency to begin a new year? Announcing a new account, of course.  And that's what Jordan, Case & McGrath did yesterday on the first working day of 1983.

headline: Zimbabwe Leader Urges A Stronger Army
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe said today that Zimbabwe's army must be strengthened to defend the nation against South Africa, the national news agency Ziana reported.

headline: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 12
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LAST HURRAH FOR THE INTEREST FREE LOAN?
abstract: THE interest-free loan between family members is under attack again,b ut there is still time to capitalize on this tax-saving technique.  J ust about everyone is delighted with the loan except the Internal R evenue Service, which has been attacking it for five years. Now the a gency has won its second important legal challenge, and the issue ish eaded for the Supreme Court, which will decide whether such loans r esult in taxable gifts.   In the meantime, financial advisers continue to support the use of interest-free loans as a way to cut taxes. ''It's still a good planning device if someone is willing to take the risk,'' said Leon M. Nad, senior tax partner with the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Chrysler's Plan
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said holders of more than 80 percent of its 1981 preferred stock series had tentatively approved the company's recapitalization plan, which includes the exchange of preference stock for common stock. Chrysler said shareholder approval of two-thirds of the issue was one of the conditions of the plan.

headline: COACHMEN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NO DRIFT TOWARD NEUTRALISM, KOHL TELLS THE FRENCH
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl sought to reassure West Germany's allies today that his country was not drifting into neutralism and pacifism.   In a speech in conjunction with ceremonies marking the 20th anniversary of the signing of the French-West German friendship treaty, Mr. Kohl said West Germany was anchored in the West and did not want a status between the two power blocs.   The remarks served as a response to a speech in Bonn before Parliament on Thursday by President Francois Mitterrand of France in which he warned of the dangers to peace as a result of policies in Europe that could damage the security relationship between the United States and the European members of the Atlantic alliance.

headline: Lockheed Order
abstract: The Air Force gave the Lockheed Corporation a $609 million contract to build the first C-5B cargo plane and to buy material for 49 more planes. The C-5B's, to be built at Lockheed's Marietta, Ga., plant, are to help the Air Force to move very large cargo.
